Title: Presenting, the ladies of Popcorn Monkey Tiger
Content: Director Suri is a man of few words when it comes to talking about his films. His logic — to let his work do the talking. So, it comes as no surprise that even the cast of his next, Popcorn Monkey Tiger , which releases this week, is tightlipped about what they do in the film . What Suri has let slip is that Dhananjaya is in the lead, with the title suggesting three stages in his life. Amid the plethora of other cast members are also three young ladies who play pivotal roles in the film. Here’s a dekko.Devi is a central character, whose graph in the narrative happens parallelly to Dhananjaya’s Seena. “Devi is a very bold, intense, emotional character, who has seen her fair share of hardships in life, which make her the way she is. The film chronicles various stages of her life,” she says.Newbie Sapthami is also a love interest in the tale — the when and how of which will only be revealed when the film releases. “Girija is a rather bold character, who has no filter to what she thinks and says. She is very Gen Now as far as being vocal about the things she is passionate about,” says Sapthami.As Sumithra, Amrutha plays a middle-class girl, who is confused about her life and what she wants out of it. “In most middle-class families, as soon as a girl finishes her education, the next step is to get her married off. Sumithra’s case is also something like that,” says Amrutha, who is one of Dhananjaya’s love interests in the film.

Title: Suriya’s Captain Gopinath biopic to release in Kannada
Content: Tamil star Suriya has already found himself a good following for his dubbed Telugu films. Though, his first venture into the Kannada film industry with the dubbed version of the upcoming Soorarai Pottru has more to do with the nature of the film. An official from the film’s team reveals, “This film deals with the life of Captain Gopinath . He is one of the biggest heroes and he hails from Bengaluru. He is the man who dared to give wings to the common man and made their dreams to fly a reality. Given the inspirational tone of the story, we wanted it to reach out to the common man. We felt it was apt to dub this subject in Kannada as the locals can watch it in their own language.”The film is being directed by Sudha Kongara , while Aparana Balamurali , Jackie Shroff, Paresh Rawal, Mohan Babu , Urvashi, Achyuth Kumar and Karunas form the rest of the cast.

Title: Agni Sreedhar on penning Jayaraj biopic
Content: Agni Sreedhar is penning the upcoming Jayaraj biopic featuring Dhananjaya in the lead. Of the film, which is being directed by Shoonya and produced by Ashu Bedra , the former gangster and now writer, said, “We plan to shoot at authentic locales in Bengaluru that still retain the ambience the city had in the 70s. Jayaraj was extremely fit and strong in his hayday and we needed an actor who can build a physique and play the role convincingly. It was Roshan Bachan who suggested Dhananjaya for the part as he believed he can do justice to the demands of this character. We are also looking at featuring Jayaraj's son Ajith , who I consider akin to my son, in an integral part, in the narrative. Apart from this series, I am looking at penning more intriguing stories for Sandalwood over the next 10 years."

Title: When Leander Paes and BNS Reddy discussed tennis
Content: IPS officer BNS Reddy ’s love for tennis is well-known in Bengaluru’s sports circle. He’s also won a hat trick of golds at the World Police Games in the sport. So, when ace Indian tennis player and good friend Leander Paes was in town for the ongoing Bengaluru Open, it was natural that the two caught up. “We’ve known each other for many years, and Leander has always admired how I have pursued my passion for tennis despite being a police officer. So, when he got to meet me in the city, he also held one of my gold medals with pride and we got this photograph together,” he says. Now, isn’t that nice!

Title: I believe if a dog walks into your house, it is a sign of prosperity: Parvati
Content: One of the first few statements that Parvati Nair makes when we talk about dogs is, “I love dogs more than humans.” Her love for animals was evident as she spoke about every single pet she has had in her life ever since she was a kid. “Once, my parents were talking about a flight crash that they saw on a news channel. The first thing that I’d asked them was if there were any pets on the flight. I love animals, especially dogs and cats. Just being around them gives me great joy,” says Parvati. The actress is a pet mom of three dogs — Cooper, a stray in Kerala, Simba, a Shih Tzu in Bengaluru, and Style, a Cocker Spaniel-Shih Tzu cross breed, in Chennai.Parvati’s love for animals began when she was a kid. “Our first dog was Tudo, a Pomeranian. She came into our lives when we were on an island. We were living in a villa, in Abu Dhabi, at that time. She was the sweetest girl and very obedient. We had her for few years, but we had to give her to a friend as we were moving into an apartment. We can’t have dogs in an apartment over there, hence the decision,” says Parvati. “Interestingly, when we moved into to our apartment, we saw a Siamese cat on the balcony. It just became our pet cat for several years. We called her Snoopy. Once I moved to Bengaluru for eduction, my friends gifted me Simba. And in our Kerala house, we have Cooper, a Daschund-cross-stray. Now that I’ve moved to Chennai, Style has come in to my life. Style’s parents are moving abroad. So, I decided to adopt him.”Though it’s unfair to ask her which is her favourite pet, Parvati says that she loves Cooper a tad bit extra. She says, “He just walked into house one day and showered us with unconditional love. I was in Kerala for over three weeks and got very attached to him. He understands our language and emotions so well. I was about to take a flight the next morning and told him that I would be leaving for a few days. He was there, waiting for me early in the morning. He is the most loving dog I’ve had in my life. I have a CCTV camera in my house in Kerala and keep checking on him all the time.”Parvati says, “ I have never bought any dog until now. All the dogs came to me when they were puppies. But Style is almost two years old. He takes time to get attached, but he became very fond of me. They are very intelligent and truly, a man’s best friend. I believe that if a dog comes into your life, it is a sign of prosperity. The only thing I look for in people is gratitude. Over the years, many people have disappointed me. But these dogs and cats have showered only love. I want to open a dog shelter some day.”Simba is the first dog Parvati had as an adult. “My friends know my love for dogs and they gifted me Simba (Shih Tzu) on my birthday. I was living in Bengaluru at that time. When Simba came in as a puppy, he looked like a lion. I couldn’t think of a better name than Simba. He is the cutest and one of the most loving pets I’ve had. He is extremely naughty and loves women. Since I had to travel a lot for shoots, I asked my friend to look after him as she was living in the same apartment. Once I went on a long shoot and my friend grew very attached to Simba. She also went through a break-up at that time. So, she wanted to have him. It was a hard choice, but it was for the best. I still video call Simba and sometimes, he waits for me at the door, thinking I’ve come. I miss him a lot,” says Parvati.Parvati says that it is very important for someone to be at home when you have a pet. “Just like how you can’t leave babies at home all alone, you can’t have a pet and leave it alone. You can’t just give him food and leave. If you are working, ensure that there is a caretaker at home. Dogs can get very lonely and depressed. So, make sure someone is there with your pet,” she says. Parvati also adds that regular check-ups are a must. “You will definitely know when your dog is unwell. You can’t expect your pet to be alright on its own. Whenever you feel there is something wrong, take him to the vet immediately. One of my friend’s dogs died because of choking. There was a small piece of bone that was stuck in its gullet. But before they decided to take him to the vet, he died. So, doctor visits are a must,” she says.

Title: Jayaram: We won’t be able to savour success without the support of family
Content: February 18 is a very special day for Jayaram and Parvathy . “Thirty years ago, on February 18, 1988, I met her for the first time. It was the day we started shooting Padmarajan’s Aparan ,” says Jayaram.For the actor, 2020 has been special, as it kicked off with the superhit Allu-Arjun-starrer Ala Vaikunthapurramloo in Telugu, he is part of Mani Ratnam’s Ponniyin Selvan and has also signed projects in Telugu with Prabhas and Pawan Kalyan.But Jayaram says family is still his priority. “I am someone who has always found more happiness while spending time with my family; even more than acting in films. That’s why over the years, I have made sure I am there with them and vice versa,” explains the veteran actor.Ask him about the support that his family has provided over his career and the veteran actor says, “Without the support of our family, I believe we won’t be able to savour whatever success we achieve. We must try to find joy in whatever we do. We shouldn’t seek that only from our work. That’s the only way you can move ahead in life. If you are bothered about the collection of your movies or finding the producers for your next projects, then you miss out on other avenues of contentment. As people, there are so many other ways we can be at peace and being with our families are probably the easiest way,” he explains.Talking about wife and former actress Parvathy, Jayaram says, “She sacrificed acting when she was at the peak of her career to get married to me. Even back then she would talk about creating a family together. She hasn’t regretted quitting films for that.”Jayaram, Parvathy, son Kalidas and daughter Malavika will be heading to Manali for a few days to celebrate the occasion. Apart from their love for cinema, their kids and travelling, Jayaram says that he and Paravthy have also bonded over their compassion for animals. “Since my childhood, I have loved animals and we have had so many pets. After wedding, Parvathy too grew fond of them. Now, inside and outside our home, we have many dogs and they are all very important part of our lives. During weekends, we try to spend time with them and that also helps us bond better,” he says.Career-wise too, Jayaram seems to be in high spirits. “The shoot of the Mani Ratnam movie is progressing. Also, the success of Ala Vaikunthapurramloo has opened doors for me in Telugu. I don’t want to misuse the opportunity and I am being careful while choosing projects there. Right now, I have signed films with Prabhas and Pawan Kalyan as well,” he says.

Title: Hungry at midnight? Munch on a healthy snack
Content: The ideal time to have dinner is before 7 pm, say nutritionists. You’ve finally decided to give it a go and have a light and breezy meal at the designated hour. You even decide to hit the sack early, but try as you might, sleep eludes you, as you toss and turn around because of hunger pangs. You finally succumb to it and grab a bite quite late in the night. Midnight munching, as it is called, turns out to be quite a common phenomenon that college students and those with late work hours are all but familiar with. The problem with this is that the easily available snacks at that hour are often the most unhealthy, like instant noodles, chips (loaded with salt and other taste additives), aerated drinks and more, which not only affect the digestive system, but your sleep cycle as well. "Sticking to a 7 pm dinner time, refraining from eating anything thereafter and getting used to the long hours of fasting, until you break it in the morning, takes some time getting used to. Until then, the focus should be on switching to healthier options to snack on, until you can finally say no to midnight munching altogether," says city-based nutritionist Ranjani Raman.Here, experts tell you just what needs to go on your plate if you are peckish at night...“Fruit popsicles can be a healthy midnight snack. While making these, avoid using sweeteners or sugar to ensure they are healthy. Although fruits are to be eaten during the day, having natural popsicles at night is a better alternative than a processed one that is loaded with sugar, artificial fruit flavours and preservatives,” says Ranjani.“Bananas are a quick, lighter option for a midnight snack, which, apart from beating hunger, also helps in another body function — digestion. The fibre content of the plantain speeds up the process of digestion in your body, even helping you clear your bowels,” says Ranjani.“In your free time, make and store chocolate at home. Up the cocoa content and cut down on sugar for a healthier version. You could also use jaggery as a substitute for sugar while making the chocolate,” suggests Tanuja.Dietitian and nutritionist Tanuja Jain suggests oatmeal if you are terribly hungry. “Oatmeal soaked in milk is the heaviest option you have for a midnight snack. Depending on how hungry you are, decide the quantity of oatmeal, soak it in milk and add some fruits as a substitute to sugar,” she says.“Dry fruits work as any other kind of snack and are also good for building one’s metabolism, while helping in curbing one’s appetite. A mix of almonds, cashews, raisins, walnut and figs can be the basic constituents of the bowl,” adds Tanuja.1) Avoid using salt or sugar while making your snacks. Try to use natural substitutes for a flavour instead.2) Avoid eating complex food, as it leads to indigestion.3) Initially, fight the urge for as long as you can. Keep the snacking to a minimum and then, try to reduce the habit by reducing the intake of the snacks.4) Eat all your meals (breakfast, lunch and dinner) and the hunger pangs will reduce eventually.

Title: An eccentric man and his romance
Content: It was a sunny Saturday in Vadapalani, Chennai, but inside the floor of one of the many studios that dot the locality’s landscape, romance was in the air. Clad in a bright yellow sari, Priya Bhavani Shankar presented a sight as sunny as the weather outside while SJ Suryah , dressed in black jeans and a greyish shirt, was keenly observing the steps that a couple of assistant choreographers performed. We were at the last day’s shoot of Radha Mohan ’s Bommai, which sees this Monster pair reuniting for the second time. The director was observing the actors via the monitor, along with choreographer Raju Sundaram , who gave out instructions over the mic.The set couldn’t have been simpler. Art director Kadhirr had recreated a dry grassland of sorts on the elevated sound stage. The background was a blue screen, over which visual effects would be done during post-production.This set-up was quite different from that of another song in the film. A couple of months ago, on a rainy day, we had dropped in to witness the shoot of that song, which was picturised in a non-descript studio lot on the outskirts of the city. This one had a more artistic backdrop, with mannequins and expressionist artwork that included a woman’s face, a butterfly and gears. Dressed in a striking red gown, Priya Bhavani Shankar starkly stood out amidst the grey background. SJ Suryah was wearing a painter’s apron over his checked shirt. Choreographer Brinda’s assistants demonstrated the postures for the two actors while the choreographer was in discussion with cinematographer Richard M Nathan over the camera movements.During the break, the team spoke to us about the film and their roles. “It’s a romantic story, but the approach is different. I don’t want to reveal much now, but there is an element involving the complications of the human brain in this story,” teases Radha Mohan.Suryah plays an artist who works in a factory that manufactures mannequins. “We went to a factory in Bengaluru to shoot some of the scenes,” he informs. “Suryah was apt for this role. When I approached him, he liked the story so much that he came forward to produce it himself. He completely surrendered himself to the script,” he praises his star.“I didn’t have to do much of a preparation technically, save for the finer techniques like how to hold the brush and stuff like that. But the emotions had to be distinct. When he is with the girl, the character had to be in a total romantic mood, and while when she isn’t beside him, he has to look like someone who has lost everything in a storm,” chips in Suryah.He says that the way Radha Mohan had conceived the character was an advantage for him. “It suited my body language. In fact, I’d go and observe him when he went to narrate the story to the other technicians to capture the nuances. That was my workshop. So, on the shooting spot, I could instantly deliver what he expected of me,” he says.“This role came to me through my Monster director Nelson (Venkatesan). While we were shooting for Monster, SJ Suryah was assembling this project and had told me that he liked the script and was going to produce it himself. He trusts Nelson so much. When he had discussed this project with him, Nelson had suggested my name,” recalls Priya on how she came to be involved in the film.The two actors and the director had a script reading session before the shoot to figure out the approach to these roles. Chandini, Doubt Senthil, and Arul Shankar will be seen in crucial supporting characters.The director is collaborating with Yuvan Shankar Raja and editor Anthony for the first time. “Yuvan has given two beautiful songs — they are both romantic numbers and have been written by Madhan Karky,” says the director, adding, “More than the songs, I’m looking forward to his background score.”As for Anthony, he says working with him is a pleasure. “Once you get the edited footage from him, you can actually see his stamp in the scenes,” he credits the editor.Both Brinda master and Raju master are different in their approach to songs. She handles it more technically while he gives more importance to the emotions–Priya Bhavani Shankar, actressI believe this story is a universal one and not culture-specific. So, audiences everywhere will relate to it. That is one of the reasons why I decided to produce it. I’m planning to take this to Bollywood– SJ Suryah, actorPriya’s character will be a big surprise. It’s a very performance-oriented role. I did not want someone who did not know the language. There are so many nuances to this character… she is like a wild river– Radha Mohan, directorThere is a major transformation that happens in this film, so I have followed a particular visual treatment. This story demanded a difference in lighting and colour to show this transformation. Usually, Radha Mohan concentrates on the emotions, but this film demands an equal importance on the visuals as well– Richard Nathan, cinematographer

Title: RLV Ramakrishnan: I eat, sleep and breathe Mohiniyattam
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

A man performing mohiniyattam is quite a rarity in Kerala, where it’s widely considered the ‘aattam’ of the ‘mohini’. So, often after his performances, RLV Ramakrishnan encounters the question, ‘Was your presentation a true depiction of the original art?’

The man, who earned his PhD in the art form a few months ago, apparently just shoots back with a few arrows from his academic quiver. Ramakrishnan says, “I ask, wasn’t the original mohiniyattam heavy on elements to entice men? Hasn’t it undergone tremendous, classical changes today? Moreover, who even said that men can’t perform mohiniyattam?”

The dancer and younger brother of late actor Kalabhavan Mani has been a popular presence in prestigious venues like Nishagandhi and Changampuzha Park. Alongside performing, his aim is to quell the myths with facts he uncovered through his doctoral thesis, Aattathinte Aanvazhikal (The path of men in dance).

Throw the famous ‘thandavam is for men and lasya is for women and thus mohiniyattam is for women’ argument at Ramakrishnan and he says, “First of all, all Indian art forms are a thandavam-lasya mix. As per Natyasastra, thandavam means pure dance, that’s all. Bharatanatyam is considered thandavam. If this argument is true, why do all genders perform it? Also, lasya just refers to abhinaya, and Natyasastra also explains it as something formed out of a man and woman’s union. Nowhere does it say that mohiniyattam is just about lasya. Also, art forms like odissi has movements that are a lot more lasya-intense than mohiniyattam. Don’t they have legends like Kelucharan Mohapatra as their greatest gurus?”

Going a bit into its history, Ramakrishnan refers to Vallathol Narayana Menon’s efforts to revive the art. “All we know from literature is that the dance form, earlier, had many elements to entice men. After 1930s, it’s in the kalaris of Kalamandalam Sathyabhama teacher that the present day mohiniyattam took shape. Vallathol took initiative to overhaul it heavily. He also defined mohiniyattam as ‘The Kerala art form without a gender discrimination!’ It is very clear in the Kerala Kalamandalam Charithra Pusthakam (a history text on Kerala Kalamandalam) that it originated as a dance form with many elements of ‘dasiyattam’ in it. The dance forms of those times reflected the feudal thought processes of the time. When art forms got revived in the following renaissance period, Vallathol originally named mohiniyattam kairali nritham, though the name didn’t stick.”

Apparently, research shows the earliest gurus of the art were all male. “During Vallathol’s time, nattuvans even used to dance with artistes on the stage, which stopped as he discouraged it wanting the dancers to get more attention. Nattuvans had to stand with the background musicians and slowly, their presence faded away,” he explains.

Smitten by the dance form, all of Ramakrishnan’s dance training has been in mohiniyattam. “I eat, sleep and breathe this art from for the past many years. I trained under my guru RLV Anand sir from the earlier days. Thankfully, colleges like RLV and Sanskrit University offered the course to men too. That’s how I took my advanced qualifications in it. I could be part of MG University’s first MA Mohiniyattam course as well, and passed it with first rank. I was the first male teacher of the subject in RLV College . I did my M Phil and PhD from Kerala Kalamandalam, and did the research under Dr MK Geetha,” he explains. Ramakrishnan, who has been performing mohiniyattam since 1998, has never been on stage in the woman’s costume of the dance form, which is often a common practice. “I have been using a Kerala style costume fashioned by myself, always. And now it’s great to see many other up-and-coming artistes doing the same.”

The artiste, who is currently a guest lecturer in Sanskrit University, performs his own choreographies for all his programmes. “I also perform giving importance to male characters in our stories. They are also presented a bit differently in comparison to how a lady dancer would showcase them, with strains of feminine bhava,” he says. All that said, he mentions the lack of platforms for male mohiniyattam dancers, whose numbers are going up. “Being an academic scholar, it has become a bit easier for me but for others, it’s still a battle,” he says.

As he mentions the contributions of his late parents and brother in his journey, Ramakrishnan gets emotional. “Despite our financial constraints, my family has always been my pillar of strength. It pains me that they weren’t there to see me earning my Ph D, but I hope to do more in their name for students from poor financial backgrounds, to keep their memories alive,” Ramakrishnan signs off.

Title: Dhananjaya signs three-part biopic on underworld don Jayaraj
Content: Actor Dhananjaya is all set to transform into one of Bengaluru’s infamous dons from the 70s, Jayaraj , for his upcoming project. Written by former gangster and writer, Agni Sreedhar , the movie is being directed by debutant Shoonya (who has worked with team Avane Srimannarayana) and backed by Ashu Bedra . “The movie is set between 1974 to 1977 and shows the reign of the don, Jayaraj, during that period. We are making it a three-part film because we wish to capture the journey of the character as effectively as possible,” he shares. He adds that taking on an underworld subject, creates curiosity among audiences. “World over, this is a theme that has captured the fancy of many. Even people like Al Pacino and Robert De Niro have taken up such roles. Coming back to the film, I love the way Agni sir has penned the script. I have read many of his works. The experiences he brings to the table, for this project, will lend more gravitas to the subject. I feel proud that I have got the opportunity to be a part of a challenging film like this,” he says.Most actors take up method acting , especially when it comes to biopics — Ranveer Singh for instance, had locked himself up in an apartment for weeks to slip into the character of Alauddin Khilji that he played in Padmaavat. Does he have a similar game plan in mind? Chuckling, he says, “I am not going to do anything of the sort.” However, he says, “Having said that, I am excited to prepare myself physically and mentally and transform into Jayaraj. I will be listening to inputs from the writer and director, and brainstorm with them on the nuances of this character. And, if a role like Khilji had come my way, I believe I would have been able to do justice to that too, without locking myself in a room.”Making biopics is a trend that many industries have taken up in the recent past, and Dhananjaya himself has dabbled in the genre too, with Allama. Speaking about the same, he says, “The mark of a good biopic is that you need to make the audience connect with the characters and make them wonder about the life that personality led, like the Keerthy Suresh-starrer Mahanati, for instance, which showed the life of the late yesteryear actress Savitri. That is the kind of impact we are looking to create,” he tells us. The shoot for this film is scheduled to begin in three months.

Title: Dads inspire Bengaluru's young biker gals to push the ante
Content: For the longest time, a girl riding a motorbike meant a non-geared easy-to-ride variant. The rare occasion she rode a more powerful mean machine, heads turned. But times have definitely changed. Girls riding geared motorbikes are still few and far between, but those who do are pushing the ante and not only doing mundane rides around town, but are also trying their hand at the more challenging dirt biking and racing, among others. We caught hold of a few college bikers to understand what drove them to it, the relationship they share with their bikes and more...A 200 cc dirt bike weighing 153 kilos with bluetooth navigationSince my dad is a biker, riding a bike came naturally to me too. As a kid I would see him ride his bike and how passionate he was about biking and I feel the same about my bike as well. I was very interested in off-roading as a kid and want to take it up professionally. The best part was that my father encouraged me to take up biking. So, when I had to buy a bike I opted for one made specifically for off-roading. My bike is different from the others as it has bigger tyres and better ground clearance. Though I have not gone off-roading yet, I do want to do it very soon. My dad has gone on many off-roading trips and has given me tips on how to go about it. I hope to join him next time.Though it is a dirt bike, I do not treat her in a rough manner. In fact, my bike is my baby and I call her Bella. I have to be careful while riding through slush, as it splatters it all around, which bystanders will not take kindly to. I take great care of my bike and have a weekly ritual to keep her spick and span — I spend more than an hour and ensure that everything is perfect. It is very difficult for me to talk about my bond with my bike, because I cannot explain it in words. It’s a feeling that I share with her and no one else. She gives me the confidence that I need. I feel like I am unique and it makes me stand out from the rest.To take up dirt biking professionally.A 300 cc bike that weighs 179 kilos and has a dual silencerOne of the main reasons I took up biking was because of my father. He goes for long rides and once I learnt riding one, I also joined him. I go for long rides with my father every Sunday. We leave by 5 am and are back by noon. Generally, we join a group of regular bikers on these trips to nearby destinations. The fun is in the ride and the stop for breakfast, which is usually at a famous darshini. After I started bringing my bike to college, I have had parents come up to me asking me to teach their daughters how to ride it. There are a lot of girls in my college who have taken up biking, which is clear indication that it is no longer just a ‘guy-thing’.This is first bike I have got and though it is not a superbike, for me it is. I am crazy about superbikes and hope to get one someday. I go biking often and recently went to the Krishnagiri Dam backwaters. Since I have a 300 cc bike, the bike ride felt like it was an exercise and I got to stretch and ride it to its true potential. Though it was a tough ride, I was comfortable and my bike bore the burnt of everything else. So, whenever I feel that it’s been tough on my bike, I apologise to it and promise to take care of it. If I find a scratch on it, or if there is some damage, I feel like someone has stabbed me in my heart.I want to explore Karnataka first and then embark on a journey around the country on my bike.A 350 cc bike that weighs 196 kilosI took up biking mainly because of my mother; she’s my inspiration. As a kid, when I saw her ride her bike, I knew that is what I wanted to do. It helped that both my parents are bikers, because they understood my fascination for biking. In fact, it was my dad who taught me how to ride a bike. I prefer solo rides, though, and have taken off on several trips since I learnt to ride a bike. The only time I had company during a ride was when I went to Savanadurga with my mother.I have named my bike Reign and she is my precious little baby. I don’t like anyone else touching my bike. It was like love at first sight for me when I saw my bike in the showroom. I remember, I had gone with the intention of buying a black bike, but the moment I laid my eyes on her, I knew I had to have her. Ever since, red became my favourite colour. I share a very close bond with my bike and I know when something is wrong with it even if I don’t get an indication from her. I speak to her as if she’s a person and believe that she speaks back to me as well.My dream is to ride to Hollywood one day. I had this dream once that I was in front of the Hollywood sign in LA with my bike. I’m going to work hard towards achieving it.

Title: ‘Mammukka didn't want Kadakkal Chandran to resemble any politician’
Content: Director Santosh Vishwanath ’s upcoming movie One has several specialities, the key ones being that it has Mammootty playing the role of chief minister for the first time in Malayalam and it is scripted by acclaimed writers Bobby and Sanjay. But for Santosh, it was a massive feat to mount the multi-starrer on such a big scale, considering that his debut venture Chirakodinja Kinavukal was a relatively smaller project.The work for One started almost two years ago, when the filmmaker approached Mammootty with the idea. “We only had Mammukka in our mind when the thought germinated. Had he rejected it, we would have shelved the whole project. In fact, we began the script work only after he came on board,” says Santosh.But within two years the movie reached a stage where it became a multi-starrer that also has artistes such as Joju George, Murali Gopy and Mathew Thomas in pivotal roles. “It wasn’t intentional, but we needed such a star cast. The legislative assembly scenes alone required 140 representatives from the ruling and opposition parties, and some of them are important characters in the story,” he says.From the start to finish, Santosh says it was Mammootty’s co-operation that spurred him on further. “He was extremely involved with the process. In the start, we were mulling about giving a reference for his character of Chief Minister Kadakkal Chandran . But by the second discussion, it was clear that he had already started preparing for it himself. He had specific inputs about the character’s gait and manner of speaking,” says the filmmaker.In fact, Mammootty was also extensively involved in creating the look for Kadakkal Chandran. “In the start, I was worried about the character’s getup. Mammukka said, ‘I am going to the sets in a look and we will take it from there’. But as the start date neared, I got nervous and met Mammukka to discuss more about the look. He told me what he had in mind and I shared what I had pictured, and in the end, I sketched a particular look of the character and sent him. He replied, ‘It’s almost there’. The next day he surprised all of us with his look at the character photoshoot. It was way better than I had imagined. So, you can say that Mammukka had conceived and created the look of the character himself. He was clear that the character’s look shouldn’t be similar to any politicians of the past or present,” explains Santosh.Incidentally, the movie will also not be referring to any political parties. “We aren’t showing their symbols either. Usually films use names of fake parties, but we didn’t want that. The audience knows that there are only two major political parties in Kerala anyway. People who watch the film are free to interpret who the characters are based on,” says Santosh.The team of the film though have shot in real locations where the political drama unfolds, including the Secretariat in Thiruvananthapuram. “We had a lot of support while we were shooting at the Secretariat, be it from Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan sir or opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala. People know that because it’s a Mammukka film, the message would be positive. We are trying to portray how an ideal chief minister should be through the movie, and Mammukka has also tried to present that idea based on his beliefs,” explains the filmmakers.On shooting at the legislative assembly, the director says, “We shot the film’s climax in there. We had about four consecutive days of shoot from 6pm to 6am. All artistes who played the 140 elected representatives had co-operated to shoot at the night and made it a big success. It was a huge support for me. I consider it a great blessing and experience to do a movie on a such a big canvas with Mammukka in just my second venture. I am someone who wants each of my movies to be different and fortunately I have been able to do that so far.”

Title: Karthi-Mithran film to go on floors in April?
Content: Even as Karthi is busy shooting for Mani Ratnam ’s ambitious magnum opus Ponniyin Selvan , there’s news on his next. The actor will most likely begin work on his film with PS Mithran from April.A source says, “Mithran has been working on the script for a while and he is now finetuning the final draft. The technicians have been locked and talks are on to sign on the female lead. Karthi’s tied up with Sultan and Ponniyin Selvan, and once he is done with that, he will start work on Mithran’s film.”While GV Prakash will compose the music, George Williams will handle the camera. Kadhirr and Ruben have been roped in as the art director and editor respectively. The source adds, “There are reports of Arunraja Kamaraj directing Karthi, but that’s not confirmed yet because the lyricist-director is still working on the script and any confirmation on them teaming up will come only after a few months.”

Title: Mysuru’s Mahesh Chaudhary does a 2,024-km endurance ride in Thailand
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

What began as an activity to lose weight and get fit has become a passion for Mysuru-based entrepreneur Mahesh Chaudhary , who recently completed a 2,024-km endurance cycling ride in Thailand. Participating in the event, Mahesh, whose target was to complete the distance in under 205 hours, managed it in 156 hours and 25 minutes.

“Cycling is something that I took up six years ago to lose weight. Honestly, back then I would not have thought even in my wildest dreams that I would ever ride at an endurance event. When I began cycling, I got myself a very basic geared bicycle, which I then upgraded to a road bike, once I got more confident. Over the years, not only have I gotten better at cycling, but it has also become a passion to be able to ride more and in various condititions to really challenge the body,” says Mahesh, who is back home after this gruelling ride.

The Thailand event, though, is not his first attempt at endurance riding . “I began with smaller events that included 200-300 km rides in Bengaluru, and slowly graduated to 1,000-km with rides in Trichy and Coimbatore, among others. Then, in August last year, I did my first international event, when I did a 1,200-km ride from Paris to Brest and back, which gave me the confidence to step it up and do the 2,024-km ride in Thailand,” he says.

From the time Mahesh was set on doing a long-distance ride, he stepped up his training. “Preparation is key to be able to endure long distances over multiple days and on varying terrains. It is not only about strength training. You also need immense patience to just keep pedalling on without any distractions. In the run-up to the Paris event, I used to cycle 500-600 kms in a week in and around Mysuru,” says Mahesh.

The Thailand event, he adds, was a thrilling experience. “The first three days, we had to ride on flat roads, which was fairly easy. The real challenge began after that, when we had to ride through steep hilly regions in adverse climatic conditions. It was tough, but I knew that I had to do the distance in under 205 hours, so, I kept at it. My patience and endurance paid off, as I was able to complete it in 156-odd hours,” he explains.

His physical and mental stamina apart, Mahesh adds that sticking to a fixed diet also helped maintain his rhythm. “I took packets of ready-to-cook and ready-to eat upma, idli , etc., for the entire duration of the event. I did not want to try a new cuisine that could affect my health,” he says.

So, what’s next for him? “I have already planned my next ride in Italy, which is a 1,000-km endurance event. Just because I have done twice the distance, I will not take it lightly and am looking at training hard for it,” he signs off.

Title: up board 2020: 56 lakh students to take UP Board exams from today
Content:
EXAM ON TUESDAY Class X Elementary Hindi 8am to 11.15am Class XII General Hindi 2pm to 5.15pm

Special buses for UP Board candidates In a first, in the interest of the candidates appearing for the UP Board exams, the UP

government has made provision of special exam buses which were flagged off by

deputy chief minister Dinesh Sharma on the eve of the exams. Principal secretary

Aradhana Shukla said that one bus will run from each depot, except Lucknow from

be on the job. “These buses will cover the farthest route where normally buses do

not ply. The idea is to ensure that no student skips the exam because of lack of

transport services,” she said.

LUCKNOW: Over 56 lakh candidates will appear for the UP Board class X, XII examinations, set to begin from Tuesday. Almost 30 lakh class X students will be taking elementary Hindi and 26 lakh class XII students are appearing for general Hindi exam on day one. The exam is being held at 7,784 centres across the state. Both high school (class X) and intermediate (class XII) exams will end on March 6.A total of 56.1 lakh candidates have registered for the examinations, over two lakh less than the 58.6 lakh in 2019. In class X, out of 30 lakh candidates who registered online, 20,789 would appear as private candidates. Out of 26 lakh candidates who had registered for class XII exams, 69,983 are private candidates.To crack down on copying mafia who facilitate mass cheating in UP Board exams, the UP government has set up a state-level ‘monitoring and control room’ for CCTV surveillance and to monitor voice recordings. To keep a close vigil, nearly 2 lakh CCTV cameras have been installed at 7,784 centres in 75 districts of UP. Around 2 lakh invigilators have been put on duty.Candidates can check the UP board exam 2020 schedule for Tuesday from the table provided below.The Uttar Pradesh Secondary Education Board (UPSEB) has identified 938 centres as ‘sensitive’ and 395 as ‘hyper-sensitive’ which means these centres are vulnerable for cheating. Sensitive districts will use colour-coded and threaded answer-copies. The class X answer-copies will be pink and yellow and that of class XII will be green and blue. The idea is to ensure that they can’t be replaced or their pages taken out by any unauthorised person.In a first, the UP government has launched a Twitter handle, @upboardexam2020 for immediate redressal of any kind of complaints and queries. In addition, helpline numbers for the control room — 1800 180 6607, 0522-2239198 and e-mail id: boardexam2020.up@gmail.com and toll free numbers 1800 180 5310 and 1800 180 5312 can be used to register complaints of anything related to UP Board exams.On the eve of UP Board exams, deputy chief minister Dinesh Sharma made an appeal to parents to not have unnecessary high expectations from their children. Instead, parents should create a healthy atmosphere and balanced diet for them, Sharma appealed.

Title: Nirbhaya case latest news: Nirbhaya convicts to be hanged March 3
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

NEW DELHI: Further delay in the execution of the Nirbhaya case convicts would be “sacrilegious” to the rights of the victim and for justice, a Delhi court noted on Monday, fixing 6am on March 3 as the fresh date for their hanging.

This means the four men will be executed on the said date, unless Pawan Gupta decides to file mercy or curative petitions at the last minute as he is the only one who hasn’t exhausted all legal remedies provided under the Constitution.

Though the Delhi high court-laid deadline for Pawan to file curative and mercy plea ended on February 11, authorities, including the President’s secretariat and the Supreme Court, are known to be lenient and open to hearing any plea till the last minute in capital punishment jurisprudence.

“Article 21 merely guarantees an opportunity to the condemned convicts to exercise their legal rights. However, whether to utilise the opportunity or not is a matter of choice of the condemned convicts,” additional sessions judge Dharmendra Rana observed, pointing out that “convict Pawan cannot be permitted to defeat the ends of justice by simply opting to remain indolent”.

“After a lapse of 33 months, Pawan has opted to file neither any curative nor mercy petition,” the court observed, saying there can be only “two possible inferences for such indolence; 1) either convict Pawan is satisfied with the verdict of the Supreme Court or 2) he is simply interested in merely delaying the court proceedings.”

In either case, he cannot claim that the execution of the sentence needs to be delayed further, the judge underlined, adding that even the HC gave “one more opportunity” to Pawan, “unambiguously clarifying to exercise his rights within a week, failing which requisite action shall be initiated without any further delay”.

The court also noted that the black warrant issued to fix a date of hanging has been deferred twice and Monday’s order is the third time it has been issued against the four men — Mukesh Singh, Pawan Gupta, Vinay Kumar Sharma and Akshay Thakur .

“It is hereby directed that the death warrants, as issued by this court vide order dated January 7, 2020 in respect of the condemned convicts namely Mukesh, Pawan, Akshay and Vinay, shall now be carried into effect by causing the said convicts to be hanged by the neck until they are dead on March 3 at 6am,” the court directed, acknowledging that the execution dates of January 22 and February 1 had to be deferred.

During the proceedings on Monday, Pawan’s counsel Ravi Qazi told the court that the convict “intends to move a curative petition before the Supreme Court and mercy petition before the President”.

Meanwhile Akshay’s counsel A P Singh told the court that he plans to file a second mercy petition since the first one that was rejected had shortcomings “due to poverty and ignorance” and complete facts could not be brought before the President.

But the court refused to entertain the argument, noting that "mere preparation of a fresh mercy petition or in the words of court 'a complete mercy petition' cannot be a ground to defer the execution of the death warrants."

The court was also informed that Vinay was on hunger strike in Tihar Jail but later took food. It directed the jail superintendent to take appropriate care of Vinay as per law. It also rejected the ground of “mental illness”, saying that the issue was raised before the apex court which found no merit in this argument on the basis of the report submitted by doctors who said the convict was “psychologically well-adjusted” and the “general condition of the petitioner is stable”.

In a related development, convict Mukesh sent a communication to the court that he does not want to be represented by advocate Vrinda Grover , after which it appointed advocate Qazi to represent him too.

Monday’s order came on applications by Nirbhaya’s parents and the Delhi government seeking fresh death warrants for the convicts after the Supreme Court granted liberty to the authorities to approach the trial court for issuance of fresh date for the execution of the convicts.

Title: Esha Gupta: I used to be one of the shortest and curviest models
Content: Esha Gupta, who was a model and pageant winner , began her career in Bollywood with 'Jannat 2' (2012).Recently, BT caught up with the actress after she walked the ramp at a fashion event in the city.Looking back at the time when she had stepped into the modelling world, she said, “I used to model years ago. I was the shortest and curviest model at the fashion week. I am thankful that I was accepted in those days when skinny, tall girls were the norm.” Though she still makes an appearance on the ramp at regular intervals, she does get a tad nervous. “Now, whenever I walk the ramp, I pray that I don’t stumble,” she said.

Title: Honeymoon with friends on the side!
Content: Flight tickets? Check. Hotel reservations? Check. Chauffeured car through the course of the honeycation? Check. Euros in the wallet? Check.Corporate lawyer Ranjith Gunashekaran went through his checklist just as he and his bride, HR professional Sumitra Kannan, took the cab to the airport, along with their three friends. No, they weren’t tagging along to see them off; they were joining the newlyweds in their honeymoon. Sounds bizarre? Maybe. But it’s definitely a fad that’s catching up.Friendmoon — or honeymooning with friends — is predicted as one of the biggest travel trends of 2020. So, what prompts youngsters to take their friends along on a vacation, which is traditionally a couple’s preserve? “I think it could be because most couples either live in or at least holiday together before taking the plunge. So, I don’t think they feel the need to spend ‘us’ time after marriage,” says Chennai-based interior designer Anitha Subramaniam, who friendmooned in Tawang. We speak to couples who went on buddymoon to find out more about this trend...When we decided to friendmoon in Rome, we also had cost-cutting in mind. We went with three of my friends and two of my wife’s friends. It was a good chance to get to know each other’s buddies. You could say we were also anxious about starting a new life together. And since we split the cost for the private bungalow, 8-seater car and food, we ended up saving a lot.— Pranav Kumar, Noida-based architectWe thought it would be fun roadtripping with friends and cost effective, too, especially since we were going to Eastern Europe. We had planned it in such a way that we’d be together while travelling from one place to another, and I could spend time with my husband while exploring the cities.— Girija Jamdar, Pune-based entrepreneurWe are three couples who got married around the same time. They waited for our wedding to get over and we all decided to friendmoon in Bali. We booked private villas to have our personal space, and partied and did adventure sports together— Zahra Motorwala Kothari, Mumbai-based media professionalSay yay to a post-nuptial partyI recently planned a wedding event in Goa. The groom is based out of Hong Kong and the bride was joining him there soon after. So, he wanted to plan a post-wedding trip to Gokarna, where they’d be joined by their childhood friends. Since he hadn’t met his pack in a long time, he wanted to make the best use of the time he had here. That was his grand honeymoon plan!— Arjun Thomas, Mangaluru-based wedding curatorIn 2015, Jennifer Aniston and Justin Theroux went on a honeymoon to Bora Bora with their friends, including Courteney Cox, Chelsea Handler, Jason Bateman, and Jimmy Kimmel. Johnny Depp and Amber Heard also took their gang of friends on a cruise after their private Bahamas wedding in 2015. Both the couples have now split.Keep your friends posted about your plans of a friendmoon much in advance. Apart from splurging on travel, outfits and presents for your wedding, they will also have to start saving for the extended vacation and plan their work schedule accordingly.Choose who you want to buddymoon with. Ideally, your idea of fun should match with your partner’s and also the friends who you are travelling with. If you and your spouse want to spend the day exploring and all that your friends want to do is laze around at the hotel, it could be trouble in paradise already!40% millennials were OK to friendmoon if it reduced cost by 50%47% of people surveyed, aged between 18 and 35, in 2018, said they’d go on a friendmoon12% of Americans, in a 2017 survey, revealed they’ve attended a buddymoon in the last five yearsIn 2011, Buddymoon found a mention in Urban Dictionary, and was defined as ‘A honeymoon taken with a group of friends in addition to the bride and groom.’ Friendmoon and group honeymoon are just other terms for the trend.Survey source: UK payment app Pingit, Travel agency Priceline and forex specialist Travelex

Title: Amitabh Bhattacharya: Songs are very sound driven today than being lyrics driven: Amitabh Bhattacharya
Content:
Amitabh Bhattacharya (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Amitabh Bhattacharya (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

National Award winning lyricist-singer Amitabh Bhattacharya of Abhi Mujh Mein Kahin fame was in the city to attend the golden jubilee celebrations of the foundation of his school, Spring Dale College . Reminiscing his school days, the Lucknow-born Emosanal Attyachaar lyricist shares, “Today, after 25-26 years, when I walked inside the school premises, it was like déjà vu. In front of me was the stage and the school prayer was going, so it was a beautiful feeling. All my teachers were there and seeing those familiar eyes with so much love and warmth was a feeling that is difficult to explain in words.”Sharing his memories of the city, Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani and Agar Zindagi lyricist says, “Lucknow poori duniya mein mashhoor hai, poori duniya mein apni tehzeeb ke liye, warmth ke liye. I have very fond memories of the city. It has changed so much in the last decade, that I am finding it difficult to recognize places especially in Indira and Gomti Nagar. Though the development is necessary, cities are today losing their identity because as soon as you step out of any airport, you will find malls, flyovers, and metro, so all the cities look the same. Woh jo shaher ki apni pehchan hoti thi ab woh kuch purani galiyon mein hi milti hai. This time, I would like to explore those old places in the city.”Talking about his journey in Bollywood, the Dangal lyricist says, “I would call my journey as unpredictable. All my growing up years, I aspired to be a singer. I used to sing in my school and was famous among my teachers because of this. Then during my college days, I was a part of a local orchestra band for a while and also worked for a small radio station. In 1999, I moved to Mumbai to become a singer and over the following years, I even struggled for it like singing in chorus or scratches etc. Writing never happened to me while I was in Lucknow. Around 2002-03, I discovered this flare in me ki haan main likh sakta hoon. Things changed when my friend and composer Amit Trivedi asked me to write on his tunes for the film Dev D and the director liked it and retained it. Though I was not keen on writing at that time also. But when the movie released in 2009, suddenly I got noticed and started getting work as a writer.”Amitabh Bhattacharya (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)So ask the Super 30 lyricist how did the language of Lucknow help in becoming a famed lyricist and he replies, “The only time I used to write Hindi was during my Hindi classes in school. Maine kabhi ghar par diary bhi theek se nahi likhi. But growing up in a place like Lucknow, yahan ki jo Hindi-Urdu mix, jo Hindustani zubaan hum bolte hain woh sahi lehja sunkar bada hua tha. And because I wanted to become a singer, so jo 50s se lekar 80s tak ke purane songs ka jo catalogue hai woh bahut sune thay. So, if you remember the lyrics of those old songs, that means you have heard the work of the best of writers and you have absorbed all this and it stays in your sub-conscious. So that came in handy for me.”Comparing the lyrics of the old songs to the contemporary songs and low shelf life of the songs today, the Channa Mereya lyricist opines, “According to me there are three factors to how the lyrics and shelf life of the songs have changed over the decades. Firstly, language is a medium that always evolves and keeps on changing. While earlier we used to converse only in Hindi but today we use English words also in our regular conversation and lyrics of the songs are likewise. Secondly, we are living in an age where songs are very sound driven today than being lyrics driven. So when sound becomes important, lyrics take a backseat. Thirdly, shelf life is not only about the content but it’s also about the attention span of the listener. There was a time when the production of music was not that much. The song was first aired on Chitrahaar show and later cassettes and CDs were released and so the value of music was more then. But today, on your mobile phone you have music from around the world that too for almost free. So, just like there is a term information overload, we are living in an era of entertainment overload and so the attention span is very low.”

Title: As coronavirus spreads, masks become a must for #airportlook
Content: Luggage – check. Boarding pass – check. Mask – check. For most flyers now, having a mask is as important as carrrying an ID when heading to the airport. As the coronavirus scare continues to grip the world, masks are flying off the shelves everywhere, including at airports.A spokesperson of a mask brand which is selling about 12,000-15,000 masks per day and supplies to stores at Delhi airport, says, “Big orders are being placed by stores at the airport, and the stock is being replenished every day. Most flyers do not want to enter a plane without wearing mask. In the markets, the sale is as high as in peak pollution season. But at the airport, even in the peak pollution season masks are as much in demand as they are now. The most efficient masks are those that filter out 99.99% particles, but very few of those are left. In the next couple of weeks, we are expecting them to be out of stock.”Uday Kaushik, who sells masks at a medical shop in Aerocity, says, “Whether they are flying domestic or international, all flyers want to carry masks with them. We are selling over 400-500 masks per day and have to replenish our stock every other day.”Balachandran, who works at a store in Khan Market, says, “These days, the standard query from customers is – ‘I am travelling to so and so place, which mask should I buy?’ People are also asking which mask is best for kids, how many masks should they buy, and should they wash it after every use. In January -February, mask sales never overshoot supply, but all of a sudden we are seeing this surge in sale.” Abhijeet Sinha, who works at a mask store in Gurgaon, says, “The demand for masks has gone up 200 times in the last few weeks. Most people who are travelling are buying masks. In Gurgaon, due to corporate offices, we are getting more orders.”Manas, a corporate executive, says, “I was travelling to Germany a few days back. My family insisted that I carry a mask with me, but I shrugged it off. But when I reached the airport, I saw so many flyers wearing masks. So, before boarding the flight, I also bought one.”JK Mishra, a start-up owner, says, “I have to travel almost every week for work, and the coronavirus scare is so visible at airports and in flights. We are going on a holiday to Istanbul and the first item on my shopping list is a mask. I couldn’t find high-quality masks in the market, so I ordered them online for my family.”Sunny Leone with husband Daniel Weber; Mini Mathur and Kabir Khan wearing masks inside an airplaneParineeti Chopra shared pictures of her wearing a mask at the airport. “Sad, but I guess this is the situation now. Stay safe guys,” she captioned the pics. Ranbir Kapoor (right) was also papped recently wearing a mask as he stepped out of an airport

Title: 1935 Rolls Royce Coupe,1950 Lambretta scooter: Vintage vehicles cruise from India Gate to Gurgaon
Content: The 21 Gun Salute International Vintage Car Rally saw the best vintage cars and bikes from India – and some from overseas – assemble at the heart of the capital on Saturday morning. From 19th century carriages and early limousines to post-World War II roadsters and Rolls Royces, the rally showcased a diverse range of vintage vehicles . There were several retro bikes and scooters, too, which caught the fancy of the visitors. The rally started at India Gate, which saw hundreds of spectators walk in and click pictures with the mean machines. Following this, Heritage Motoring Club of India President KTS Tulsi flagged off the rally, and over a hundred vintage cars and two-wheelers drove a distance of 42km from India Gate to Karma Lakelands Golf Course in Gurgaon. For the participants, the rally is a much-awaited event for which they prepare for eagerly. Aditya Malik, who was driving his 1965 Jaguar Roadster, told us, “It’s always great to be here because you get to meet so many like-minded people and see some great cars.” Jagdish Thackersey, who drove his 1935 Bentley , quipped, “I always dread it when I have to drive this car out of Delhi. But in all seriousness, it is always fun to be at this event.”A 1935 Rolls Royce Coupe was also part of the rallyA Morris Eight, which was once owned by the royal family of BikanerA Lambretta scooter from the 1950s(L-R) Madan Mohan, founder, 21 Gun Salute Vintage Car Rally, and KTS Tulsi, President, Heritage Motoring Club of IndiaThe 1946 Buick Super 8 Convertible (below) at the rally was once Gayatri Devi’s favourite car (above)The Fiat Corsa (below) was driven by legendary racing driver Giulio Masetti to win the prestigious Targa Florio in 1921 (above)The Bentley Batem Drophead was one of the first cars in the world with a power hood. Title: Himansh Kohli: Nobody wanted to know the real story and I was made out to be the villain
