LUCKNOW: A 15-year-old boy who was in custody since December 25 for anti-CAA protests in Lucknow and sent to the juvenile home has been granted special leave to appear in UP Secondary Education Board’s Class 10 examinations which begin on Tuesday.

The minor boy, a resident of Sheesh Mahal in the Old City, was granted special leave by the Juvenile Justice Board (JJB) where his case is pending.

He walked out of the juvenile home on Monday evening after spending 55 days in custody. The order, passed on February 14, stated that special leave was from February 17 evening till February 23. So, he will have to return to the juvenile home situated on Mohaan Road on February 24.

As per his documents, including birth certificate, school marksheet and Aadhaar card, the boy’s date of birth is May 19, 2004.

It was an emotional moment as he walked out on Monday evening and re-united with his father, who was waiting at the gates of the juvenile home along with his lawyer.

“I received my books inside the home but could not prepare much for the exams since we have to follow a tight schedule in the shelter home. After cleaning tables to washing dishes to other such chores, hardly any time was left for studies,” the boy told TOI.

“I have my Hindi examination on Tuesday and will stay up the night to prepare for it,” he added.

His lawyer Mohd Tanveer said the boy’s name was not mentioned in the initial FIR lodged by the police on December 20. “He was picked up by the police on December 25 and shown under ‘identified persons’ in the FIR. He was produced before a magistrate on December 26 and sent to the juvenile home,” Tanveer claimed.

“We filed an application before the JJB seeking permission that the boy be allowed to write his board examinations and our plea was acknowledged by the board,” he added.

As per Section 98 (1) of The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015, the board can permit leave on special occasions like examination, marriage of relatives, death of kith or kin or accident or serious illness of parent or any emergency of like nature, for seven days.

Title: Delhi: Public bus fleet crosses 6,000 for first time in 10 years
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Last December, 100 standard-floor buses were officially launched under the Cluster scheme

NEW DELHI: In the past one and a half months when Delhi was in the grip of the election fever, its public transport system reached a milestone. After witnessing a constant dip for a decade, the number of public buses again breached the 6,000 mark during this period, even crossing the peak witnessed in 2010.

Last December, 100 standard-floor buses were officially launched under the Cluster scheme, taking the total number of buses in Delhi , including Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) ones, to 5,989. This batch of non-AC standard-floor buses, with hydraulic lifts, took the number of Cluster scheme buses to 2,208.

After the model code of conduct for the assembly elections came into force on January 6, no announcement could be made. But 204 standard-floor buses were inducted in the Cluster scheme fleet in January-February, taking the total number of public buses in Delhi to 6,223 against the 2010 peak of 6,204.

Another 30 airconditioned, blue-coloured buses have arrived in the city for the Cluster scheme. “The airconditioned buses, a first for the scheme, are in the final stage of certification,” an official said. The capital has 1,275 AC buses at present, all of which are in the DTC fleet.

During the 2010 Commonwealth Games, Delhi government inducted air condition and non-AC low-floor buses into DTC. This was the time when private Blueline buses were on their way out following a string of fatal accidents. The Cluster scheme was yet to be launched.

While the DTC fleet has since been dipping every year, the Cluster scheme, starting with 231 buses in November 2011, has gained in strength. However, its total strength is still only 56.5% of the required 11,000 buses. Delhi government is trying to get 4,000 more buses at the earliest.

The standard-floor buses under the Cluster scheme are part of the 650 buses for which a contract was earlier awarded and the bidding is on for 350 more. DTC is also in the process of procuring 1,000 low-floor CNG Buses, for which work order is expected to be awarded soon.

Electric buses are likely to roll out in the city this year for the first time, but the process may take a little longer than expected. These include 1,000 electric buses under the Cluster model. DTC is also in the process of procuring 1,000 electric buses. Tender for 300 buses each for both DTC and the Cluster scheme were floated earlier but will have to be issued afresh.

Title: To promote cashless transactions, this ashram accepts online ‘dakshina’
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The ashram accepts online donations from its members only

Allahabad: At a time when the government is making all efforts to promote cashless transactions, saints at a camp in the ongoing Magh Mela are receiving dakshina (donations) via online transactions through BHIM app.

The camp of Aum Waheguru Rishi ashram , having its headquarters at Delhi, has been operating its Annakshetra at Sangam Lower Marg wherein around 40,000 devotees are served food thrice a day.

Members of the ashram offer ‘dakshina’ either directly to the account of the ashram through BHIM app or in cash. The ashram has been encouraging its members to make online donations during prominent religious events like Magh Mela, Khumbh or Maha Kumbh.

According to office-bearers, the ashram does not receive donations from devotees visiting their camp and only members of the ashram can donate.

Swami Satyanand Saraswati Satyam, who manages the Annakshetra of the ashram, said: “We have been coming to Teerthraj Prayag for last 35-40 years to attend Kumbh, Ardh Kumbh & Magh Mela. We have also been attending Kumbh Melas in Ujjain, Trimbakeshwar Nashik & Haridwar along with Surya Grahan Mela at Kurukshetra. Donations are an integral part of the camp. We introduced cashless donations after demonetisation in 2017.”

“Seers are encouraged to use mobile app and their number is increasing every year — starting from a modest 18 in 2018 to over 300 this year,” he said.

Besides, the entire activities of Annakshetra, wherein around 100-110 quintal of foodgrains (flour, pulses, rice, etc) and 200 litres of milk per day is consumed, are sponsored by the members of the ashram alone.

“We donate 11% of our income with an undertaking mostly in cheques, which upon acceptance are pooled as a common fund as no CSR fund, government aid or any individual donation is used at all,” said Swami Satyam, a practising lawyer in Supreme Court.

“We believe that whatever is served to the deity should be pure and not used by others. The same applies to currency notes which is offered to god and later distributed among the saints, who are around 25% of the total attendance of the Annakshetra on any given day. Therefore, we accept only new currency notes if the donation is not online,” he added.

The kitchen area of the Annakshetra is partly mechanized and food is served in steel utensils in the camp which is washed by women members of the ashram.

Another aspect which makes this camp special is the fact that besides offering free food thrice a day, the common public is offered various items as dakshina.

“Distribution of clothes, blankets, steel utensils, umbrellas, shawls, oil, roasted healthy food & digestive tablets, Chyavanprash, torches, carpets, yoga mats, caps, socks, jackets and other items of utility are given in ‘dakshina’ on our part,” he said.

Title: Police identify all seven Unnao van blaze victims
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Kanpur: Police on Monday have identified the seven deceased, who were burnt alive following a collision of their van with a truck on Unnao-Hardoi road near Bangarmau toll plaza in Unnao district on Sunday.

They have been identified as Shambhu, Himanshu, Amit Mishra, Kallu, Khajan Singh, Ankit Bajpayee and Bal Krishna.

SP Unnao Vikrant Vir Singh said that preliminary investigations have shown that the accident took place when one of the tyres of the speeding van burst, the vehicle veered to the left and caught fire after hitting a truck in another lane. The CNG kit installed in the van caught fire.

Police said that the family members of the deceased had a tough time identifying their bodies.

"DNA sampling would be done to identify the bodies which have been completely charred and beyond recognition," the SP said.

Police said that as per the kin, Shambhu, Himanshu, Amit Mishra, Kallu, Khajan Singh and Bal Krishna, were relatives and residents of Unnao who were on way to Shahjahanpur to attend a marriage function.

They had booked a van belonging to one Ankit Bajpayee of Kalyani Devi locality of Unnao. "Ankit was on the wheels when the accident took place," the police further said.

Title: How coronavirus scare may impact Ashok Gehlot's free medicine scheme
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Increased dependence on imports of key bulk drugs from China, which is currently in the grip of novel coronavirus (nCoV), might severely affect chief minister Ashok Gehlot ’s flagship free medicine scheme.The scheme had earned Centre’s pat in December last year.The companies, which provides drugs to the state government for distributing them among people free, import their Active Pharmaceutical Ingredient (API) from China.The situation is alarming, but health department claimed that as of now there was nothing to worry about. However, the health department officials are closely monitoring the situation.“At the moment, no manufacturer has warned us of any imminent problems,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary, health department.At a time when the state government is taking measures to increase the number of drugs under the free medicine scheme, there is a scare of shortage of medicines, which might affect the scheme due to nCoV in China.The health department has started taking measures so that the scheme is not affected. “We are talking to the Centre and other states to explore alternative sources to procure such drugs in case there are shortages,” Singh said.Indian pharmaceutical companies look worried about the situation emerging in the sector due to nCoV. However, the companies claimed that as of now there was no such shortage of medicines, but in future there might be difficulties. “As of now, there is no shortage of medicines in the market as the supply chain holds enough stocks to last two to three months. There will be issues if supply of API from China doesn't resume in the next 20 to 30 days,” Vinod Kalani, president Rajasthan Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Association (RPMA) told TOI.Kalani added, “Due to nCoV vis-a-vis shortage of medicines as per our information, the situation is improving except in Wuhan region of China and the API units situated in that region may take some time to start. Few of the manufacturers have started receiving supplies through air route of expensive molecules.”The state is providing more than 600 drugs free of cost to patients for its drug distribution counters established at government hospitals. Recently, it has added more than 100 drugs useful in treatment of kidney and heart ailments and for cancer treatment.In Lok Sabha in 2016, the ministry of commerce and industry informed the House that the country was highly depending on imports for essential drugs such as metformin, paracetamol, acetyl salicylic acid and other nine such essential drugs.

Title: Pune airport parking woes to persist for two years
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

PUNE: Flyers will have to brave parking hassles at the Pune airport for two more years as the multilevel car parking facility will be completed only by 2022.

“The Rs 120-crore multilevel car parking facility is being constructed to accommodate 1,000 cars. It will come up in the parking number 1, which is opposite to the entry gate of the airport, and will be completed in the next two years. The parking problems will be resolved once it is ready. Due meagre land resources, we are not able to immediately shift the existing car parking to any other location,” the airport authorities said in a series of tweets.

Ravi Suresh Jain, the director of Pune-based Pebbles Infratech, which is developing the parking lot, had earlier said the parking number 1, which is spread over 90,000sqft, had not been fully given to them. “We are presently working on 35,000sqft where digging works are going on. We were told that we will get the whole area by mid-February but that has not happened. We have heard that talks are on with the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) in the matter,” he said.

Taking to Twitter, the airport authorities further said, “We are exploring several options to accommodate passengers and visitors’ vehicles during the construction period. None of these options have yet been finalized due to several reasons.”

In January, former airport director Ajay Kumar had said that the matter had been sorted out, adding that a plot owned by a private party adjacent to the parking number-1 would be used for parking till the new facility was ready.

However, in a recent conversation, Kuldeep Singh, the new airport director, said otherwise. “The landowner stopped responding to us,” he said.

When contacted, PMC commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad told TOI the matter had been brought to his notice by Airports Authority of India officials. “There are two private landowners, who do not seem to be interested in giving their land for the parking. Our chief engineer will have a word with them again in a bid to convince them,” he said.

The developments mean that the passengers will have to face parking inconvenience till the multilevel car parking facility is completed.

“The other day, it took me around 20 minutes just to get my two-wheeler out of the parking lot due to lack of space and haphazard parking. The authorities should address the situation at the earliest,” Paritosh Jain, who went to the airport to drop his brother recently, said.

Title: Celebratory firing death: Two arrested
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Priyarajsinh Jadeja

Rajkot: In the investigation into the celebratory firing case that resulted in a death, Vallabhipur police station officials arrested two persons and booked one more on Sunday night. However, the main accused, Vishwarajsinh Gohil, is still at large.

In the celebratory firing during a marriage festivity, a bullet carelessly fired by Gohil got lodged in the head of Priyarajsinh Jadeja (20) and scorched the eardrum of Shaktisinh Jadeja (22) in Pachhegam village of Vallabhipur taluka in Bhavnagar district on Saturday night.

The police said Gohil had fired one round from his revolver, while there a garba dance programme was going on in the village.

Meanwhile, the police arrested Dharmadeepsinh Gohil, the groom at whose marriage the crime had taken place and Shailendrasinh Rana, a jawan from the Indian Army.

“In a video footage of the marriage festivities, we saw Dharmadeepsinh and Rana fire one round each from the revolver belonging to Rana. The footage shows that Rana approaches Dharmadeepsinh and hands him over his revolver. Dharmadeepsinh first fires in the air and then Rana also fires one round in the air,” said M D Makwana, sub-inspector with Vallabhipur police station.

The footage also showed Satyarajsinh Gohil opening fire in the air. The police have launched a manhunt for Satyarajsinh. The police have also seized Rana’s revolver and sent it to laboratory for forensic testing.

Title: ‘People often confuse attraction with love’
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Dr Manjushree Sardeshpande gives a lecture in a programme organized by Association of Counsellors and Psychoth... Read More

Nagpur: ‘Ek mai aur ek tu.. love, intimacy and beyond’, a special Valentine’s Day programme organized by the Association of Counsellors and Psychotherapists (ACPN), Nagpur, at Laburnum Hall, Chitnavis Centre, on Sunday evening highlighted the issues of social taboos and stigmas on relationships.

“Given the era of modernization, people often confuse attraction with love,” said keynote speaker, Dr Hemant Mittal, a consulting psychiatrist, while delivering his speech on the topic —‘Power and responsibility of love’.

“The power of love is a thought of making it last. If there’s direction and focus, love will have a long run. If two people do not find this thought uplifting enough, then it is clearly not love, but attraction,” said Mittal.

He clarified where love actually comes from and stated that it’s an emotion that gets generated emotionally due to external inputs. He also described the direction of love as an attraction formed in one’s mind, but with logic.

According to Mittal, most relationships fail because they do not advance in a stage-wise manner.

Guest speaker, Dr Manjushree Sardeshpande, HOD of the English department from RS Mundle College, began with a sonnet by William Shakespeare.

“True love is not easy to find,” she said, adding, “The purest form of love is a mother’s love.”

She spoke about the past, present and future of love relationships and how changes are taking place from generation to generation. “Love is selfless. The one who only thinks about others displays genuine and selfless love. The current generation is confused and highly mistaken about what real love is all about. Most youngsters do not think about their partners and this ruins their relationship.”

In the group discussion, coordinator Dr Chetan Rewatkar questioned the panellists — Mittal, Sardeshpande, Shruti Rathi, a student and Palash Makadwar, an entrepreneur — on subjects like the difference between the past and current generation, basic difference between ‘crush’ and ‘love’ and love marriages.

The interaction between the audience and the panellists was lively, interesting and informative.

Title: Hit-and-run: HC upholds Vismay Shah’s conviction
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Ahmedabad: The Gujarat high court on Monday upheld the conviction of Vismay Shah, 32, in the Vastrapur hit-and-run case in which two youths — Rahul Patel and Shivam Dave — were killed in February 2013. The court ordered Shah to surrender within six weeks to serve the remainder of his five-year jail term.

Justice Sonia Gokani rejected the appeal filed by Shah against his conviction on charges of rash driving and culpable homicide not amounting to murder and against his jail sentence. The HC also rejected the state government’s demand to enhance Shah’s punishment.

However, the HC imposed an additional fine of Rs 2 lakh on Shah besides the Rs 31,000 fine imposed by the trial court in July 2015. “The court may also impose additional punishment of social work but this will become clear once a copy of the order is available,” said additional public prosecutor Hardik Soni.

The HC lifted the stay on the trial against two witnesses, Lalit Gupta and Dinesh Chaudhary, and ordered the trial court to complete proceedings against them on perjury charges. The lower court decided to try them for perjury after they turned hostile in court. They were friends of the deceased boys and had testified about the accident before police.

While the appeal was pending before the high court, Shah struck a settlement with the parents of both the deceased boys. An affidavit filed by Patel’s father, Ghanshyam Patel, informed the high court that each of the two families received Rs 1.5 crore towards the settlement.

Before pronouncement of order, Justice Gokani inquired about the settlement amount. Shah’s advocate argued that since the compensation was paid by Shah to the victims’ families they had no issue with him. The court may take into consideration the satisfaction on the part of the parents while deciding Shah’s punishment, though the satisfaction of the parents and that of the court are two different issues.

Title: Debris, silt dredged from Mula river near Holkar bridge by KCB, Army
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

PUNE: Huge quantities of debris and silt were removed from the Mula river near the Holkar bridge by the Khadi Cantonment Board (KCB)and the Bombay Engineering Group (BEG) and Centre in the past few days.

The Mula river passes through the cantonment area before merging with Mutha river at Sangamwadi . The four-km stretch of the river is unclean and often covered by hyacinth.

“A private contractor, who constructed the new bridge parallel to the Holkar bridge, had dumped construction debris on the riverbed which had disturbed the natural flow of water. Water used to accumulate in large quantities under the new bridge and the Holkar bridge and posed a health risk for residents living in the surrounding areas,” Pramod Kumar Singh, the KCB’s chief executive officer, told TOI.

He said, “The KCB, along with the army personnel from the BEG, worked on the project and removed debris with the help of earth movers over the past few days. The accumulated water was impure as several housing societies along the river in Vishrantwadi directly released untreated drainage water into the river. This has disturbed the river’s ecosystem completely. As for the water hyacinth, the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation has hired a private agency and included the river stretch passing through the KCB limits for the work.”

Title: Karnataka: Woman ensures dignity in death for unclaimed bodies
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Jubeda Akbar Ali

CHIKKAMAGALURU: Women are not usually allowed into burial grounds. But in NR Pura of Chikkamagaluru district , a Muslim woman has broken the barrier and won the hearts of locals.

Jubeda Akbar Ali, a 45-year-old Muslim widow, is member of the local town panchayat performs the last rites of unidentified bodies.

This mother of two girls also works as an ambulance driver. She graduated from Koppa First Grade College .

On Saturday, she transported the body of an unidentified person in his fifties in her ambulance and arranged the burial. “He had been ill for many days. After his death, the body was kept in the mortuary for many days. As no one came forward to claim it, we decided to bury it as per rules. As no relative was present, I offered prayers and did the burial,” she said.

She said her father wanted her to be involved in social service. She said: “I did my first burial in 2003. A woman’s body was being transported in a tractor used to dump garbage. That made me take up this service and provide dignified last rites. Now, if I come across an unidentified body, I organise the funeral and so far, I’ve buried 10 persons. I learnt driving when I was young and started driving the ambulance two years ago. Some persons donated an ambulance and I ferry patients, the destitute, among others, in it.”

For locals, she is a familiar face. “What makes her special is her decision to take up a challenging task like organising a burial for unclaimed bodies,” said Raju, a local resident.

Title: SCR announces monthly fee for auto & taxi drivers
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Aurangabad: The South Central Railway (SCR) has announced monthly charges of Rs 350 and Rs 450 for autorickshaws and taxis, respectively for parking vehicles to pick passengers at Aurangabad railway station .

Besides Aurangabad, Nanded, Jalna and Parbhani railway stations have also witnessed this new fee that has sparked angry reactions from autorickshaw and taxi drivers. Other than the fee, these private transporters will also have to submit a police verification certificate for registration.

Moreover, apprehensions are being raised that charging of fee could discourage private transporters to venture on the premise of railway stations which in turn would cause hardship to passengers.

Nisar Ahmed Khan, leader of autorickshaw drivers in Aurangabad, said the railway officials have no right to levy monthly charges for stationing of rickshaws and taxis.

“It is unjust and unilateral decision. We cater to commuting needs of passengers and the railway authorities must keep this fact in mind before coming out with any arbitrary decision,” he said.

As per official record, around over 12,000 passengers book unreserved tickets from Aurangabad railway station every day, whereas the station witnesses footfall of over 34,000 passengers on any given day, including foreign tourists.

Keshav Mhaske, an auto driver, said he would avoid visiting the railway station to pick-up passengers. “We will not share an iota of our hard-earned money with the railway authorities. Instead, we will pick the passengers from other public places,” he said.

Meanwhile, SCR authorities said drivers/owners of autorickshaws and taxis will have to submit a written application along with vehicle documents, Aadhaar card and police verification for necessary registration.

“The practice of charging fee from autorickshaws and taxis is already in place in other divisions of the SCR and it is now being introduced in Nanded division. The move aims at streamlining traffic of private transporters and offer safe commuting to the passengers,” he said.

Title: FMS registers new high with Rs 58L package
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

New Delhi: Faculty of Management Studies ( FMS ) saw a significant improvement in its final placement , recording its highest domestic package of Rs 58.6 lakh per annum, while the average for the top quartile stood at Rs 37.3 lakh per annum. At Rs 25.6 lakh per annum, the average CTC, too, recorded 11% increase.

The final placements for the batch of 2018-20 ended on Monday and witnessed a 100% record. As many as 104 recruiters participated in the process, 88 of which made 234 offers. Of the 230 students, 219 sat for placements, while 11 took a placement holiday. This year, the institute received 68 pre-placement offers of which 62 were accepted.

As compared with last year, there have been 36% increase in the number of PPOs and a 42% increase in the number of consulting offers. For the first time, 75% of the offers were above Rs 20 LPA and the average CTC for women increased to Rs 26.2 LPA. The biggest chunk, 33%, got hired in consulting, strategy and general management fields.

Like the past few years, e-commerce companies, too, recruited in large numbers and offered coveted product and programme management roles.

Title: Jaipur: Forest department notice to resort owner near Mukundara reserve
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Construction work in full swing at the resort near Mukundara tiger reserve

JAIPUR: The forest department has issued notice to a resort owner near Kala Khuyi for illegal construction in the proposed eco-sensitive zone of Mukundara Hills Tiger Reserve .

After the ministry of environment and forests (MoEF) issued draft for declaring a radius of 1km at the reserve as eco-sensitive zone, the construction was started in full swing. A senior forest official at MHTR said, “The owner applied for no objection certificate (NoC) in district collectorate. Following this, an application was forwarded to us. We have turned down the proposal as it falls under the proposed ESZ. The final report from the ranger is awaited.”

After the notification was issued, villagers of Morkukala, Morkunj, Darrah and Kalikui have started protesting as this will prohibit all types of construction in their farms.

On January 10, the ministry had issued a draft notification to declare a 1km eco-sensitive zone around MHTR, which is spread over 759.99sqkm covering four districts of Kota, Bundi, Chittorgarh and Jhalawar. The ministry has sought suggestions and objections within 60 days. An official said, “So far, we have received only one objection from Morkukala. It is believed that the objections are directly submitted on MoEF website.”

A senior forest official said the eco-sensitive zones will be treated as a ‘breathing space’ for wildlife. It is demarcated based on their ecological importance which reins in development activities inimical to wildlife and their habitats. While the zone will be completely compatible to livelihoods of local communities living around the tiger reserve, it will bring the order on tourism, mining activities, industries and other footloose development activities disrupting wildlife corridors outside the reserve boundary.

Title: Ahmedabad: Driver returns bag with Rs 1.20 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Ramesh Chunara displayed exemplary honesty by returning the bag of a passenger.

AHMEDABAD: A 45-year-old rickshaw driver from Raipur, Ramesh Chunara, displayed exemplary honesty by returning the bag of a passenger, the cashier of a petrol pump in Maninagar, which had Rs 1.20 lakh cash in it.

According to police sources, Dilipsinh Vaghela, the cashier boarded Chunara’s rickshaw to go to Hatkeshwar for some work. He had Rs 1.20 lakh in his bag and the petrol pump’s account books and chequebooks.

As the rickshaw met with a minor accident, Vaghela got off but forgot his bag in the rickshaw. Chunara then went forward with another passenger but learned that Vaghela had forgotten his bag.

“He opened the bag and saw the Rs 1.20 lakh cash and bank documents. He went to the bank got the address of the petrol pump from there,” said a police official.

Meanwhile, Vaghela realized he had forgotten his bag and went to Maninagar police station, and was pleasantly surprised to see the rickshaw driver there.

Title: Centre’s Rs 100cr bounty to Cantt, boost to civic works
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Secunderabad: Civic works that have been pending in all eight civilian wards of Secunderabad Cantonment for over a year may soon get a push as the Ministry of Defence (MoD) has approved the release of Rs 100 crore grant-in-aid to the cash-starved Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB).

In each civilian ward, works worth at least Rs 2 crore to Rs 3 crore were proposed at several SCB general body meetings, however, the works have remained pending due to the SCB’s deep financial crisis.

Last June, the SCB had urged the MoD to sanction Rs 100 crore as ‘grant-in-aid’ to help it tide over the financial crisis and take up pending civic works.

“Responding to our plea, the MoD has agreed to sanction Rs 100 crore for completion of civic works in Cantonment areas,” SCB officials told TOI.

Pandu Yadav, an SCB ward member, said, “As our tenures have been extended by another six months, we have an opportunity to get pending projects completed. In ward number 6, works regarding sewerage network and laying of water pipelines and CC Roads are pending. I can complete at least a few works that need to be carried out immediately once the SCB releases the funds .”

Another ward member said that he plans to complete at least 60% of the pending works. “Residents are already complaining about drinking water problem and borewells are also drying up. I need to get 30 borewells repaired in my ward,” he said.

Veerabhadra Nath, a resident of Bowenpally, said that instead of constructing community halls, ward members must first resolve issues of poor sewerage network.

In fact, the long wait to get the state government’s share of entertainment tax and other taxes to the tune of Rs 60 crore to Rs 80 crore has been pending for over five years. “We will get a little respite if the state government takes the initiative to release these pending taxes,” said a senior official of the Secunderabad Cantonment Board.

Title: Gandhi’s ‘Gram Swaraj’ is still a dream: Writer
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Mysuru: Writer Rupa Hassan on Monday regretted the sorry state of affairs in rural India and said the ‘Gram Swaraj’ vision of Mahatma Gandhi has failed.

Speaking at the meet on Gandhian ideals hosted as part of Bahuroopi, she said villages in the country are becoming dumping ground for urban waste, where inequality and discrimination based on caste and gender are still rampant. The present economic policies have rendered farmers’ lives miserable. There was a time when farmers were self-sufficient for their daily family needs. But now they have to depend on the government and multinational companies for seeds, fertilizers, loans, subsidies and ultimately for the survival and their families, she observed.

Mahatama Gandhi had strongly believed in the development of model villages by promoting human effort-centric sustainable living and promotion of cottage industries. But this vision has not materialised even today, she rued.

“Gandhi had also dreamt of decentralization of political and economic powers. But we are seeing concentration of money and power in a few hands. He stressed on women’s safety. But unfortunately, rape and atrocities on women have become the order of the day,” she pointed out.

Despite Gandhi’s warning about the ill-effects of alcohol, the governments have been giving licence to open more and more liquor shops. Shockingly, the number of people drinking liquor is increasing at the rate of 18% every year. The government is also encouraging prostitution by distribution of condoms and contraceptives through rehabilitated prostitutes, she alleged.

Social activist Kadashettyhalli Satish was present.

Title: Jaipur: Mining body wants leases on first-come basis
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The mining industry wants the newly imposed land tax lifted

JAIPUR: For bringing in transparency and enhancing revenues for the state, the Federation of Mining Associations of Rajasthan (FMAR) has urged the state government to follow the system of ‘first come first serve’ route for granting mining leases to khatedar or its NOC holder.

In its budget recommendations to the state government, FMAR also said the newly imposed land tax on mining leases should be lifted to provide relief to the mine operators.

“The government should reconsider the process of issuing mining leases on first come first serve basis in addition to auction route. For mineral deposits in khatedari land, application route by khatedar or his registered NOC holder should be adopted which would invite better response from investors. If the application model is used, it will remove uncertainties and development will see faster implementation,” said Akshaydeep Mathur, secretary general of FAMR.

Similarly, Mathur said up to 25% of government land adjacent to or inside khatedari land should be included in the mining leases for safe and scientific mining.

The industry body urged the government to make changes in the registration fees. Currently, the fee is charged as a percentage of the DLC rate prevailing in the area. But Mathur said since mining leases do not provide ownership, the calculation of registration fee should be based on the dead rent fees.

“Till 2007, registration fees in case of new leases and transfer used to be calculated as a percentage of twice dead-rent fees. Recently, this has been changed to a percentage of 4-times of the DLC rate of the land falling inside the mining lease. Since mining leases does not award ownership, dead rent method should be followed,” Mathur said.

The land tax, which was withdrawn by the Congress government in 2013, has again been re-imposed from November 2019 on leases above 10 hectares. Mathur said land tax is detrimental to the growth of mining industry as it imposes financial hardship on the lease holder.

“Mining lease holders are already paying heavy amount to the DMF fund for betterment of the society. The federation has requested the government to withdraw the tax. Legal validity of land tax to be imposed by state governments is already under review of the SC and as such the matter is subjudice,” Mathur added.

FAMR also suggested the government to bring in a separate policy for sands and not club it with mining policy. “There is no value addition to sands like other minerals,” Mathur said.

Even though mining in Rajasthan takes place in 0.7% of the land area, it currently contributes the highest non-tax revenue to the state and provides employment opportunities, both directly and indirectly, to 30 lakh people.

Title: Man held with 1.8kg of gold at Ahmedabad airport
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The price of pure gold in Ahmedabad stood at Rs 42,200 per 10g on Monday and accordingly, the value of seized ... Read More

AHMEDABAD: A male passenger coming from Sharjah to Ahmedabad was nabbed by officials of Ahmedabad customs at Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport, in the wee hours of Sunday, for trying to smuggle in gold. Well-placed sources confirmed that 1.8kg of undeclared gold was seized from the passenger who was arrested.

The price of pure gold in Ahmedabad stood at Rs 42,200 per 10g on Monday and accordingly, the value of seized gold is estimated at Rs 75.8 lakh. “The passenger was carrying the gold in the form of a belt embedded along the waist of his trousers,” said the source.

With the increase in gold prices, gold seizures have seen a sharp rise at SVPI. In January and February, 25kg of undeclared gold was seized at the city airport in 50 cases.

Some 17 cases of gold seizures involving 8.3kg of gold were reported in January 2020 at the city airport. On the other hand, some 33 cases involving 17.5kg gold were reported in the first fortnight of February. Sixteen passengers were arrested by officials of Ahmedabad customs in the first fifteen days of February.

The value of gold seized during these two months is Rs 10.5 crore. Sources revealed that the most common modus operandi was capsules in one’s rectum. Other ways include bars concealed in false bottoms and handles of bags, in the form of belts or concealed in layers of clothing.

Most of those arrested were travelling from Dubai and Sharjah in UAE, Kuwait, Doha in Qatar and Bangkok in Thailand. “Most of those arrested are from Punjab, Rajasthan, UP, Maharashtra and Kerala, among other states of India,” said a source in Ahmedabad customs.

Title: 13 days to go, Agra univ yet to list exam centres
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: The authorities at Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University are yet to shortlist examination centres. The main examinations for 2019-20 academic session is scheduled to begin on March 2.

Earlier, the university administration had sought details on 21 parameters from affiliated colleges for determination of the exam centres. So far, the managements of a majority of the colleges have not provided the required details.

After getting details, university officials will conduct a physical verification of each of the proposed examination centre.

There are 996 colleges affiliated to Agra University. Out of these, 39 are government-aided colleges and 17 are owned by the state government. More than five lakh students are enrolled in these colleges.

According to university officials, around 300 colleges will be made examination centres. So far, only 100 colleges have provided details regarding the required parameters, including number of classrooms, availability of furniture and number of CCTV cameras and voice recorders.

University’s public relations officer GS Sharma said, “The process for determination of the examination centres has been initiated and will be completed by February-end. Examination centres will be determined after inspection of the shortlisted colleges”.

Title: 1.19 lakh students to take UP Board exams under 2,000 CCTV cameras in dist
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: As many as 1.19 lakh students will be appearing in the UP Board high school and intermediate examinations , starting on Tuesday. Students of both Class X and XII will be writing their Hindi exam, a compulsory subject, on the first day. The exams will be conducted across 158 centres under the surveillance of 2,000 CCTV cameras in Agra district .

The exams will be conducted in two shifts. The first shift will be from 8 am to 11.15 am. The second shift will be from 2 pm to 5.15 pm. The students will be allowed to enter the exam centre 30 minutes before time.

According to the secondary education department, duties have been assigned to 2,700 teachers to conduct the exam. In Agra district, 62,865 students are eligible to appear for Class X exams and 56,949 for the intermediate.

Out of the 158 exam centres in the district, 21 centres are marked “sensitive” and five “highly sensitive”. Here magistrates have been assigned duties for fair conduct of examinations. Besides, policemen will remain on duty outside all examination centres to maintain the law and order.

District inspector of schools (DIOS) Ravindra Kumar said, “Adequate arrangements have been made for fair and peaceful conduct of the board exams. A control room has been set up at the government inter college in Shahganj . The computers at the control room are connected with the CCTVs at the exam centres. Two teams have been constituted for monitoring at the control room, Besides, six flying squads will conduct spot inspections at the exam centres.”

Title: New scheme proposes water meters for all consumers
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Aurangabad: In a major development, the Aurangabad municipal commissioner stated that under the new water supply scheme, electric water meters are proposed to be installed for all water consumers. Once that is in place, the Delhi model of free water — up to a certain limit — can be implemented in the city, he said.

Incidentally, a new water supply scheme worth Rs 1,680 crore to meet the water supply needs of the city until 2051 is in the tendering process. The new scheme will have the capacity to supply 605 million litres per day (MLD) to the city.

Currently, the AMC charges household water consumers Rs 4,050 annually towards water tax. The civic body has been widely criticised for the exorbitant tax rate. According to social activist Vijay Diwan, the water tax in Aurangabad is the highest in the country — especially keeping in mind the fact that the civic body supplies water only once in 6 days.

During his interaction with the press on Monday, AMC commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey was asked about the administration’s take on reducing the water tax. Pandey agreed that the tax system is unjust. “I am of the opinion that the water tax rates should be less and that all consumers should be brought under the tax net. For the new water scheme, we have received a green signal from the state government to install water meters for all consumers. The water metering will ensure that the consumer only pays for the water used,” Pandey said.

He added that once the water meters are installed, the AMC can implement a Delhi-like system in which consumers can be supplied free water up to a certain quantity.

Around half of water consumers do not pay tax

The AMC has the data of 1.3 lakh water consumers in the city. However, there are an estimated 1.2 lakh water consumers who are currently out of the tax net. The AMC is in the process of screening the water consumer data received from the private company, which had been managing the city’s water supply for two years until September 2016. Meanwhile, in order to regularise illegal water connections, the AMC has planned to initiate a drive. The drive is yet to be implemented.

Title: Where else winged guests love to roost in Banyan City
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Vadodara: Bird watching Barodians flock to Wadhwana Lake to see the winged guests settle at the sprawling wetland in Dabhoi every winter. But only a few know that a variety of migratory birds that fly in from as far as Europe also spread around at water bodies across the city. These birds arrive in November and fly out by February every year. TOI takes a sneak peek into these local bird paradise.

Timbi Lake (Waghodia)

It is the second most frequented wetland after Wadhwana. Located 12km east of the city in Waghodia taluka, Timbi lake attracts a large number of migratory birds. Over 124 species including resident and migratory birds visit this lake every year. From black night stork to red crested pochard and greater painted snipe to tufted duck, this lake is home to many migratory species.

Kotana (Mahi River)

It is one of the serene spots where you can walk up to Mahi River and spot some beautiful birds. Kotana is an unexplored place just ahead of a popular hangout spot for youngsters – Sindhrot. One can reach river bank in Kotana through the village. From brahmini duck to mallard duck, Siberian stonechat, Eurasian curlew and northern pintail, bird enthusiasts can spot 15 to 20 species in this wetland in this village.

Jawla Lake (Savli)

Located about 30km away from the city, Jawala Lake is yet another haven for the migratory birds because of its rich flora and fauna. This water body is surrounded by lush green fields and tall grasses that are home to a variety of munia birds. From grey lag geese, black cormorants, pond heron, red munias, coots to blue rock pigeons, nearly 80 species are spotted here.

Luna (Padra)

This non-descript village in Padra taluka is home to over 100 painted storks which have made the pond in Luna their permanent home. Located about 15km from the city, the pond also hosts common coots, rosy starlings, purple moorhen to scaly breasted munia, little egret and pond heron. The locals too protect the birds in their natural habitat.

Title: Agra: 25,000 school students along route, a dozen gates to welcome US President Donald Trump
Content:
On Monday, the local discom removed loose wires on the VVIP route

Trees are being cleaned with water sprays

AGRA: With flags of India and US in both hands, 25,000 school students will be lining up to welcome the US President Donald Trump and first lady Melania Trump during their likely short trip to the city of Taj on February 24.At a dozen points on the route Presidnet Trump is likely to take, elaborately decorated welcome gates will be erected. Besides painting on the walls on both sides of the road, rangolis will be decorated at crossings. Cutouts of PM Narendra Modi and US President will also be placed on the VVIP route from Kheria airbase to the Taj Mahal.According to the sources, the district administration’s move to line up students on the route is a learning from the past. During his visit to the city in 2000, then US President Bill Clinton is believed to have called the city a “ghost town” due to extra sanitization which gave the city a deserted look.Meanwhile, a team of Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) has launched a drive to clean the Yamuna stretch behind the Taj Mahal. Over 500 kilograms of silt and other waste was removed. Trees are being cleaned with water sprays.The state horticulture department is sprucing up trees lining the road and painting the tree guards.On Monday, the local discom removed loose wires on the VVIP route. Besides repairing of road and footpaths, removal of encroachment, unauthorized hoardings is being done on a war-footing.Following orders of district magistrate Prabhu Narayan Singh, road signals on the Mall Road have been repainted and statues on the roundabouts cleaned. The exterior of the shops and houses are being whitewashed. The colour is off-white and cream to give a fresh ambience.To ensure foolproof arrangements for the possible visit of the state guests to the city of Taj, Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath is scheduled to chair a review meeting in the city on February 18. He will also inspect the VVIP route.Ahead of the CM’s inspection, AMC deployed over 200 workers for cleanliness on the VVIP route. All the garbage dumps were removed from the route and people were asked to ensure the maintenance of sanitation and hygiene.As per the tentative program, President Trump will land at the Kheria airbase at 4:15 pm. The VVIP fleet will head from the airport to the hotel Oberoi Amarvilas close to the Taj Mahal. The guests will then take a ride on battery-operated golf carts to the Taj Mahal.Trump will be the third US President to visit the Taj Mahal. Earlier, Dwight D. Eisenhower (1959) and Bill Clinton (2000) had visited the 17th-century monument of love.

Title: 56 lakh students to take Uttar Pradesh Board exams from today at over 7,000 centres
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: Over 56 lakh candidates will appear for the UP Secondary Education Board class X, XII examinations which begin on Tuesday. Almost 30 lakh class X students will be taking elementary Hindi and 26 lakh class XII students are appearing for general Hindi exam on day one. The exam is being held at 7,784 centres across the state. Both high school (class X) and intermediate (class XII) exams will end on March 6.

A total of 56.1 lakh candidates have registered for the examinations, over two lakh less than the 58.6 lakh in 2019. In class X, out of 30 lakh candidates who registered online, 20,789 would appear as private candidates. Out of 26 lakh candidates who had registered for class XII exams, 69,983 are private candidates. To crack down on copying mafia who facilitate mass cheating in UP Board exams , the UP government has set up a state-level ‘monitoring and control room’ for CCTV surveillance and to monitor voice recordings. To keep a close vigil, nearly 2 lakh CCTV cameras have been installed at 7,784 centres in 75 districts of UP. Around 2 lakh invigilators have been put on duty. Uttar Pradesh Secondary Education Board (UPSEB) has identified 938 centres as ‘sensitive’ and 395 as ‘hyper-sensitive’ which means these centres are vulnerable for cheating. Sensitive districts will use colour-coded and threaded answer-copies. The class X answer-copies will be pink and yellow and that of class XII will be green and blue. The idea is to ensure that they can’t be replaced or their pages taken out by any unauthorised person.

In a first, the UP government has launched a Twitter handle, @upboardexam2020 for immediate redressal of any kind of complaints and queries. In addition, helpline numbers for the control room — 1800 180 6607, 0522-2239198 and e-mail id: boardexam2020.up@gmail.com and toll free numbers 1800 180 5310 and 1800 180 5312 can be used to register complaints of anything related to UP Board exams.

Deputy CM Dinesh Sharma appealled to parents to not have unnecessary high expectations from their children.

Title: 4,000 UP artistes to perform during Trump’s short trip
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Agra: Nearly 4 ,000 artistes from across the state will perform at various locations in Agra to welcome US President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania Trump, who are likely to visit the Taj Mahal on February 24.

Confirming this, Agra district magistrate Prabhu N Singh said that 10 such locations have been identified between the airport and the Mughal-era monument, where the visiting dignitaries would be welcomed by artistes from various parts of the state.

A senior administrative official said that 3,800 artistes from Braj region, Bundelkhand, Purvanchal, Paschim and Avadh have been engaged to perform their traditional styles of dance and music, including Mayur, Rasiya, Saira, Dhubiya, Faruwahi etc, to welcome the visiting couple.

The locations for performances that have been finalised by the administration are Kheria crossing police chowki, Idgah bus stand crossing, ADRDE crossing, Pratappura crossing, Agra Ashok/Mehar talkies crossing, Indira Gandhi/Commissioner camp crossing, ASI crossing, Phool Sayyad crossing, Howard crossing and Trident crossing.

A five-member team from US Embassy and an Advance Team of 35 members reached Agra on Monday to take stock of the arrangements on the Kheria airport-Eastern gate of Taj Mahal route. They will stay here till the completion of US President’s visit. Besides, a five-member team of Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) will also visit Agra on Tuesday to meet local administration to discuss the arrangements and security measures.

Though the Taj Mahal is usually closed for public for two-three hours during the visit of country heads, it could be closed for almost half day for US President’s visit on February 24, said officials. However, a final decision will be taken on Tuesday after the meeting, said an ASI official.

Meanwhile, tourism fraternity have alerted their clients visiting Taj Mahal on February 24 that the movement of traffic and entry to the monument could be highly limited because of unprecedented security measures in view of Trump’s visit.

Title: Water fountain inaugurated at Alugaddabavi
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Secunderabad: A water fountain at Alugaddabavi junction at Mettuguda was inaugurated by deputy speaker of legislative assembly T Padma Rao Goud and mayor Bonthu Rammohan on Monday to mark the 66th birthday of chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao.

The Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) urban biodiversity wing developed the fountain at a cost of Rs 30 lakh. The fountain was part of beautification of major junctions in the city, which GHMC has initiated across various parts of the city.Speaking on the occasion, Padma Rao said there was a need to beautify all major junctions in the city so that more number of tourists would visit the city.

The junction area used to stink a lot due to continuous flow of nala water and has now a beautiful spot, said Eswar Reddy, a resident of Mettuguda.

The Mettuguda junction is one of the many junctions that has been chosen by the GHMC for its beautification work. Other junctions which have undergone a major transformation are Suchitra, Aramgarh and LB Nagar (towards Chintalkunta underpass).

Title: Civic chief asks contractors to sponsor dividers for new roads under CSR funds
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has decided to install road dividers through the contractors, who are undertaking Rs 100 crore cement road projects. The work will be done as a penalty on the contractors for failing to meet deadlines.

Incidentally, the concretising work of 30 city roads at the cost of Rs 100 crore was initiated in January 2019 through four contractors. As per the work order, the project should have been completed by December 31, 2019. However, this deadline was missed with roads far from completion.

According to city engineer Sakharam Panzade, the work on 20 out of 30 roads have been 100 percent completed by Monday. The work on six roads is under progress and on four roads the work has not been initiated due to various reasons.

The factors which delayed the work include the inability of the AMC to clear the encroachments, failure to shift utilities on time and other technical issues. However, in some cases, the contractors have not been able to complete the project on time in spite of no issues.

Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey on Monday stated that the contractors, who caused the delay will have to be either penalised or blacklisted for failing to meet the deadline. “As the road dividers were not covered in the road project. We are asking the contractors if they can use two percent of their CSR funds to install road dividers. Instead of the concrete road dividers, we have decided that plantation will be done in the middle of the road and this will be covered with an iron net to work as a divider,” Pandey said. The municipal commissioner said that the decision has been taken for the benefit of people.

Separate DPR for footpath and stormwater drain

Meanwhile, city engineer Sakharam Panzade said that the constructing work of footpaths and stormwater drains along with the newly constructed roads would cost more. “We are in the process of preparing a detailed project report (DPR) for the footpaths and stormwater drains. This DPR worth Rs 25 crore will be presented to the state government for its approval as the AMC is financially incapable of funding the project,” Panzade said.

Title: Numbers shrinking, Parsis appeal for preserving their legacy in city
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Members of Parsi community release a book in the city on Monday

Lucknow: Members of Parsi community in Lucknow on Monday urged the administration to free their properties of encroachments and help in its preservation.

Speaking at the book launch of ‘Bharat Ka Parsi Samaj’ by Dr Naresh Singh, president of Avadh Girls’ Degree College, Zarine Viccajee, whose family was one of the first settlers from the community in Lucknow, said: “Parsis have contributed to the country’s development and continues to do so in different fields. But the community’s strength is dwindling. Today, 40 Parsi families reside in the city as compared to 300 earlier.”

“Be it Lucknow or Delhi, we mingled with people wherever we settled. At a time when only limited number of Parsis are there to keep their heritage and culture alive in Lucknow, a few places like 73-year-old Parsi Anjuman and the graveyard need to be preserved,” she said.

“In our religion, we let the bodies of the dead decompose naturally. This is why Mumbai has the ‘Tower of Silence’. Lucknow has no such place, therefore, we go for burial,” Viccajee added.

Highlighting the history of the community, president of Lucknow Parsi Community Homi Sipai said it was Nauroji Damkewala, a trader of silk and pearls from Gujarat, who first settled in Lucknow during the times of third king of Awadh Mohammad Ali Shah.

“Gradually, a number of families started settling in the city. Most of the families stayed in the compound of Parsi Anjuman. We made Lucknow our home and embraced the city’s lifestyle,” he said. The members also expressed concern over the fact that their festivals, Navroz and Khordad Sal, were not declared public holidays.

Title: Temp soars amid forecast of torrid summer for city
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Hyderabad: Rising temperatures have paved way for an early summer in Hyderabad with maximum temperatures already touching 33-35 degree Celsius in many parts of the city.

At 33.6 degree Celsius, the maximum temperature already spiralled beyond normal temperatures on Monday for the month of February.

Sudden showers on February 10 had brought down mercury levels by nine degree Celsius to 23.4 degree Celsius. However, within a week, the maximum temperatures have returned to 33 degree Celsius, giving a teaser of what could be in store over the next few months.

According to the Telangana State Development Planning Society, Tolichowki, Quthbullapur, Lingampally, Khairtabad, Nagole and Musheerabad are a few areas which are already experiencing high temperatures of up to 35 degree Celsius. Last year, the mercury levels had touched 37.3 degree Celsius only by February 27. This year too, meteorologists expect a similar trend wherein mercury levels are only expected to rise.

“Given the prevailing weather conditions, we can say that summer has already made inroads into the city. We can expect a gradual rise of two to three degree Celsius over the next few days,” said Naga Ratna, director, India Meteorology Department (IMD), Hyderabad.

After experiencing a warm winter, meteorologists forecast that summer will be equally harsh with the maximum temperatures expected to rise further due to prevalence of southeasterly winds over Telangana.

“As the sun’s position over the globe is shifting towards the northern hemisphere day by day, conditions are favourable for further increase in temperatures. The weather is likely to remain dry over most parts of the state,” read a weather report issued by Skymet, a private weather forecasting agency.

It further added that days will be very warm while the nights will be pleasant. The sky will remain mainly clear as surface winds will be light.

Title: Cosmos Bank recovers Rs 5.73 crore moved to Hong Kong account
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A sustained follow-up by the cybercrime branch of the Pune police has led to the recovery of Rs 5.73 crore from a frozen account of a private bank in Hong Kong.

The money is part of the Rs 94.42 crore siphoned off in a sensational online heist from the city-based Cosmos Cooperative Bank in August 2018. “The money was moved to the Cosmos Bank on Monday following an order by a court in Hong Kong on Saturday,” deputy commissioner of police (cyber) Sambhaji Kadam said.

He said it was the first instalment of the Rs10 crore they were expecting to recover from the frozen account in Hong Kong. “The suspects behind the online heist had effected a Rs13.92 crore transfer to this account and further siphoned off Rs3 crore from this account before the authorities managed to freeze it,” he added.

A court in Hong Kong had ordered the account to be frozen after the Pune police and their legal team put forth their case for such action. The Hong Kong police too had assisted the Pune police in the matter following the latter’s request. Besides, officials from the Ministry of External Affairs played an important role in the follow-up.

“The Hong Kong court heard the case and directed the bank and other authorities to transfer 802,283.65 US Dollars (Rs 5.73 crore) to Cosmos Bank,” Kadam said, adding that further deliberations and follow-up action is in progress for the recovery of the remainder of the Rs10 crore in the frozen account.

Senior inspector Jayram Paygude and other cybercrime officials pursued the matter with the counterparts in Hong Kong. A legal team from the Cosmos Bank too chipped in. They had discussed matters with the authorities in Hong Kong which yielded positive results, Kadam said.

Unidentified hackers had infiltrated the Cosmos Bank’s online system to siphon off Rs 94.42 crore in two strikes on August 11 and 13, 2018. The suspects deployed two modus operandi for effecting the heist. They used a malware to hack into the bank’s server and created a parallel virtual server containing details of the bank. The virtual server then approved the fraudulent transactions.

During investigations, the police realized that 12,000 unauthorised transactions worth Rs 78 crore took place using the VISA card facility of the bank. The money was mainly transferred outside India. Also, 2,849 illegal transactions worth Rs 2.5 crore took place within India using the Rupay card facility of the bank. The money was withdrawn by agents of the fraudsters based in 21 countries, using duplicate ATM cards.

Investigations also revealed that the suspects executed three suspicious transactions using the bank’s SWIFT (Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication ) facility. Through these transactions, a sum of Rs 13.92 crore was transferred from the Cosmos Bank to the account of a trading company with its office in Hong Kong. The account of the company was with the private bank. The sum of Rs5.73 crore is part of this amount, the police said.

Paygude said the cybercrime police have so far arrested 18 people, mostly agents, who effected withdrawals using duplicate ATM cards, from Kolhapur, Mumbai, Ahmedabad, Ajmer, Indore and other cities, and cash Rs10 lakh have been recovered from them.

Title: Dr Kafeel Khan to file reply to State Advisory Board in NSA case today: Lawyer
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Dr Kafeel Khan

AGRA: Gorakhpur pediatrician Dr Kafeel Khan who was booked under National Security Act (NSA) by Aligarh police will submit his reply to UP State Advisory Board through the Mathura Jail authorities on Tuesday.

Confirming this, Khan’s lawyer, Irfan Ghazi , said though the response, as per the magistrate’s directions, has to be sent through the jail superintendent, the doctor wants to physically represent his case to the advisory board. Ghazi termed as “incorrect” Aligarh police and district authorities’ allegations that on December 12, Khan’s speech to AMU students had sparked protests on university campus. He said in the same context, there were protests by women in Shahjamal area from January 29 and the same continued till date. He said all the grounds made by the administration in support of booking Khan under NSA are baseless.

The lawyer said in his reply, Khan has said that he had given a speech on December 12 whereas the protests on AMU campus had already started on December 9. He said Khan had spent only a day on AMU campus and had returned after delivering his speech. The violence witnessed on campus had taken place on December 15, when Khan was not there and it was in reaction to the Jamia Millia Islamia incident in Delhi.

Ghazi said UP government had been indulging in a witch-hunt against Khan in retaliation for raising his voice against the negligence by government in the death of 63 children at the BRD Medical College Hospital in Gorakhpur in 2016. It may be recalled that Khan was then suspended, arrested and later released on bail. Though Khan was given a clean chit by the medical college authorities for his involvement in the death of the infants, the state government had launched a new departmental investigation against him for allegedly spreading incorrect information about the inquiry report and for making “anti-government” remarks during his suspension.

According to the FIR, in his speech, Khan had allegedly said that “CAA will make us second-grade citizens” and that “Mota Bhai” teaches us to be Hindus or Muslims. He had further said, “This fight is for our existence. We have to fight.” Khan also stated that students in RSS school are being taught that those who have beards are terrorists. He said through CAA, the government had showed that India is not “our” country.

Title: Two missing as bike falls into Narmada canal
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Rescuers searching for survivors near Bhimpura village on Monday

Vadodara: In a repeat of an incident that took place at Sisva village near the city last week, three persons on Monday morning fell in the Narmada canal near Bhimpura village on the outskirts of the city as the bike rider lost control over the vehicle.

A teenager Laxman Parmar who was sitting pillion was saved as he came out of the water with the help of his bag and then held a plant on the bank of the canal. Firemen unsuccessfully searched for the other two – Vaibhav Valand (25) and Gopal Parmar (22) – till late Monday evening. Rescuers searched for four kilometres downstream of the canal on Monday using boats.

According to 16-year-old Laxman, the trio was going to Gorwa BIDC from their native Kosindra village in Anand district. Vaibhav and Gopal work at Gorwa BIDC and daily commute on the bike. Laxman tagged along with them as the duo wanted to show him around the place where they work. Initially, Laxman had denied but when he was promised that they will return early, he agreed. Laxman told firemen that while taking sharp turn along the canal road near Bhimpura village Vaibhav lost control over the two-wheeler and the bike went straight into the canal.

Fire officials said that while holding the plant, Laxman shouted plant hearing which passers-by came to his help. Later the firemen fished out the bike but Vaibhav and Gopal were untraceable. “There are strong currents in the water due to which the two men could not be found on Monday. On Tuesday, the National Disaster Response Force will also join the search,” a fire official said.

On February 15, a sedan car had fallen in a pond at Sisva village when the driver had lost control over the vehicle at a curve on the road. One passenger sitting on the backseat was drowned and two others were rescued.

Title: Hot run-up to summer as real-feel hits 35°C
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Pune: Day temperatures have touched the season’s highest in the city and are likely to reach another high soon with the India Meteorological Department (IMD) forecasting the temperature to rise to 35ºC in the next few days.

On Monday, the day temperatures in Shivajinagar and Lohegaon were a warm 33.7ºC and 34.1ºC, respectively. These were the highest day temperatures in the 2019-2020 winter for Pune city.

It’s already feeling like summer, with the sunny afternoons pushing up the city’s “real feel” temperature to 35-plus degrees C, around one to two notches higher than the actual. With the night temperatures remaining high, the heat load over Pune has gone up significantly.

This is a stark contrast to what was witnessed during the same period last year. On February 17 in 2019, the city’s night temperature was 10.8º C. On Monday, it was a warm 16.1ºC in Shivajinagar.

A senior IMD scientist told TOI that summer-like conditions have already started prevailing in the city and parts of the state. “Slight chill is present in seven to eight districts in the state — in parts of Vidarbha and north Marathwada, north Madhya Maharashtra. But the chill factor seems to have left Konkan and almost 70% of north to central and south Madhya Maharashtra, including Pune,” he said.

“The minimum temperatures are likely to rise further in the city during the next 5-7 days. The day temperatures may touch a warm 34-35ºC during the next few days,” the official said.

The city is currently experiencing warm afternoons and nights. “Though there is a slight chance of partial northerly wind component entering north Maharashtra on February 18-19, the flow is likely to be countered by the southeasterly/southerly winds,” he said.

The northerly winds are cooler winds originating from north India, while the southeasterly/southerly winds come from the southeast and southern regions, respectively, and are relatively warmer.

“Though some northerly wind component will be trickling in from one side, the southeasterly/southerly winds will be penetrating parts of the state from the other side, resulting in their interaction. The presence of the northerly winds may not make much difference in night temperatures, which are expected to stay high in Pune district and Konkan during that time,” the scientist said.

The current day temperatures are a stark contrast from what the readings showed a few days ago, when below-30 degrees C temperatures were being witnessed in Pune. On February 9, the day temperature in Shivajinagar was a pleasant 27.4 degrees C. In Lohegaon the same day, it was 28.2º C, below normal by 3.8ºC in both the locations.

Title: IIM-Ahmedabad PGP Placements: McKinsey makes record 27 offers
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

File photo of IIM Ahmedabad

AHMEDABAD: Bucking fear of a slowdown in the global economy, McKinsey & Company, a management consultancy major, made 27 offers to IIM-Ahmedabad (IIM-A) students who were part of PGP 2020 final placements. According to IIM-A sources, this figure is the highest for the firm at IIM-A and also the highest among the top IIMs this year.

Boston Consulting Group (BCG) was second highest with 23 offers, cementing management consultancy as the top choice for IIM-A grads, in line with the trend over the past few years. Close to 400 students were placed over three days.

Other major recruiters were TCS with 12 offers, MasterCard and FinIQ with 11 offers each, Avendus and Amazon with 10 offers each, JP Morgan and AB InBev with 8 offers each, Airtel and Microsoft with 7 offers each and CK Birla Group with 6 offers to name a few. A total of 153 companies participated with 182 different roles in 20-plus cohorts.

Prof Amit Karna, chairperson of the placement committee at IIM-A, said that given the economic scenario, they were apprehensive about the results. “The outcome has not only been more positive than expected, but also better than in previous years,” he said. “With our consistent record of producing high achievers, we continued to attract several new recruiters expanding our recruiter pool considerably.”

He added that about 40% of the batch exercised the ‘dream application’ option that allowed them to sit for interviews even after having an offer from one cluster.

Title: Milind Deora’s praise for AAP sparks spat with Ajay Maken
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

NEW DELHI: Senior Congress functionaries Milind Deora and Ajay Maken were involved in a spat on Twitter after the former praised the Arvind Kejriwal-led Delhi government for doubling its revenue. Former Delhi Congress chief Maken criticised Deora for his “half-baked facts” and said he may leave the party if he wished to. This forced the party to intervene and urge its members to desist from lauding AAP .

Deora’s tweet came days after Congress faced questions from within about party seniors celebrating the AAP win. “Sharing a lesser known and welcome fact — Kejriwal-led Delhi government doubled its revenues to Rs 60,000 crore and maintained a revenue surplus over the last five years. Food for thought: Delhi is now one of India's most fiscally prudent governments,” Deora tweeted.

It invited a strong riposte from Maken who tweeted, “Brother, you want to leave Congress, please do. Then propagate half-baked facts.” He said the compound annual growth rate during Congress government in Delhi was over 14% while it was 9.9% in AAP’s tenure.

The bitter response appeared to allude to speculation about Deora looking to leave Congress, a speculation that he has already quashed in interviews.

But it did not end there as Deora got back to Maken with an equally biting counter-punch. “Brother, I would never undermine Sheila Dikshit’s stellar performance as Delhi CM. That’s your speciality. But it is never too late to change. Instead of advocating an alliance with AAP, if only you had highlighted Sheilaji’s achievements, Congress would have been in power today,” he shot back, underlining the rivalry that existed between Maken and Dikshit who passed away recently. This was also seen as a reference to Maken’s anxiety to have an alliance with AAP for last year’s Lok Sabha polls.

The nasty exchange stemmed from Deora’s praise for AAP which swept the Delhi polls in which Congress again failed to open its account. While many Congress functionaries have been celebrating that AAP defeated rival BJP in a polarised campaign, it has miffed insiders who argue that Congress members should be concerned about the party’s wipeout. As the Deora-Maken clash dominated the discourse on Monday, Congress repeated its appeal to partymen to focus on their responsibilities instead of commenting on others, which it said would strengthen the organisation.

At the same time, party spokesman Randeep Surjewala came out on the side of Maken by saying Kejriwal had done nothing great on the revenue side as tax collections in Delhi had historically been high.

He said AAP had benefited from the development work done by Dikshit government. Surjewala said sometimes in the heat of the moment, people made remarks but every such statement was not treated as an affront.

Title: Woman attacked by in-laws
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Ahmedabad: A 22-year-old woman from the Zundal area in city on Sunday filed a complaint alleging her five in-laws had beaten her when she asked about her husband.

In her FIR with Chandkheda police, the woman said that she had contacted her husband on Facebook around 18 months ago and they fell in love.

She had married the man 10 months ago, but it did not go well with her husband’s family. The woman and her husband began living at Zundal after their marriage to avoid quarrels with her husband’s family members. She stated in the FIR that she had gone to attend her ailing uncle in Radhanpur on February 10 while her husband stayed at their house in Zundal.

When she returned the next day, she did not find her husband at home and she filed an application to file complaint at Adalaj police station. She came to know on Sunday that her husband was at her in-laws’ place in Chandkheda. When she went there to inquire, her in-laws beat her and pushed her out of their house.

Title: Officials without ‘measuring books’ will be booked
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Aurangabad: Directives have been sent out to the civic department officials warning them of FIRs if they fail to produce the measurement books (MBs) while verifying bills produced by civic contractors.

A measurement book, maintained by officials of various government departments, has records of all civic projects carried out in a city. It serves as a record of cost, bills, scale of work done and payments made to procure equipment and labour. An MB is critical when approving contractor bills.

Last year, as many as 250 contractors working with the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) held a 78-day protest outside the civic body’s office to seek settlement of dues. Their strike was called off on December 19 after municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey promised that the AMC would restart payments after verification of bills submitted by the contractors.

Pandey then formed nine squads for nine zones of the city that were tasked with the verification of all civil works. But the squads soon found out that MBs of many civic works, such as road construction and water pipeline work, were missing.

The civic commissioner said FIRs would now be registered against officials who have lost the MBs.

He added that payments to contractors will not be made in cases where MBs are missing. “These officials are custodians of the MBs. And if they fail to produce the documents, we will be filing FIRs against them,” he said.

Title: No new hiring before civic polls, says commissioner
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Aurangabad: The civic administration will not be initiating any new recruitments before the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation elections.

The AMC has sent the staffing pattern proposal to the state government to increase the approved posts. In the meeting held on January 7, the general body of the AMC had scrapped the new proposal staffing pattern proposal and had asked the AMC administration to send the old proposal to the state government for its approval.

After one-and-a-half months, the municipal commissioner has signed the proposal and it has been sent to the urban development department of the state government. On Monday, municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey stated that the AMC has also sought the permission from the state government to recruit staff for the existing vacant posts.

There are 444 vacant posts in the AMC, for Classes I to III employees. Due to the lack of manpower, the civic body often fails to conduct its business properly. The staff shortage especially takes a toll during the tax recovery process. The AMC always fails to achieve its annual tax recovery target and as a result, development works are not being taken up on time. The poorly staffed water works department also requires the existing employees to work extra hours.

However, when asked if the AMC plans on hiring employees to fill the existing vacant posts, Pandey said since the elections are approaching, it will require the resources and funds of the AMC.

“Recruitment is an extensive process, which if once started, will require all our focus. So, after the elections, we will most likely get the approval of the state government of the staffing pattern proposal and then we can carry out the recruitment process,” Pandey said.

Title: Delhi: Soon, pay up to Rs 200 for garbage to be picked up
Content:
Solid waste management rules (2016) empower the local bodies to decide the user fee

NEW DELHI: Soon, residents in north Delhi may have to pay “user charges” for garbage collection . Cash-strapped North Delhi Municipal Corporation is likely to start collecting the charges from February itself.A senior official said: “Pamphlets and receipts are being printed.
