Title: Cyient opens wire harness lab in US
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Hyderabad: Homegrown global engineering and technology solutions company, Cyient Ltd, on Monday announced the opening of a wire harness lab facility in its office in Peoria Heights, Illinois.

The lab, spread over 1,100 sq ft, is equipped with pneumatic crimping tools, including an ultrasonic splicer and braider, to facilitate quality production and prototypes for electrical wire harnesses.

Besides, Cyient will also offer harness rework, testing, field installation and troubleshooting as additional services from the new facility. While the facility has been launched with a single, nine-hour shift, the company will expand operations for 24/7 support in the future, it added.

Commenting on the development, Gordon Hilbun, head of Cyient’s industrial business, said, “This is a critical addition to our portfolio and will help us offer full product life cycle support to our customers, especially for time-critical new product introduction requirements. Our new wire harness lab strengthens our electronics and electrical solution offering, addressing the demand for end-to-end support.

The facility complements the company’s design, build, and maintain approach, and adds capabilities to support customers in harness prototyping by increasing design process speed and iterative development for electrical systems, it added.

Title: Dalit shot dead by Madhya Pradesh forest staff after squabble over water
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: A Dalit was shot dead, allegedly by a forest ranger, in MP’s Shivpuri during an altercation between his family and foresters over filling of water from a hand pump on Sunday. A case has been registered against 14 forest department personnel, including a woman, under IPC and SC/ST Prevention of Atrocities Act.

The victim, 35-year-old Madan Balmiki, lived in Fatehpur village, about 55km from Shivpuri town. His family alleges that forest personnel humiliated them when they were drawing water from a tubewell near the Fatehpur outpost. It triggered an altercation during which Madan was shot dead.

The forest department, on the other hand, claims stones were thrown at them during an anti-encroachment drive and Madan was shot when some villagers were trying to snatch a gun. TI of Karera police station Rakesh Sharma said they are trying to arrest the 14 accused forest employees, who fled after the incident.

Sources say Madan’s wife and cousin were washing utensils at the hand pump near Fatehpur forest checkpost when ranger Suresh Sharma came to fill his waterbottle and a few drops of water spilled on him. He got angry and hurled casteist remarks at them, says the FIR. Madan’s wife alleges in her complaint: “My daughter ran over and told him not to abuse us. But a woman forester dragged her by the hair and slapped her. When my husband came running to intervene, he was shot dead.”

The Forest department tried to defend its personnel, claiming that Madan was shot dead as villagers tried to snatch the gun of a forest guard who was part of the anti-encroachment squad.

Shivpuri SP Rajesh Singh Chandel told TOI that there was no “caste issue” in this incident, as Madan and two of those booked in the case belong to the same community. “Madan’s father is also a forest guard. Forest employees claim they had to fire after villagers started pelting stones at them, but the family members of the deceased claim otherwise,” Chandel said.

Villagers staged a protest outside Karera police station, following which a murder case under IPC 302 was registered against seven people, including ranger Suresh Sharma. Opposition BJP and BSP targeted the government, alleging that atrocities against Dalits have risen in the past year. BSP says it will submit a memorandum to the district collector for action against the forest officials.

The MP forest department started issuing firearms to its staff in 1985. Following controversy, the forest department restricted distribution of revolvers only to rangers posted in sensitive zones, but other forest staff can be armed with .315 rifles, 12-bore guns and pump-action shotguns. Forest officials maintain they have powers of protection under Section 197 CrPC, like any government officer, while discharging their duty. They point to at a home department circular (June 11, 1996) which orders police not to initiate criminal proceedings against forest employees or officials named in FIRs, unless use of firearms is proven “unnecessary and unwarranted” in a magisterial inquiry. On Monday, the Shivpuri SP said this circular doesn’t apply in this case as there was no forest near where scene of firing.

Title: Warasia priest denied anticipatory bail
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Dr Prashant Upadhyay

Vadodara: The sessions court on Monday denied anticipatory bail to priest of Shri Baglamukhi Brahmastra Vidya Mandir in Warasia in connection with a cheating case.

Priest Dr Prashant Upadhyay, who has been accused of cheating a businessman of Rs 21.8 lakh, had moved bail application pleading innocence. Upadhyay claimed the complainant Devraj Pandya had filed a false case against him as he is a naturopath practitioner in Warasia and offers service to the temple. Upadhyay’s lawyer also questioned the timing of the complaint as the offence had taken place between 2013 and 2015. Additional public prosecutor told court that Upadhyay won’t cooperate in investigation if granted bail.

Investigating officer also submitted an affidavit in the court mentioning that prima facie evidence found against the priest which indicate that he had taken money from other people too.

Upadhyay had promised solutions to Pandya to recover from business losses and debts for which he took cash and gold worth Rs 21.8 lakh. Pandya was asked to keep a ‘yantra’ in his factory to recover from losses, but when nothing improved Pandya asked for refund of his money which the priest denied and threatened him.

Title: Rural SP orders probe in assault of woman by cops
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: A woman with physical disability was allegedly assaulted by a woman assistant inspector after the former took her deceased husband ’s body to Paithan police station , demanding immediate arrest of the person who was driving the vehicle that killed him.

The woman and her 10 relatives have also been booked by police for unlawful assembly, rioting and using criminal force to deter a government employee from performing his duty.

Assistant inspector Archana Patil, accused of assaulting the woman, justified the action. “After autopsy, instead of taking the body for last rites the woman brought it to the police station. She allegedly demanded that we should get Rs 10 lakh in compensation from the suspect and give it to her,” she said.

“The body was kept at the police station from 7pm to 1am and despite repeated requests the woman did not listen to us. At around 1 am, one of her relatives caught the collar of my constable and manhandled him following which we were compelled to use force for dispersing unruly mob,” she added.

The deceased, Arjun Rathod, was a resident of Kapusvadi village and was hit by speeding SUV on February 11 that led to his death. Following this, Rathod’s wife Devki and kin went to the police station demanding the arrest of the suspect.

The alleged use of force by the police was carried out in the wee hours of February 12, and later the family was forced to accept the body and perform the last rites. The woman went to the office of superintendent of police on Monday morning to complaint about the police inaction and injustice.

“After hours of deadlock, police the woman officer heading the police station assaulted me and my relatives. They kicked us and used batons to disperse us. This was followed by booking us under false charges.”

She said her cousin who accompanied her to the police station has also been booked. “He is preparing for competitive exams. Now, all of my relatives have turned against me and blaming me for ruining his career,” she said, adding the police are reluctant in arresting the suspect.

Meanwhile, Aurangabad rural superintendent of police Mokshada Patil said a senior officer has been asked to cross verify the version from both the sides.

“I have sought CCTV footage of the police station for personally cross verifying the allegations following which appropriate action would be taken against those guilty,” she said.

Sources informed that the SP has expressed unhappiness over the manner in which the issue was handled by the local police and has issued specific directives asking them to be more sensitive while handling such cases.

Title: Girls outdo boys in SRCC placement
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Shri Ram College of Commerce

NEW DELHI: With one of its students getting a package of Rs 31 lakh per annum, and the batch an average package of over Rs 9 lakh per annum, the first placement season for 2019-2020 went quite well for Delhi University ’s Shri Ram College of Commerce ( SRCC ). The number of students getting more than the average salary is 42 this season, compared with 19 last time.

The girl students have also done better as the ratio of placed candidates stands at 1:1.9 (boys: girls).

The first season of the placement drive at SRCC had started in August and ended in December. It saw the students getting an average package of Rs 9,40,000 per annum. The placement season is, however, still on for 2019-2020.

According to the college’s placement cell, as many as 42 students have got placed in the top category companies. Apart from finance and banking sectors, consulting has proved to be the major recruiter this year.

At Delhi University’s Daulat Ram College , another placement and internship drive saw over 1,200 students from across the university participating in it. Over 70 companies offered jobs in different sectors with CTC as high as 12 lakh rupees per annum.

Title: Is Jagjit Kaur’s family seeking asylum in India?
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Amritsar: When Pakistan’s Jagjit Kaur got married to Mohammad Hassan and changed her name to Ayesha Bibi, she almost created a religious rift with her family opposing it vehemently and local Muslims storming Gurdwara Nankana Sahib. Now, sources said Jagjit’s family is reportedly exploring possibilities of seeking asylum in India as they feel unsafe there.

According to sources, Manmohan Singh, Jagjit’s brother has approached his contacts in India to discuss a way out. “Let people say the relations between Sikhs and Muslims in Nankana Sahib are cordial. But the attack on Gurdwara Nankana Sahib by Hassan’s brothers, with the help of other Muslims, had laid bare all such tall claims. The family feels unsafe living there and wants to shift to India before it it too late,” said sources.

Jagjit and Hassan’s lawyer, Mohammad Sultan Sheikh, said on Thursday that he had heard the that Jagjit’s family was willing to take asylum in India. “But I am not sure how authentic this news is,” he added.

However, Amarjeet Singh, Jagjit’s uncle who lives in Nankana Sahib, denied that Jagjit’s family is planning to go to India. He said Hassan’s elder brother Imran, who had stormed the gurdwara, is behind bars, now so the family does not have any immediate threat.

Meanwhile, Sheikh said the forensic report of Hassan’s mobile phone was presented in the court on Thursday. The report said there was no evidence of Hassan sending obscene photographs or objectionable messages to Kaur’s family members. “The report has been submitted and the case had been adjured till Monday,” said the lawyer.

Nankana Sahib police had lodged a FIR against Jagjit’s husband Hassan on the complaint of Kaur’s brother Manmohan Singh, who had alleged that Hassan had been harassing them by sending objectionable messages.

Title: 4 dists including Trichy bag berth in TN Kabaddi Premier League
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Trichy: Four teams, including Trichy have qualified for the championship roound of the Tamil Nadu Kabaddi Premier League (TKPL) scheduled to be held in Chennai from March 27 to 29. The qualifier round in Trichy zone was held here on Saturday and Sunday.

Jointly organised by the Tamil Nadu Amateur Kabaddi Association and brand media eventz, districts across the state were classified under four zones namely Trichy, Madurai, Coimbatore and Vellore. With each zone having eight teams, qualifier matches were held to select four teams in each zone.

In Trichy zone, the qualifier matches were held at the Vestry school ground in which Thanjavur, Tiruvarur, Nagapattinam and Trichy teams qualified. “Purpose of hosting the premier league for kabaddi is to promote the talents from rural to international arena. By encouraging such players, they can even land in a good job utilising the sports quota,” S Suresh, founder of TKPL said. The top four teams of the championship event of TKPL in Chennai will be given cash prizes. While the winner will receive Rs 3 lakh, the runner-up will get Rs 2 lakh and the two semi-finalists will receive a Rs 1 lakh each. TNN

Title: Dehradun: RTO conducts surprise check, issues 100 challans
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Around 15 private vehicles were also seized during the drive that will continue on Tuesday as well

DEHRADUN: The Regional Transport Office ( RTO ) on Monday issued 100 challans under updated compounding rates of new Motor Vehicle Act during its vehicle checking drive.

Around 15 private vehicles were also seized during the drive that will continue on Tuesday as well.

Dehradun assistant regional transport officer (ARTO) Arvind Pandey told TOI that most of the challans issued on Monday were of offenses such as pillion riding without helmet, using phone while driving, and not using seat belts.

“A couple of people were also challaned for not having all required documents of the vehicle. We have also seized 15 big and small vehicles during the drive,” he said, adding that five teams of RTO officials are covering the entire city. The teams have also collectively issued 35 challans for unavailability of pollution control certificates by the vehicle owners.

Title: Sops for former CMs: Uttarakhand HC disposes PIL challenging ordinance
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The HC order came after it was informed that the ordinance has now been turned into an Act as the Uttarakhand ... Read More

NAINITAL: Uttarakhand high court ( HC ) on Monday disposed of a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) that has challenged the legality of the ordinance brought by the Uttarakhand government giving sops to former chief ministers of the state.

The HC order came after it was informed that the ordinance has now been turned into an Act as the Uttarakhand assembly ratified it during the winter session in December. “We informed the court that the ordinance brought by the government has become an Act as it has been ratified by the state assembly in December. Since the ordinance no longer exists, the HC dismissed the current petition challenging the provisions and legality of the ordinance,” said Kartikey Hari Gupta, the counsel appearing for Dehradun-based NGO, Rural Litigation and Entitlement Kendra (RLEK). The NGO has challenged the ordinance in the HC.

The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma has been hearing the PIL against the state’s ordinance. Gupta, meanwhile, added that they have already challenged the Act before the high court as well and the court has already issued notices to former CMs. “The court had ordered the state government to deliver notices to the former CMs as the earlier notices had come back as undelivered,” Gupta said, adding that the case will be heard next on February 25.

Title: Panaji: Bicholim minor boy says he had drugs, police says it was alcohol
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: A two-minute video clip, which was widely circulated through a messaging app, showed a minor boy from Bicholim claiming that he has got free drugs from his friends and subsequently got into a drug-fuelled feud which left him bleeding from the head.

In the clip, the boy states that he consumed ganja (cannabis) which was given to him for free by two other youth which some citizens say once again highlights the prevalence of drugs even in the remote areas of the state.

However, Goa police denied the role of drugs and said that the school student had consumed alcohol and met with an accident at Karaswada while going home.

The incident, which took place on Saturday, was shared via a mobile-app on Monday. Police said that the boy was on his way home after school and consumed two beers and while heading home on a bike he met with an accident at Karaswada and suffered mild injuries.

The boy was found by locals who quizzed him and handed him over to a patrol team that was passing by, police said. Police personnel took him to Mapusa police station and then shifted him to North Goa district hospital for treatment since he was bleeding. It is not known whether the boy had a fall or was beaten up by some vigilante group of boys.

Even as his injuries were being treated, the minor’s uncle came and took him home.

The incident gave Congress an opportunity to criticise the government. State Congress president Girish Chodankar said that the boy’s statements prove that drugs are widely available in the villages and in the hinterland.

“Children’s future is being destroyed because of drugs. If the chief minister does not take this seriously then we will protest outside his residence,” Chodankar said.

Title: Bihar to ‘ring’ migratory birds to track movement
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Migratory birds coming to the state will now be tagged with information regarding their origin and route taken... Read More

PATNA: Migratory birds coming to the state will now be tagged with information regarding their origin and route taken by them. The forest department will set up “ringing” stations at various bird habitats before the next winter.

Bihar will be the fourth state in the country after Tamil Nadu, Rajasthan and Orissa to initiate this process in which rings containing a satellite-enabled chip will be fitted in one of the legs of the migratory species.

Senior officials in state environment, forests and climate change department said bird ringing stations will be set up at migratory bird habitats and the rings will help in providing information of their origin, route taken as well as their weight and gender.

A memorandum of understanding (MoU) to implement the process was signed between the state forest department and the Bombay Natural History Society (BNHS) at the 13th Conference of Parties (COP) of the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory at Gandhinagar in Gujarat on Monday.

The MoU is for five years under which the state government will spend Rs5 crore on the project. The forest department principal secretary, Dipak Kumar Singh, said, “Mobile ringing stations will be set up at places like Nagi-Natki in Jamui, Kusheshwarsthan in Darbhanga, Baraila Jheel in Vaishali and Kanwar lake in Begusarai, places where migratory birds come during winter.”

The main ringing centre will be set up in Bhagalpur as the diara region attracts many migratory birds. It is also one of the three known breeding places of the Greater Adjutant in the world, apart from Assam and Cambodia.

“At the main ringing station, scientists will study the information gathered from mobile stations. Study of information gathered from the rings will help in knowing migration pattern of the birds, and if their number has decreased and reasons for the same,” Singh said.

He added, “Initially for five years, scientist from BNHA will be assisting our team and later we will do all the work on our own. Local communities and bird lovers will also be involved in such activities to take them closer to nature.”

Emphasising on the need to have such ringing stations, Dipak said, out of the 13 flyways used by migratory species across the globe, two —Central Asian Flyways and East Asian Flyways — pass through Bihar. A flyway is a geographical area within which migratory species complete their annual cycle.

Title: 11 DMs among 22 IAS officers transferred in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Amit Kumar Pandey

PATNA: In a late night reshuffle in the state bureaucracy, altogether 22 IAS officers, including 11 district magistrates, were transferred and given new assignments on Monday. Himanshu Sharma will be the new Patna Municipal corporation (PMC) commissioner, replacing Amit Kumar Pandey who has been made new DM of Siwan. Sharma was earlier posted as Kishanganj DM.

According to a notification issued by the general administration department, the DMs of Aurangabad, Khagaria, Araria, East Champaran, West Champaran, Muzaffarpur, Kishanganj, Madhubani, Nawada, Saharsa and Siwan have been transferred. In addition, three senior IAS officers have been given additional charge of different departments.

Animal and fisheries resources department principal secretary N Vijay Laxmi has been shifted to sugarcane department while mines and geology department principal secretary Harjot Kaur Bamrah has been given additional charge of animal and fisheries resource department. Similarly, agriculture department principal secretary N Sarvan Kumar will hold additional charge of animal and fisheries resource department secretary.

Pankaj Kumar Pal, secretary of food and consumer protection department, has been given additional charge of managing director of state food corporation. Additional secretary of rural works department Kawal Tanuj has been appointed Katihar DM, replacing Poonam, who has been made special secretary of agriculture department. Additional secretary in CM secretariat Chandrashekhar Singh will be the new DM of Muzaffarpur, replacing Alok Ranjan Ghosh, who has been shifted to Khagaria as its DM.

East Champaran DM Raman Kumar has been transferred and made managing director of Bihar Urban Infrastructure Development Corporation. Madhubani DM Shirshat Kapil Ashok will replace Raman Kumar. West Champaran DM D N Ramchandra will be the new DM of Madhubani. Banka DM Kundan Kumar has been transferred to West Champaran in the same capacity. While Nawada DM Kaushal Kumar goes to Saharsa, Saharsa DM Shailja Sharma will assume charge as joint director in road construction department.

Siwan DM Ranjeeta has been made labour department commissioner whereas Saran DDC Aditya Prakash will assume charge as DM of Kishanganj. Kishanganj DDC Yashpal Meena has been made Nawada DM. Patna DDC Shuharsh Bhagat will join as Banka DM. Biharsharif town commissioner Saurabh Jorwal has been made Aurangabad DM, replacing Rahul Ranjan Mahiwal, who has been shifted to rural works department and made special secretary.

Khagaria DM Anirudh Kumar has been transferred and made special secretary in home department while Araria DM Baidyanath goes to health department as additional secretary. Labour department director Dharmendra Singh will join as director of fisheries. State food corporation managing director Animesh Kumar Parashar goes to additional secretary of art, culture and youth affairs.

Munger DDC Prashant Kumar C H has been made DM of Araria while Purnia DDC Aman Samir will be the new DM of Buxar.

Title: Rabid dog bites 20 in Limdi town
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

CCTV grab of the dog attacking a man in Limdi village of Dahod on Monday

Vadodara: A stray dog went on a spree to bite pedestrians and other commuters in the busy marketplace in Limdi town in Dahod district on Monday. The local administration has begun efforts to capture the dog that may be rabid.

Sources said that the dog started biting people in the morning and it is believed that it attacked around 20 persons. The reason for such behaviour of the canine is believed to be rabies, but this has not been confirmed yet.

Those bitten by the dog were taken to the government hospital in Limdi for treatment and vaccination. The dog will also be taken to a veterinary hospital after it is rescued, sources said.

The incidents of dog bites were recorded on CCTV cameras located in the busy street. The dog, however, became evasive when attempts were made to capture it. The local administration also did not have expert teams to handle the canine.

Title: Women in rural Odisha earn nearly 3 times less than men: Eco survey
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Bhubaneswar: There’s a yawning gap between the average wages of men and women in Odisha with rural women earning on an average Rs 7,477 less than their male counterparts, while for urban women the pay gap is less at Rs 6,763, according to the Economic Survey Report 2018-19 released here on Monday.

There’s a nearly three-fold gap between the average earnings of a male and a female salaried employee in rural Odisha, with the man earning Rs 11, 503 as against a woman’s average salary of R 4,026. Similarly in urban areas, a male employee gets an average salary of Rs 19,623 while the average salary of a female employee is Rs 12,860 with a gender pay gap of Rs 6,763.

For casual workers, too, there is wage disparity between male and female workers. However, the wage gap is higher in urban areas as compared to rural areas, the report said. The situation is equally bad in the unorganized sector, especially in agriculture and other labour-intensive sectors where women continue to get paid significantly less than men. The average per day wage of a causal labourer (other than public works) for men is Rs 244.71 per day against Rs 160.77 per day for women in rural areas.

Similarly, in urban areas the average per day wage for men is Rs 265.94 against Rs 178.48 per day for women. The gender pay gap in unorganised sector in urban and rural areas is Rs 87.46 and Rs 83.94 per day in the state. “The disparity begins from childhood when not many girls are allowed to go to school. Very few of them continue higher education and lesser number get skill training. Women are not considered as a skilled workforce. If they join the workforce they have to take leave for maternity, childcare and health of family members. Unlike men they have to work both at home and at workplace affecting their performance,” said women’s rights activist Prajna Bastia.

The high gender pay gap is also affected by lower labour force participation rate (LFPR) of women in the state. The LFPR for men and women in Odisha is 84.1 and 21.6 respectively against the national average of 80.2 and 25.3. Financial independence being one of the key strands for gender equality and women’s empowerment, there is a considerable gap in access to finance for women. Of the total bank deposits, 60.3% bank accounts are owned by men compared to 28.9% by women and remaining by non-individuals. Amounts deposited by men are more than double that of women, the report pointed out.

Activist Namrata Chadha said, “Neither women’s rights activists nor policy makers have ever focused on economic empowerment of women.” She added, “Women’s issues are confined to either domestic violence or formation of self-help groups. The issue equal work for equal pay for men and women has never been raised in a proper forum, so the gender pay gap is widening.”

Title: Mindless waste dumping near anganwadi puts children at risk
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Trichy: Indiscriminate dumping of waste near an anganwadi centre on Pakkali street in Bhima Nagar has become a health hazard for the students and teachers. Citing heaps of garbage including animal waste and dead rodents at the entrance of the anganwadi, parents are hesitating to send their children here.

There were 100 students in the centre last year, but the strength has now come down to 60. Teachers attribute the decline to the garbage mound. According to residents, since waste collection by the corporation is irregular in Bhima Nagar and adjoining localities, waste is dumped outside the anganwadi centre. While bins in all parts of the city were removed, a tank-like garbage bin constructed with brick and mortar near the anganwadi is among the last few standing bins in the city, thus attracting tonnes of waste each day.

“Since corporation’s vehicles arrive to collect waste only once in 10 days, people dump garbage in the bin near the anganwadi. Preying on the food and animal waste, a pack of stray dogs often loiter near the anganwadi,” said K Janardhanan, a resident of Bhima Nagar.

Teachers at the anganwadi claimed that the garbage attracts rodents, flies and mosquitoes. Waste including from beef and chicken stalls in Alwarthope also heads here.

When contacted, corporation officials said that waste collection was regular in Bhima Nagar. “A proposal is on the cards to redevelop the road in Pakkali street. While relaying the road, the bin where waste is dumped will be demolished,” the source said.

Title: Rajasthan to Centre: Give ₹200 crore for locust menace
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The central team members meeting

JAIPUR: The state government has sought Rs 200-crore compensation from the Centre for the locust menace . A four-member central team reached here on Monday and held a meeting with state government and agriculture and disaster management officials. The team will visit locust affected districts in the state from Tuesday. The state government briefed the team about the measures taken by them and also requested for an early assistance. The team will visit and assess the locust-hit districts of Jodhpur and Bikaner divisions. At a meeting chaired by chief secretary DB Gupta was held at the secretariat on Monday. Gupta informed the team about the damage to crops in the locust-hit districts. “A joint team of patwari, tehsildar, subdivision officers and officers of agriculture department in various districts were on duty to facilitate the farmers,” Gupta told the team. Information about efforts made by the teams for containment of locusts were also shared. On February 18, the central team will meet public representatives in Jodhpur, Jaisalmer , Jalore and Barmer. The team will also hold discussions with district collectors and representatives of Jodhpur, Barmer, Bikaner and other districts. The team comprising Aatish Chandra, joint secretary department of agriculture cooperation, Santosh R, assistant adviser (PHED) and Manash Choudhary , joint advisor, Niti Aayog. It may be recalled that the state has witnessed the biggest ever locust attack in which almost 3.71 lakh hectares was damaged by locusts since May 2019. in some districts, the state government has already completed the crop assessment and distributed ex-gratia.

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: 406 from Wuhan start leaving ITBP facility in Delhi, but to stay isolated at home
Content:
A total of 406 people were kept at the Indo Tibetan Border Police facility in Chhawla area (ANI photo)

NEW DELHI: The ordeal of the 406 evacuees from Wuhan is not completely over as yet. While all of them, quarantined at an ITBP facility in Delhi, tested negative for novel coronavirus and is being discharged in a phased manner starting Monday, they will be kept in home quarantine for another 14 days given the uncertainty about the incubation period of the virus, an official said.“These people will be regularly monitored and their health parameters will be charted by state health agencies with the help of local health authorities and nearby hospitals to ensure there is no infection,” Dr A P Joshi, chief medical officer at Indo Tibetan Border Police (ITBP) told TOI.A batch of 200 people, including seven Maldivian nationals, who were among 406 quarantined at ITBP’s Chhawla Camp after being evacuated earlier this month from coronavirus-hit Wuhan, were discharged on Monday.“The rest will be sent on Tuesday and in the subsequent days as per the travel plans of the inmates,” the official said.Health minister Harsh Vardhan also visited the facility in Chhawla and interacted with the evacuees on Monday.Vardhan briefed the evacuees about the steps taken by the government to combat the virus and the precautions to be taken in this context.The minister also took a quick review of the measures taken over the last fortnight from the doctors supervising the campus. Vardhan also handed out the discharged evacuees a rose and a packet containing the annual ITBP calendar each as a token of remembrance.The evacuees thanked the government, medical staff and ITBP personnel for ensuring proper food, hygiene, hot water, indoor games and entertainment at the facility for them.A total of 650 people were brought back from Wuhan in China on February 1 and 2 in two 747 Boeing Air India aircraft after the outbreak of the novel coronavirus in China.While 406 of these were sent to the ITBP facility, the rest were quarantined at an Army centre in Haryana's Manesar.

Title: Locals oppose STP scheme, corpn firm on executing it
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Trichy: Residents of Keelakalkandar Kottai have raised objection to the Trichy Corporation’s proposal to construct a sewage treatment plant (STP) in the area as they fear that it would affect the quality of groundwater and agriculture. However, the corporation has said that it will implement the project as the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) has given the green signal.

The STP at Keelakalkandar Kottai was proposed as part of the package III of Phase II of the underground drainage (UGD) project under AMRUT scheme funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). As per plan, the STP would treat wastewater from five wards which would be collected through a proposed underground drainage system. The wastewater will be retreated using the modern sequential batch reactor (SBR) technology and let into the Uyyakondan canal.

“Keelakalkandar Kottai is a fertile agrarian area. Proposing an STP here is a bad choice. We are not against the STP, it can be relocated to a barren site,” J Mathivanan, a resident said.

The corporation said that land at Keelakalkandar Kottai was availed from the revenue department and the civic body has constructed an alternative threshing platform for the farmers as the existing one will be utilized for the STP. Undeterred by the opposition, corporation rallying with clearances from the district administration and TNPCB said the civil work will commence soon. “We are following the proper code of practice to construct the STP. The wastewater will be processed and treated at the STP as per safety standards and there is no chance for ground or water contamination,” an official said. The civic body added that the proposed site will not be relocated.

Title: 17.9% rise in rape cases in 2019, minister tells house
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Amid nationwide concern over the safety of women, Odisha registered 17.9% rise in rape cases in 2019 compared to 2018, according to a written reply by minister of state for home Dibya Shankar Mishra in the assembly here on Monday.

Mishra, while replying to a question from BJD’s Satyabadi MLA Umakant Samantray, said 2,950 rape cases were registered in 2019.

Police registered 2,502 rape cases in 2018, Mishra’s reply stated.

Police sources said most of the rape offences were unpreventable as the accused were close acquaintances of the survivors. “We found that at least 92% of the rape survivors were known to the accused. The accused included friends, relatives and neighbours of the survivors,” a senior police officer said.

The officer said police promptly took action after receiving the complaints. “We would have been blamed had we suppressed such complaints. Post-Nirbhaya incident, registration of cases relating to crime against women increased across the country. Women, who some years ago were reluctant to report the matters to police, have now shown courage and approached police. We have made prompt arrests and filed chargesheets in time. Efforts are being made to improve the conviction rate,” the officer said.

Data shared by Mishra in the assembly also showed increase in some other forms of crime against women.

Molestation cases increased to 6,848 in 2019 as against 5,875 in 2018. Incidents of stalking of women rose to 351 in 2019 from 281 cases reported in 2018. Trafficking of women increased alarmingly by 129 % in the state last year. While 51 women were trafficked in 2018, the number went up to 117 in 2019. Kidnapping of women also shot up to 4,089 cases in 2019 from 3,424 cases in 2018.

Bhubaneswar witnessed nearly 14% rise in overall registration of criminal cases last year compared to 2018.

While 7,219 criminal cases were registered in Bhubaneswar in 2018, the figure went up to 8,229 in 2019. Bhubaneswar witnessed rise in rapes, dacoities, thefts, stalkings, eve-teasing and abduction of women last year.

Title: Sanitation workers seek regular jobs
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Sanitation workers protesting outside VMC office in Khanderao Market

Vadodara: Sanitation workers of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) held demonstrations at the Khanderao Market headquarters of the civic body demanding that they should be given regular appointments. The workers stayed put in the compound outside the office till late on Monday night.

A large majority of sanitation workers of the civic body are on temporary employment. These include those on 11-month contracts and those being paid based on the days of work allocated to them.

Sanitation workers have been demanding since several years that they should be given regular employment. The VMC has been dodging the issue and has been making promises to consider their demands without any concrete steps being taken.

The top brass of the VMC officials met the representatives of the workers late in the evening. The civic body sought time of a month to resolve the issue. Not in a mood to take any more promises, the sanitation workers turned down the offer. They said that they had given enough time regarding their demands and wanted the VMC to come up with a circular for employment of workers.

With the talks reaching a stalemate, the representatives declared that they would continue the protest in the night too.

Title: Trichy: Man dies of renal failure after return from China
Content:
Representative Image

TRICHY: The death of a 43-year-old man at a Madurai hospital on Friday, a few days after his return from China, triggered panic among people in Pudukottai district . However, the district administration confirmed that he tested negative for coronavirus and the cause of death was kidney ailment.The deceased, identified as S Sakthi Kumar from Aranthangi in Pudukottai district, was working as a cook in China. He was also operating as an agent to recruit labourers from Pudukottai in China.He landed in Trichy airport on February 4 and went to his home at Avudaiyarkoil. He is said to have misled health officials at Aranthangi when they contacted him over phone. “Sakthi Kumar was hesitant to undergo medical examination and misled us by saying that he is at Avudaiyarkoil. We alerted health officials in Nilgiris but he could not be traced by them,” said Kalaivani, deputy director of health services (DDHS), Aranthangi. Kumar was a relative of one of the health officials and we could trace him at Avudaiyarkoil. Though he tested negative for coronavirus, we asked him to remain in his village, she said.“On Friday, Kumar died of kidney ailment at a private hospital in Madurai for which he was undergoing treatment for quite some time,” said P Uma Maheswari, Pudukottai district collector.Confirming that he tested negative for coronavirus and it was an accident a few months ago that had complicated his health condition, she said Kumar died after developing complications at the hospital in Madurai.Asked whether his name was missed from the list of people who had returned recently from China, she said the district administration receives the list of people returning from China on a daily basis. While there is no chance of missing anybody, in the case of Kumar, he was absconding for a few days, she said.

Title: No National Population Register updation in state says Madhya Pradesh CM Kamal Nath
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Madhya Pradesh CM Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: The Congress-led government in Madhya Pradesh will not carry out the proposed National Population Register (NPR) update exercise, chief minister Kamal Nath said on Monday evening.

“The NPR notification, about which talks were going on, was issued on December 9, 2019. After this, the Centre has decided to implement Citizen (Amendment) Act. It means the NPR notified by the government is not the one under CAA 2019, but as per provisions of CAA- 1955s, 2003s rule 3. Despite this, NPR will not be implemented in the state,” said Nath.

The Nath cabinet has already passed a resolution against CAA.

Earlier in the day, Congress MLA from Bhopal, Arif Masood, had warned of protests if the government decides to undertake NPR update. Soon after this, law minister P C Sharma said there will be no updation of NPR in Madhya Pradesh. “There is no move at present to undertake the proposed NPR update exercise in the state. The government is not going to implement it,” he said.

NPR is scheduled to be carried out along with the house-listing phase of the Census exercise from April 1 to September 30. The Census Commission has said the objective of NPR is to create a comprehensive identity database of every ‘usual resident’ of the country.

Title: Three idols stolen from temple in Nagai
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nagapattinam: Three idols were stolen from a temple in Kondal village near Sirkazhi in Nagapattinam district on Sunday night. Police have registered a case.

According to police, the theft of the three idols - Subramaniyar, Valli and Theivanai - from the Kumara Subramaniya Swami Temple in Kondal village, was noticed when temple priest Babu alias Natarajan, 55, arrived at the temple in the morning on Monday to perform puja. He immediately alerted temple trustee Rajarajan, who informed Sirkazhi police.

Sirkazhi DSP Vandhana and inspector Manimaran conducted an enquiry. Forensic experts and a sniffer dog were pressed into service. Though CCTV cameras were installed at the temple, they were defunct, police said.

“Miscreants used duplicate keys to open the front door of the temple. So, it seems like a well-planned theft executed by known people,” police added.

During interrogation, the temple trustee said that they have been maintaining the temple for more than 100 years. However, he was not sure whether the idols stolen by the miscreants were panchaloha or copper or any other metals. His forefathers had told that the idols were made of panchaloha, police said.

Sirkazhi police have registered a case.

Title: Delhi Airport: IGI up to 7th spot in terms of seats offered
Content: MUMBAI: Delhi emerged as the seventh largest airport in the world in terms of seat capacity with 3 million seats offered on departing flights in February, a growth of 14% compared with February 2019, says the latest data from UK-based OAG.Delhi airport had the second largest growth in seat capacity globally this month as airports like Beijing, Shanghai Pudong saw a sharp decline in seats offered due to the coronavirus impact. Without this, the airport wouldn’t have made it to the top 10 this month, because if data for the past 12 months leading up to February 2020 is considered, Delhi airport stands at number 16 globally with just 41 million seats.The Airports Council International in its traffic report in September 2019 had put Delhi at number 12 for handling 69.9 million passengers in 2018. According to OAG data, the number of seats offered by Delhi airport grew by a modest 1.9% in the past 12 months as compared to the year before.The coronavirus impact also made UAE-India the 6th largest “country pair” in the world in February 2020 with 1.78 million seats flown between the two countries at the expense of country-pairs like China-Thailand, Japan-South Korea that saw huge declines. India-UAE is 10th largest with 21 million seats when it comes to the past 12 months. The top country pair for February was Mexico-US with 3 million seats, while the top country pair for the past one year was Spain-UK.The fastest growing country pair in the past 12 months was China-Japan with a growth of 38%, and in February 2020, it was South Korea-Vietnam with a 36% increase as carriers added nearly 300,000 seats, said OAG data.IndiGo emerged the eight largest airline in the world in terms of number of flights operated; American Airlines came out on top with 2.3 million flights. Up to February 2020, IndiGo operated 5.3 lakh flights in the last 12 months, making its 20% growth the fastest in the world.

Title: Sursagar lake filled with water, activists see red
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The pond was emptied for rejuvenation and beautification

Vadodara: The Sursagar has water again as the day of its inauguration nears. And seeing red over the blue water is the green brigade in the city that has called it a waste of a precious resource.

The pond was emptied for the rejuvenation and beautification work and only a small quantity of water was left in the Sursagar pond to ensure that the aquatic animals in it did not die. As the work neared completion, the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) started pumping water into the pond.

Pipes and tubes carrying water to the pond were seen on the embankment of the pond till recently. Those worried over the step even recorded the process of water being released into the on their mobile phones.

Environmentalist Rohit Prajapati said that the water from the pond was emptied earlier to facilitate work. “It is now being filled with water again. Why is the VMC doing so secretively? It even did not declare its intentions of filling the pond in such a way,” said Prajapati.

Prajapati said that the pond had been narrowed down for renovation and even raised doubts regarding the functioning of inlets that brought water to the pond during monsoon. “There have been clear violations of the high court directives regarding the conservation of water bodies,” he said.

A top VMC official admitted that water had been pumped into the pond. “The renovation and beautification would have made no sense without water in the pond,” he said. A source added that the pond had not been filled completely.

Title: For many kids, straight is boring
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Chennai: When the parents of two students insisted on meeting school counsellor *Sujatha, she thought it had something to do with their grades. But she soon found herself out of her depth. Both sets of parents were worried as their daughters had boasted to their classmates that they were bisexual .

“It had become a topic of discussion in school, and the gossip finally reached the parents. I spoke to the girls and they said they are equally attracted to both the sexes and were not ashamed to disclose it to their classmates,” says Sujatha. “I referred them to a psychologist as I felt I wasn’t qualified to handle the situation.”

Being gay , lesbian or bisexual wasn’t something that was spoken about openly, especially at school. But, of late, a few schools in Chennai have seen instances where children have disclosed to their classmates that they are homosexual or bisexual, a claim which they are not sure is true or not. And activists and healthcare professionals feel that while such disclosures shouldn’t be dismissed lightly, and need to be dealt with sensitively, sometimes it may be a bid to get attention or a need to be seen as “cool”.

“Some of them may be bisexual but there are those who do it to get attention. When somebody realises he/ she is bisexual, it is not some kind of jolly erotic trip; it takes the person some time to process it in their mind and understand the pros and cons,” says psychiatrist N Rangarajan.

During the course of an individual’s sexual development, there is a stage when many things, including same sex contact, can be sexually attractive. “But that doesn’t mean that the person is homosexual or bisexual. It’s all part and parcel of the development of one’s sexuality,” he says, adding that concerned parents do bring in children who are confused about their sexual orientation. “While some parents are accepting and want to help, others come down heavily on their children and don’t let them express their sexuality. In such cases, the children are usually brought in as their academic performance is dipping and only when we talk to them they disclose the sexual issues that are bothering them.”

Sexologist Dr Narayana Reddy agrees, saying that when children attain puberty, they are likely to experiment. “They may have same sex experiences but it’s not the same as being homosexual or bisexual,” he says.

Male fantasies related to porn could be another reason why young girls claim to be bisexual, says L Ramakrishnan of SAATHII, a health and human rights NGO. “It may not be seen as cool to be lesbian, gay, transgender or a bisexual man. But, being a bisexual woman may be considered cool partly because of the influence of pornography developed for straight men as a lot of them have sexual scenes between two or more women,” he says.

“The idea that women together is considered a turn-on for straight guys could be one of the reasons why young women say they are bisexual as it would get the attention of straight guys or increase their desirability factor,” says Ramakrishnan. “But, though I say this, I would not want to dismiss somebody’s identity.”

Dr Reddy feels that in the present climate, there is more societal acceptance of different sexual orientations. “Many celebrities are coming out in the open and there are also more movies dealing with such subjects, which may make children think it is cool,” he says.

However, experts say that to really understand what your child is really dealing with, parents have to wait and watch, and be accepting before rushing to a professional for help. “You have to watchful and see whether your child feels the same way or not. If you feel he/ she needs help, then you should approach a counsellor or psychologist,” says Dr Reddy.*Name changed

Title: Team that evacuated 647 Indians earns PM Modi’s praise
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

NEW DELHI: Six doctors and four nurses, who were part of the team that evacuated 647 Indian citizens and seven Maldivian citizens from Wuhan in China, were handed over letters of appreciation written by Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Monday.

The PM lauded the efforts of the medical team and Air India crew, saying the rescue operation has reassured the Indian diaspora across the world that the entire nation will stand by them in times of crisis. “Strength during adversity gets expression in the collective effort of Air India personnel and the medical team from Safdarjung and Ram Manohar Lohia hospitals,” he said.

The letters of appreciation were handed over to the medical team individually by union health minister Harsh Vardhan. He congratulated each and every member of the team, which had gone to Wuhan on February 1 and 2 in two batches.

The health minister also met the Indians evacuated from Wuhan at an ITBP quarantine facility, as the first batch of nearly 200 of them left for their respective homes. They have all tested negative for coronavirus, the minister said. Dr Sanjeet Panesar, assistant professor in the department of community medicine at RML hospital, told TOI he was pleasantly surprised to receive words of appreciation by the PM directly.

Dr Pulin Gupta, another doctor from RML hospital, said that his mother was the first one to support him to go to Wuhan. “She told me someone has to do the job of rescuing Indian students stuck there and I must accept this challenge,” he added.

Title: Restaurant sealed amidst ruckus in Mama Ni Pol
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The restaurant that was sealed

Vadodara: High drama ensued in the Mama Ni Pole in the Raopura on Monday morning when Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) teams reached there to seal a restaurant. The owner of the restaurant and an aide entered into a confrontation with the team and had to be detained by police.

The incident took place when officials tried to seal a Kathiyawadi food restaurant in the locality. The restaurant was operating in violation of rules from a space categorised as a residential building. VMC had received a series of complaints against the restaurant .

When VMC officials reached the site with security, the owner and his aide became aggressive and alleged that the restaurant was being sealed at the behest of the mayor, a charge that mayor Dr Jigeesha Sheth denied.

The VMC team called the police that took away the owner and his aide. The restaurant was sealed after the duo was taken away.

Title: US citizen alleges police apathy after bike-borne snatchers flee with bag
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The bag of an American national was snatched from her lap by two bike-borne assailants when she was returning home in an auto-rickshaw near Kailash Hills in south Delhi late on Saturday night.

McKenna Parker (25), who works as a Clinton fellow with the American India foundation, alleged that officers at Amar Colony police station did not register an FIR though she gave a complaint. Later, she registered an online FIR of theft.

“They received my complaint and stamped it. I called the officer later who asked me to wait but did not get back. On Monday, I filed the online FIR,” Parker said.

RP Meena, DCP (southeast), said “Parker had to leave for Lucknow. All efforts are being made to nab the accused.”

On Saturday, Parker — who stayed at Kailash Hills — had gone out with her friend to Hauz Khas Village. On way back she booked an auto through a cab aggregator. She dropped her friend at Sant Nagar and continued in the same auto. Speaking to TOI she said, “Around 11.30pm, my bag — which was kept on my lap — was snatched by two people who came on a black motorcycle. I was not able to note down the number as they sped away. My auto driver slowed down and tried to talk to another auto driver at the next intersection.”

Parker said that they tried to follow the bikers till Captain Gaur marg, but they fled. She said her bag contained many items, including her camera equipment worth $7,000 and mobile phone.

Title: Call to fall in line: APSERMC to release list of errant schools soon
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

VIJAYAWADA: In a strong pro-student move, the Andhra Pradesh government has decided to cancel licences of schools found violating set norms. The Andhra Pradesh School Education Regulatory and Monitoring Commission ( APSERMC ), which has inspecting corporate schools and junior colleges across the state, will soon release the list of errant schools.

APSERMC chairman Justice Kantha Rao in a press conference here on Monday said corporate schools across the state are playing with the future of the children. “We have inspected the schools, which are collecting exorbitant fees from students. Most of the corporate schools do not meet teaching standards. A majority of schools are using stressful teaching methods, including pressurising students. We will soon release the list of the schools which are not following rules,” he said.

Pointing out the importance of physical activity in the overall development of the children, Rao said, “A majority of corporate schools are continuing their operations from concrete buildings. We have come to know that many schools are operating from commercial complexes and apartments. Every school should have a playground and we will soon issue notices to schools without playgrounds. These schools should relocate their campuses within the notice period, or else their recognition will be cancelled.”

Commission vice-chairperson Sarada Reddy, who was present on the occasion said, the school managements are neglecting the health of children. “Students complained about the poor quality of the food supplied in residential campuses. Many schools are not allowing students to drink water to prevent them from visiting toilets frequently. This is a serious offence and we will initiate stringent action against such schools,” she said.

Speaking on similar lines, Aluri Sambasiva Reddy, secretary of APSERMC, said several schools have been employing underqualified teachers. “ We observed that multiple teachers were dealing with a single subject in schools. This will confuse the students and affect their concentration level. The positive approach of teachers will help students in their studies and our government will frame rules to ensure this in private schools,” he said.

Title: Trichy: Panchayat work gets delayed due to issues in online payment system
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Village panchayat presidents from Trichy submitted a petition to Trichy collector S Sivarasu demanding that th... Read More

TRICHY: The federation of village panchayat in Trichy has urged the district administration to speed up the process of online payment system, implemented to pay for the work to be done in village panchayats. Many elected representatives are unfamiliar with the online payment system, which has developed some technical glitches as well. This is delaying basic amenities to the villagers, the federation said.

A group of village panchayat presidents, vice-presidents of village panchayats submitted a petition to Trichy collector S Sivarasu on Monday stating that they were unable to cope with the online payment system that has been introduced instead of bank cheques for all the expenses in the village panchayat.

The new local body representatives were stripped of their power of signing cheques and were authorised to spend the government fund for public purpose through an online banking system. The presidents and vice-presidents had the power to sign cheques till October 24, 2016.

As per the new system, the president and vice-president should issue a note with their signatures to the payee who can submit the note in the bank and get the money transferred to their account. The payee can be a company, a contractor or any individual.

The presidents of village panchayats said they were unable to transfer the payment to the contractors, suppliers and workers towards their work on drinking water supply, repair works, street lights, drainage and sewage cleaning etc.

“We are not opposing the online payment system and we don’t demand to bring back the cheque signing power also. As soon as the presidents take charge, they would like to do some work on the basic amenities but they can’t do now because they are unable to operate the new system for the past 45 days. We appeal to the officials to set things right in a day or two,” said Andhanallur union chairman S Durairaj who led the federation.

An official in the assistant director of village panchayats, Trichy, on condition of anonymity attributed technical glitches in the internet to the delay in the online system. “It is a usual hiccup in any new system. Things will be sorted out in a day or two,” he said.

Title: Sand mining: 2 booked for criminal intimidation of VAO at Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

TRICHY: Manapparai police registered a case against two people on charges of criminal intimidation of a village administrative officer near Manapparai on Monday.

Police filed case against R Bhuvaneswaran of Poigaipatti and an unidentified man for threatening J Karuppaiah, 40, VAO of Poigaipatti village, when the latter objected to the illegal sand mining of the two in a field at Thoppampatti hamlet on Sunday afternoon. The two were also accused of preventing the government officer from discharging his duties.

According to the complaint of Karuppiah, he and his assistant were on an inspection at the spot on a tip-off about sand mining. Bhuvaneswaran and the other man were mining sand using an earth mover and a tipper lorry. As the VAO and the officer asked them to stop the mining, the tipper driver fled the scene whereas Bhuvaneswaran, who was operating the earth mover, frightened them by moving the vehicle towards them.

Karuppaiah said that they moved to the other side quickly to escape from the hit. Based on his complaint, the police registered a case. Manpparai inspector Kannadasan said that the accused are absconding.

Title: Trichy: Collector launches mobile app for self-help groups
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

District collector S Sivarasu launching Thirumathi Kart, an e-commerce mobile application for self-help groups

TRICHY: District collector S Sivarasu on Monday launched Thirumathi Kart, an e-commerce mobile application for self-help groups (SHG) to promote their products. The main aim of this application is to link the customers with SHGs, which will eventually empower women with an imperishable income.

The app was developed by the computer science department at National Institute of Technology (NIT) Trichy. The department of science and technology (DST) sponsored the project.

M Brindha of the computer science department and her team developed three customized mobile application namely - Thirumathi kart , Thirumathi kart (seller) and Thirumathi kart (logistics), which is a cloud-based mobile application for the self-promotion of products developed by SHGs.

Sivarasu appealed to the SHG members to make use of the app. He also thanked NIT Trichy for addressing many social problems. He also quoted the current scenario of online purchase and its need.

NIT Trichy director Mini Shaji Thomas said Thirumathi Kart is a bridge between SHGs and the customer. She said that this app should be extended to other districts for the welfare of SHGs.

In connection with this, NIT-T organized a five-day executive development programme titled-- Marketing Strategies in the Digital Era: Self Promotion of SHG Products through Thirumathi kart. This programme included an inauguration ceremony of the android applications and awareness talks with the SHG members.

The project director of Mahalir Thittam, Trichy, N Saravanan shared his experience about the current marketing strategies for SHGs.

Title: Nirbhaya Case: Hope it’s the last death warrant, says Nirbhaya's mother
Content:
Nirbhaya's mother

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

NEW DELHI: “Ye teesra death warrant hain, umeed hai ki final ho (this is the third death warrant, I hope this is the final one),” said Nirbhaya ’s mother, Asha Devi , after a Delhi court fixed March 3 as the execution date for the four men convicted in the gang rape and murder case.Her reaction on Monday was different from what it was after the death warrant was issued for the first time. “I was very happy when the death warrant was issued for the first time, then it got postponed. Later on again their was a stay as the legal remedies available to the convicts were pending. Somewhere down the line my faith got shaken. Now when another date has been announced, there’s a new ray of hope and I hope this is the final warrant,” she said.Referring to her family’s seven-year struggle for justice, Asha Devi said they had tried to ensure that “the case reaches its logical conclusion. During these years, we have been challenged multiple times; from some comments it seemed as if I am a criminal”.One of the convicts, Pawan Gupta, is yet to file his mercy and curative petitions. “The court has given them time earlier as well, which is now over. The jail authorities had also informed them about their rights,” said Asha Devi.The fact that the juvenile who was the most brutal is roaming freely has left a permanent scar in her heart, said the mother. “The law was changed but the case happened earlier. I couldn’t find a way to continue my fight against him,” she rued.In Video: Hope our struggle will end on March 3: Nirbhaya's mother

Title: Odisha has lowest slum population in the country
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

BHUBANESWAR: The Odisha Economic Survey, 2019-20, has pointed out that Odisha has the lowest 3.72% slum population (people living in slums of the total state population) in the country. The survey covered both urban and rural slums.

Although there has been rapid urbanisation, pointed out in the survey between 2001 and 2011 with coming up of class IV and class III towns and cities (which is about 35.06% and 25% population, respectively), the number of people living in slums is only 15.60 lakh. While the male population is 8 lakh, 7.6 lakh women live in slums with 1.9 lakh children. Bhubaneswar and Cuttack have the highest slums with population of 1.64 lakh each. Andhra Pradesh has the highest 12.04% people living in slums, followed by National Capital New Delhi and Puducherry, the survey said.

In the state, urban slum population is 22% of the total population. There are 3.50 lakh slum households in the state.

The survey has said there has been steep demographic shift from rural to urban areas, resulting in shortage of affordable space in urban areas and resulting in patches of government land being encroached on by the settlers.

The survey has focused on the government’s Jaga Mission, which is aimed at providing land rights to slum dwellers, redeveloping the slums and rehabilitating the dwellers. For this, the government had formulated Odisha Land Rights to Slum Dwellers Act, 2017.

Under the Act, the survey has highlighted that the slum dwellers get land rights for residential use and the land is heritable and can be mortgaged but not transferable. The slum dwellers in notified area councils (NACs) will get land up to 646 sqft while it is 484 sqft in municipalities. This land criterion is applicable in case of their settlement in the place, which they have occupied. But in case of relocation, 323 sqft land will be granted for each household for free.

After Bhubaneswar was accorded number one smart city in the country, the slums, coming under Bhubaneswar Town Centre District (BTCD) area, have been getting special attention. Besides, redevelopment and ensuring better sanitation and descent urban living, under socially-smart programmes, the slum children are provided self-defence training. They are also imparted other skill development training so that they can become self-reliant.

Title: Assam outfit moves SC on ‘removal’ of state’s ILP provision
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

JORHAT: The All Tai Ahom Students’ Union has challenged the presidential order to amend the Bengal Eastern Frontier Regulation (BEFR) of 1873 in the Supreme Court, calling it a “politically motivated” step to deny Assam an inner-line permit system to insulate it against the new citizenship law. “We have filed a writ petition before the Supreme Court against the order of the President, dated December 11, 2019, to amend the BEFR. This is against the Constitution , unsustainable and liable to be set aside,” the student union said on Monday.

“The President passed the order for amendment under Article 372 (2) of the Constitution, although as per Article 372 (3), he has the power to do so for only three years from the date of enactment of the Constitution, i.e, till 1953,” the union claimed.

On December 24, an official release announced that the Union cabinet had given its ex-post facto approval to the Adaptation of Laws (Amendment) Order, 2019, issued by the President under Clause (2) of Article 372 of the Constitution to amend the BEFR.

The union accused the Centre of getting this done “to impose the CAA in Assam.” “According to the BEFR, 27 districts of Assam are under the purview of the BEFR and entitled to get an inner-line permit system. The Centre intentionally removed the provision to implement an inner-line permit system in Assam so that it could impose CAA. We oppose this order and, therefore, filed a writ petition challenging it in the Supreme Court on February 13. We have placed strong belief in the judiciary and are hopeful of getting justice,” the student union said.

Title: Vijayawada: Krishna home to most students with learning disability
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

VIJAYAWADA: Thirty-six per cent of the total number of children with disability in Krishna district suffer from learning disability, as per recent data. According to the latest data from the state education department, Krishna district has 2,130 children, with learning disabilities , accounting for 19% alone in the state, that range from dyslexia, Dysgraphia, Dyscalculia and non-verbal learning disabilities.

With 32%, the second most common disability in the state is that of mental retardation. There are 1,916 students who come under this category. In terms of physical disabilities, the district has high number of students with speech-impairment followed by hearing impairment and low vision. In total, Krishna district has 5,816 students suffering from various kinds of disabilities.

Multiple disabilities stands as the third commonest disability in the district with 799 students suffering from it. Anantapur has most number of visually impaired student in the state.

Speaking to TOI, Gummala Babu, general secretary of Special Educators’ Federation pointed out that there is a large ratio disparity between the number of disabled children in a district and the number of teachers. “The notification was given, exams too were conducted but ultimately, the results were stayed by the court after some of them objected to the entire selection process. While the court battles go on, the children continue to suffer,” Babu told TOI.

Overall in Andhra Pradesh , there around 21,123 mentally-impaired students and 11,156 students have learning disabilities. Under the physical disability category, the state has the highest number of speech impaired students — 9,002 students have it.

As per the data, Kurnool has the highest number of speech and visually impaired students and mental retardation cases.

Title: Trichy: Villagers’ scuffle leaves one dead
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

A man was stabbed to death in a scuffle that broke out between him and a few people, including two few village... Read More

NAGAPATTINAM: A man was stabbed to death in a scuffle that broke out between him and a few people, including two few village heads, during a village meeting. Police have arrested four people in connection with the murder . The victim, identified as S Saravanan , 24, a farmer, was a resident of Chinna Kokkur village near Mayiladuthurai in the district.

Police said that during the funeral procession taken out in the village on Sunday two people named Madhavan, Ranjith had thrown flowers on their way to the crematorium. When the duo threw flowers on a path near a temple in the village, Saravanan objected to it, leading to an altercation and fist fight. Later in the night, Madhavan and Ranjith raised a complaint against Saravanan with the village heads after a meeting was called to sort out the issue. During the compromise meeting, another fight broke out and at one point both Ranjith and Madhavan along with village heads, Ramachandran and Senthilkumar, attacked Saravanan.

During the fight one of them stabbed Saravanan, leaving seriously injured. He was rushed to Kuthalam government hospital for treatment but succumbed to his injuries later that night. Based on a compliant, Palaiyur police secured all the four and further inquiries are on.

Title: Surgeries performed on 174 needy kids during MSS workshop
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nagpur: Matru Sewa Sangh (MSS) Mahal branch organized paediatric surgical operative workshop as part of its Bal Shalyakriya Mission (BSM) from January 27 to 31. City based organizations Balmitra Foundation, GSB Sabha and Shanta Spine Centre along with Peedh Parai International from Houstan, Texas (USA) joined hands to make this workshop a success.

Total 174 children with major surgical problems of wide spectrum of complexities of various organ system (liver, food pipe, spine, intestine, kidney, lungs and diaphragm) got the benefit of cutting-edge technology and expertise during this camp.

More than 350 persons, including children and their family members, received nutritious meals, breakfast and lunch made and served by chef Rajesh Bhat and team of GSB Sabha.

This mission also received support from Dr Sajal Mitra, dean of Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), and Dr Naresh Tirpud, HoD, anesthesia, GMCH. Dr Tirpude paid a visit during the mission to ensure smooth conduct of the procedures. They also assured support and involvement of their team in future missions. Dr Rajendra Saoji and his team of Balmitra Foundation coordinated the entire project.

Dr BP Khobragade, senior consultant paediatrician and his team, looked after pre-operative assessment and post-operative care of all patients. Nursing staff and students of MSS Mahal branch nursing institute provided care under the guidance of Husain and Klera Patla.

Satish Agale and Liladhar Damaye of Balmitra Foundation did a commendable job with their central sterilization unit and operation room assistance to minimize the infection. Supply of drugs and disposable was maintained by Bombay Medical Store, Sitabuldi.

Educational session during this mission involved workshop and lectures for nursing students and staff on ‘Stoma care (colostomy, ileostomy, gastrostomy, ureterostomy) by an expert from Germany, Dr Ilka Gilbert. PowerPoint presentation regarding importance of hygiene and cleanliness, nutrition to parents was provided by Dr VS Dani and Dr Jayshree Pendharkar. They also distributed locally made high protein and calorie packets to the kids.

Bal Shalyakriya Mission (BSM 2020) was inaugurated by retired air marshal and vice chief of Indian Air Force Shirish Deo. Sonali Deshpande, chairperson of Persistent Foundation, was the chief guest. President of MSS Mahal branch Kanchan Gadkari, chief medical officer at MSS Dr Chhaya Chourasia, and chairman of Peedh Parai International Dr Ashwin Pimpalwar also addressed the gathering.

Jitendra Nayak, secretary of GSB Sabha, Nagpur, gave detail account of Bal Shalyakriya Mission. Secretary of MSS Mahal Vaidehi Bhate proposed a vote of thanks and Dr Snehal Satone conducted the inaugural function.

Certificates, mementoes, and sweets were distributed to all the participants on the concluding day. Treasurer of MSS Mahal Irawati Dani said this service must continue throughout the year and good paediatric surgical services should start on regular basis. She also assured all possible help.
