Title: In Haridwar for Ganga dip, Pak Hindus hail CAA
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Around 50 Pak Hindus are currently in Haridwar

HARIDWAR: A group of 50 Pakistani Hindus, who reached Haridwar on Monday to take a holy dip in Ganga , lauded the Citizenship (Amendment) Act saying that the law will give identity to those Hindus who migrated to India from Pakistan .

Amrit Lal, a trader from Larkana district of Pakistan, told TOI, “CAA is good for Pakistani Hindus who have migrated to India as they had been awaiting Indian citizenship for long. Many such Hindus had to buy land or shop in the name of their Indian relatives. This has led to many cheating cases as well. Citizenship rights will ensure their dignity.” Lal, who is on a trip to India with his family, added, “Some Pakistani Hindus want to migrate to India. However, religious discrimination is not the only reason. Some want to come here for better economic opportunities.” When asked about conditions in Pakistan, he said, “Law and order is an issue in Pakistan. Not just Hindus, but poor people of other sects also face problems. Imran Khan government is taking some measures but a lot remains to be done in this regard.”

Every year Pakistani pilgrims reach Haridwar during the summer season to take a holy dip in Ganga. During their stay, they live in different ashrams of the holy town.

Darshan Lal, from Sindh province of Pakistan, said, “Narendra Modi government’s decision is a big relief for Pakistani Hindus who have migrated here. We love our country and both the communities live peacefully there. Some old temples have also been reopened. However, security remains a big concern. Both the governments should try to soften visa regulations so that pilgrims from both sides do not face issues.” Lal runs a shop in Godki district of Pakistan’s Sindh.

Title: Jaipur Development Authority notice to clubs on trash disposal in park
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

JAIPUR: The Jaipur Development Authority (JDA) has issued notices to three establishments, including a Jain temple and two clubs, for disposing of garbage inside the Central Park . These establishments are situated inside and adjacent to the park.

The notices were issued to the Polo and Golf clubs on the complaint of morning walkers after they witnessed garbage strewn at various spots near these complexes.

In a notice to Polo Club, the JDA said, “In the parking of Polo Club, which is adjacent to Central Park walkway, plastic bottles, polythene bags and kitchen waste have been dumped. It’s causing pollution in the surroundings as wind pushes plastic and polythene in Central Park area.”

Similarly, a warning has been issued to the temple authorities not to dump kitchen waste in park. A senior official at JDA said, “Ideally, the club authorities should set up a plant to produce compost. If not waste should be disposed of scientifically as they are operating in eco-sensitive zone .”

In November 2017, the corporation made treatment of wet waste mandatory for government and private institutions with an area of 5,000sqm or above. It also directed them to produce compost in their own campuses. However, none of them established compost plants on their campuses.

After the corporation issued orders, a one-month deadline was given to institutions to set up compost plants of required capacity to treat wet waste. Other than the central and state government offices, it was also made mandatory for commercial establishments such as hospitals, clubs, hotels, schools, colleges and restaurants which generate over 100kg of waste daily. However, the corporation did not make efforts to impose the orders.

A source at JMC said, “Initially, 77 properties in the city were shortlisted where compost plants were proposed to be established. But, of these properties, not even 10% have set up the plant.”

Title: Bageshwar cyclist pedals to Cambodia to push for environmental conservation
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Rana, who is resident of Bageshwar's Rithad village, embarked on the journey on September 18, 2019, from Dehra... Read More

BAGESHWAR: “As the journey progressed, I conquered my fears,” says Pradeep Rana (21), who travelled from Dehradun to Cambodia while covering Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, and Vietnam. He peddled for 9,000 kilometres during the course of his journey, which aimed at spreading the message of environmental conservation, love, and peace.

Rana, who is a resident of Bageshwar’s Rithad village, embarked on the journey on September 18, 2019, from Dehradun’s Graphic Era, from where he is pursuing MSc (IT). His father Kishan is a farmer and social worker. He has been working to spread awareness regarding scientific farming among the local people in Bageshwar district for years.

"Crossing the international border for the first time in my life and that too on a bicycle was a thrilling and a scary experience for me,'' Rana told TOI during a phone conversation. He said that the money for the journey was arranged through crowd-funding. “Many people, who hail from Uttarakhand or other parts of India and are settled abroad, donated money for this journey,” informed Rana, who plans to peddle to countries like Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, and others.

"When I started my journey from Dehradun, I had just planned to cycle to six countries but the people that I met during my journey encouraged and funded me to explore more territory. At present, I have enough funds to go to Malaysia and then to Singapore. However, I will try to raise more funds so I can travel to other Asian nations like Indonesia, Brunei, Philippines, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, China, and others," Rana added.

Sharing experience of his trip, Rana said, "I stayed in Buddhist temples in Thailand and Laos. Indian restaurants in every city of Vietnam provided me with a free meal to support my journey. My college and the community of people from our state living in Singapore helped me a lot financially.''

Notably, this isn’t Rana’s first such adventure. In 2017, he cycled 18,671 km across India. Back then, he wished to register his name in the Guinness Book of World Records but couldn’t break the record set by an Australian cyclist .

When asked about his source of inspiration for such journeys, Rana said, "During my trip across India in 2017, I realised that travelling makes you generous and tolerant. You witness the diversity of this beautiful planet and start believing in co-existence. Since childhood, I have been fond of travelling and cycling."

Title: Fasting seer Padmavati admitted to AIIMS-Delhi in ‘unconscious’ state
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Seers have also alleged that police and district administration tried to stop them from going to Delhi, thus f... Read More

DEHRADUN: After sitting on hunger strike for 66 days, Ganga crusader Padmavati was reported to be in an ‘unconscious state’ on Monday morning. Fearing threat to her life, seers of Haridwar-based Matri Sadan ashram took her to a local hospital from where she was referred to AIIMS-Delhi after the ashram refused to admit the seer to any government hospital in Uttarkhand , including AIIMS-Rishikesh citing threat to her life from doctors and the administration.

Matri Sadan seer Dayanand, who accompanied Padmavati to Delhi, said, “They have killed professor GD Agrawal at AIIMS-Rishikesh and have also tried to kill seer Aatmabodhanand. So Padmavati has been taken to AIIMS-Delhi. So far, all her vitals are okay but she is unconscious and doctors have said that she is in mental trauma.”

Seers have also alleged that police and district administration tried to stop them from going to Delhi, thus further risking her life.

Dayanand alleged, “We were stopped for over two hours at Bahadrabad by police and administration, who wanted to take the seer to AIIMS Rishikesh. Surprisingly, they also said that they would airlift Padmavati to Delhi from Rishikesh. If they were so concerned, then they could have offered to do the same from Haridwar as well.”

Shivanand Saraswati, head of Matri Sadan ashram, said, “Padmavati had refused treatment by doctors of the state government. However, even then, those doctors, who were involved in killing our previous seers, were sent to check her. Two days ago, these doctors pasted a notice outside the seer’s room stating that she needs to be referred to a higher centre. And after that, she slipped into a state of shock. On Monday morning, when I went to see her, she was only chanting ‘Om’ and after that she stopped talking.”

Meanwhile, Bahadrabad SHO Gopal Kumar said that the seer’s ambulance was stopped for just five minutes. “Going by the orders, we had stopped the ambulance to ask them if they want to opt for the airlifting option as the patient’s condition was critical.”

Haridwar sub-divisional magistrate Kusum Chauhan said that no notice was pasted by the district administration team at the ashram. “The seer is not doing any mediation, she is on indefinite hunger strike as stated in her demands. That’s why it is our moral responsibility to save her life. We have been requesting her to end her fast but she is not ready to listen. We had gone to the ashram to save her as her medical reports showed deteriorated health. And eventually she had to be rushed to a hospital.”

Title: Nanital: NCC girl students march for Beti Bachao Beti Padhao
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

NAINITAL: Almost one thousand National Cadet Corps girl students gathered in Nainital and took out a march to spread the message of “Beti Bachao Beti Padhao” on Monday.

“The young girls took out a “Beti Bachao Beti Padhao” march near Naini Lake and also rode boats in the lake," said Nainital DM Savin Bansal. Later, a counselling session, organised by local administration, was held at the Boathouse Club. During the session, girls were given career counselling.

"It is our duty to boost their confidence so that they make their own decision. Their families should also give them freedom to choose their career path," DM Bansal added.

Title: Jaipur: Shopkeepers in debt trap after market fire hits their livelihood
Content:
Fire at Indira Bazaar (file photo)

JAIPUR: On February 15, Prakash Makhija was talking with his wife over the phone discussing about his daughter's engagement held a week back when he heard the sound of crackers bursting. Before he could realise, clothes hanging in front of his shop caught fire and suddenly rockets and other crackers were entering his outlet at Indira Bazaar.He called his sons working on the first floor and within a minute they ran out. Prakash is almost bankrupt now after suffering losses of around Rs 40 lakh. That afternoon eight shops of the area were reduced to ashes due to the negligence of one crackers shopkeeper who was given licence by authorities to run an outlet in a congested lane.“What was my fault. Both my shops have been totally gutted. I have lost everything without any mistake of my own. It will take me years to get on my feet,” Prakash said.A crackers shopkeeper at Indira Bazaar was giving a demo of a cracker to a customer when things spiralled out of control and within two minutes entire area was engulfed in fire. It took five fire tenders four hours to douse the fire. The congested lanes even made it difficult for fire officials to work.Bhagwan Das, who had a garments shop in front of the fire crackers shop, said he recently purchased materials worth thousands of rupees material for the shop. “Christmas, Sankranti, Valentines Day and many other special occasions were good business opportunities for us. Not only have I lost my shop and belongings, I might have to borrow money to restart again. Already I was living on rent. Who will pay for the renovation? We are completely destroyed,” said Bhagwan.There are many such fire crackers shop in the market and now market association is demanding for them to be shift outside.

Title: Question bank on CBSE site
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Ahmedabad: The Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) has announced that its much awaited question bank for Class 10 students has been uploaded on its website.

The question bank has been designed to cater to students who wish to measure their understanding of curriculum subjects. A CBSE press release said, “The bank comprises more than 2,000 questions and answers for all core subjects like maths, science, English, Hindi, political science, geography, economics, and history.”

Title: Dehardun: Mother, daughter run over by speeding truck
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

RUDRAPUR: A woman and her daughter were killed on the spot after a truck hit the bike they were on. The accident took place on Dandi bridge at Moradabad road near Kashipur town in Udham Singh Nagar on Monday afternoon. The two deceased were riding pillion on the bike which the woman’s husband was driving, who also sustained grievous injuries. The driver has been arrested, police said.

The victims were identified as Lakshmi Sharma, 50, and her daughter Priya, 16. They were residents of Rampur village, Thakurdwara tehsil of Moradabad district , Uttar Pradesh.

According to officials at Surya police station, a speeding truck hit them as Rajesh Sharma was driving a bike to hospital along with his wife and children.

Thakurdwara Police was also informed about the incident and the bodies have been sent for post-mortem.

Title: Voice from Shaheen Bagh: Site may change but sit-in to go on
Content:
Women wave tricolours during their ongoing protest against CAA and NRC at Shaheen Bagh in New Delhi (PTI photo... Read More

NEW DELHI: Shaheen Bagh is an idea that is bulletproof: the women at the 24x7 dharna in Delhi’s southeast neighbourhood echoed this sentiment on Monday, as Supreme Court ’s observations on the protest came in.The apex court, while recognising their right to protest, reiterated that there should be a balance between dissent and flow of traffic. “We know that SC has asked mediators to come and speak to us. But we have made our position clear. We want this law to be repealed,” said Ruby, a 22-year-old, as she announced the next speaker to address the protesters from the makeshift stage.“Hum watan pe tan mann lutaney pe hain. Humko malum hai hum nishane pe hain (we are ready to sacrifice our body and soul for the nation, we know we are the target),” the woman protester in a black hijab sang, amid a thundering applause. Her self-composed song was rusty, and her voice faltered, but the message was clear: the women will continue their fight against CAA, NRC and NPR. The site of protest may change, but their resolve will remain unfettered.On Twitter, too, the official handle of the protest site acknowledged the SC observation. “SC has denied any direct state action. Delhi Police directed to identify alternative site for protest,” it tweeted, adding that they “look forward to a mutually beneficial dialogue” with Delhi Police.The women say they are ready for a conversation, but on their own terms. They also acknowledge their responsibility of furthering the movement. “We are here today. We, the women, have to always remember thousands of people who gathered in our support in so many places… There is a responsibility,” said a woman in her 50s.The dadis also have a word of advice for the interlocutors. “Yahan makan nahin banaya hai (we haven’t constructed permanent houses here). We have always opened the road for ambulances and emergencies. We are ready to talk. But everyone needs to be consulted,” said Bilkis Bano, an 82-year-old who has become one of the most recognisable faces of the protest.The residents of the area are not indifferent to the concerns raised by SC and they believe that dialogues can lead to a resolution. Taseer Ahmad, a ‘volunteer-in-chief’ who helped with the overall arrangement from the start, said “the court has agreed to our right to protest”.“No resident welfare association from neighbouring Sarita Vihar and Okhla Vihar has come to address the people here. It is wrong to say they are not supporting us. This is an open platform. If they had real problems with us, they would have surely approached us,” Ahmad said.Read this article in BengaliIn Video: Shaheen Bagh protests: Supreme Court names 3 mediators

Title: Jaipur: Traders want firecracker shops outside Walled City
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The recent Indira Bazaar fire mishap.

JAIPUR: The Walled City market association has flagged the issue of giving licenses to firecracker shopkeepers to function in the congested lanes following the recent Indira Bazaar fire mishap.

Licenses to such shops are being issued by police commissionerate while following certain provisions of the Explosives Act 2008 that mentions that firecracker shops should be on a safe distance from residential areas with proper road connectivity. As per police sources, most of the shops in the Walled City area are being granted licenses since 1960, which is still being continued.

“Three decades ago the population and traffic in the Walled City was low. Now, when the lanes have become congested and small fire incidents can cause heavy damage to life and property, this should be reviewed by the administration,” said a police official.

Indira Bazaar, which is known for cloth shops, has 15 cracker shops in the same lane where the fire incident took place.

Subhash Goyal, president of Jaipur Vyapaar Mandal, said these incidences can be avoided only when firecracker shops are shifted outside Walled City.

“Cracker shops should be shifted outside the Walled City. The verandahs in front of the shops in Indira Bazaar have been destroyed and will take a long time to be repaired. Prakash and other businessmen should be provided with compensation from the government and an undertaking must be signed by cracker shop owners to pay for losses if any damage is caused due to their negligence,” Subhash said.

A case has been registered against the owner and his license has been suspended till further notice by police.

Jagdish Keswani, general secretary of Indira Bazaar Market Association , was seen vehemently supporting the idea of shifting firecracker shops outside the market. “There are 800 shops in Indira Bazaar and these 15 firecracker shops can destroy the entire market. Before granting the license, an undertaking must be signed by these shopkeepers stating that any mishap will be their responsibility so that in such situation someone can be held liable for financial losses of others,” Jagdish said.

Title: Six dead, one missing after car falls into Bhagirathi
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

An SDRD team engaged in rescue operation at the accident site

UTTARKASHI: Six people of a family were killed after the car they were travelling in fell into Bhagirathi river in Dharasu-Nalupani region of Chinyalisaur in Uttarkashi district on Monday. Meanwhile, rescue forces are still in search of a nine-year-old kid, who went missing after the accident .

According to TOI sources, seven local villagers, including three children and two women, were going to Chinyalisaur from Uttarkashi town on Monday afternoon. However, the car they were travelling in fell into a 400-metre-deep gorge in Bhagirathi from Gangotri National Highway in Dharasu-Nalupani region.

Soon after getting information of the accident, teams of State Disaster Response Force (SDRF), local police, fire brigade, and health departments reached at the spot and began rescue operation. The teams were led by district magistrate Ashish Chauhan. Forces fished out bodies of two women and three men, including a kid, from the gorge. One critically injured girl child was sent to local health centre but was later declared dead by doctors during treatment.

Devendra Patwal, district disaster management officer, told TOI, “The deceased have been identified as — car driver Budhi Prakash (35), Arti (24) and her daughter Yamini (5), Brijlal (35), his wife Roshni Devi (30), and his son Divyanshu (8). Brijlal’s son Priyanshu is still missing. Bodies of all the deceased persons have been sent to district hospital for postmortem examination.”

The official added, “Rescue forces halted the search operation in the evening. The teams will resume the search operation for the missing child on Tuesday morning. The exact cause of the accident can only be ascertained after investigation.”

Title: Trump may take off shoes at Sabarmati Ashram
Content: Gandhinagar: A US consulate official is said to have asked Sabarmati Gandhi Ashram officials whether it would be compulsory for US President Donald Trump to remove his shoes at the ashram. Sources now say Trump is likely to remove his footwear while visiting Hriday Kunj in the ashram.Trump will be gifted a set of Gandhiji’s Three Monkeys — which remind people of the virtues of not seeing, speaking, or hearing evil. Trump’s ashram visit is expected to last about 15 minutes on February 24. A key government source said, “Trump and his wife Melania Trump have agreed to follow the tradition and take off their shoes before entering Hriday Kunj, where Gandhiji lived.”Sources said that Trump and the first lady will be welcomed at the ashram with khadi sutar aati — a cotton garland. “Trump and Prime Minister Narendra Modi will greet people on the other side of the riverfront from a podium erected near Hriday Kunj,” a source said. “Trump might make an entry in the visitors’ book as well.”Sources said that mementos gifted to Trump will include photo frames of Gandhiji’s famous quotes and some photographs. “From the ashram, the two leaders will leave for the Motera stadium,” the source said.Trump will be the first serving US president to visit Gujarat. In 2001, when Bill Clinton visited the Gandhi ashram, he was no longer the US president. In 2015, John Kerry — the US secretary of state at the time — visited the Gandhi ashram before participating in the Vibrant Summit. Former US secretary of state Hillary Clinton has also visited the ashram. China President Xi Jinping, Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, and Israel Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu have visited Ahmedabad and the Gandhi ashram.

Title: Vijayawada: Beneficiaries not happy with one cent land away from city
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

VIJAYAWADA: Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) and Krishna district administration on Monday intensified efforts to identify land for beneficiaries of Housing for all Poor scheme. Ward volunteers went door-to-door and took consent forms from beneficiaries on the day. Authorities have proposed to give land in the Amaravati capital region to eligible beneficiaries residing in slums across the city.

The civic body, which initially proposed to construct G+3 apartments for the eligible poor, has now decided to give away plots of land. With the government promising to give one cent of land to each eligible family, officials are busy identifying around 800 acres of land to be given to to the 80,000 eligible beneficiaries.

The government’s proposal to allocate one cent of land has elicited mixed responses from beneficiaries. “Bearing house rents has become a major concern for us. We thought that the government will give us the house. But ward volunteers informed that the government will give us one cent of land in Mandadam village which is very far from the city. The government should at least give two cents for construction of the house,” said K Devarani, a resident of Gattenaka area.

Meanwhile, opposition parties criticised the consent forms collected by the VMC and the decision to allocate land in the capital region. “ Plots of land in Amaravati were sacrificed by farmers for construction of the capital. We heard that officials of VMC are collecting consent forms from people for allocation of house sites in Mandadam and other villages. The government should first allocate the completed houses in Jakkampudi area,” CPM state secretariat member Ch Babu Rao said.

Title: Speaker tells Shanti Dhariwal to suspend excise official within 24 hours for violating rules
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

shanti dhariwal



JAIPUR: Parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal on Monday assured the Assembly that the then Excise Inspector Lokesh Kumar and District Excise Officer, Dausa, Laxminarayan Devanda were issued charge sheet under CCA Rule-16 and 17 respectively for irregularities in liquor shop allocation at Hadiya village on Jaipur-Agra national highway.

Independent MLA Om Prakash Hudla has alleged that an excise officer in Dausa sanctioned liquor shops on Jaipur-Agra National Highway in violation of rules, but the government failed to initiate action against him.

Raising the issue during Zero Hour, Hudla said the issue was brought to the notice of the government on January 27 but it did not act against the official who flouted the rules. He raised the issue again in the assembly through a call attention motion on Monday.

Parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal said the officer had been served a notice under Rajasthan Civil Service rules 16 CC. But the minister’s reply did not satisfy the MLA and the speaker.

Speaker Joshi asked the minister whether he was ready suspend the official as such a move would send out a message that the government would not tolerate violation of the law.

The minister said he will act, but due process had to be followed.

Title: Vijayawada: 50 Blue Colt teams launched in Krishna district police limits
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The Blue Colt teams in Machilipatnam on Monday

VIJAYAWADA: The Krishna police launched 50 new Blue Colt teams at Machilipatnam on Monday.

Addressing the media, Krishna district SP M Ravindranath Babu explained that the teams would be deployed across important police stations within their limits where crime rate is relatively higher. Each team of Blue Colt comprises two personnel . They also received bikes equipped with GPS.

The tracking device will enable the control room to directly monitor the movement of the vehicles that will help in coordination while deploying the nearest beat officers.

Babu said the Blue Colt personnel will receive smartphones with Dial 100 and 112 applications, which will allow them to get the details of complainants and use it to reach out to them quickly. “The Blue Colt personnel will have body cameras, capable of broadcasting video footages live to the control room for remote investigations,” Babu said.

Title: Will honour the right to protest & that of public life: Shaheen Bagh mediators
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

NEW DELHI: India’s first chief information commissioner, a Supreme Court lawyer often sparring on, and sometimes with, Twitter, and an SC advocate with 42 years’ experience: the three interlocutors asked to mediate with protesters at Shaheen Bagh struck a cautious note on Monday when news of their appointment broke, but agreed that both the right to protest and that of public life would be honoured.

“I really have no idea. I’ve only read reports of this and not received any official communication,” said Wajahat Habibullah. The former CIC and J&K interlocutor has been a vocal critic of the way things were handled in Kashmir — from the writing down of Article 370 to the killing of “militants” by armed forces in encounters.

When it came to Shaheen Bagh, the former chairperson of the National Commission for Minorities stood up for the right to protest again. After a petition was filed in Supreme Court to remove the anti-CAA protesters at Shaheen Bagh because the “blockade” was considered a “disruption” to public life, he joined Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad in filing an impleadment application. “We had petitioned Supreme Court saying that no harm should be brought to the women and children at Shaheen Bagh, whatever be the legal position SC upholds,” he said.

But that petition does not apply to what comes next, he said. “If the court asks me to assist the interlocutors, I will naturally have to look at it from the point of view that the court expects. I don’t know, at this point, what the court expects,” he added.

Supreme Court advocate Sanjay Hegde, too, held back on committing to any roadmap. “I don’t want to speak right now about anything. Whatever statement has to be made will be made by me and Sadhana Ramachandran together,” he said. The firebrand Hegde, a Supreme Court lawyer since 2015, has taken up the cudgels on behalf of the families of mob lynching victims, Aarey protesters and those excluded from NRC.

Sadhana Ramachandran, practicing in Supreme Court since 1978, has been a senior mediator in SC and has been working with the Delhi High Court Mediation and Conciliation Centre.

“We will be meeting all the parties … to resolve their issues in a manner that respects and safeguards both the right to protest and the requirements of orderly civic life. We hope that our assistance leads to these matters being resolved in good faith and to the satisfaction of all parties,” said a joint statement issued by Hegde and Ramachandran.

Title: Kashmir news: Centre begins process of delimitation of assembly seats in J&K
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

NEW DELHI: In a move that will pave the way for assembly elections in the Union Territory of J&K, the Centre has begun the process of fresh delimitation of assembly seats as well as readjustment of boundaries of parliamentary constituencies.

The move comes more than six months after abrogation of Article 370 in J&K and three-and-a-half months since the state of J&K was reorganised into the UTs of J&K and Ladakh.

Sources told TOI that the law secretary wrote to chief election commissioner Sunil Arora on Monday stating that the government had decided to go ahead with constitution of the Delimitation Commission provided for in the Jammu and Kashmir Reorganisation Act, 2019. The panel, to be set up under Section 3 of the Delimitation Act of 2002, will be headed by a serving or retired judge of the Supreme Court, with the CEC or an election commissioner nominated by him and the state election commissioner of the UT concerned as its ex-officio members.

The law secretary requested the CEC to confirm himself as a member of the delimitation panel or nominate an election commissioner for the job. Arora chose to nominate election commissioner Sushil Chandra for the panel. A communication in this regard has gone to the law secretary.

The delimitation process may take at least four months. Assembly polls in J&K, which is currently under President’s rule, can be held after that. The delimitation, which will be carried out based on 2011 Census figures, is expected to address Jammu region’s long-standing demand for better representation in the assembly.

The last time a delimitation exercise took place in J&K was in 1995. The state was under President’s rule even then, as the delimitation panel headed by Justice K K Gupta (retd) went about the exercise in extremely difficult circumstances.

As per Section 60 of J&K Reorganisation Act, the number of seats in the legislative assembly shall be increased from 107 to 114. Delimitation of constituencies must be carried out to determine the number of seats to be reserved for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in the assembly. The delimitation panel will also determine the assembly constituencies into which the UT shall be divided, the extent of such constituencies and which of these shall be reserved for SCs/STs. The panel is also tasked with adjustment of boundaries and description of the extent of parliamentary constituencies in each UT.

A presidential notification had earlier corrected an anomaly pertaining to Section 63 of J&K Reorganisation Act, which stated that “until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 2026 have been published, it shall not be necessary to readjust the division of successor UT of J&K into assembly and parliamentary constituencies”. The President on October 31 suspended operation of this section.

Title: Coimbatore: Man demands action against ex-minister
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

COIMBATORE: A man from Thaneerpandhal in Karamadai on Monday requested the collector to direct police register a cheating case against former transport minister V Senthil Balaji.

A Sabapathy said Balaji made his brother, a Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation bus conductor, collect lakhs of rupees from job seekers, promising jobs.

“My brother Arul Raj, who was also an office bearer of one of the TNSTC staff unions, was tasked with collecting money from people interested in getting government jobs. He was tasked by the minister to promise jobs on his behalf. However, once the money was handed over, no jobs were given, and my brother went missing on November 5, 2015,” the complainant said. “Now those people, who gave my brother money, are harassing my family and my sister-in-law.”

Sabapathy requested the collector to direct police act against the former minister and find his missing brother.

Title: Vijayawada: Scholarship worth Rs 4 crore up for grabs
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

VIJAYAWADA: JK Lakshmipat University in Jaipur, Rajasthan, is set to shortlist 100 meritorious students from the city for their flagship higher education scholarship programme.

Senior faculty from the university, including pro-vice-chancellor Asheesh Gupta and dean of research and development, Dr Jyoti Prakash CR Naidu addressed a media conference here on Monday about it.

They said the university is offering a scholarship worth Rs 4.5 crore to encourage meritorious students and provide them with world-class learning experiences.

Asheesh Gupta said that they believe in the need to build future talent that can become the driver of economic growth for the country.

“While most universities continue to focus on quality education, we have taken a conscious decision to not just invest in ensuring quality education but specialised courses, teaching methods, and learning outcomes that prepare the students for the future,” he said.

Title: Hemant Bhatt: US president Donald Trump’s Gujarati friend
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Donald Trump with Hemant Bhatt

GANDHINAGAR: US President Donald Trump’s most ardent fan in the United States of America is an excited man. With Trump scheduled to visit Ahmedabad next week, US citizen and businessman Hemant Bhatt says the visit will cement Indo-US ties further.

Bhatt, who hails from Vadodara in Gujarat, runs the https://www.trumpmypresident.com portal even as the US president seeks a second term in office. Bhatt is also the founder of ‘Hindus For Trump’ and ‘AmericaWinningCoalition’ campaigns. Besides, Bhatt had played a key role in organzsing the Chalo Gujarat-Chalo India events and also founded the South Asian Republic Coalition (SARC).

Bhatt is clearly very enthusiastic about Trump’s visit to Gujarat and India. When contacted, he said, “I am really excited about President Donald Trump and the first lady’s visit to Gujarat and India. This move will give a major boost to USA-India relations. The world’s oldest and largest democracies have a lot of things to share with each other. The Indian community in the US is excited about Trump’s India visit.”

Having played a key role in Donald Trump’s election campaign in 2016, Bhatt has already started the Republican party’s campaign for the 2020 presidential election under the ‘trumpmypresident’ banner. Bhatt is among the few Republicans who have close association with both Donald Trump and his son Donald Trump Jr.

“President Trump has always been pro-India and has the respect of the Indian community in the US. Like in 2016, Trump will win again in 2020 with a bigger margin. `mypresidenttrump’ campaign is a humble effort to contribute towards supporting him,’’ Bhatt added.

Title: Dehradun: 2 dead in US Nagar in bike accident
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

RUDRAPUR: Two men were killed after their motorcycle was hit by an unidentified vehicle in Nanakmatta area of Udham Singh Nagar district on late Sunday night. According to police , the driver responsible for the accident fled the spot and is yet to be identified.

The deceased have been identified as Pankaj Rana, 27, and Yogesh Rana, 29, both residents of Kuan Khera village in Khatima.

According to police, the incident took place near a national highway bypass, when both the deceased were returning from Haldwani on a bike.

SHO of Nanakmatta police station Kamlesh Bhatt said that both the victims were declared dead on arrival at Civil Hospital in Khatima.

The bodies have been sent for postmortem. A case was registered against the unidentified driver under sections 279 (rash driving or riding on a voluntary way) and 304-A (death by negligence) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) at Nanakmatta police station.

Title: Parents hassled as violator vehicles play truant
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Ludhiana: With the district administration and the police launching a crackdown on vehicles not following the Safe School Vahan Policy on Monday, parents and students were a harried lot as the violator vehicles played hooky.

While many parents had to drop and pick up their children from schools, some school vehicle drivers shifted children to other vehicles ahead of the checkpoint.

Neha Sharma, a homemaker and resident of Old City, said, “Usually, the bus arrives till 8am to pick up my son. But when it did not come till 8.15am, I called up the driver. He said he was not coming due to some issues. I had to rush to drop my son to school.”

Lalit Bagga, a dying unit owner of Kirpal Nagar, said, “When the school bus driver did not turn up, I called him up. He said he will not be able to come for a few days as the district administration has started a checking drive. I first dropped my son to school and then went to office. In the afternoon, I left office to pick up my son. Despite the hassle we faced, we appreciate the checking drive as it will ensure our children’s safety.”

Deepak Sood, a banker from Civil Lines, said, “My wife and I were getting ready for our offices when the school van driver informed us that he will not be coming today. We had to hurry as our children’s school does not let latecomers in. During the drive, the administration should ask the schools to allow students if they are late. Else, there will be much chaos.”

While Regional Transport Authority and SDMs challaned and impounded the violator vehicles, the police gave seven-day notice to those whose vehicles failed to abide by a few rules.

Commissioner of police Rakesh Agarwal said, “Police are not focusing on issuing challans. Our motive is to make drivers follow the rules. Therefore, on first day of the drive, the police have issued over 500 notices to school vehicle drivers, giving them seven days to comply with the rules.”

Assistant commissioner of police (traffic) Gurdev Singh said, “Police have impounded buses that were in poor condition, challaned those that were violating more than two rules and issued notices to those whose violation count was less. Those served notices will have to comply with rules in a week, after which action will be taken against the non-complying ones.”

Title: NRIs give facelift, Jagraon village school becomes big draw
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Akhara (Jagraon): NRIs have helped the local government primary school wear an attractive look, drawing a large number of students.

The village has a sizeable number of NRIs who contribute to education, apart from other development works here. “The institute had come up in 1950 and was upgraded to high school. As it was outside the village, young children faced problems in going there and so the enrolment dropped. However, after the school was shifted to the heart of the village, the number of students swelled. Some years ago, paint of the building started coming off. At that time, a group of youth in the village thought that instead of donating money to religious places, it should be contributed towards education. They then informed the NRIs,” said head teacher Lakhvir Singh.

“The idea was to make school building vibrant with colourful messages about education so that students find it an attractive place. Since children have a liking for trains, we got walls painted like locomotives with doors and windows. Apart from that, we got pillars painted with pictures and names of body parts, 10 Sikh gurus, freedom struggle messages and math tables. The attractive ambience is drawing more students. As of now, we have 200 students and have enrolled 20 more who would join soon,” he added.

A Class V student Jasmeen Kaur said, “It is a dream to go somewhere on a train someday. I am happy to see a train almost every day at my school. Besides, I also love to learn about parts of body, tables, plants, planets, among others, painted on walls.”

The village leaders said NRIs also help in development works. “There are around 400 NRIs from the village of over 7,000. Not only have they helped in improving education, but also contributed to overall development with projects like tree plantation and cleanliness, among others,” said sarpanch Sukhjeet Singh.

An NRI said by contributing to the development of the village, they were just trying to pay back to their native place and don’t want credit for it.

Swings, generators needed, says teacher

Harnarayan Singh, one of the seven teachers at the school, said whenever NRIs met them, they asked about other requirements at the school. He said they have asked them to provide funds for swings and generators as there were more students now. He said there were 11 rooms in the school and seven teachers, including five women teachers. “We are setting up a herbal garden and have planted tulsi, curry leaves and jamun plants there,” he added.

Title: JAIPUR: Will soon fill vacancies for college principals says Bhanwar Singh Bhati
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Bhanwar Singh Bhati

JAIPUR: The state government has assured the assembly that all vacant posts of principals in government colleges will be filled up before the next academic session.

Replying to a question by BJP MLA Vasudev Devnani, higher education minister Bhanwar Singh Bhati said 267 out of 292 posts of principals are vacant.

The minister informed that the DPC got delayed as the government plans to review eligibility of teachers to qualify for selection since the previous BJP government made it mandatory that only PhD holders were eligible.

Bhati informed that before the code of conduct came into force on October 5, 2018, the government had revised rules for the selection process for the post of principal under which qualifications was raised to PhD. Considering protest by various teacher organisations, the government is now reviewing the change in qualification for principal and the DPC will be conducted at the earliest.

He said due to new rules, many senior teachers selected through Rajasthan Public Service Commission were deprived of promotion to the post of principal.

Committee to take a decision on Sambhar lake

Industries minister Parasadi Lal Meena informed the assembly on Monday that a committee had been formed at the level of chief secretary to take Sambhar Salt Limited completely under the state government.

Meena was replying to a question during the Question Hour. He said Sambhar Salt Limited is a Government of India Enterprise with 60 per cent held by it and 40 per cent by the state government. The state government only gets the lease amount.

He said the Centre had said in August 2019 that the company was running at a loss and the Union government was preparing to shut it down or ready to hand over the ownership to the state.

Title: Kochi Metro authorities demolish bund across Kaniyampuzha backwaters
Content:
Water flows freely through Kaniyampuzha backwaters after the demolition of bund

KOCHI: After more than two years since the completion of works on Metro pillars across Kaniyampuzha backwaters near Vyttila Mobility Hub, Metro authorities have demolished a bund constructed across the waterbody obstructing the flow of water.It was following a series of reports published in TOI questioning the Metro authorities’ apathy that they pulled down the bund.While constructing the bund more than three years ago, Metro authorities had promised that they would demolish the structure once the work on the pillars across the backwaters is over. But the Metro authorities didn’t keep their promise and the bund obstructed the flow of water, thereby causing waterlogging in many places on the banks of Kaniyampuzha. “We had asked Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC), which constructed the bund, to take necessary action. Now, they have informed us that they demolished the bund,” said Kochi Metro Rail Ltd (KMRL) managing director Alkesh Kumar Sharma. Metro authorities have removed at least two metre-deep mud so as to demolish the bund.The bund was constructed across the backwaters for facilitating the movement of heavy vehicles, including containers, to reach the stacking yards of the Metro project located under the pillars of the viaduct. The bund was as wide as a four-lane highway. “It is a welcome move that the Metro authorities demolished the bund,” said RTI activist K T Cheshire, who had lodged a complaint with Metro authorities demanding demolition of the structure.Now, the bund along the width of around 30m have been demolished. Still, the authorities haven’t removed the mud used for reclaiming the creek, which was spread across the wetland in the area. “They reclaimed the creek up to at least 100m. They should remove the mud used for filling the creek as well,” Cheshire said. There were allegations that the Metro authorities were reluctant to demolish the bund so as to help somebody, who purchased land in the Silver Sand Island which is being connected through the bund. “Now, a realtor who has presence all across the nation is learnt to have purchased land in the island. If the creek is not restored, the realtor can later use the reclaimed land as road. Given the fact that the realtors are very influential, they will also manage to secure nod for constructing a bridge across the 30-metre-wide stretch of the backwaters where the Metro authorities demolished the bund,” Cheshire said. “Moreover, the Metro authorities constructed three pillars in the waterbody. As per the normal distance between two pillars, it would have required just two pillars to cover the 30-metre distance of the backwaters. The act of Metro authorities raise suspicion that their aim is to help realtors,” Cheshire said.Meanwhile, it is learnt that there is a plan to construct a bridge across the river to the island side from the mobility hub area. Officials associated with the Metro agency visited the area and explored the possibilities of constructing a bridge. They said that the plan to construct bridge is mooted by one builder in the island.

Title: ‘Floating ward’ concept soon at Kozhikode MCH
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Kozhikode: Government Medical College authorities here have decided to introduce ‘ floating ward’ concept at all the four hospitals situated in its campus to resolve the shortage of beds. Shortage of beds forces the patients to lie on the floors during their hospital stay.

If the proposal materializes, various departments will share available beds in their wards to accommodate patients from other wards to resolve the complaints on dearth of beds.

The facility will be introduced in all the four hospitals — Kozhikode Government Medical College Hospital , Institute of Maternal and Child Health , Institute of Chest Diseases and Super Specialty Hospital.

The medical college authorities have commenced the floating ward concept on an experimental basis at the Kozhikode Government Medical College Hospital (KGMCH). It has set up a floating ward at the medicine ward one in the initial phase. KGMCH authorities have informed that they will make use of the geriatric ward, which is now being used as an isolation ward for coronavirus infection, as floating ward once the government withdraws the isolation facility.

A decision on setting up floating ward was taken at a meeting of the hospital development core committee chaired by district collector Sambasiva Rao on February 15. The meeting was held to discuss about solutions to rectify the anomalies in the medical college campus.

According to the medical college authorities, on an average, a minimum of 5,500 patients per day visit the various outpatients wings of the four hospitals. The dearth of beds often forces the inpatients to lay on the hospital floors during their stay at the hospitals for treatment.

Dr V R Rajendran, principal of the Kozhikode Government Medical College said that with the introduction of the floating ward concept, we hope to resolve existing complaints of bed shortage to a certain extent. “We have started the trial run at the Kozhikode Government Medical College hospital which witnesses the highest number of patients flow per day. The facility will be expanded to all the other three hospitals in the medical college campus in a phased manner,” he said.

Title: Farmers demand free electricity
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Coimbatore: The Tamil Nadu Farmers Association , associated with the All India Kisan Sabha (AIKS), on Monday petitioned the collector demanding free power to farmers.

President of the association S Palanisamy petitioned collector K Rajamani saying that the government has not given connection to any farmer, who had applied for free power, since 2000. “In 2017, it announced a tatkal scheme for farmers who could pay 2.5 lakh to Rs 4 lakh, depending on their pumpset’s capacity, a one-time fee power scheme for the rest of their lives,” he said. “It has been repeating the scheme for the last three years and have given around 40,000 new farmers electricity.”

Free power will truly be free only if it requires no advance payment or no one-time fee, said Palanisamy.TNN

Title: Women event mgmt group set up by panchayat
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Alappuzha: These days it is not an easy task to get experienced persons for taking care of women in their postpartum and the new-born baby, even in rural areas.

People also face difficulties to get workers to make arrangements for wedding and funeral rituals. People of Thanneermukkom and its neighbouring villages don’t want to get worried. Thanneermukkom grama panchayat has started a women-only event management group for solving all these issues.

The event management group named ‘Smart Thanneermukkom’ will help bachelors and bachelorettes to find a life partner and the group will also arrange the wedding venue, cook and serve food for the guests of their weddings

Thanneermukkom panchayat chief P S Jyothis said, their event management group would provide well-trained event management members for nursing the woman and her infant soon after delivery. “All villages are developing, but if somebody died, it is a tough task to find people for making arrangements for the funeral, even in rural areas. So, we also have a women team for meeting such needs. Our team will come and will provide our service for the funeral. The panchayat authorities have bought a casket costing Rs 1.5 lakh for the event management team,” said the panchayat president.

The implementing agency of this project is Community Development Society (CDS), the panchayat-level apex body of the Kudumbashree. If a villager needs the service of the event management group, they can approach the CDS and book the team. There will also be a fee and rent for the service of the team.

“The event management members have been undergoing training for the last one month to prepare for the services. The service of the group will be available from March. Over 35, Kudumbashree members are undergoing training for nursing women and infants. Three teams consisting of 45 members are receiving training related to the management of wedding parties. Six members are getting training for managing funeral matters,” said Sreeja Shibu, CDS chairperson.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Thousands of youth fall victim to job scam
Content:
Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: A major problem facing the police in north Andhra right now is the problem of imposters posing as government officials and duping people by promising favours. Although the police have caught some such fraudsters, people are being cheated by such imposters every day. The major policing issue is that these fraudsters keep shifting base, making them extremely difficult to locate.Recently, the city task force police arrested a person named G Anil Kumar. Kumar had allegedly posed as additional collector-3 of Visakhapatnam district and had collected over Rs 10 lakh from people promising to solve their land disputes. Preliminary investigation has revealed that Kumar, a resident of Srikakulam, had also committed some white-collar offences in Srikakulam district.Speaking to TOI, ACP (task force) A Trinad Rao said that the frauds committed by such imposters come to light only when the people cheated on lodge a police complaint. “As a result, the imposters have enough time to flee. Ironically, it is the educated youngsters who are falling into their trap,” he added.More than 2,100 cases of cheating and white-collar offences were reported in the city between 2017 and 2019. However, most of the accused in such cases remain at large as police have failed to find clues to follow up on the accused.DCP (law and order) S Ranga Reddy related the incident of a 42-year-old Srinivas who would pose as the assistant general manager of a company. Srinivas had allegedly cheated more than 20 youngsters having taken around Rs 60 lakh from them upon promising employment in government departments and private firms. “Recovery of siphoned off money is difficult as these fraudsters usually spend all the money,” he added.Some police officials also find fault with those who fall victim to such frauds by paying money without conducting sufficient background checks in the hope of securing employment through unscrupulous means. They say that not only intermediate and polytechnic diplomas, graduates and post graduates in engineering and business administration also fall victim to such frauds.CPI(M) leader K Lokanatham said that people from north Andhra are easy victims to such fraud. “We have been requesting the police to create awareness about such imposters, fake agents and institutions and to set up a job fraud cell to deal with such cases. However, our requests have fallen on deaf ears,” he said.

Title: Passengers from Singapore advised home quarantine for two weeks
Content:
Representative Image

COIMBATORE: With the number of COVID-19 cases increasing to 75 in Singapore as of Monday, the health department has begun asking all visitors from Singapore to home quarantine themselves for at least two weeks.While people with flu symptoms are strictly told to stay indoors for 28 days and be monitored, those without symptoms are also told to stay home and avoid public places for at least two weeks. Every day, close to 80-100 people fly into the city from Singapore.Meanwhile, many Coimbatorians who have booked tickets and trips to Singapore in February and March, are desperately calling helplines and travel agents, trying to get at least a portion of their trip refunded or rescheduling their tickets and bookings.Many of them stand to lose close to Rs 1.2 lakh each, because they are choosing to cautiously not travel now.The Singapore tourism board has acknowledged the panic but maintains that their country and tourist attractions are open, and thus no refunds will be ordered.The public health department on Monday confirmed that they have begun requesting even asymptomatic patients landing in the district from Singapore, to home quarantine themselves for two weeks, which will be incubation period for the virus. “Unlike passengers coming from China, where we compulsorily tell them to home quarantine themselves and carefully monitor them through the 28-day period, even without symptoms, we only request asymptomatic patients from Singapore to home quarantine themselves for two weeks,” said deputy director of public health, Dr Ramesh.Patients who fly in after visiting and spending a few days in Singapore, and show symptoms of the flu, are told to home quarantine themselves for 28 days and if their condition gets more serious, to get tested for the virus. “Since cases in Singapore are rising, we have decided to closely monitor patients from Singapore who show symptoms of the flu while passing our thermal scanners,” said the deputy director.“We are giving refunds only to passengers who have a travel history of China. The rest of Indian passport holders don’t get refunds, because neither the Indian nor Singaporean governments have issued travel restrictions between both countries,” said an agent of an airliner in the city.

Title: Sharjeel Imam, in custody for sedition, arrested for Jamia violence
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Sharjeel Imam

NEW DELHI: The special investigating team (SIT) probing the Jamia Millia Islamia clashes has arrested JNU student Sharjeel Imam , already in custody in a sedition case, allegedly for inciting violence.

The arrest was made after one of his associates reportedly told the Crime Branch that Imam had abetted some local youths to block the Shaheen Bagh road and put up a violent resistance to the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

SIT on Monday got Imam’s remand for a day to question him about his role after the December 13 speech, which allegedly acted as a trigger for the violent clashes between Jamia residents and police. DCP (crime) Rajesh Deo said Imam, who was in judicial custody, had been charged with rioting after his role in instigating rioters became clear. “Apart from analysing his speech, we questioned a number of local residents and people known to him who acknowledged his role in abetting the violent outburst later. He will be questioned further on this,” Deo said.

An investigating officer claimed despite being a JNU student, Imam used to spend most of his time at Jamia. During his stay with some Jamia students on the campus, he planned the agitation, the officer alleged, adding that Imam incited locals of Taimoor Nagar and Batla House by convincing them that only a violent protest would draw attention to their cause.

Some locals allegedly said Imam had termed it to be a second freedom struggle. “Prima facie, a probe suggests that the trouble was planned beforehand,” an officer claimed.

Imam’s associates reportedly said they had distributed pamphlets in New Friend’s Colony and Jamia areas on December 13 and 14, prompting many locals to join the protest. It has also been found that Imam had paid the money from his bank account to print 5,000 copies of three anti-CAA posters he had designed, a cop said. The WhatsApp groups through which Imam was keeping in touch with his associates had been tampered with, he added.

Title: Jaipur: Guru Golwalkar Jan Bhagidari Vikas Yojana named after Gandhi
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The state’s Congress government has changed the name of Guru Golwalkar Jan Bhagidari Vikas Yojana, under rural development and panchayati raj department, to Mahatma Gandhi Jan Bhagidari Vikas Yojana as a mark of respect to the country’s Father of the Nation on his 150th birth anniversary.

M S Golwalkar was the second sarsanghchalak of Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) and was one of the most prominent ideologues of Hindutva.

State BJP president Satish Poonia slammed the state government saying it “practices politics of hatred”. “In this country, all great men are the equal. They are all important to us. Both Mahatma Gandhi and Guru Golwalkar are respected in our country.”

“They (Congress) sometimes talk about removing pictures (of the leaders) or removing the characters from the syllabus or change the name of the schemes. The name of Atal Seva Kendra (named after former Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee ) was changed to Rajiv Gandhi Seva Kendra. It is in their nature to worship the Gandhi family, and, hence they try to score political mileage by doing such things. As per political tradition, this is absolutely wrong. However, this government is encouraging such a tradition. We will again change the name (of the scheme) when we come to power,” he added.

This is the third time the name of this scheme has been changed by the state government. Initially, the name of scheme was Apna Gaon, Apna Kaam when it was introduced in 1991-92. It was changed by Gehot government to Jan Bhagidari Yojana during his second term, 2009-2013. When Vasundhara Raje-led BJP government came to power, the name of the scheme was changed to Guru Golwalkar Jan Bhagidari Yojana in 2014.

“The file pertaining to changing the name of the scheme on its guidelines has been sent to chief minister’s office (CMO) for approval,” said an official.

Under the scheme, 30 per cent of the funds are generated through public contribution and 70 per cent is funded by the government. The fund is used for all kinds of community building works in villages. These include building schools, roads, community halls, toilets etc.

In Rajasthan, the priority was changed to building and renovation of cemetries and burial grounds in the villages as per 2014 guidelines.

Title: Anti-rabies serum used in only 7% dog bite cases last year
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Bengaluru: The vital anti-rabies serum was administered in just 7% of the dog bite cases reported in Bengaluru during 2019. The figure is a cause of concern for doctors , who say ARS should be used in every case.

A 31-year-old Cox Town woman who did not avail treatment after she was bitten by a stray dog four months back died of rabies in a city hospital on Saturday. This was the second rabies-related death in BBMP limits this year.

According to data with BBMP’s public health information and epidemiological cell (PHIEC), 8,994 dog bite cases were reported last year and ARS or rabies immunoglobulin was used only in 661. The cell collates reasons for hospital visits by patients.

Factors like severity of the dog bite, whether its caused by a stray or pet and the animal’s vaccination status are crucial to decide the mode of treatment. However, doctors say ARS should be given irrespective of the severity. Victims’ families are asked to keep track of the dog as it could die if it’s rabid.

ARS is the first line of treatment and has to be followed by the rabies vaccine. It provides a protective mechanism before the vaccine shows effects. Incidentally, 5,785 (64%) of dog bite cases reported last year involved strays, according to BBMP statistics.

Oversight and lack of awareness regarding treatment are major concerns, say doctors. “In case of a dog bite, overtreatment is fine so that rabies can be prevented. The serum reacts immediately and kills the rabies virus before it enters the human nervous system. Once it enters the nerves, there is no medicine to treat it and it’s 100% fatal. The best thing is to treat dog bites with ARS, along with the rabies vaccine. While the vaccine takes 14 days to work, the serum provides antibodies immediately,” explained Dr NR Ramesh Masthi, professor and head, department of community medicine, Kempegowda Institute of Medical Sciences (KIMS). The hospital treats at least 200 cases of dog bite a month.

According to BBMP data, 8338 vials of the rabies vaccine were administered in Bengaluru last year. However, it is not clear how many dog bite victims were administered the vaccine. Depending on the severity and nature of the dog bite, a patient is administered up to 28 doses of 0.1 ml. The BBMP data is not clear about the vial size.

“The number of dog bite victims given ARS is low but if patients have gone to private hospitals enrolled with PHIEC, we may not have the exact figure,” said BBMP authorities.

“One must go to a doctor and avail the required treatment. Ignoring a dog bite can prove costly as was the case of the Cox Town woman,” said Dr Vijay Kumar Annayya Reddy, consultant, critical care medicine, Vikram Hospital, who treated her.

According Dr Ansar Ahmed, medical superintendent, Epidemic Diseases Hospital (earlier known as Isolation Hospital) on Old Madras Road, 15 cases of rabies were reported in 2019. “All rabies cases are fatal. This year, we have seen one case each from Nelamangala, Shivamogga, Ballari and Hanumanthnagar in BBMP limits,” he said.

Box: Wash wound with soap water first

In case of dog bite, the first thing to do is to wash the wound with detergent soap (hard soap) and water, said Dr NR Ramesh Masthi, professor and head, department of community medicine, KIMS hospital. Further medical care is necessary with ARS and the vaccine.

“There is a lack of awareness among many patients. Even now we get dog bite cases where lime, juice of green leaves and chilli powder have been the first line of treatment,” he added.

Source: PHIEC

Title: Corporator’s move to inspect another ward miffs peers
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Bengaluru: A turf war is brewing in the BBMP council, with BJP member KA Munindra Kumar’s decision to conduct an inspection of road and drain works in Kuvempunagar rankling corporators, cutting across party lines.

The aggrieved Kuvempunagar corporator, VV Prathibha Rajan of Congress, has got support from mayor M Goutham Kumar, who too has taken exception to his party colleague, Munindra’s decision.

According to the BBMP rulebook and code of conduct, a councillor can inspect only his or her ward and has no authority to inspect others. If s/he does so, then the corporator of that ward, mayor or the commissioner have to be informed. Only the mayor, commissioner or joint commissioners can inspect wards across the city, Goutham Kumar said.

Munindra represents Jakkur ward, and the only link between Jakkur and Kuvempunagar wards is that they fall in Byatarayanapura assembly constituency.

Asserting that Munindra is not her leader, Prathibha said, “Except for the mayor, no one is permitted to visit other councillors ’ wards for inspection. Seems like Munindra is making new rules.”

Munindra said, “A couple of residents from Kuvempunagar ward visited my office and complained about horrible roads, overflowing drains and other problems.” To address their woes, he wrote to the joint commissioner three days ago to arrange for an inspection of the ward. “The opposition party is unnecessarily making it a political issue. I have no hidden interest,” he added.

The inspection was slated for Tuesday but has now been put off to next week, sources said.

While Munindra claimed the mayor will accompany him on the inspection, Goutham Kumar said, “No way. I will accompany him only if it is a tour of his Jakkur ward.”

Title: Now, drones sow seeds as farming takes hi-tech way
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Founded by a team of Indian Institute of Technology, Guwahati alumni, Marut Drones has been mentored by T-Work... Read More

Hyderabad: Tree plantation has gone hi-tech in Telangana with city-based startup Marut Drones pressing its drones into service for dropping seed balls in Veernapalli in Sircilla as part of the Telangana government’s Haritha Haaram programme.

Explaining the process, Marut Drones co-founder Prem Kumar Vislawath said, drones are first used to survey and map the terrain that helps determine the number of trees to be grown based on various parameters like soil and climate, among others, following which seedballs are created by local communities and dropped by drones in the targeted areas.

On Monday, drones did seeding by releasing over 15,000 seed balls, consisting of Velaga, Gangaravi, Gummadi Teak, Seema Chinta, Raavi and Sitaphal seeds , from around 40 to 50 feet above the ground in Sircilla.

He pointed out that the advantage of using drones is that it can accomplish the task much faster and the path followed by the drones are geotagged, facilitating periodic monitoring of the sown area to collect tree statistics.

“The entire process cuts down on manpower, time, danger to the tree-planters and results in nearly 10-fold reduction in the cost of forest landscape reforestation,” he said.

In fact, the box for releasing the seed balls was 3D-printed with the help of technology developed at T-Works, a state-run incubator for electronics startups.

Founded by a team of Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Guwahati alumni, Marut Drones has been mentored by T-Works and RICH and was recently selected for Facebook’s India Innovation Accelerator Programme.

With its drones being used for seeding, Marut Drones intends to make reforestation scalable through ‘Drone Swarms’ that can plant up to 1 lakh trees a day. The startup has also built India’s first drone to eradicate mosquito larvae and water hyacinth and has tested its solutions in some of the lakes in and around the city.

Title: Telangana: Tippler takes the driver’s seat, puts lives of RTC bus passengers at risk
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Passengers aboard a TSRTC bus at Vikarabad’s Tandur bus station had a ride to forget when a man in a drunken state took to the wheel. On Monday evening, while the actual driver was having a meal, the man got into the bus, took the driver’s seat and started the engine. However, the ride came to an end when the man was forced to stop by enraged passengers who had started objecting to his rash driving.

When questioned by passengers, the man claimed that he was the driver-cum-conductor of the bus. As irate passengers called up the depot to lodge a complaint against their “drunk driver”, authorities told them that the man they were complaining about was not really their driver. Before passengers could catch the man, he gave them the slip and ran away.

Tandur depot manager Rajasekhar told TOI that the bus had been parked near the edge at the depot by the actual driver for passengers to get in. With the bus parked, the bus driver and conductor had gone to the canteen to have their dinner. To their surprise, the bus had vanished upon their return.

Worried, the driver informed the security who immediately launched a search. It was only when they got a call from one of the passengers when they came to know that someone had driven away with the bus.

Following the incident, a complaint was lodged by the depot manager at the Tandur police station. “The police is trying to identify the accused and arrest him,” the depot manager said. Asked how the person could have driven away with the bus, the manager said that since the bus had a self-start switch which the man had used to start the bus which was not locked.

Depot authorities were also told that the man had hit another vehicle while driving the bus. However, upon inspection, no other vehicle was found near the site.

Title: Delhi Air Pollution: Delhi air very poor, no relief till Thursday
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

AQI on Monday was in the higher end of ‘poor’ category at 293 on its index (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Delhi on Monday recorded ‘very poor’ air quality with an AQI of 303, according to System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting and Research (SAFAR).

At 6.40pm on Monday, the PM2.5 reading was 308 in the ‘very poor’ range, while PM10 was 210 in the ‘poor’ range. On Tuesday too, it is expected to be 322 and 249 respectively.

Track the pollution level in your city

According to Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) readings, however, the AQI on Monday was in the higher end of ‘poor’ category at 293 on its index. Data according to CPCB’s central control room showed NCR’s average PM2.5 levels recorded at 148.1 micrograms per cubic metre at 6pm on Monday. The average PM10 levels, at the same time, also nearly two times the safe standards, were recorded at 275 micrograms per cubic metre, data showed.

Pollution levels are likely to remain within the lower end of the ‘very poor’ category till Thursday, when an approaching western disturbance will help clean up the air in the region.

The maximum and minimum temperatures on Monday were 26.7 degree Celsius — three notches above normal — and 9 degree Celsius — two notches below normal — respectively. On Tuesday, partly cloudy sky is expected with mist or shallow fog in the morning. The maximum and minimum temperatures will be around 27 and 10 degrees Celsius, respectively.

Title: Rape of minor at Coimbatore: 5 arrested
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

COIMBATORE: The government railway police (GRP) at Mettupalayam have arrested five people for sexually assaulting a 17-year-old Chennai-based girl

Preliminary inquiry revealed that the incident happened six months ago. “Malarvizhi of Medavakkam, a tout involved in flesh trade, had offered the minor girl a job as a live-in maid. But she handed the girl over to five local youths, who raped her several times,” a police officer said.

The girl’s parents, who came to know about the incident, reprimanded her. “It prompted her to leave the house. She took a train to Mettupalayam and was roaming in the Mettupalayam railway station when call taxi driver Manikandan approached her. He promised to get a job for her in Mettupalayam and also offered to accommodate her in his house. He raped her twice,” the officer said.

The girl left for Chennai after two days. A few days ago, she was taken to a government hospital in Chennai, where doctors confirmed that she was pregnant.

The girl lodged a complaint with GRP Mettupalayam, who registered a case under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 and arrested Jayakumar, Rangaraj, Jebaraj, Malarvizhi and Manikandan two days ago. They were remanded in judicial custody and lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison .

Police are on the lookout for two Medavakkam-based youths in connection with the case, GRP deputy superintendent A Annadurai said. The case will be transferred to the respective police station soon.

Title: Karnataka: Bus fare revision on cards, activists criticise proposal
Content:
With operational costs soaring, all STUs are incurring heavy losses

TimesView An upward fare revision will not just be unfair to passengers, but will also make state transport undertakings less attractive. The whole of Metro Phase 2 will be operational only by 2024 and a dedicated suburban rail project is still way off the track. As such, a robust bus transport is the most feasible option to save Bengaluru’s choking roads. Instead of hiking rates, the government should work out other ways to support the fragile STUs. It could even pick a lesson or two from other states dealing with similar concerns. Setting eyes on profit is fine, but not at the cost of losing patronage, which is already shrinking.

How it works in other states

BENGALURU: Fares of state transport undertakings — BMTC, KSRTC , NWKRTC and NEKRTC — are likely to be hiked to stem losses from rising operational costs. Confirming that discussions along similar lines were on, a senior transport department official said: “Fare revision is inevitable, but we haven’t yet decided if it will be applicable to all corporations or if BMTC will be exempted from it. It’s a policy decision to revise fares.”The proposal, which comes close on the heels of Bengaluru earning the tag of ‘the most traffic congested city in the world’, is likely to further discourage public transport users and add to congestion on roads. In November last year, chief minister BS Yediyurappa said the government would reduce bus fares of STUs to encourage people to use public transport. However, the CM recently backtracked on the promise. Transport minister Laxman Savadi too recently said that there is a ‘demand’ to increase fares.With skyrocketing operational costs, all STUs are incurring heavy losses. Statistics show that at Rs 349.4 crore, BMTC suffered maximum financial loss in 2018-19, followed by KSRTC (Rs 134.9 crore), NWKRTC (Rs 89 crore) and NEKRTC (Rs 68.2 crore).A fare increase between 10%-18% has been proposed, said sources.With state budget round the corner, all four STUs are hoping for a significant allocation to stem losses. According to sources, all STUs had suggested viability gap funding (which supports projects that are economically justified, but not financially viable) from the state government to enhance existing fleet and also expand the same. Currently, STUs are spending about 50% of their outlay on staff wages and 30% on fuel costs. In fact, many of them have already trimmed several schedules to reduce losses.“The government had exempted only BMTC from paying motor vehicles tax, but it still has to pay property tax and GST. We are hoping for a significant allocation for STUs in the budget,” said an official.Despite spiralling fuel costs, fares of STUs haven’t been revised since 2014. However, STUs in Karnataka still have one of the highest fares in the country. BMTC’s daily ridership has fallen to 35.8 lakh in 2018-2019 from 51.3 lakh in 2014-15. While a hike of 18% was announced in September 2018, it was reversed by then chief minister HD Kumaraswamy in less than 30 minutes due to public backlash.Many public transport activists say the move to hike rates could be detrimental as it’ll only increase traffic snarls in the city. “Bengaluru has the highest bus fares in the country. There are thousands of people who actually walk a certain distance because they can’t afford bus fares. When the fares were hiked last time, many people shifted to two-wheelers and illegal transport modes.
