Title: Karnataka: Bus fare revision on cards, activists criticise proposal
Content:
With operational costs soaring, all STUs are incurring heavy losses

TimesView An upward fare revision will not just be unfair to passengers, but will also make state transport undertakings less attractive. The whole of Metro Phase 2 will be operational only by 2024 and a dedicated suburban rail project is still way off the track. As such, a robust bus transport is the most feasible option to save Bengaluru’s choking roads. Instead of hiking rates, the government should work out other ways to support the fragile STUs. It could even pick a lesson or two from other states dealing with similar concerns. Setting eyes on profit is fine, but not at the cost of losing patronage, which is already shrinking.

How it works in other states

BENGALURU: Fares of state transport undertakings — BMTC, KSRTC , NWKRTC and NEKRTC — are likely to be hiked to stem losses from rising operational costs. Confirming that discussions along similar lines were on, a senior transport department official said: “Fare revision is inevitable, but we haven’t yet decided if it will be applicable to all corporations or if BMTC will be exempted from it. It’s a policy decision to revise fares.”The proposal, which comes close on the heels of Bengaluru earning the tag of ‘the most traffic congested city in the world’, is likely to further discourage public transport users and add to congestion on roads. In November last year, chief minister BS Yediyurappa said the government would reduce bus fares of STUs to encourage people to use public transport. However, the CM recently backtracked on the promise. Transport minister Laxman Savadi too recently said that there is a ‘demand’ to increase fares.With skyrocketing operational costs, all STUs are incurring heavy losses. Statistics show that at Rs 349.4 crore, BMTC suffered maximum financial loss in 2018-19, followed by KSRTC (Rs 134.9 crore), NWKRTC (Rs 89 crore) and NEKRTC (Rs 68.2 crore).A fare increase between 10%-18% has been proposed, said sources.With state budget round the corner, all four STUs are hoping for a significant allocation to stem losses. According to sources, all STUs had suggested viability gap funding (which supports projects that are economically justified, but not financially viable) from the state government to enhance existing fleet and also expand the same. Currently, STUs are spending about 50% of their outlay on staff wages and 30% on fuel costs. In fact, many of them have already trimmed several schedules to reduce losses.“The government had exempted only BMTC from paying motor vehicles tax, but it still has to pay property tax and GST. We are hoping for a significant allocation for STUs in the budget,” said an official.Despite spiralling fuel costs, fares of STUs haven’t been revised since 2014. However, STUs in Karnataka still have one of the highest fares in the country. BMTC’s daily ridership has fallen to 35.8 lakh in 2018-2019 from 51.3 lakh in 2014-15. While a hike of 18% was announced in September 2018, it was reversed by then chief minister HD Kumaraswamy in less than 30 minutes due to public backlash.Many public transport activists say the move to hike rates could be detrimental as it’ll only increase traffic snarls in the city. “Bengaluru has the highest bus fares in the country. There are thousands of people who actually walk a certain distance because they can’t afford bus fares. When the fares were hiked last time, many people shifted to two-wheelers and illegal transport modes. If we reduce fares, all these commuters will, in all likelihood, move back to buses,” said a statement from Bangalore Bus Prayaanikara Vedike, an NGO.Experts say making public transport free will reduce traffic congestion, pollution, fuel consumption and offer better quality of life.MumbaiIn Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) 2020-21 budget, Rs 1,500 crore was allocated to enhance bus services of the undertakings. In 2019-20 budget, BMC gave a grant of Rs 1,941.3 crore.KeralaKerala government allocated Rs 1,000 crore special assistance to Kerala RTC to stem losses. It is also providing Rs 20 crore a month to Kerala RTC to pay salaries of employeesTamil NaduIn its budget, the Tamil Nadu government announced that it’d compensate a portion of losses incurred by state transport corporations in terms of fuel hike. Nearly Rs 300 crore has been provided in the budget to compensate hike in diesel prices.Andhra PradeshAndhra Pradesh state government merged Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation with the state government to take care of salaries and other retirement benefits. In 2019-20 budget, it allocated Rs 1,000 crore financial assistance and Rs 500 crore for reimbursement of subsidies given by the corporation to passengers.

Title: Biological E opens Rs 300cr facility at Genome Valley
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Hyderabad: City-based life sciences player Biological E Limited on Monday inaugurated its manufacturing unit spread across 29 acres at Genome Valley in Hyderabad. The plant has been set up with an investment of Rs 300 crore. “This new facility will help our existing vaccines plant enhance the production and manufacture new products which are in the pipeline,’’ managing director Mahima Datla said and added that the facility would generate around 1,000 jobs.

The company also unveiled its new Typhoid Conjugate Vaccine (TCV), an injectable single-dose vaccine to be administered to children who are 6-month old and above as well as adults. The vaccine was developed in partnership with the GSK Vaccines Institute for Global Health, based in Italy’s Siena, which first developed the asset and transferred it to Biological E in 2013.

Subsequent developmental work on TCV was done by the company, including manufacturing process optimisation and scale up, pre-clinical studies and full clinical trials in India, the company said. It will be manufactured in the company’s manufacturing facilities in Hyderabad and is expected to be commercially available within three months.

Biological E has received approval from the Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) to sell vaccine in India and has also submitted the vaccine for WHO pre-qualification (PQ) and registration in other countries.

Inaugurating the unit, Telangana industries and IT minister KT Rama Rao said: “We already produce one-third of the global vaccine requirement. We would like to strengthen our capabilities further and consolidate our position as the disease prevention capital of the world.”

Title: Outside of B’luru, Syngene Int’l opens its first R&D centre in Hyd
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Hyderabad: In a major boost to the life sciences industry in Telangana, Bengaluru-based Syngene International Limited, which is Biocon’s contract research arm, on Monday announced the commissioning of the first phase of its new R&D centre at Genome Valley in Hyderabad.

This is Syngene’s first operational research centre outside Bengaluru and is coming up at an investment of Rs 167 crore. Syngene currently operates through multiple facilities in Bengaluru spread across an area of 1.5 million sq ft.

The company’s centre at Genome Valley, spread across 52,000 sq ft, has around 150 scientists working at the facility. By the end of the year, when the centre will be fully commissioned, it will cover 94,000 sq ft and house around 270 scientists. Initially, the company will offer discovery chemistry services from Hyderabad. In the next phase, other research services will move to this centre providing research to the world’s leading pharmaceutical companies.

The facility was inaugurated Telangana industries and IT minister KT Rama Rao along with Syngene International Ltd managing director Kiran Mazumdar Shaw, who lauded the state government’s efforts towards creating an environment that fosters the growth and development of the biotech industry.

Syngene International CEO Jonathan Hunt said, “With increasing demand for our research services, we needed to find a location that offered the right environment to drive scientific innovation and seamless delivery. This means not just having the ability to build, equip and maintain world class laboratories, we also need to be able to attract top scientists in chemistry, biology, biometrics and other disciplines.”

Inaugurating the unit, KT Rama Rao said that Syngene will act as a “role model” because of its track record of delivering complex research projects at global standards. “With 800-plus pharma, biotech and med-tech companies in the state, Telangana has one of the largest base for life sciences sectors in Asia,” KTR added.

Title: Police set to crack down on history-sheeters in north AP
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Police are taking tough measures against history-sheeters in north Andhra Pradesh, especially in Visakhapatnam, Vizianagaram and Srikakulam districts.

The number of history-sheeters in north Andhra has increased to 5,357 in 2020 with Vizag city limits having the highest--1,187-- followed by Vizianagaram district (1,413), Srikakulam district (1,113) and Vizag Rural (944).

A Trinad Rao, assistant commissioner of police (Task Force, Vizag city), said they are keenly monitoring history-sheeters in their limits. “We have been using resources and data from various wings of police department to keep a tab on active rowdy-sheeters in the city to ensure peace,” he said.

Leaders of the Left parties, including B Lokanatham of CPI(M) said rowdy-sheeters with the support of a few political leaders may indulge in criminal activities in Vizag and Vizianagaram region, where real estate business has picked up following the announcement of the executive capital.

Since majority of the rowdy-sheeters are backed by political leaders, the police have to register cases against their supporters, said Lokanadham.

“Our top priority is to safeguard the city’s image. Apart from counselling the rowdy-sheeters, we will cut down their revenue sources by cracking down on illegal activities,” said a senior police officer.

Title: Bengaluru: Unruly fans assault cop during Darshan’s birthday celebrations outside residence
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The injured head constable in hospital

BENGALURU: A 26-year-old head constable sustained serious injuries after Sandalwood star Darshan’s fans pelted stones and assaulted him while he was on security duty near the actor’s RR Nagar residence on Sunday night.

The fans were celebrating Darshan’s birthday in front of his house. As more than 4,000 people had gathered, about 750 police personnel were deputed there. The injured cop, Devaraj DR, is attached to Jnanabharathi police station.

According to RR Nagar police, cops resorted to mild lathicharge to control the crowd around 12.30am. Devaraj was hit by stones and assaulted. He sustained injuries in his right eye and nose and was shifted to a nearby hospital, where he underwent a surgery on Monday.

RR Nagar police have booked a case against Darshan’s fans and those who organised the birthday celebrations under IPC sections 353 (assault on duty official) and 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from duty). No arrests have been made.

Devaraj is admitted to SSNMC Super Specialty Hospital, RR Nagar, and neither Darshan nor anyone from his fans’ associations have turned up to see him, said a police source.

A neighbour of Darshan also filed a complaint against the fans after they vandalised his Swift Dzire. Residents in the vicinity said the nuisance had become an annual feature. “Though we can’t sleep through the night, we don’t blame fans for coming to their idol’s house on his birthday. But what’s worrying is that every time they vandalise things in the name of celebrations,” said a neighbour who didn’t wish to be named.

A retired employee said, “If police can’t handle the situation, why do they give permission to the actor’s fans to assemble? Some of them, who are drunk, climb compound walls and create nuisance. It is impossible to tell them anything.”

Darshan did not respond to messages and calls from TOI.

Title: Hyderabad gets IMAGE boost, to host India’s first CoE for gaming, VFX
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: In a mega boost to new-age industries, the Telangana government along with the Software Technology Parks of India (STPI) as well as the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY) announced the opening of STPI-IMAGE, which is touted as the country’s first centre of excellence (CoE) for gaming , VFX , computer vision and AI, in Hyderabad.

STPI-IMAGE, spread over 10,000 sq ft, expects to incubate around 25 to 30 startups per year for the next five years. The centre will primarily focus on companies that are working on creating IP in gaming, VFX, AI and computer vision. These government entities plan to invest Rs 19.68 crore over a period of five years in the centre. The applications for startups to be a part of the CoE are open till March 31, 2020.

In the first year, 20 start-ups will be chosen for on-boarding as part of this programme. The selected startups will be assisted with a seed fund of Rs 5 lakh and the funds will be released at regular intervals, based on achieving set milestones, during the programme.

Each startup will be given access to infrastructure and R&D lab facilities for development and validation of solutions from design to prototyping stage.

Inaugurating the CoE, Telangana IT & industries principal secretary Jayesh Ranjan said: “Hyderabad is fast emerging as the best global destination for gaming and AI landscape. That’s one key reason we believe STPI chose to set up its CoE in Hyderabad, and as partners, we are fully committed to this initiative. We have a strong ecosystem...”

Omkar Rai, director-general, STPI, said: “The CoE will bring a paradigm shift in revving up research and innovation in gaming, VFX, computer vision & AI through a robust ecosystem in collaboration with tech partners, industry, investors, industry associations and government, and will bolster indigenous product development while propelling the growth of tech entrepreneurship in the country.

Title: Kochi: Illegal bund yet to be pulled down
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

An aerial view of Chilavannur backwaters

KOCHI: The walkway and cycle path project ( Padmasarovaram ) of Kochi corporation figures in the list of Coastal Regulation Zone (CRZ) violations along Chilavannoor backwaters. Still, the authorities are reluctant to demolish the bund constructed to develop the walkway.

Last month, Kerala Coastal Zone Management Authority (KCZMA) had denied approval for Padamasarovaram project, which envisages construction of a cycle track and walkway across Chilavannoor backwaters connecting Subhash Chandra Bose Road and Sahodaran Ayyappan Road. While denying the approval, KCZMA had made it clear that the construction will obstruct the flow of tidal-influenced waterbody in the flood-prone area. Moreover, vigilance court, Muvattupuzha, has ordered a probe into the allegations that there were financial and other misappropriations pertaining to the project. It was based on a complaint by RTI activist K T Cheshire that the court ordered a probe regarding the allegations that those including additional chief secretary T K Jose and mayor Soumini Jain erred.

Kochi Metro Rail Ltd (KMRL) started the work on Padmasarovaram (now Sarovaram) project in December 2018 on behalf of the corporation. The work on the Rs 9.5-crore project was started without even submitting application for getting CRZ clearance. Later, KCZMA denied nod after it found that the project will obstruct the flow of tidal-influenced waterbody.

Chilavannoor backwaters fall under CRZ-I area, where constructions cannot be allowed. The project is being funded by Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation (Amrut). As per norms, Amrut funds should not be used for any projects which cause damage to the environment.

Title: Left parties hold protest
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: CPM and CPI functionaries, on Monday, staged a massive protest against the BJP’s government’s ‘raw deal’ to Andhra Pradesh and they also alleged that chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy met Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Home Minister Amit Shah for his political needs and not for the state.

Speaking at the protest, B Ganga Rao of CPM and JV Satyanarayana Murthy of CPI alleged that Jagan had utterly failed to get special category status for Andhra Pradesh. “Instead of fighting for special category status for AP, Jagan has been trying to please both Modi and Amit Shah by making frequent visits to New Delhi for his selfish gains and political growth,” Ganga Rao and Satyanarayana Murthy added. tnn

Title: Telangana aims to double size of life sciences industry to $100bn in 2020s
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

American oncologist Dr Carl June receives the Genome Valley award from Telangana minister for industries and I... Read More

Hyderabad: The Telangana government is targeting doubling the size of the state’s life sciences industry to $100 billion this decade, state IT and industries minister KT Rama Rao said here on Monday. “With more than 800 pharma, biotech and medical technology companies, Telangana’s lifesciences sector already has a combined enterprise value of $50 billion…We have a vision to grow this to $100 billion and create four lakh new jobs in this decade,” he said at the inauguration of the BioAsia 2020 .

Biotech giant Biocon Ltd’s CMD Kiran Mazumdar Shaw too said Hyderabad has the potential to make it big in this sector. “Hyderabad has what it takes to be a world-class bio-cluster and now, all you need is to go beyond life sciences institutes…Today, I think the emergence and convergence of technology has led to data science and computational science becoming important part of life tech. I think, Hyderabad has been fortunate to have all of these elements that go to make a great biotech ecosystem,” she said.

KTR, meanwhile, said the state government will be developing the requisite infrastructure and creating a network of stakeholders and skilled workforce to achieve this goal. “One of the key steps we have taken as part of our GRID strategy is to expand Genome Valley, which is among Asia’s largest life sciences clusters. Genome Valley 2.0 masterplan has been prepared and we are looking at improving social infrastructure around the cluster,” he added.

He pointed out Hyderabad contributes over 35% to India’s pharma production and manufactures over 2 billion doses of vaccines every year, accounting for one-third of the global vaccine output.

He also said the 276-acre Medical Devices Park, the country’s largest, has attracted over 20 companies in the last two years.

On the upcoming Pharma City, he said the planning work is complete and environmental clearances are in place. “GoI also has recognized the potential of Pharma City by according the status of National Investment and Manufacturing Zone. We are very close to land allotments to industries,” he added.

KTR said the Department of Biotechnology has agreed to partner with Telangana to set up B-Hub, a first-of-its-kind scale-up manufacturing facility in Genome Valley. The project is expected to be grounded in the next two months.

The BioAsia 2020 organizing committee bestowed the Genome Valley Excellence Award 2020 to Dr Carl H June for his contribution to global lifesciences industry.

Title: Donald Trump’s visit: Cops to take over vacant houses in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

AHMEDABAD: City police, which will provide outer security cover for US President Donald Trump’s visit on February 24, will take over all vacant houses in Motera, Vadaj and Sardarnagar areas to ensure no such house is used for any criminal activity.

Besides taking over around 40 vacant houses, the city police will also take over an under-construction four-storey building near the gate No. 1 of Motera stadium where US President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Narendra Modi will be present for the Namaste Trump event.

“We have been identifying vacant houses in the area and so far we have identified around 40 such houses. At least five police personnel will be deployed at each house to ensure criminal’s can’t use them,” said a police official deployed at the Motera cricket stadium.

Apart from this, police have started round the clock patrolling in Motera causing some inconvenience for local residents.

A resident of Motera said that cops are frequently visiting their housing society and checking identity proofs. “Now we always have to carry our identity proofs with us because of random checks by police. They, barge into our society any time and start inquiries,” said the Motera resident.

When asked, a police official said they will continue checking people in these areas to avoid any security lapse until the US president’s visit is over.

Title: Hyderabad: On weekends, this team makes bus stops spotless
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The group comes together on weekends for their project

HYDERABAD: Bus stops in Miyapur are getting a facelift by the Parivarthan Team. The group which presently consists of around 20 people, has been cleaning up defaced bus shelters for over a month now. So far, they have worked on six bus stops with work on three more stops on their immediate to-do list.

“The effort costs a mere Rs 1,500 for which we raise the amount by ourselves,” says Vinay Vangala, an employee with a private firm, who started the initiative. “We clean up the entire premises. This includes removing flexis and posters stuck to the shelters,” Vangala said and added the work is more about commitment than the money.

As part of their efforts, team members scrape off flexis and posters from top to bottom and give it a fresh coat of paint. The group comes together on weekends for their project. “We continue to monitor if the bus stops remain clean and that there are no fresh items stuck to them,” said team member Srinivas Bellam who works as a facility manager centre. “It is not a one-time job,” he says.

According to Bellam, mere words were not enough if they are not followed by action. “We did not want to just speak out on social media, but wanted to actually make a difference on ground,” he said. Another volunteer, Nanda Kishore, an entrepreneur by trade said that the idea germinated from the need to “fix issues ourselves” instead of simply complaining.

“We wanted to support the GHMC as we understand that officials too have their own set of problems,” Kishore said. From the time they have started their work, more people have approached the group asking for help for clean-ups in their area as well.

Crediting the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC), Vinay Vangala said that the team’s efforts have been helped in an instrumental way by the civic body, which lends some its staff for the clean-up work. ““We hope that we can create more awareness that public property belongs to us, and as custodians we need to take care of it,” Vangala says.

The group plans to make their way towards Madinaguda and Patancheru in the coming months. Volunteers said they would also train others so that more volunteer groups become active across the city.

Title: Baby steps towards a new waste plant
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

New Delhi: Having taken over possession of 42.5 acres of land in Ghonda Gujran from Delhi Development Authority in December, East Delhi Municipal Corporation has finally initiated the exercise of setting up an integrated waste-processing facility there.

A senior EDMC official said National Thermal Power Corporation Limited had started the tendering process for setting up a waste-to-energy plant at the location. Soon, a similar exercise for a bio-methanation plant will start.

“We formed a joint venture with NTPC to implement the project last year. Thereafter, several rounds of meetings were held to decide the future course of action. The project includes setting up of a WTE plant, a bio-methanation plant, an aerobic composter and a small construction and demolition waste plant. The project will consume 2000 tonne of waste every day,” an EDMC official said.

The civic agency expects to start work on the site in another six months after securing the environmental go-ahead. The tentative deadline for the project is December 2021.

Officials say just like Ghazipur WTE, which handles 1,300 metric tonnes of garbage that comes in daily, the new plant will also handle fresh waste. “The facility will be of global standards and odourless, so that locals are not hassled. There will be no unprocessed waste left there,” the official quoted above said.

EDMC generates 2,800 tonnes of waste daily. Of this, around 1,300 tonnes go to the oversaturated Ghazipur landfill. The civic agency has been demanding an alternative site from DDA for a long time. After two people were killed in Ghazipur when a portion of the landfill collapsed in September 2017, the hunt for a new site gained fresh urgency. DDA agreed to hand over land at Ghonda Gujran along with another site at Sonia Vihar.

After objections from environmentalists stalled the move, National Green Tribunal finally approved the handover of the two sites in May last year. Officials said these won’t be traditional dumping sites and, as such, there was no question of harm to the floodplain, as feared by the activists.

After the Ghonda Gujran site was inundated in the monsoon season, DDA decided to carry out a survey before approving the allotment of land to EDMC. An EDMC official said all such issues had now been sorted out and work would start soon at the site.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Fifth corridor of metro rail to connect Vellalore and Ukkadam
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

File photo of Chennai metro

COIMBATORE: Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL), which conducted a feasibility study for the Coimbatore metro rail project, has decided to create a fifth corridor to connect Vellalore and Ukkadam . It has also identified two places, at Press Colony near Periyanaickenpalayam and Chinniyampalayam, to station the trains.

CMRL had selected engineering and consulting firm Systra to conduct feasibility study for implementing the project in the city. The feasibility report suggested four corridors. The first corridor would be 26-kilometre long between Ukkadam and Kaniyur. The second would cover 24 kilometres between Ukkadam and Bilichi near Karamadai on the Mettupalayam Road. The third corridor will cover 42 kilometres between Thanneerpandal on Thadagam Road and Karanampettai on Trichy Road and the fourth will cover 44 kilometres between Karunya Nagar and Ganeshapuram.

Now, CMRL has decided to create a fifth corridor, which will be 11 kilometres long, to connect the integrated bus stand to be constructed at Vellalore at an estimated cost of 178.26 crore, to Ukkadam. “After shifting the bus stand to Vellalore, metro train service from Vellalore to Ukkadam would help commuters reach the city easily,” an official said.

CMRL has identified a plot at Press Colony that belongs to the Union government to station metro trains, apart from a place at Chinniyampalayam. “After getting financial sanction for land acquisition, the revenue department will help CMRL acquire the lands to station the trains,” the official added.

The private firm had submitted details of the development work to be implemented in the city for the metro project to the district administration and the city corporation last November.

Title: Authorities look to attract tourists with special project
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Kozhikode: Kozhikode district panchayat is planning to explore the scenic beauty of rivers in the district . A special project combining river tourism and rural tourism will be prepared to attract foreign and domestic tourists to the riverbanks of Kozhikode.

The project will cover Chaliyar and Iruvanhi river in the first phase. The initiative aims to give employment opportunities to large number of people living on the banks of the two rivers.

“We held a seminar to get ideas and suggestions for the preparation of the river-rural tourism project,” said district panchayat president Babu Parassery. “Our plan is to implement the project with the support of individuals, cooperative firms and local bodies,” he said.

In the initial phase, a set of houses situated on the riverbanks will be identified for introducing home stays or paying guest facilities for tourists. All houses having the facility to accommodate tourists can join the venture.

River tourism is remaining unexplored in Kozhikode despite the presence of many major and minor rivers with scenic viewpoints. The district panchayat is trying to identify more scenic spots and introduce basic amenities for tourists with the support of local residents.

Employment for rural youth is also a major focus, said the district panchayat president. The district panchayat is also joining hands with Responsible Tourism Mission to train the local residents to start tourism-oriented enterprises. Under the river tourism project, the district panchayat is also planning to cooperate with the sand miners. Large number of people, mostly youths, used to engage in sand mining from Chaliyar, Iruvanhi and other rivers in the district. As sand mining is banned at many rivers and the youths have no job, the plan is to provide them job opportunity under the tourism project. Sand miners who are willing to operate the country boats to take tourists for water cruise can join the tourism project.

The river tourism project also aims to ensure protection of rivers. The problems faced by rivers, post flood condition of the rivers and river protection from flood will also be studied before the introduction of the project, the district panchayat president said. TNN

Title: Major fire breaks out at dumping yard
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Kochi: A major fire broke out in the heaps of garbage present at the Kalamassery municipality waste dumping yard on Monday afternoon. The fire was doused by two units of fire tenders from Eloor after a strenuous effort of nearly one hour. The incident led to the billowing of thick smoke in the area causing difficulty to motorists and residents.

According to officials, the incident took place around 2.30pm after someone tried to burn the waste. Wind caused the fire to spread fast. The locals alerted the fire and rescue personnel, who reached the spot by 3pm and by that time the fire spread to nearby heaps of waste. tnn

Title: Tirupati: Pedestrian route sealed off after leopard attack
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

TIRUPATI: The pedestrian route leading to Tirumala through Srivari Mettu was sealed off by the vigilance and security department of Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams after the carcass of a stag was found in the middle of the pedestrian route on Monday evening.

TTD’s vigilance and security wing sleuths, who inspected the spot, suspect that a leopard on the prowl could have killed the stag and left behind the carcass after spotting the movement of devotees along the route.

The sleuths confirmed that the carcass of a wild stag was found near the 250th step leading to Tirumala along the Srivari mettu pedestrian route on Monday evening.

Pilgrims trekking along the pedestrian route, who first spotted the carcass of the wild stag, had told TTD’s vigilance wing that they had heard a loud growl emanating from the nearby forest area, following which the vigilance wing sleuths reached the spot and decided to seal off the Srivari mettu pedestrian route till 7 am on Tuesday morning.

TTD’s forest department staff were also roped in to confirm whether the wild stag was killed by a leopard or by a group of wild dogs, which are commonly spotted in the nearby forests here.

Title: Cash incentive for Bengali Hindus who marry into Assamese families
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

GUWAHATI: Bengali Hindu brides and grooms in Assam choosing Assamese Hindu partners could receive around Rs 40,000 each as financial assistance under a scheme proposed by the state Linguistic Minority Development Board “to strengthen the bond between the two communities”.

“Couples in inter-community marriages are often deprived of property rights, besides facing a social boycott. We intend to assist such couples in setting up shops, beauty salons and also in farming,” Board chairman Alok Kumar Ghose said. “The proposal was submitted to the state government two days ago.” A website is already being designed for Bengali-Assamese Hindu couples to register their details online.

While Ghose claimed the initiative would foster amity, the All Assam Minority Students’ Union termed the proposal “divisive” and accused the board of attempting religious polarisation. “The government has been taking steps to create divisions between Hindus and Muslims. The board’s proposal is just another example of this. Rather than providing assistance along religious lines, the board could have extended help to any financially unstable Bengali person marrying into any religion or community,” said Rejaul Karim Sarkar , president of the student union.

All Assam Bengali Youth Students’ Federation president Samrat Bhowal said his organisation would back any initiative to remove “mistrust” between the Bengalis and Assamese. “There have been some incidents of late that have created mistrust between the two communities. This (the offer of financial assistance to inter-community Hindu couples) is a timely approach and we welcome it.”

Title: Soon, rythu bazaars to sate your organic food appetite
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Visakhapatnam district administration has developed a proposal to launch organic rythu bazaars on an experimental basis in the city.

The city has at present two organic hotels and demand for organic food items is on the rise.

Discussions are at present underway with stakeholders, including organic vegetable farmers, millet farmers and other producers. The department of civil supplies and marketing plans to introduce the bazaars this summer. Based on the public’s reception to the initiative, organic rythu bazaars may also be introduced in Vijayawada, Tirupati, Kakinada and Rajamundry.

Speaking to TOI, Visakhapatnam joint collector L Shiva Shankar said that initially, two of the 13 rythu bazaars in the city will sell organic vegetables. The bazaars at Seethammadhara and MVP Colony have been selected, in view of the large number of customers they draw.

“We are still negotiating with the stakeholders. I will be able to confirm this project within the next week. We plan to hold these bazaars once every week, every Tuesday at Seethammadhara and every Saturday at MVP Colony,” the joint collector said.

J Kumara Swamy, founder-member of the Andhra Pradesh Organic Farmers’ Welfare Association said that they have requested the government to not include in the proposal persons with political affiliations. He added that they have requested that only genuine organic farmers be allowed to sell produce and to ensure that other districts also adopt the concept of organic rythu bazaars.

On the feasibility of organic rythu bazaars, Kumara Swamy said the district tops in organic farming in the state, with nearly 15 per cent of land devoted to the organic farming of various crops, such as paddy, millets and vegetables.

An official with the agriculture department said mandals such as Chodavaram, Anandapuram, Padmanabha and Payakaraopeta have a high proportion of land under organic farming.

“Farming in some villages is completely organic as farmers have adopted Zero Budget Natural Farming (ZBNF) method,” said JV Ratnam, an environmentalist.

Title: Jamia violence: Academic ambitions take hit, students seek crores for police action
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Mohammad Mustafa, who is pursuing a master’s degree in social exclusion and Inclusive policy, has demanded a c... Read More

NEW DELHI: On December 15, when Shayaan Mujeeb , a third-year Bachelor of Business Administration student , was in the old library building , or the Ibn-e-Sina Block, at Jamia Millia Islamia , when he heard a din at the gates of the university. Mujeeb says that what followed left him unable to go out of his house for two months.

It was only due to exams that Mujeeb ventured out of his house and reached the Jamia campus on Monday. He is among the six students who have filed a petition in Delhi high court seeking monetary compensation for the “physical pain and mental trauma” they suffered when police swarmed the Jamia Millia Islamia campus in pursuit of anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protest that day.

The 21-year-old from Amroha, Uttar Pradesh, is undergoing treatment at Jaypee Hospital in Noida, His father, a government official, said, “He has two rods in his legs and will need many more months before he can walk.” The youngster says that “my plans to undertake a master’s degree course have been derailed” and has asked for a compensation of Rs 2 crore.

On December 15, Mujeeb recalled, “Policemen barged in and began beating us. Seven-eight of us hid around the lawns, but the policemen found us and thrashed us.” He was hit on his legs and fell to the ground, unable to move until some students helped him an hour later.

Mohammad Mustafa, who is pursuing a master’s degree in social exclusion and Inclusive policy, has demanded a compensation of Rs 1 crore. “I wanted to sit for the civil services exams this year, but I can’t because the cops injured both my hands. The metacarpal on my left hand yet to heal, ” he added.

The 26-year-old from Paschim Champaran in Bihar thought the cops wouldn’t resort to beating. In fact, when a cop shouted “chahiye azadi?” he replied, “Nahi, sarkari naukri chahiye.” But he was thrashed “like a criminal”, though he claimed he wasn’t a protest participant.

Title: JAIPUR: Anti-Corruption Bureau have proof against arrested transport staff
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

A few of the arrested accused in ACB office on Monday

JAIPUR: A day after the Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) busted a bribery nexus between a few transport department officials and agents, sleuths said they had enough evidence against the 15 arrested. The accused were presented before the ACB court on Monday.

Among the arrested are eight transport department officials and seven agents. The ACB had claimed that they had recovered Rs 1.5 crore from their possession. Few months ago, transport company owners had filed complaint against some transport officials who threatened to cancel their registrations and allegedly demanded bribes through their agents.

“Seizure of money from their possessions is one aspect, but we have got a lot of other evidence against the arrested. They were involved in threatening the owners of vehicles and transporters,” said Dinesh MN, additional director general (ADG), ACB.

The ACB had to arrange a bus for the transportation of accused from its office to its court. It is one of the biggest ever raids conducted by the bureau.

“They were on our radar for the past six months. We had been closely monitoring their activities for the past six months. We have documentary evidence against them,” he said.

He said two transport inspectors, Sukhveer Choudhary and Rajiv Jain, are still out of ACB net. “They have fled and we are searching for them,” he said.

On Monday, ACB sleuths continued their searches. ACB director general of police (DGP) Alok Tripathy said they broke the seal of Tanushree Logistics office and claimed to have found documents of exchange of bribery and seized Rs 16.9 lakh.

They have also searched SUV owned by one Sheojiram Gadwal, a resident of Dudu, who has fled. They found records of exchange of money.

Title: Coimbatore: Deadly phone snatchers still at large
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

COIMBATORE: The rural police are collecting CCTV footage from commercial establishments to trace the three mobile phone snatchers , who murdered a college student for refusing to hand over his phone in Sulur on Saturday night.

“Six special teams are working round-the-clock to crack the case. We hope to solve it within two days,” said a police officer. “The teams collected some surveillance footage and also verified registration plates of some motorcycles. The registration number plates were fake, and the footage were not clear enough to identify the faces of the motorcycle riders and pillion riders.”

Meanwhile, people caught a 20-year-old man red-handed while he attempted to snatch a mobile phone from a man at Kovilpalayam police limit on Monday evening. Two of his accomplices managed to escape. Police are grilling the youth to verify his involvement in the Sulur incident.

A three-member gang had stabbed D Tamilselvan, 20, of Nadu Arasur to death when he refused to hand over his mobile phone on Saturday night. He was a third year Mechanical Engineering student in a private college.

Ten minutes later, the same gang snatched the phone of 25-year-old K Mahalingam of Arasur and stabbed him using a knife. They escaped in his motorcycle. They abandoned the two-wheeler a kilometre away from the crime scene, after Mahalingam, with the help of a motorist, chased them.

Title: Kerala: Aadhaar likely to be must in land deals
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose.

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Following the decision to link details of land holders with their respective Aadhaar numbers, the government is also likely to take a favourable decision on the proposal by the registration department to make it mandatory to submit Aadhaar number of buyers and sellers of properties during property registrations .

A proposal in this regard from IG, registrations, on the basis of recommendations from the Centre, (accessed by TOI) is pending before the government for more than a year now. The department of land resources under the ministry of rural development of the Centre, had written to the states in 2017, that Aadhaar authentication should be made mandatory for registration of properties for identification and prevention of benami property transactions.

As per directions from the Centre, every sub-registrar office should have provisions for readily enrolling citizens and provide them with Aadhaar number if they do not have one. Once the proposal comes into force, an applicant executing the registration of a deed will be required to provide the Aadhaar number along with other details. According to registration department sources, once approved by the government, all the registration under an Aadhaar number can be easily tracked from any office. Also, since the process of integration of the registration department with the revenue department is underway, the Aadhaar details will be readily available in the village records once the property registration is completed.

Even before the Centre asked the states to use Aadhaar for property registration, the state revenue department had in 2012 come up with the idea of unique thandaper number (UTN), a unique 10-digit alphanumeric number. The first two digits would be alphabets that would capture the details like district, taluk and village and the remaining eight digits would be the unique thandaper assigned to each land holder in the state. However, the UDF government did not proceed with the idea.

“Now that a policy decision has been taken, the government is likely to give clearance for the proposal of the registrations department as well. This decision to link land details with Aadhaar is the best in terms of implementing the Kerala Land Reforms Act in its true letter and spirit,” a senior government officials said.

At present, individuals are allowed to hold a maximum of 7.5 acres and families a maximum of 15 acres. Since there is no single number linking all transactions, it is impossible to know how much land an individual or a family is holding in various parts of the state. Once Aadhaar is linked, the land held under a single Aadhaar number can easily be detected.

Title: Vizianagaram hopes to shine bright on state’s tourism map
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The historic and picturesque district of Vizianagaram has the potential to become the state’s tourist hot spot. Despite being known for its beautiful reservoirs, picnic spots and historic locales, the district has failed to make the best use of its tourism potential, and the reasons are varied.

One of the main reasons is lack of organised tourist infrastructure. There has been little or no promotion of its locales, road infrastructure is inadequate in tourist places, nor are there enough good places for the tourists to stay. Things, however, might be changing for the better. Tourism department officials say though a lot of ground work was done in the last five years to identify places with tourism potential, project grounding was never done. Now, the government is reviewing the tourism policy, and it might signal good tidings for the district.

PNV Lakshmi Narayana, tourism and culture officer for Vizianagaram district, said 20 tourist destinations have been identified to be developed in the district. “Among those are the three reservoir hot spots — Gosthani, Thatipudi and Thotapalli — which have been earmarked for reservoir tourism projects. The other attractions include Kumili village, Mukam estuary, Chintapalli beach and other places of historical relevance such as the old Bobbili mud fort, which witnessed the battle of Bobbili fought in the mid-18th century involving the French led by Bussy,” Lakshmi Narayana said.

“Initially, we did introduce boat services for tourists in Thotapalli and Thatipudi, and plans were also drawn to make Thatipudi a water sports and adventure enclave, but the funds were not adequate. Now, with the government reviewing the tourism policy, we are planning to give Vizianagaram its due prominence on the state’s tourist map,” the tourism officer added.

Vizianagaram’s potential for tourism can be gauged by looking at the numbers. The footfall for last year was 58 lakh, out of which over 2,000 were foreigners. Most tourists visited Pydithalamma, Govindapuram and Punyagiri temples, besides Thatipudi reservoir and Vizanagaram fort. The numbers can only go up now.

Title: Two guests collapse and die after consuming liquor at a wedding feast
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Bareilly: At least two people died in Nagala Chaturbhanpur village under Dhanari police station limits of Sambhal district after consuming liquor at a wedding feast on the intervening night of Sunday and Monday.

The feast had been thrown by village resident Kalyan Singh on the occasion of his daughter’s wedding. Eyewitnesses said the two people started vomiting while guests were enjoying dinner. They were rushed to the hospital, where doctors declared they were “brought dead”.

SP Yamuna Prasad quashed rumours that the liquor was poisonous, saying, “It doesn’t seem the liquor was poisonous, as other guests had also consumed the same alcohol at the party. The bodies have been sent for autopsy. The matter is being investigated.”

According to police, Kalyan Singh has said he didn’t serve any liquor at the feast, that the two victims — Tauki Singh (45) of neighbouring Saimla village and his cousin Urman (46) — must have brought the liquor with them, or bought and consumed it before arriving at his home.

“Upon arriving, Tauki and Urman went to have dinner, after which they suddenly started vomiting. Some of my relatives took them to hospital, where they were declared brought dead,” Singh said.

The Nagala Chaturbhanpur village head and other locals claimed they died from consuming hooch. Police have recovered an empty liquor bottle from the site.

On being informed, the DM also reached the spot to take stock. He said, “During interrogation, it was learnt that both deceased had consumed branded liquor manufactured by Mansurpur distillery in Shamli. Some other guests had also consumed the same liquor before arriving for the function and eating dinner. The cause of death will be clear once the post-mortem reports arrive. Meanwhile, probe is underway.”

He added that excise department has been instructed to carry out an intensive drive to eradicate sale of hooch in the area.

Title: Jaipur: Enforcement Department busts gold racket, seizes cash & gold worth Rs 15 crore
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Enforcement Department seizes cash & gold worth Rs 15 crore

JAIPUR: The Enforcement Department’s zonal office (Jaipur) on Monday seized foreign and Indian currency worth Rs 3.75 crore and over 39 kg of gold and silver in raids in multiple cities against jewellers associated with an alleged gold-smuggling hawala racket. The total seizure was worth nearly Rs 15 crore.

The raids were conducted in Jaipur, Kolkata and Chennai under the provisions of the Foreign Exchange Management Act (FEMA) with the ED claiming that the action has led to detection of “huge evasion” of customs duty, GST and income tax.

“Searches at various premises in Jaipur, Kolkata and Chennai resulted in seizure of unaccounted Indian and foreign currency worth Rs 3.75 crore, gold bar and jewellery weighing 26.97 kg and silver weighing 12.22 kg along with incriminating documents. Electronic and digital devices seized are still to be examined and may lead to further details of illegal dealings,” the ED said.

According to ED sources, sleuths got reliable inputs that M/s Maharaja Jewellers and its proprietor Tara Chand Soni, M/s Bhagwati Jewellers through its proprietor Ram Gopal Soni, Ladiwala Associates through its proprietor Honey Ladiwala of Jaipur were purchasing smuggled gold bars from one Harsh Bothra based in Chennai.

Acting on the information, it was found that various individuals were involved in smuggling of gold bars and subsequent dispatch of those to Jaipur. Gold bars were mainly arriving in Jaipur via Kolkata and had high purity level, the ED said.

The suspects used to remove the foreign mark of manufacturer or bank engraved or embossed on the gold bars and then smuggle those into the country, the ED said, adding those were then dispatched to various domestic markets by different modes of transportation to escape the scanner of enforcement agencies.

The accused jewellers did not account for jewellery manufactured from smuggled gold and the illegal funds generated were then transferred through hawala agents based in these cities, the probe agency said.

Electronic and digital devices seized were yet to be examined and may lead to further details of illegal dealings.

Title: MP Gambhir visits Ghazipur, chalks out plan to treat waste
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

New Delhi: East Delhi MP Gautam Gambhir inspected the Ghazipur landfill along with senior officials on Tuesday and held a review meeting about its condition. It was decided that talks would be initiated with all ministries concerned on a priority basis to find the best possible solutions to accelerate the pace of treating legacy waste left by a trommel machine after segregating waste.

The participants also focused on pursuing the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) afresh to utilise the soil left even after processing legacy waste in road filling.

In September 2019, EDMC started segregating and processing the waste at Ghazipur landfill by using a trommel-cum-ballistic machine, which is basically a gigantic cylindrical sieve that sorts the waste into detritus of different sizes and types for suitable treatment. The machine segregates 640 metric tonnes of waste daily, which is bringing down the height of the garbage dump at Ghazipur.

“Getting the height of the landfill down is my biggest priority and I will take every possible step for it,” Gambhir said. East Delhi Municipal Corporation commissioner Dilraj Kaur, mayor Anju Kamalkant and the joint secretary of Swachh Bharat Mission under the Union housing and urban development ministry were present at the meeting.

In 2016, there were efforts to make NHAI use at least 65% of the then 13 million metric tonnes of garbage at the landfill in road embankments along the Delhi-Meerut Expressway. However, the project didn’t materialise. The hurdles included high cost to excavate and process the garbage.

Title: Pune: Cops rescue six women from spa in housing society
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Kondhwa police on Sunday busted a sex racket operating from a spa in a housing society in the NIBM Annexe Road area and rescued six women.

The police have arrested the spa operator and booked the flat owner and a woman under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act. “Search is on for the other two,” an officer from the Kondhwa police said.

A police team comprising senior inspector Vinayak Gaikwad and inspector Mahadeo Kumbhar raided the spa following a tip-off. “The team found six women forced into flesh trade by the spa owner. They were rescued and sent to a correction home on Sunday,” the officer said.

The officer said the rescued women were in the age group of 23 and 33 years. “They are from Mizoram, Assam, Manipur, Madhya Pradesh and Nashik and were living in various parts of Pune. They would be sent to their native places following the completion of legal formalities,” the officer said.

Title: YS Jaganmohan Reddy: Andhra Pradesh CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy to launch 3rd phase of Kanti Velugu today
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

TIRUPATI: Andhra Pradesh chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy formally launched the third phase of the Kanti Velugu programme in Kurnool on Tuesday.

The initiative, which is aimed at providing free eye care to all, was launched at the STBC grounds at 11am.

The free eye screening and provision of spectacles after cataract operations would be held in six phases within a span of three years. The first and second phases of the programme covered school children.

Jagan has also laid the foundation stone for health sub-centres as part of the government’s ‘Nadu-Nedu’ programme.

Title: Pension, land issues raised at collectorate
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Grievance day at the collectorate has recently seen large turnouts.

This week 750 petitioners came forth with their pleas.

District collector V Vinay Chand, joint collectors L Siva Shankar and J Vengopal Reddy and other officials attended the grievance meet.

The petitions largely related to land issues and many petitioners sought the help of the collectorate to look into irregularities in online records. There were also petitions regarding the allotment of pension and land for house construction.

Some petitioners said they were yet to receive Rythu Bharosa payouts while others flagged irregularities in granting pattas by ignoring court directives. A vast majority of petitioners sought reapproval for pension benefits.

Title: Tirupati: Verdict in 5-year-old’s rape and murder case today
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

TIRUPATI: The special POCSO court on Monday postponed the verdict in the rape-and-murder of a five-year-old girl to Tuesday.

The accused Mohammad Rafi (27) had filed a recall petition with I Additional District and Sessions Judge, Chittoor, M. Venkata Harinath.

A five-year-old girl was found dead at the precincts of KNR Convention at Chenetha Nagar in Angallu in Chittoor district on November 8, 2019.

The girl was seen playing with an unidentified youth, who had befriended her by taking her photographs in his phone on the night of November 7.

On November 8, around 6.15 am, the girl was found dead with minor injuries on the back side of her waist, stomach, abdomen and feet.

Based on the complaint given by the victim’s parents, a case was registered at Mudivedu Police Station.

Madanapalle sub division police led by deputy superintendent of police K Ravi Manoharachari verified CCTV footage and found the girl was lured by an unidentified person with whom she was moving closely and walked out of the function hall at around 9.54 pm on November 7.

After analysing the CCTV footage and based on the details given by eyewitnesses, a portrait of the suspect was drawn and circulated on social media and police stations across the state.

The police got inputs from various quarters and it led them to Mohammad Rafi, a native of Basinikonda, who was arrested on November 16. The police produced him before the court the next day.

The evidence from the scene of offence was sent to Forensic Science Laboratory (FSL) and the report was submitted to the court in 10 days.

It was found that the accused was involved in a similar rape case involving a minor at nearby Basinikonda in 2008 but was acquitted.

Chittoor SP S Senthil Kumar said the accused had admitted to raping the child before committing the murder .

The charge sheet was filed on December 10, within 17 working days from the date of arrest, though a 90-day period is allowed for filing charge sheet in rape cases.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Bhopal: 3000 students get degrees at IGNOU’s 33rd convocation
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The 33rd convocation of IGNOU centre

BHOPAL: The 33rd convocation of IGNOU centre ( Bhopal and Jabalpur) was held in the state capital on Monday. Barkatullah University’s vice-chancellor Prof RJ Rao was the chief guest for the occasion. During the convocation, Apoorvi Gautam (philosophy), Abdul Aqueel (PG diploma in hotel operations) and Shivani Jatav (diploma in women development) were awarded gold medals.

In all, 3000 students were awarded degrees during the convocation. 922 students were from Jabalpur, while 1888 belonged to Bhopal. Addressing the gathering, regional director (IGNOU), UC Pandey said that distance learning has played an important role in our country. He also shed light on the work being done by the IGNOU Bhopal centre. “Despite several challenges, IGNOU is striving for betterment this can be gauged from the fact that every year several thousand students get their degrees from the university,” said Pandey. Chief guest Prof Rao in his address to the students said that IGNOU has set a benchmark in the education sector. “Youth today has a lot of responsibility to make the future of the country. Students getting degrees from IGNOU should play their best role in shaping the future of the country,” said Prof Rao.

Title: Jamia Violence: Jamia Millia Islamia students question release of ‘vague video’
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

NEW DELHI: Three new videos were released on Monday morning that appear to show not only police beating students at Jamia Millia Islamia on December 15, but also protesters apparently entering the campus and some students with brickbats in their hands. Student group Jamia Coordination Committee alleged on Monday that Delhi Police was leaking “vague videos to hide their actions”. Other students believed that if some had stones in their hands, it was to defend themselves against the thrashing and tear-gassing by the cops.

Members of Jamia Coordination Committee clarified that they did not have any videos of the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protests of December 15 in their possession. “The manner in which these videos are being leaked... there appears to be a bid to paint Jamia students as culprits,” observed Safoora Zargar, JCC member.

The Jamia Millia administration, which has distanced itself from the videos that came online from 1am on Monday, has reiterated that it did not leak the recordings. Waseem Ahmed Khan, proctor of the varsity, said, “We are not sure who is leaking the videos; it is the job of the police to find out.” Khan also expressed doubts about the authenticity of the videos in circulation and said that they required to be investigated.

The videos corroborate the sequence of the police action in Jamia. Tanjil Ahmed Choudhury, a final year BEd student and one of the injured trio highlighted in graffiti near the university stadium walls, recalled being at the campus gates around 5.30pm that day when he hear the crack of bursting teargas shells. “When we saw smoke billowing, I and a senior student decided to stay put because we had heard of the violence near the Mata Ki Mandir at southeast Delhi’s New Friends Colony. We thought the police officers would not enter the university campus,” said Choudhury. “But policemen rushed in and began beating the students. As I ran towards the central canteen, I saw teargas shells being lobbed at us. The panicky students ran to the new and the old library buildings nearby.”

A student confirmed that some people had picked up stones and bricks. “The students felt that they had to defend themselves against the policemen,” he asserted.

The videos, which have the watermark of student-run news organisation, show police entering through the library door on the ground floor, making the students there near the gate before raining blows on them. They can also be seen breaking the CCTV cameras. Among the many students affected, Shayaan Mujeeb, 21, was hit on his legs and is still undergoing treatment.

Mohammad Mustafa and Mohammad Minhajuddin, the other two names invoked in the Jamia graffiti, too heard the commotion. “There were many students running up from the ground floor and screaming that police were attacking them. To cope with the teargas, many had tied handkerchiefs around their faces,” remembered Mustafa. The masters student had both his arms fractured and even got his laptop damaged during the melee. Minhajuddin, who lost vision in one eye, offered similar details of the incident.

Title: Covid-19: Vishwajit Rane for ban on tourists from Maharashtra, Karnataka
Content:
Vishwajit Rane

PANAJI: Health minister Vishwajit Rane on Tuesday said he has proposed a ban on entry of tourists through road from the bordering states of Maharashtra and Karnataka for “at least two months”, as a precautionary measure against coronavirus The decision, Rane said, needs to be taken in the interest of the state. “A lot of tourists come from the neighbouring states in four-wheelers. It could become a disaster point,” he said, adding CM Pramod Sawant should take a call.“I have sought advice from Union health minister Harsh Vardhan to see how we can block the borders. We have to at some point seal the borders with the neighbouring states. I have moved a parallel note in this regard to the chief minister,” Rane said.He said only two entry points could be kept open for vehicles bringing in essential supplies into Goa.Goa relies on the neighbouring states for the supply of vegetables and grains.While there are four entry points into Goa from Maharashtra, there are three routes from Karnataka.Both the states have reported Covid-19 positive cases and one death each, while Goa is yet to report anyone positive, while four suspects have been placed in isolation.Rane said the state government would also ensure that it keeps track of railway passengers. “Rail travelers will be checked,” he said.A senior health official said it would be difficult to conduct checks at border points, as they do not have adequate manpower to do the job. “We will be left with fewer doctors to conduct surveillance, if border checking is undertaken,” he said.

Title: PCMC for ‘rational’ property tax system to boost revenue
Content:
Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Taxes for old properties in Pimpri Chinchwad assessed in 2006-07 may increase by up to 2.5 times if the civic administration has its way.The property tax department of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) has proposed rationalization of the taxes of these properties. It claimed that the move would fetch an additional revenue of Rs100-Rs150 crore in the 2020-21 financial year.“There will be no change in the taxes on the new properties,” municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar told TOI after presenting the draft budget of 2020-21 with an outlay Rs6,627.99 crore and revised budget of 2019-20 with a Rs 6,187-crore outlay to PCMC standing committee chairperson Vilas Madigeri on Monday.Though the draft budget has not proposed any increase in the property tax rates, the civic body is eyeing a tax rationalization to reduce the difference in the taxes of the old and new properties in an area.Hardikar said, “The rateable value of properties was frozen in some areas in 1996. The value was subsequently changed in a way that the old properties were not affected. This has created a massive gap between the taxes of the old and new properties in an area.”He added that the civic body would consider the depreciation of old properties while conducting rationalisation. “This will lead to an increase in the property tax of the old properties by 2-2.5 times. The municipal commissioner has powers to decide the rateable value of properties and there is no need to take the general body’s (GB) approval for it. Properties assessed before 2006-07 will be identified for rationalisation. These constitute 30-40% of the total properties in the city,” Hardikar said.Among the other major highlight of the draft budget proposals are the plan to raise Rs400 crore through bonds for environmental services and water supply projects. Hardikar said, “We will need around Rs600 crore in the next few years for implementing projects to have water security for the next 30 years. We want to implement projects to bring water from the Bhama Askhed and Andra dams. We also want to increase the pumping capacity of the Ravet pumping station. But the annual income of the department is only Rs75 crore.”

Title: Vasundhara Raje: Bungalow remains with Vasundhara Raje
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Former Chief Minister of Rajasthan Vasundhara Raje


JAIPUR: The state has government on Monday informed the Rajasthan High court that former chief minister Vasundhara Raje will continue to occupy bungalow number 13 in the Civil Lines, Jaipur, while the bungalow no-5 has been vacated by former chief minister Jagannath Pahadia . Raje and Pahadia have already returned the vehicles allotted to them along with the services of drivers. The information was given by the state government facing a contempt notice in connecting to the petition challenging allotment of government bungalow to the former chief ministers and facilities given to them. The previous Raje-government’s law on allowing free lifelong facilities to ex-CMs was struck down by HC and then upheld by the SC. “It is humbly submitted that Raje continues to occupy the Bungalow no 13 since she being entitled for it as a member of legislative assembly,” the reply filed in the court said. The bench comprising Justice Sabina and Justice NS Dhadha has given April 20 as the next date of hearing.

Title: Duo shot in south Delhi encounter had planned to kill Ghaziabad politician
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Two criminals, Raja Qureshi and Ramesh Bahadur, killed in an encounter with Delhi Police Special Cell in Pul P... Read More

NEW DELHI: The two criminals who were killed in an encounter with Special Cell near Pul Prahladpur on Monday had hatched a conspiracy to kill a politician in Ghaziabad . However, the politician got know about it and informed police after which the criminals put the plan on hold. A probe is on to find out who had paid them to carry out the murder.

The criminals, Raja Qureshi and Ramesh, were found involved in back-to-back robberies in north, northwest and northeast Delhi. Qureshi had been trying to establish supremacy in the areas to gain followers and create terror among businessmen. He had roped in Ramesh by promising him a share in the contract amount.

Teams led by ACPs Lalit Mohan Negi and Hriday Bhushan had been tracking the duo for the past few months. They found that to establish clout in the region, Qureshi had murdered his associates claiming that they had turned into police informers.

Last week, Qureshi had attacked two policemen at a builder’s office in Karawal Nagar and asked them whether police knew who he was. When one of the cops replied in the negative, he placed his pistol on his abdomen and opened fire.

A sensational robbery committed by the duo at a shop in Khajuri Khas was captured on CCTV. They carried out the crime by holding the shop owner and a customer at a gunpoint. They had also robbed a businessman at Ashok Vihar last month.

What is startling for police is the huge amount of firearms found with the duo. Police seized 69 rounds of different bores and three pistols from their bags. The role of Loni-based arms dealers is being probed.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Oppose the propose tariff hike? MPERC seeks your suggestion
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: After discoms submitted a petition before Madhya Pradesh Electricity Regulatory Commission (MPERC) seeking 5.28% tariff hike for domestic consumers against Rs 2000 crore losses for financial year 2020-21, the regulator has sought objections from the stakeholders over this demand by March 7. This hike has been sought to bridge the gap of around Rs2000 crore in the estimated figures of income and expenditure for financial year 2020-21.Power tariff is determined on the basis of projected consumption and sale of energy i.e., before the financial year for which the tariff hike is sought had actually started and true-up losses are actual revenue losses, which are filed by discoms after actual consumption and payments, i.e., after the end of the financial year for which ARR was filed. If the commission allows the ARR petition of the discoms, then the monthly energy bill of an average consumer — who uses two ACs, a couple of fans, an LED TV and five LED bulbs, or about 425 units per month will go up by at least Rs200 from Rs3600, which he/she is paying at current prices.It is noteworthy that prior to this, discoms had also sought a hike against true-up petitions for years 2014-15, 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18, which amount to Rs25,000 crore and urged the MPERC to recover these losses from consumers by increasing the power tariff. And then additional hike was sought against losses of Rs 5000 crores incurred in the financial year 2018-19.Unlike ARR petitions which are based on the estimated income and losses, true-up petitions are based on the actual income and losses in the financial year and these are submitted after the tariff period is over, urging the commission to allow the discom to recover it through the petitions filed for seeking tariff hike in next financial year.After receiving the objections from stakeholders till March 7, MPERC will hold a public hearing in the matter to decide the petitions.

Title: Kerala: 14-day home quarantine a must for Wuhan returnees
Content:
Malayali students from Wuhan who were tested negative for COVID-19 after spending 14 days in isolation wards i... Read More

KOCHI: Malayali students from Wuhan who tested negative for novel coronavirus COVID-19 ) after spending 14 days in isolation wards in Delhi and Manesar, will need to compulsorily undergo another 14 days of home quarantine on their return to Kerala . They are set to be discharged in a phased manner from Monday.“Though they have tested negative, as a matter of extra caution, we have decided that these students will need to be quarantined for 28 days. Since they have completed 14 days in isolation ward, they will be home quarantined for the remaining days here,” said Dr Amar Fettle, state nodal officer (public emergency), currently in charge of anti-coronavirus effort.Of the 654 evacuees who were brought back from Wuhan on February 1 and 2 in two Air India Boeing 747 aircrafts after the outbreak of the virus in China, around 110 are Malayalis. They were housed at two facilities; 406 at an Indo-Tibetan Border Police facility at Chhawla, Delhi and the remaining at an army centre in Manesar, Haryana. Majority of students are from Kollam district (30).The state health department has asked the student’s relatives not to rush to the airport to receive them. Instead, only one person has been asked to pick up the student from the airport in a non-ac vehicle. “They have been asked to keep the window down and should not stop anywhere on the way home for shopping or eating,” said a health official.Each district team working on COVID-19 has been provided with details of those who are reaching here. The district team has contacted family members and asked them to take necessary measures to prepare for home quarantine.

Title: Workshop owner bludgeoned to death, four held
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Four men were arrested late on Monday evening on the charge of bludgeoning a 45-year-old owner of an engineering workshop to death at Biradwadi in Khed taluka , about 35km from Pune, following a quarrel in the morning. Their three accomplices are at large.

The Chakan police identified the deceased as Harishchandra Kisan Dete of Bhairavnagar in Dhanori. “Dete was the owner of the VHD engineering workshop in Biradwadi. The main suspect, Jeevan Dongare , of Biradwadi and three others are in the police custody,” Ram Jadhav, assistant commissioner of police (Pimpri Chinchwad), said.

Jadhav said prima facie probe revealed that Dete’s murder was fallout of a quarrel, which happened in the morning on the premises of the workshop.

Senior inspector Kalyan Pawar of the Chakan police told TOI that for the past year, Dongare’s estranged wife had been working at Dete’s workshop. “Dongare, who had shifted to Mumbai, used to suspect the woman of infidelity,” he said.

Recently, Dongare moved to Biradwadi and started working as an autorickshaw driver. “Around 10am on Monday, he went to the workshop and started harassing his estranged wife when Dete intervened and reprimanded him,” Pawar said.

Around 3pm, Dongare returned to the workshop with his six accomplices and began abusing Dete. “When Dete came out of the workshop, all the suspects beat him brutally. Our probe has revealed that Dongare picked up a stone and bludgeoned Dete to death,” Pawar said.

The employees in the workshop rushed Dete to a nearby hospital, where he was pronounced dead by the doctors.

Pramod Kolhe, an engineer from the workshop, has lodged an FIR against the suspects. “We have launched a search for the remaining suspects involved in the murder,” Pawar said.

Title: Goods worth Rs 4.35L stolen from 3 flats
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Pune: Burglars broke into three flats in Pimpri Chinchwad on Saturday and decamped with gold and silver ornaments, cash and a camera, collectively worth Rs4.35 lakh.

The burglaries occurred at Waghire colony in Pimpri and in Rahatani.

Sandip Mulik, a resident of Stone Ridge society in Waghire colony, has lodged an FIR with the Pimpri police stating that he had gone out after locking his flat on February 14.

When he returned the following day, he found that the locks of his flat were broken and gold and silver ornaments — collectively worth Rs1.71 lakh — along with a sum of Rs9,000, had been stolen from, a Pimpri police officer said.

The suspects also broke into his neighbour’s (Sunil Pawar) flat and stole gold ornaments worth Rs30,000, the officer said.

In another incident, the suspects broke into a flat at Regency Paradise society in Rahatani between 8pm and 11pm on Saturday and stole valuables worth Rs2.25 lakh. Abhijit Virgaonkar has lodged an FIR with the Wakad police.

The police said the suspects stole gold and silver ornaments, cash and a camera, collectively worth Rs2.25 lakh, from Virgaonkar’s flat.

Title: Passengers escape with injuries after bus falls 15ft
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nashik: Passengers onboard a state transport bus had a lucky escape on Monday after the vehicle fell 15 feet off the Peth-Dindori road in Chachadgaon, Dindori taluka, about 35 km from here.

Apart from the driver and the conductor, 12 passengers were travelling in the bus.

The injured were shifted to a nearby hospital for treatment. The Dindori police said all the passengers in the bus suffered minor to medium injuries. The accident happened sometime around 7.30 am.

“The bus was heading towards Dindori from Peth. At around 7.30 am, it went off the road after the driver lost control of the steering wheel because of a bad stretch of road near a bridge. It fell 15 feet and came to rest after turning turtle,” said Anil Borse, the inspector with the Dindori police station.

Personnel from a nearby police outpost were able to quickly respond to the incident and the 108 ambulance service was dispatched to take the injured to a nearby hospital.

“Two of the passengers were referred to the Nashik Civil Hospital as they had suffered slightly serious injuries,” Borse said.

He added that the bus driver lost control after the vehicle hit a broken stretch of road near a bridge. “The bridge was recently concretised. But there’s still a small crater on the concreted part of the road. The bus suffered a big jerk when it hit the crater. And the driver lost control,” he said.

Borse added that the police in the area have now written to authorities concerned to repair the road as soon as possible. “This could have ended in a tragedy. What if it was a school bus?” he asked.

Title: Security on alert to foil Maoist menace
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: To ward off any reckless attack by Maoists, security forces have been put on alert in all states.

After the rejig of the central committee of the CPI Maoists, the Centre is keen to crack down on Maoists. With the intelligence wing alerting on possible aggression by the Maoists, the Centre has been updating the state governments.

Vijay Kumar, special advisor to the Union ministry of home, last Saturday visited a police outpost at Nurmathi in G Madugula mandal, a Maoist stronghold.

He appreciated the state police after his visit to Nurmathi outpost, set up at an interior place.

“He told us to be cautious during anti-Maoist operations,” said Visakha Rural SP Babujee Attada. Sources said Vijay Kumar advised them to prepare for a scale up of operations in the summer.

“They (Maoists) are desperate to show their existence and action teams have been pressed into action. Security forces are continuing combing operations,” said a senior officer involved in anti-Maoist operations.

Vijay Kumar also attended meetings at Malkangiri in Odisha and Bijapur in Chhattisgarh to discuss anti-Maoist operations.

Title: Ready for grand welcome of President Trump: Rupani
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Gandhinagar: Chief minister Vijay Rupani on Monday visited the Motera stadium to review arrangements for the visit of the US President Donald Trump. PM Narendra Modi and President Trump will inaugurate the stadium on February 24.

Speaking to mediapersons, the CM said, “US President Donald Trump will arrive in Ahmedabad on February 24 directly from Washington DC. He will take part in a grand celebration accompanying the inauguration of the world’s largest cricket stadium at Motera. There will be a mega road show along with a cultural show.
