We are ready for a grand welcome for the US President.”

Minister of state for home Pradipsinh Jadeja, DGP Shivanand Jha, city police commissioner Ashish Bhatia, municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra and senior government officers accompanied the CM to the stadium.

Title: Tirupati: ‘Pattu vastrams’ for Srisailam temple deities
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

TIRUPATI: Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams chairman YV Subba Reddy and executive officer Anil Kumar Singhal presented pattu vastrams—a set of silk robes—to Lord Mallikarjuna Swamy and Goddess Brahmaramba Devi at the Srisailam temple on Monday.

It is customary for the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams to present pattu vastrams to the Srisailam temple on the eve of the annual Brahmotsavams ahead of the Mahasivaratri festival every year.

TTD chairman YV Subba Reddy and EO Anil Kumar Singhal, who arrived with the Pattu Vastrams at the main entrance of the Srisailam temple, were accorded a traditional welcome by the priests and officials of the Srisaila Devasthanams on Monday.

After being led into the sanctum sanctorum, TTD chairman and officials presented silk robes to the presiding deity.

Title: Tirupati: Six-day vedic meet in Tirumala from Feb 25
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

TIRUPATI: Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) additional executive officer AV Dharma Reddy inspected arrangements for Veda Agama Vidwat Sadas to be held at Sri Venkateswara Veda Vignana Peetham at Vedagiri in Tirumala from February 25. Around 750 students and 115 vedic scholars will take part in the six-day event, which will conclude on March 1.

Reddy reviewed the progress of works with TTD officials from the engineering, electrical, reception, Annaprasadam, sanitation, garden and other wings. He also inspected the Yagashala site, conference area, ongoing civil, electrical and other works for the mega event. Chaturveda havanam and Stouta yagam will be held every day between 8 am and 12 pm on the six days of the event, he said.

Venkateswara Veda Vignana Peetham principal KSS Avadhani said examinations will be held from February 26-29 in various vedic departments and those who win the top two positions will be felicitated with 5 grams gold and 10 grams silver dollars during the valedictory on March 1. Brahmasri Madugula Nagaphani Sharma will render religious discourses on Vedam-Srimadramayanam, Vedam-Mahabharatam and Vedam-Bhagavatham on February 27, 28 and 29.

Title: Vijayawada: Disquiet in Agency areas over violation of SC orders
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Supreme Court

VIJAYAWADA: The disquiet among the Adivasi community in the tribal regions of Visakhapatnam has been rising in recent months as the state government appears to be turning a blind eye to critical rulings by the courts, including the Supreme Court, on the rights of Adivasis to their land.

One important ruling on the rights of the Adivasis was given by the Supreme Court in July 1997. In its judgment filed in the lawsuit brought by Samata, a non-governmental organisation, the apex court declared null and void the transfer of land in the scheduled areas and also upheld the Forest Protection Act of 1980.

“The Supreme Court decision, which has since been called the Samata judgment, is by far the most progressive of rulings, but unfortunately its efficacy has been steadily diluted in AP and other states,” says Ravi Rebbapragada, who is the executive director of Samata, which had brought the lawsuit against the AP government. The Samata ruling had allocated 20% of the net profit to the local area development councils in the states, but somehow that order has been followed more in the breach than in practice, Rebbapragada claimed.

The AP government has also been tardy in enforcing laws pertaining to the Fifth Schedule of the Constitution, which governs the laws in Adivasi land. “While the AP government has not given any licence for mining of bauxite in the Agency areas of Visakhapatnam, it has allowed the mining of laterite, which is also illegal. More importantly, the government has been allowing plains people to illegally set up so-called tourism projects in Agency areas like Lambasingi, Paderu and Anantagiri,” Rebbapragada alleged.

“The Adivasis are even not paid minimum wages. They are treated like slaves by owners of guest houses and hotels and other attractions in these places,” Rebbapragada said.

Apart from over-exploiting the fragile ecology of the Agency areas, tourists have made a mess of the region with rampant littering. “Dallapalli has been almost drowned in single-use plastic bags and other litter, which has not been removed by the administration, making it clear that it wants to exploit the Agency areas at the expense of the Adivasis who have been living in the region for generations, eking a living out of the forests,” he added.

The alleged continuing onslaught on Adivasi rights has prompted them to get together to launch an agitation for the protection of the Fifth Schedule rights. The community held a massive show of strength in Paderu on February 12 which was attended by over one lakh people. A joint action committee of the Adivasis has also requested the AP government to resolve their issues at the earliest.

According to EAS Sarma, a former Union expenditure secretary, Adivasis’ land was being commandeered illegally by plains people on the pretext of setting up hotels in Anantagiri, Paderu and Lambasingi

Title: Rajasthan: TM Pratap Singh Khachariyawas vows action against corrupt officials
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Pratap Singh Khachariyawas

JAIPUR: A day after ACB busted corruption racket at the transport department, the transport minister held a review meeting. He urged that no innocent officer should be harassed by the sleuths of the ACB and advocated for stern action against those involved in corrupt practices in his department.

Khachariyawas, in a meeting with various officers at the transport office, told the officers that the government is committed to zero-tolerance in corruption.

“There is panic among transport department employees. I have assured them that no innocent officers will be harassed by the ACB. But, we will take strict action against those responsible for the corrupt practice in the department,” said Khachariyawas while talking to TOI after the meeting.

He added that family members of various employees of the transport department approached him at his residence on Monday morning. “If ACB has a right to take action against any officer, the family members also have the right to speak. After getting feedback on ACB action, I will urge the authorities to ensure no innocent officer be unnecessarily dragged in the case,” Khachariyawas added.

According to sources, the transport minister has also spoken to chief minister Ashok Gehlot and urged him to ensure sleuths of ACB should not create panic among the employees in the name of investigation.

ACB on Sunday had arrested 15 people including brokers and officials of the transport department and claimed to have busted one of the biggest corruption rackets involved in extortion of transporters.

Title: Jamia News: BJP accuses Congress of giving political colour to Jamia violence case
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

BJP’s remarks came after Congress attacked the government over a new video showing police and paramilitary per... Read More

NEW DELHI: BJP on Monday accused Congress of “giving a political colour” to the violence at Jamia Millia Islamia on December 15, alleging that its functionaries always railed against security forces and stood with those who were inimical to the country.

BJP’s remarks came after Congress attacked the government over a new video showing police and paramilitary personnel caning students in the university’s library on December 15.

“Congress has continuously supports antisocial elements and those who indulge in violence. It raises voice against the security forces and police personnel of the country,” BJP spokesperson GVL Narasimha Rao said at a press conference.

Talking about another video in which people were seen in the gangway with some covering their faces, while at least two of them were carrying stones, Rao asked why the students were wearing masks and why they were studying with stones in their hands.

Rao highlighted the Supreme Court’s stand on December 16 while hearing cases pertaining to violence at Jamia and Aligarh Muslim University . The SC had said: “We will determine the students’ rights but not in the atmosphere of riots.”

Title: Amit Shah on 3-day visit to state from Feb 20
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Gandhinagar: Union home minister and Gandhinagar lok sabha constituency MP Amit Shah will be in Gujarat on a three-day visit beginning February 20. Shah will participate in a government function at Vadodara after which he is expected to be in Ahmedabad till the evening of February 22. Shah is also expected to review preparations for the visit of US President Donald Trump and also preside over a meeting of Gujarat BJP leaders.

Title: Donald Trump visit: Government machinery running full gear to ensure, manage spectator numbers at Motera stadium
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Donald Trump with Melania Trump (AFP)

AHMEDABAD: Crowd management is emerging as the biggest headache for organizers and security personnel at the Motera stadium on February 24. It is estimated that with 120 metal detector door frames and 250 handheld devices, it will take approximately 2.5 hours to 3 hours to complete security checks for 1.1 lakh people who will be entering the stadium.

A large chunk of the crowd is coming from nearby districts of Patan, Sabarkantha, Aravalli , Gandhinagar districts and outskirts of Ahmedabad. There is tremendous pressure on BJP party workers to gather numbers. Children as spectators will be avoided within the stadium, unless they are part of cultural performances said a senior AMC official.

“Spectators from outside Ahmedabad district will be given preferential treatment and will be taken inside the stadium first,” said a senior BJP leader in the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC).

Government officials including mamlatdars in the collectorate and assistant municipal commissioners have been given targets to bring spectators. “Each assistant municipal commissioner in every zone has been asked to gather at least 220 to 250 people for the roadshow by contracting NGOs and religious institutions. Incentives like banners of the NGO will be allowed to be put up along the VIP route,” said a senior AMC official. In all space for 2,300 buses and more than 6,000 cars have earmarked in 28 plots, most of which are private.

“People have happily given us their plots as the AMC is clearing their plots of debris and garbage, levelling them and watering them for parking purposes. It’s a win-win deal,” says the AMC official.

Title: AIIMS: Hearts of gold of two families save 7 lives
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Anil Mittal (L), Sachin

NEW DELHI: At least seven people suffering from end-stage organ failure received a new lease of life on Monday, thanks to organ donation by the families of two individuals who were declared brain dead at AIIMS .

Sachin, a 26-year-old daily wage labourer from Kashganj in UP fell from second floor of a building and was brought to the AIIMS Trauma Centre last week.

On Saturday, he was declared brain dead. After counselling by the Organ Retrieval Banking Organisation (ORBO) at the institute, the grieving family members took the brave decision of multi-organ and tissue donation. “Sachin’s heart, liver, kidneys and corneas were donated,” said a senior official.

The second cadaver donor, Anil Mittal, had suffered from irreversible brain damage due to a haemorrhage. He was admitted to AIIMS on Saturday night. By Sunday, he had been declared brain dead. Mittal, 61, was a pledged donor with Dadhichi Deh Dan Samiti and his family fulfilled his wish of organ and tissue donation. An offical said Mittal’s heart, liver, kidneys, corneas and bones were donated. All the organs, except two kidneys, were used in AIIMS itself to save the life of patients suffering from organ failure. Two kidneys were sent to Ram Manohar Lohia (RML) hospital for transplantation,

The tissues and heart valve have been preserved for future use. Overall, more than 30 patients will benefit from the donations, the AIIMS official said.

Dr Randeep Guleria, director of AIIMS, lauded the contribution of the donor families and said that the families were gracious enough to take decision in the most painful moments of their lives.

“There are a lot of misconceptions and hurdles like non-acceptance of brain stem death, fear of disfigurement of the body, religious myths and divided family opinion that lead to lower rates of such donations in India as compared to developed nations. But we are hopeful of positive change,” Dr Aarti Vij, who is also in charge of ORBO, said.

Title: Youth on way to distribute sister’s wedding card dies in accident
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: A 22-year-old youth who was on way to Bareilly from Kichcha in Uttarakhand to distribute invitation cards for his sister’s marriage died and his cousin was critically injured on Sunday night when their bike was hit by an unidentified vehicle on Nainital-Bareilly state highway near Atamanda village under Bhojipura police station.

Victim Akash Kumar was the only son among three children. His father had also died in an accident four years ago. Akash was an employee of a paper mill in Uttarakhand. His sister’s marriage is scheduled on February 25. His cousin, Pawan, has been admitted to a private hospital and has slipped into coma.

Both victims were taken to hospital by police. Akash succumbed to injuries during treatment while Pawan, who sustained severe head injury, is battling for life.

A relative, Akash Babu , told TOI, “After completing his shift, Akash and Pawan were on way to Bareilly to invite guests for his sister’s marriage when they met with the accident. Both were wearing helmets. Akash was the youngest among his siblings. One of his oldest sister is married.”

Manoj Kumar, SHO of Bhojipura police station, said, “The incident was reported during midnight and our patrolling team took the victims to hospital. Both were residents of Kichcha town in Uttarakhand. We have filed an FIR against an unidentified driver under IPC section 304a (causing death by negligence) and 279 (rash driving).”

Title: Why aren’t you filing civil suit for damages, asks HC
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

NEW DELHI: Frowning upon the practice of seeking damages by way of a writ petition , Delhi high court on Monday sought the stand of the Centre, AAP government and Delhi Police on a fresh plea by a Jamia Millia Islamia student seeking compensation for injuries.

The student claimed that he was seriously wounded in police assault during protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act on December 15. A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar was initially of the view that the petitioner should have filed a civil suit, if he was demanding compensation as claims would have to be proved through evidence.

“These are matters of evidence. Why are you not filing a suit for damages? On the basis of annexures in a writ, claims cannot be proved,” the high court said and added that “it has become a fashion in Delhi to file a writ for everything.”

But the bench subsequently issued notices to the Union ministry of home affairs, Jamia Millia and others asking them to file their response to the plea in which the student, Shayaan Mujeeb, alleged that both his legs got fractured in the “brutal violence carried out” by security personnel. Mujeeb has said he was at the university library on the day, when policemen entered the building and allegedly beat up the students there.

He also cited the available CCTV footage to allege that police entered the library and beat up the students, arguing that he should be granted Rs 2 crore as compensation for the injuries suffered. Mujeeb also sought registration of an FIR for the offences allegedly committed by cops, along with reimbursement of Rs 2 lakh, claiming he was forced to pay the amount for his medical treatment.

Earlier, another student, Mohammad Minhajuddin, had moved a plea seeking a probe into the incident and demanding compensation for injuries he suffered. Minhajuddin, according to the plea, lost vision in one eye during the incident.

On December 15 last year, anti-CAA protests near southeast Delhi’s Jamia turned violent, with demonstrators pelting stones at police and setting public buses and private vehicles on fire. Police later entered the university, firing teargas shells and baton-charged students. Several students, including the petitioner, were injured in the police crackdown.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Scindia repeats ‘hit the street’ vow; no comment, says Congress
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

AICC general secretary Jyotiraditya Scindia

BHOPAL/INDORE:AICC general secretary Jyotiraditya Scindia on Sunday reiterated his vow to “hit the streets” despite all the controversy it has generated.

Speaking to reporters in Gwalior, Scindia said, “I am a public servant. Fighting for people’s issues is my dharma. Like I said, we must have patience since it has only been one year of the government. And promises we (Congress party) made in the manifesto must be fulfilled. If not, we have to hit the streets.”

On Monday, AICC general secretaries Mukul Wasnik and Deepak Babaria addressed a press conference in Bhopal but refused to answer questions on Scindia. Asked about bickering in the party, Wasnik handed over the microphone to Babaria who said, “I am here for the next two to three days. I will answer these questions later.”

Last Thursday, Scindia had told guest teachers, who are on strike demanding regularization of service, that he will be their “shield and sword” if the Kamal Nath government does not fulfil the manifesto promise of regularizing them. “Your demands were made part of the Congress’ election manifesto. That manifesto is holy text for us. If the promises made in the manifesto are not fulfilled, then don’t think you will be left alone. Jyotiraditya Scindia will hit the streets with you.”

In Indore, BJP ‘sympathized’ with Scindia, with Indore-2 MLA Ramesh Mendola inviting him to the installation ceremony of a 66-ft-tall statue of Lord Hanuman. He advised Scindia that reciting Hanuman Chalisa will “show him a way out of the crisis he is in”.

Mendola, a trusted aide of BJP general secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya, wrote to Scindia about the event at Pitra Parvat (a hill on Indore’s outskirts), and said: “The kind of treatment chief minister Kamal Nath has given you, after you reminded him of promises made in the manifesto, is sad and painful. I believe, praying to Lord Hanuman will give you strength and courage in this time of grief. Through this letter, I am inviting you to participate in idol installation ceremony of Piterashwar Hanuman Dham, which is being carried out in presence of many saints till March 3.”

“Reciting ‘Sundarkand’ or Hanuman Chalisa will help you deal with the challenges you are facing in your party and will also give you strength to fight injustice and win (the political battle). This letter is written with good intention and don’t draw any political conclusions or other sense of it,” Mendola mentions at the end.

MPCC general secretary Satyanarayan Patel — a Scindia supporter — denied there is any crisis. “Scindia ji is facing no challenge in the party, neither is he in any trouble. However, if Mendola wants him to attend the religious programme and if he has written with good intentions, Scindia ji may participate.”

Title: Kerala HC: No licence sans privacy assessment
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Kerala high court

KOCHI: No new licence or renewal should be granted for toddy shops in residential areas without assessing impact on privacy of nearby residents, the high court has ordered.

The order was issued by Justice A Muhamed Mustaque after considering five petitions by residents alleging violation of fundamental rights due to operation of toddy shops in residential areas.

In the 46-page judgment, the court also asked the state government to consider ways to modernize toddy shops.

Being the protector and guardian of fundamental rights, the government is obliged to take positive measures against breach of fundamental rights due to its action or private action, the court said.

“There is no embargo in our Constitution in recognizing human rights protected under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights to have protection to respect for private and family life and his home. Therefore, no toddy shops can be established in a residential area in derogation of the rights of the individual to have respect for his private and family life and home,” the judgment said.

Whether operation of a toddy shop violates the fundamental rights of nearby residents is a matter that can only be ascertained on a case by case basis, the court said. European Convention on Human Rights adopted assessment based on ‘threshold severity test’, which refers to the minimum level of severity of the action complained of, the court noted.

As per the judgment, such tests would take place in proximity of toddy shop with a residential building and other factors that would affect privacy right such as noise, emissions, odours, and any other forms of interference for the quiet enjoyment of one’s home. The assessment should also contain a negative test, which refers to amenities one would be able to enjoy in the absence of a toddy shop nearby. The court also said no empirical data is needed and violation of one person’s privacy right is sufficient to deny licence.

Laying down the test of assessment on the impact of privacy rights, the court said no toddy shop should be located in a residential area infringing the right of privacy of a nearby resident, that threshold severity test assessment must be conducted for assessing breach of privacy right, and the commissioner of excise can consider complaints of privacy breach.

Title: Trichy: Archaeological excavation a people’s movement, says Keeladi architect
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

K Amarnath Ramakrishna, Superintending Archaeologist, Archaeological Survey of India, addressing students a... Read More TRICHY: Archaeological excavation has become a people’s movement as public have come forward demanding excavation at Keeladi, ASI (Archaeological survey of India) superintending archaeologist Amarnath Ramakrishna said on Monday. He was addressing students at Jamal Mohamed College as part of a national seminar on Keeladi excavations. “Excavation was carried out in 157 places in Tamil Nadu, but that has not been noticed. Keeladi became popular as people were made aware of the history of the land,” he said. He thanked many Muslim land owners for offering their land during the initial period of excavation and as a result it has become so popular. Saying that excavation in Keeladi must continue setting aside politics, he said, “It was a small team in 2012-13 led by me that carried preliminary survey along Vaigai river. It has now popularised the history of this region across the world.” “But it was possible only when people were made aware of our history and significance of this place. It took this long as we did not realise the richness of our history,” said Amarnath as he asked students across discipline to read history. Explaining the effectiveness of grid pattern of excavation which was adopted across north India by ASI, he said the state archaeology relied on vertical trench during its previous excavations which wasn’t very effective. The Keeladi excavation has taken history of Sangam era from 300 BC to 600 BC. “Several archaeological excavation findings in 2004 have given evidence that Harappan civilization was built by ancestral south Indians. We have established that it was Dravidians who have migrated from Harappa to the south of India but there is need for further exploration to establish the links,” he said.

Title: Encounter in Delhi: Two criminals killed in south Delhi encounter
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

As the men tried to speed away, the cops blocked their way due to which the bike skidded and they both fell on... Read More

NEW DELHI: Two men on their way to allegedly extort money from a trader at the Okhla mandi were killed in an encounter with the special cell in the early hours of Monday near Pul Prahladpur in south Delhi.

Following a tip-off, police spotted Rafiq and Ramesh on a motorcycle around 5.51am and asked them to surrender. But the men tried to flee and allegedly opened fire at the cops, who fired back. A huge cache of arms, including pistols and ammunition of different bores, were found on them.

As the men reportedly tried to speed away, the cops blocked their way due to which the bike skidded and both fell on the road. Instead of surrendering, both Rafiq and Ramesh whipped out pistols and started firing at the police team. Five of the shots hit four cops, all of whom were saved due to bullet-proof jackets. A police Gypsy was also damaged.

When the cops retaliated, Rafiq and Ramesh were hit on the chest, back and the legs. They were immediately taken to the AIIMS trauma centre but were declared dead on arrival.

Ramesh was using a 9mm pistol and Rafiq, a .30 bore one, said an officer. They were also found to be carrying a bag containing another .32 bore pistol and eight live rounds. Four pouches containing about 60 rounds of 7.62mm cartridges were also found on Rafiq. Police claimed the duo had been threatening several wholesale dealers in the Okhla mandi to extort money from them.

A probe revealed that Ramesh and Rafiq had killed Ramesh’s father over a property dispute, said a source. Rafiq was also involved in shooting at two cops and a property dealer in Karawal Nagar last week and then travelled to Loni to eliminate another property dealer for refusing to pay him protection money. Later that night, he killed Salman, who used to deal in real estate, in Loni.

Rafiq, who was involved in at least seven attempt-to-murder and murder cases, was earlier booked under the Gangster Act in Uttar Pradesh. Last year, he killed Kishor alias Langda from Karawal Nagar, with whom he was involved in a turf war. He was also wanted in the murder of a cricket bookie, Javed, in 2019.

Title: Abhijit Bangar posted as director of textiles
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nagpur: IAS officer of 2008 batch Abhijit Bangar has been posted as director, Textiles, here. He was without charge after being replaced by Tukaram Mundhe from the post of municipal commissioner at the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) since January 28.

The state government on Tuesday issued a notification shuffling 21 IAS officials, including Bangar. He replaced Madhavi Khode-Chaure. The government has transferred Khode to Jalgaon Municipal Corporation as municipal commissioner.

The government had transferred Bangar within 14 months from the NMC despite tenure of 36 months. He was transferred to make way for Mundhe.

During his 14-month tenure, Bangar used to meet people whenever present in his cabin and never fixed any time table for visitors. Bangar had successfully revised door-to-door garbage collection system, improved city’s ranking under Swachh Bharat Mission, took city to top post under Smart City Mission, tackled water crisis very well last year and expedited various developmental projects.

Among the other transfers, Devendra Singh has been appointed as collector of Yavatmal.

Title: Youth arrested for raping three-year-old Dalit girl in Kheri
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: A 19-year-old youth was arrested for allegedly raping a three-year-old Dalit girl in Sampoornanagar area of Lakhimpur Kheri district on Monday.

Finding the girl alone at her home on Sunday evening — her parents had not yet returned from work — the youth, a neighbour, raped her, said police.

The family came to know about the sexual assault on the girl when she complained of pain. Following the complaint , Sampoornanagar police booked the accused under IPC section 376 (rape) and relevant sections of the POCSO and SC/ST Acts. He was sent to jail on Monday.

Sampoornanagar SHO Sandeep Singh told TOI, “The accused was arrested immediately after receiving a complaint over the phone, while the girl was sent to a hospital. She is stable. Her medical examination was completed on Monday. We have recorded her statement and collected sufficient evidence against the accused, who will be chargesheeted for rape, soon.”

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Vishnu Dutt Sharma takes charge of BJP chief
Content:
VD Sharma being welcomed by former state president Rakesh Singh and ex-CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan at BJP Headqua... Read More

BHOPAL: Taking charge at the party’s office on Monday, newly-appointed BJP state president Vishnu Dutt Sharma said the present situation in Madhya Pradesh is similar to that of Congress rule under Digvijaya Singh.“Situation in Madhya Pradesh is similar to one during Congress rule led by then chief minister Digvijaya Singh in the late nineties. The Congress government should stop harassing BJP workers. The party workers will not back down from protests in any case,” said Sharma.He said the programmes and agitations launched under outgoing state unit chief Rakesh Singh would continue. The BJP workers will join hands to fight the Kamal Nath government and expose its failures, Sharma said.“I am thankful to all senior leaders who have been giving huge support to fulfil my duty. I need their support, guidance and blessings to fulfil my responsibilities. We all together will face the Kamal Nath government and will hit streets. There is no big challenge before the BJP,” said Sharma.Earlier, the BJP Lok Sabha MP from Khajuraho took blessings of his parents at his Gwalior residence. After reaching Bhopal, he was taken to the party office in a rally taken out in an open jeep. He was accompanied by senior party leaders and MLAs. Sharma also garlanded the statue of BJP ideologue Pandit Deendayal Upadhyaya and performed rituals at the party’s state headquarters before taking official charge.BJP leaders including former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan, Rakesh Singh, union ministers Narendra Singh Tomar , Thawar Chand Gehlot, Faggan Singh Kulaste, Leader of Opposition Gopal Bhargava, chief whip in assembly, Narottam Mishra and Rajya Sabha member Prabhat Jha were present during the function among others.

Title: Mundhe drops garbage transfer stations plan
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nagpur: Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe has dropped the plan to develop five garbage transfer stations and transferred its allocated funds of Rs40 crore for the bio-mining project. Garbage transfer stations were planned to achieve the status of Garbage Free City.

Mundhe, who took over the charge of CEO of Smart City special purpose vehicle — Nagpur Smart and Sustainable City Development Corporation Limited (NSSCDCL) — took the decision in the meeting to review the Smart City Project on Tuesday.

Mundhe directed NSSCDCL officials to stop the ongoing tendering process for the appointment of private contractors to develop the stations.

Mundhe’s predecessor Abhijit Bangar had planned to develop one garbage transfer station in each of the ten zones. For decades, sanitary workers of Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) used to dump garbage collected from streets and roads in a given location in each area. Also, staffers of the private garbage operator used to dump garbage collected from households at the same spots. Then, big trucks used to come and take away the garbage. But the garbage used to exist at many locations across the city causing inconvenience to the people and pollution. Therefore, Bangar planned garbage transfer stations where garbage will come and systematically taken away in big trucks to Bhandewadi dumping yard. Funds of Rs40 crore from Smart City Project was sanctioned for five stations and remaining five were supposed to be developed later.

NMC sources told TOI that Mundhe directed the officials of health department to ensure no garbage is dumped and transferred directly from sanitary workers’ tubs and small vehicles into big trucks. “Mundhe might have felt shortage of funds for bio-mining which is under way and very crucial for scientific disposal of 6-8 lakh tonne garbage lying at Bhandewadi dumping yard for decades and also to free the 32-acre land,” sources said.

Considering the past experience, now Garbage Free City may not be achieved without garbage transfer stations.

Mundhe directed the officials to adopt and spread awareness about the four Rs — reduce, reuse, recycle and refuse. He meant citizens should reduce the quantum of garbage by reusing wet garbage at households itself for compost, recycle dry waste and refuse to use plastic.

As the decision was taken by board of directors of NSSCDCL, Mundhe reportedly took the decision after taking the consent of chairman Praveen Pardeshi.

Title: DVAC yet to upload FIR in walkie-talkie scam
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Chennai: State government’s anti-corruption agency Directorate of Vigilance and Anti-Corruption ( DVAC ) is yet to publish on its website the FIR in a case related to the walkie-talkie scam. The scam relates to corruption in the multi-crore procurement of technical gadgets such as mobile phones, CCTV systems, tablet PCs, GPS, CCTV camera and spare battery for VHF sets by the technical wing in the office of the Director General of Police (DGP).

A superintendent of police (SP) level officer, Anbuchezhian, is the main accused in the case and his residence was one of the 18 places raided by the DVAC on February 8. An FIR was registered the previous day, according to a DVAC statement.

The FIR in this case, if published, would shed light on private companies and individuals which/ who are alleged beneficiaries of procedural violations in the tender processing. At least three officers of the technical wing are under the scanner in the case.

The DVAC is supposed to publish all FIRs on its website as per a Supreme court order dated September 7, 2016, in the writ petition no 68/2016. All FIRs are usually to its portal within 3 or 4 days. The agency has uploaded an FIR relating to another case booked on February 7. It has published FIRs of the several high-profile cases such as the Anna University re-evaluation scam, the arrest of a vice-chancellor and the corruption allegations against former vice-chancellors of Anna and TN Law universities. However, when it comes to high profile cases involving the police department, the DVAC has in an earlier occasion too avoided publishing the FIR. DVAC officers including its heads are drawn from the police.

In the gutka scam, the first case was filed by the special investigation cell (SIC) of the DVAC. The FIR was not published on its website and many activists had raised a stink then.

Jayaram Venkatesan, convenor of Arappor Iyakkam which had earlier campaigned for greater transparency in the DVAC, said government bodies can’t be selective when it comes to transparency. “The agency cannot say they will put out only those FIRs they deem as fit. In cases where privacy of victims is at stake, publication can be avoided. But in corruption cases, the agency should be as transparent as possible,” he said.

Vijaykumar, the director of DVAC, did not respond to calls from TOI seeking comment. However, sources in the agency said it was their prerogative to publish FIRs. “If the officials feel some cases are sensitive, the case details will not be uploaded,” a source said.

Title: Central agency to prepare DPR for Kailasagiri planetarium
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The National Council of Science Museums (NCSM) under the ministry of culture will prepare the detailed project report (DPR) for the proposed planetarium on Kailasagiri Hilltop Park. The Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority (VMRDA) has decided to hand over the responsibility of the DPR to NCSM instead of opting for a private consultant in view of the council’s expertise in setting up planetariums and science centres. The NCSM will shortly start work on the DPR based on inputs provided by the VMRDA.

The VMRDA has also constituted a technical committee comprising professionals in developing planetariums and museums from across the country to receive inputs on dome size, seating arrangement, type of projectors, content available for screening and maintenance. Representatives from the NCSM are also part of the technical committee.

Speaking to TOI, VMRDA metropolitan commissioner P Koteswara Rao said the agency convened the second technical committee meeting this Sunday. “The team extensively discussed the technical specifications and modalities of operation of the proposed planetarium. Besides proposing various emerging and advanced technologies, the committee recommended visiting at least three to four planetariums in the country to get an idea of merits and demerits of the existing technology and future technology,” said Koteswara Rao.

The metropolitan commissioner added that the VMRDA plans to design and develop the planetarium by studying various immersive models in the world such that it meets technology needs for the next two decades. “The virtual tour of the universe will help create scientific curiosity on astronomy, space science and other related fields among students and youth. The NCSM will start preparing the DPR in the next 15 days. It may take about 45 days to complete the DPR. International seminars, lectures and workshops will be conducted at the planetarium apart from providing a platform for a discipline-based education research for postgraduates and research scholars,” said Koteswara Rao.

A team of officials from the VMRDA headed by Koteswara Rao recently visited the National Council of Science Museum and Birla Planetarium in Kolkata.

Title: 24x7 water supply: CM seeks timeline
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

New Delhi: With 24-hour water supply being one of the 10 promises made by AAP in its “guarantee card” ahead of the polls, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Tuesday called a meeting of various stakeholders to prepare a roadmap to achieve the target.

Apart from DJB officials, minister Satyendar Jain, who has been given the charge of water department in the third term of AAP government, also attended the meeting. Sources said Kejriwal sought a timeline on achieving the target of supplying good-quality piped water round-the-clock to every household in the city in the next five years.

The CM has also called a meeting of all officials and ministers on Wednesday where the implementation of the 10-point guarantee card will be discussed.

Sources said about 93% of the residential areas in Delhi were so far connected with water pipelines. To provide round-the-clock water, the government’s first target is to connect every colony with the network. Augmenting the availability of water to meet the increased demand is another challenge it faces.

“The CM also discussed the possible ways of increasing the availability of water. Rejuvenation of waterbodies and the creation of a reservoir along the Yamuna north of Wazirabad are two important projects that were discussed,” an official said.

Delhi government has initiated an ambitious plan to tap Yamuna rainwater by building a 1,000-acre mega reservoir. The project aims at conserving water in the floodplain between Palla on Delhi-Haryana border and Wazirabad to deal with the shortage in the capital. The government will build small ponds on the floodplain, which will catch excess water from the overflowing river during monsoons.

According to officials, civil work has already started on the project.

Delhi’s estimated water demand at present is around 1,150 million gallons daily (MGD) while DJB provides around 950 MGD. For the 24×7 water supply project, this 200 MGD gap could be the difference between success and failure, said officials.

Two upscale colonies in Malviya Nagar area — Navjeevan Vihar and Geetanjali Enclave — are already part of a PPP-mode pilot project where over 600 houses have been getting 24X7 supply. A similar project all over Delhi will not only require a robust leakage proof pipeline system but also surplus availability of water.

Title: Bhopal: Official gets Rs 25,000 penalty for not providing information
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: The state information commission on Monday slapped a penalty of Rs 25000 on a joint collector for not providing information to an applicant under RTI Act 2005. The move came after the official denied information regarding the disbursement of drought relief and funds used for digging a well to an applicant.

Sources said that the applicant Pradeep Ahirwar, a Bhopal resident, had sought information regarding fund used in digging a well on his land and also about disbursement of drought relief money from chief municipal officer of Tikamgarh in March 2017. When the information was not provided, he moved a first appeal with Tikamgarh collector who ordered the PIO to provide the information. But despite orders, the deputy collector Pratap Singh Chouhan did not provide the information. Later the applicant moved a second appeal before the commission. A total of five hearings were held, but the official concerned did not appear. Later, he moved an application saying that he should not be penalised as he had provided the information sought in “point 1 of the application” and he had been transferred from the district.

State information commissioner Rahul Singh, in his order, said that the first appellate authority in the case, who was the then collector, had ordered to provide the information much before the transfer of the PIO, but the information was not provided. Thereafter, Singh imposed a penalty of Rs 25000 on the official. Besides, the then CMO Singh also issued show-cause notice to the present CMO asking why a fine of Rs 25000 should not be imposed on him as he too had not provided the information.

Title: Kerala govt to upgrade 50 adventure tourism spots
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Activities covered under the guidelines include trekking and mountaineering, jeep safaris, all-terrain vehicle... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Highlighting that safety and quality are pivotal for the growth of high-potential adventure tourism in Kerala , tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran said on Monday that 50 major adventure tourism centres in the state will be upgraded to meet the national and global standards.

The minister’s announcement came during the launch of a set of comprehensive safety and security regulations aimed to position the state as a prime, secure and hassle-free destination for adventure-loving holidaymakers and nature buffs.

Surendran also launched an online accreditation portal to provide registration for qualified adventure activity providers (AAP), based on the guidelines drawn up by Kerala Adventure Tourism Promotion Society (KATPS), under the state tourism department. The validity of the registration is for two years.

Noting the guidelines set by Kerala Adventure and Activities Based Tourism Safety and Security Regulations for conduct of 31 land, water and air-based activities, the minister said Muzhappilangad (Kannur), Kaapil (Varkala) and Vagamon (Idukki) will be designated as adventurous tourism centres. “A proposal to set up adventure parks in all districts is also under the consideration of the government, as per the availability of land,” he said.

Listing five ways of developing adventure tourism, the minister said basic infrastructure in the existing adventure tourism spots needs to be developed initially. This should be followed by identifying and developing new spots, promoting public-private projects and creating a circuit connecting adventure tourism centres. Finally, the state has to brand its adventure tourism nationally and internationally. Currently, KATPS in association with the forest department is conducting activities in forest areas, he said.

“Soft adventure parks have already been started in Veli, Asramam in Kollam, Thenmala, Karlad in Wayand and Kottappuram. Preparations are in the final stages in Munnar to start paragliding activities. Besides, an adventure tourism academy will be set up at Sasthampara near the state capital,” Surendran added.

Tourism secretary Rani George, who presided over the function, said except desert-based activities and snow-capped mountain activities, Kerala has all the potential to emerge as a top adventure tourism destination. “Approval has been given for commencing a training course in adventure tourism at Kerala Institute of Tourism and Travel Studies (KITTS), in association with private tour operator Muddy Boots,” she added.

The guidelines lay emphasis on essential parameters for activity providers such as having proper licence as prescribed by the state or central government norms, deployment of qualified personnel, including well-trained activity leaders with hands-on experience, use of quality equipment and knowledge of first aid and safety and risk mitigation ability.

Title: Bengali actor and former MP Tapas Paul dies in Juhu hosp
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Mumbai: Noted Bengali actor and former Trinamool Congress MP Tapas Paul died of cardiac arrest in a Juhu hospital early on Tuesday. He was 61. Hindi audiences know him as the co-actor who featured opposite Madhuri Dixit in her debut film ‘Abodh’ in 1984.

The Kolkata-based artiste had arrived in Mumbai to meet his daughter Sohini last month. His wife Nandini said he was leaving for the US for treatment on February 1 when he took ill at the airport and was taken to a hospital. He remained on ventilator till February 6. “He was taken off the ventilator and was recovering but suddenly his condition worsened and he died of cardiac arrest around 3.30am on Tuesday,” she told PTI.

Paul became popular from his first film ‘Dadar Kirti’ (1980) followed by ‘Parabat Priya’, ‘Bhalobasa Bhalobasa’, ‘Anurager Choyan’ and ‘Amar Bandhan’. Madhuri Dixit tweeted: “The loss of Tapas Paul, who was one of the very first actors I have worked with, is felt by many. May God bless and comfort his family during this difficult period.”

He worked with artistes like Prosenjit, Soumitra Chatterjee, Ranjit Mallick and Raakhee. His colleagues Debashree Roy and Chiranjeet Chakraborty, both TMC MLAs, said they had lost a dear friend and the film industry a brilliant actor.

The two-term former MP from Krishnanagar retreated from cinema and active politics after CBI arrested him in the Rose Valley chit-fund scam in December 2016. He was in prison for 13 months.

West Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee said, “Saddened and shocked to hear about the demise of Tapas Paul. He was a superstar of Bengali cinema who was a member of the Trinamool family. Tapas served the people as a two-term MP and MLA. We will miss him dearly. My condolences to his wife Nandini, daughter Sohini and his many fans.”

Title: Unemployed national-level shooter found hanging
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: A 24-year-old national level shooter, who was depressed over not being able to find a job, was found hanging at her house in Biharipur on Saturday night.

The victim, Lavi Yadav , had won several state-level championships and participated in national events.

According to family members, the victim, a BSc in physical education and daughter of an anganwadi worker, was upset over not being able to build a career which might have prompted her to take the extreme step. They said that the other family members were away in Rampur to attend a wedding since February 9. They added that she had not spoken with them since Thursday after which they sent a relative to check on her.

The family members said that the relative then alerted police who broke open the door and found Lavi hanging. Kotwali SHO Geestesh Kapil said, “Lavi was a national shooter and had represented the state in several events. Her father told us that she was upset because of her career. She was looking for a job after completing her education. The autopsy report has confirmed that she died due to hanging and the room was locked from inside which suggests that she ended her life. We have recorded the statement of all family members.”

Title: CRZ norms flouted along coast: Activists
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: City activists, in a letter to the chief city planner of Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC), have drawn attention to violation of coastal regulation zone ( CRZ ) norms by new constructions at three locations on the Beach Road .

The activists have also sought an explanation from the civic body on how the upcoming structures are being allowed to come up against the prescribed norms.

“CRZ violations are happening at several places, mainly in areas close to the Beach Road and beyond towards Bheemli. We have asked the chief city planner to look into the issue,” said Narashimham Tenneti, a city-based social activist. “Most of these are under-construction projects. There are other completed projects as well which violate the CRZ norms.”

In the last few years, dozens of activists have filed RTI applications seeking the status of buildings in the city that violate CRZ norms. However, the civic body is yet to reply to a single RTI. “We have identified around 37 CRZ violations along the district’s 136km-long coastline. Most of these structures are within city limits and come under the jurisdiction of GVMC. But the civic body is yet to reply to our RTI queries,” alleged Arijili Dasu, who has been protesting against ‘illegal’ constructions on Beach Road.

The constructions include both private and government properties. Besides hotels, residential and commercial complexes, a religious complex belonging to an international organization is also in the ‘CRZ norms violating’ list, he added.

GVMC officials, when asked for their reaction, said they have stopped giving new permissions to constructions on the eastern side of the Beach Road stretch which is along the coastline. “We have hired a private agency to study the issue. It will submit a status report soon on the future course of action along the coastline,” a GVMC official said.

Title: Gargi College Protest: Plea in HC for investigation monitored by court
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Monday sought response of the Centre and CBI on a plea seeking a court-monitored probe into the alleged molestation of students at Delhi University’s Gargi College last week.

A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar issued a notice to both the authorities on a plea filed by advocate M L Sharma.

Sharma moved the court last week, hours after the Supreme Court declined to entertain the petition and asked him to move the high court. He has sought preservation of all recordings and CCTV footage of the college campus. The plea also sought the arrest of people behind the “planned criminal conspiracy.”

Meanwhile, Delhi Police has arrested several people between 18 and 25 years on February 12 in connection with the incident. On February 6, a group of men broke into Gargi College during a festival, ‘Reverie’, and allegedly groped, harassed and molested the students, who claimed that the security officials stood watching.

The incident came to light after some students took to Instagram to narrate their ordeal and alleged that security personnel did nothing to control the unruly groups.

“It is a clear criminal conspiracy hatched by the political party to deploy accused persons to provoke the public for voting in their favour. Despite the presence of Delhi Police... on February 6, neither the principal nor the other state authorities tried to stop and arrest the accused persons,” the PIL claimed. It added, “deliberate chants of Jai Shri Ram disclose that it is a political, planned conspiracy” and blamed the chief minister for not taking action against the accused.

According to police, a case was registered under IPC sections 452 (house-trespass after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint), 354 (assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty), 509 (word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman) and 34 (acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention).

Title: Bhopal: BMHRC, AIIMS merger junked, hospital may get status of autonomous body
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Bhopal Memorial Hospital & Research Centre, Bhopal

BHOPAL: After reiterating in MP high court for a couple of years that a proposal to merge Bhopal Memorial Hospital & Research Centre (BMHRC) with All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) was under active consideration of the health department, department of health & research (DHR) seems to have abandoned the idea.

The minutes of a meeting of a high-level committee in January 2020 clearly indicates that in place of merger of BMHRC with AIIMS, Bhopal, the committee is now looking to run the hospital on the lines of Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences and Technology (SCTIMST), an autonomous institution under the ministry of science and technology, government of India. The committee was constituted by Union health minister to find ways and means for the revival of BMHRC, the hospital established in 1998 under the monitoring of the apex court for proper medical care of survivors of gas disaster.

The minutes have reference to detailed discussion on the ‘fate’ of BMHRC and how could it be used to its optimum potential but there is no mention of why the idea of BMHRC’s merger with AIIMS was dropped and how administering the hospital on the lines of SCTIMST caught fancy of the high-level committee comprising representatives of DHR, AIIMS, Bhopal, AIIMS Delhi and BMHRC.

It only states, “During discussions, members were of the view that BMHRC may be administered and run on the lines of Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences and Technology”. It was also pointed out that during the meeting held by secretary of DHR with the representatives of staff of BMHRC, it had emerged that the merger of AIIMS with AIIMS, Bhopal will have certain difficulties in terms of integration of manpower. It was felt that certain steps needed to be taken to attract and retain the faculty and doctors in BMHRC. Attempts need to be made to fulfill the requirements for commencement/continuation of DNB courses in the hospital on regular basis. The possibility of award of degrees of DM/MCH by SCTIMST to students enrolled in BMHRC may also be explored”.

In its recommendations, the high-level committee said that BMHRC may function as an independent institute on the lines of SCTIMST, Trivandrum, as a teaching institute, an MoU may be entered into with SCTIMST for awarding post-graduate degrees to students in BMHRC, an MoU may be entered with AIIMS, Bhopal for faculty sharing for clinical services and for posting of students to fulfil NBE and other requirements. The committee further recommended that faculty may be recruited on contractual basis with a consolidated remuneration as on par with SCTIMST/AIIMS, New Delhi.

Rachna Dhingra, co-founder of Bhopal Group for Information & Action (BGIA), which is an intervener in the contempt petition against DHR for not complying with the August 2012 Supreme Court order asking DHA to promote BMHRC as an institute of medical education, while reacting strongly to fresh proposal to run the hospital on the lines of SCTIMST, said: “SCTIMST is run on PP (public-private) partnership model. It means DHR wants to go back to Justice Ahmadi’s Trust era, when the hospital was run on that model. We fail to understand when AIIMS, Bhopal is there in the backyard of BMHRC, why should they think of aligning with a hospital as far away as Trivandrum. Besides, there is no clarification why idea of merger with AIIMS was dropped and who gave the idea of developing the hospital on the lines of SCTIMST. If you look at the minutes carefully, you will see that there is reference to stakeholders in the context of BMHRC time and again but no reference to gas disaster survivors even once. In fact, DHR could never understand why BMHRC was special and why it must be administered with personal attention”.

Purnendu Shukla, member of Supreme Court monitoring committee formed to keep a tab on medical facilities being provided to gas victims at gas relief hospitals and BMHRC and report it to the MP high court, said: “As far as I understand, it is another ploy to buy time as the high court is being very strict with DHR on appointment of doctors and other issues related to BMHRC or else there is no logic in not exploring the possibility of its merger with AIIMS, Bhopal and abruptly start talking about a hospital in Kerala. I can’t say more since details of discussions or anything related to the high-level committee was ever discussed with us”.

Title: Two arrested for bid to abduct girls, thrashing their father
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: Two youths were arrested for allegedly attempting to abduct two girls and thrashing their father in Bahjoi area of Sambhal district late in the night of January 25.

in his complaint, the father alleged, “Few men in police uniform introduced themselves as excise officers and barged into my house late in the night of January 25. They asked for liquor, but when we failed to provide them liquor, they gangraped my daughters and thrashed me when I resisted. The accused tried to abduct my daughters in their car, but they fled when I raised alarm.”

Following the complaint, police lodged an FIR against the unidentified men under sections 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 354 (assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty) and 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Sambhal district police chief Yamuna Prasad said, “After the girls’ family stated that the girls were gangraped, we sent them for a medical examination, but it was not established in the medical report. In their statement recorded before the magistrate, the girls didn’t mention about rape. Meanwhile, two crime branch teams were pressed to nab the accused. Two accused, Krishan Pal and Mate Pal, were arrested on Monday.”

Prasad said acting on a tip-off, crime team inspector Rakam Singh nabbed two persons, both residents of Bahrauli village under Behjoi police station limits, from the crossing of Behata Jai Singh village and seized two country-made pistols and cartridges from their possession, which they had snatched from passers-by.

“During interrogation, they disclosed the names of their accomplices, who had accompanied them on January 25, as Dhirendra and Rajendra, residents of the same village,” said Prasad.

Title: Slow work on two city flyovers trigger traffic jams, irk commuters, shopkeepers
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Bareilly: The commute between the busy crossings at Choupla and Lal Phatak — along both of which two separate flyovers are being built — has become a nightmare, allege residents, what with the slow pace of construction work.

Roads in both areas are lying damaged for several months owing to the construction work. This is on top of the chaos after 9pm every day, when heavy vehicles enter the city and crowd these roads. While commuters decry the dilapidated roads, locals and shopkeepers allege businesses are suffering.

Gaurav Singh, who lives near Lal Phatak and uses the road every day, said, “Construction work kicks up dust, and its slow pace exacerbates our suffering. Motorists going to Budaun have been driving through dust on both roads for around a year now.”

According to the Bridge Corporation, the Lal Phatak flyover is currently awaiting a no-objection certificate (NOC) from the military.

The plight of those who live near or commute via Choupla and City Station road is similar. Anil, a shopkeeper at Choupla, said, “Traffic is allowed on the dilapidated road close to the construction site, which has created the potholes that commuters have to negotiate while driving to Chowki crossing and Rampur-Moradabad highway. Authorities haven’t taken any steps to even mend that part of the road which is open to traffic.”

“Congestion, which is bad during the day, becomes worse after 9pm as Roadways buses and loaded trucks enter city limits. Choupla remains blocked for around two hours every night, as soon as they enter. I get stuck in jams on my way home almost every day,” said shopkeeper Raju Rathore.

Bridge Corporation officials admitted undertaking construction work and simultaneously ensuring free vehicular movement is a tough job. Speaking to TOI, Bareilly deputy project manager of Uttar Pradesh State Bridge Corporation (UPSBC), B K Sen, said, “The flyover at Choupla is a complex project as it has to be connected with an existing flyover. We’ve already taken steps to ensure traffic is not completely stopped. We’re working on the project from three directions, to ensure that partial movement is allowed. It’s a time-consuming project.”

Sen added, “Approximately 80% of the Lal Phatak project work is completed. The part left is a bridge over the railway line, which will be done by Railways. We’re waiting for an NOC from the military, as land needed to build a service road comes under them. We expect to acquire it within a month.”

Title: ICC women’s WC brings cheer to travel to Aus
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Chennai: ‘Women in Blue’ seem to have come to the rescue for Oz land tourism when bush fires were proving a dampner downunder. Given that the Women’s Cricket World Cup is about to be hosted in Australi starting February 21, the country is seeing a jump in bookings for February and March.

Travel portals such as Ixigo, Pickyourtrail etc are seeing a 10%-20% pick up in bookings compared to December and January. Industry players add that Tourism Australia’s campaign to promote their Women’s World Cup drew interest. The tournament is drawing Indian travellers interest after what Mithali Raj and her team achieved in 2019.

Curated travel platform Pickyourtrail is offering trips woven around the match schedule. The platform is seeing a spike in interest from women after the bushfires caused a 40% drop in travel to the land down under in Decmber-January. “The ICC roped in Mithali Raj, who was a star last world cup and this promotion has struck a chord with cricket fans. We are seeing a 20% increase in booking quarter on quarter,” said Hari Ganapathy, co-founder, Pickyourtrail. The travel curator has packages starting from Rs 35,999 for one match as an official partner for the ICC.

Flight-booking platform Ixigo, which saw a 21% drop in December-January, is seeing an 80% jump since then, in the bookings for February. "While bookings for Australia took a slight dip in Dec and Jan due to the bushfires, there has been a 10%-15% increase in search queries for travel to Australia in February and March as compared to the same time last year. Around 45% of the search queries are coming from Mumbai and Bangalore. Travellers are spending anywhere between Rs 2 -Rs 5 lakh on their trips. Melbourne is the most searched for destination followed by Sydney, Brisbane and Adelaide,” said Aloke Bajpai, co-founder and CEO, Ixigo.

Besides watching the match, women-only travel groups are planning a holiday timed with the World Cup series. Packaged tours company SOTC is seeing a 5%-7% increase in demand for vacations coinciding with the dates for World Cup matches where India is a part of. “We have witnessed a rise in demand for women centric experiences that incorporate wine tasting, Cruises, shopping, dolphin kayaking tours, nature trails, food workshops,” said Daniel D’souza, president and country head, leisure, SOTC.

Title: Madurai: Plea against GO notifying conduct of jallikattu
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Represenatative Image

MADURAI: The Madras high court has sought a response from the state on a plea challenging a government order (GO) notifying the conduct of jallikattu at Srivaikuntam taluk in Tuticorin district.

In his petition, deputy secretary of Anaithu Viyabarigal Sangam at Srivaikundam, M Balasubramanian stated that the government had brought an amendment in the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act, 1960, in order to permit jallikattu which is part of the tradition and culture in Tamil Nadu . He stated that jallikattu is unknown to the people of Srivaikuntam as it was not conducted there in the past.

No one is rearing bulls for the purpose of jallikattu in Srivaikuntam and it has not been organised during any temple festivals. He said the government had passed a GO on February 4, notifying to conduct jallikattu at Srivaikuntam.

Srivaikuntam had witnesses several communal tensions in the past and apprehended that the conduct of jallikattu would cause communal tension in the area.

He noted that the panchayat presidents of 15 villages have sent a representation to the authorities against granting permission to conduct jallikattu.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to quash the GO which was passed notifying the conduct of jallikattu and also sought the authorities concerned not to grant permission for jallikattu at Srivaikuntam.

When the petition was taken up for hearing on Monday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran sought a response from the government and adjourned the case to a further date.

Title: PTR plans alternative sites for night stay of tourists
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Pilibhit: Responding to the directive of the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) in October that all tiger reserves, national parks and wildlife sanctuaries across the country phase out night stay of tourists in core forest areas, Pilibhit Tiger Reserve on Monday sent details of two alternative sites to the state forest administration.

According to principal chief conservator of forest (wildlife) of UP, Sunil Pandey, the state forest administration had consented to wind up all night stay facilities of tourists in core forest areas in phases in a span of five years. Following this, the state forest administration had issued directions to all three tiger reserves in UP to expedite the submission of optional sites for their transformation into the eco tourist spots.

In PTR, tourists can stay the night at a facility in Chuka tourist spot, situated in the dense core forest area of Mahof forest range.

The forest officials said while the NTCA has only banned night stay facility in core forest areas, at least 20% of the core forest will remain open for tourists for day visits.

“Of the two sites, the mouth of river Gomti in Madhotanda has already been developed by the district administration into a tourist destination in association with local volunteers. This comprises the Phulhar lake from where the river originates. It is saturated with Indian soft shell turtles which are listed in Schedule I of the Wildlife Protection Act,” said H Rajamohan, the field director of PTR.

A turtle rescue centre is already being set up at Phulhar lake and this will enhance the tourist centre, he added. The second site is proposed at Katakwara village near Barahi forest range, where seven to eight acres of gram panchayat land is available for developing the tourist spot, Rajamohan said.

Giving details about the proposed tourist spots, deputy director of PTR Naveen Khandelwal said tourists will be able to go boating in nearby river Sharda and bird watching, especially migratory birds in winter.

He said after reviewing the proposal, the state administration will send a team of experts for inspection of the sites before giving approval.

Title: Tech glitches slow down mapping of secretariat
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Technical issues delayed the ongoing secretariat mapping on Monday in the district. District officials have started mapping households with ward/village secretariats a few days ago. The state government had designed a mobile application to collect data and complete the mapping process.

Technical issues such as frequent logging out and server disconnection are being reported in various parts of the district. On the other hand, poor connectivity is the biggest issue being faced by village volunteers in the tribal parts of the district.

Once a household is mapped to a certain volunteer, the volunteer is responsible for service delivery to it. Several migrants have returned to their villages to register their biometrics and get themselves mapped in the initiative but technical issues have slowed the process.

The district officials want to complete the mapping process by February 18 but the public wants an extension of the deadline in view of the technical glitches.

Title: AAP MLA Saurabh Bharadwaj plans to organise ‘Sunderkand’ once a month
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

AAP MLA from Greater Kailash Saurabh Bharadwaj

NEW DELHI: Saurabh Bharadwaj , Aam Aadmi Party MLA from Greater Kailash , on Tuesday announced his decision to organise the recitation of “Sunderkand” on the first Tuesday of every month in areas of his constituency to seek the blessings of Lord Hanuman. The move prompted a sharp reaction from BJP.

Sunderkand is a chapter in Ramcharitmanas written by Tulsidas. It talks about Hanuman’s visit to Lanka. The first event was organised on Tuesday in Chirag Dilli. Bharadwaj participated in the programme and shared a video on Twitter. He said advance bookings had been made for the scheduled programmes and sponsors had also been found.

Delhi BJP spokesperson Praveen Shankar Kapoor claimed that the “sudden attachment” of chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and other AAP functionaries with Hanuman wasn’t a matter of faith, but just melodrama. Kapoor, however, added that he welcomed the move, as “those who were earlier seen at mosques and mazars are now going to temples, even though for political benefits”.

Bharadwaj responded by tweeting that while BJP might be fuming, people were happy to be a part of the programme. “It is so positive,” he stated.

During his election campaign, AAP chief convenor Arvind Kejriwal had told a TV channel that he was a staunch Hanuman bhakt and a firm believer in him since childhood. He had even recited a few lines from Hanuman Chalisa. Kejriwal’s visits to Hanuman Temple were criticised by many in BJP.

Title: Cabinet sub-committee to look into NICE land acquisition
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Bengaluru: The state cabinet on Monday constituted a sub-committee to look into the controversy surrounding land acquisition by Nandi Infrastructure Corridor Enterprise (NICE).

Sources say the sub-committee will specifically look into the acquisition of 370 acres which is under dispute. KIADB had purchased the land on behalf of the company and it is worth Rs 600 crore at current market prices. However, it is said NICE wants the land at rates prevalent when it was notified — at approximately Rs 60 crore.

The government will also examine the possibility of approaching court to iron out land acquisitions wrinkles involving the Bangalore Metro Rail Corporation Limited (BMRCL) and NICE.

A minister said 4.5 acres of land was supposed to have been handed over to BMRCL after managing director Ajay Sethi had initiated a process to purchase it from NICE. However, the government halted the process due to a dispute over NICE owning the property. “As a result, we have decided to form a cabinet sub-committee to discuss all these issues related to land acquisitions,” said the minister.

Meanwhile, another sub-committee has been formed to rationalise duplication of posts under various departments and expenditure on the state exchequer. This includes posts for engineers and other departmental posts, considering 60 to 65% of the government budget goes towards paying salaries.

The government has also decided to expand the ambit of the Open Disfigurement Act, currently only limited to Bengaluru, to the entire state.

Title: Not enough screening for virus at airports, finds study
Content: Chennai: Passengers from China, Hong Kong, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore are being screened at major airports including Chennai for symptoms of novel coronavirus (COVID-19), but people who took a survey and also posted comments on an online platform have mentioned that the screening arrangements are inadequate and porous.Passengers are being screened at special counters using thermal scanners but many travellers say posting two to three staff to screen 300 passengers who arrive by a flight is inadequate. This raised a concern at Chennai airport too, where immigration officials often face passengers who do not meet the screening parameters, say the ones arriving from destinations without infection risk, requesting to be screened.Sources say the number of passengers who arrive from these destinations is too high for staff of the Airport Health Office (APHO) under the ministry of health to handle. Often, they have to go by the self declaration given by the passengers on a card before they disembark.A survey by LocalCircles conducted among 40,000 people across the country, and also by going through the posts put up by people on their platform, show that people are not happy with the kind of screening done at airports. Around 2,000 people from Chennai took part in the survey.A spokesperson of LocalCircles said “multiple LocalCircles members outlined how screening at airports were minimum and one counter with two individuals to take temperature of 300-plus passengers and note their details is just not enough. A few of them reported how people were getting away from the screening. Infection experts on the platform said airport screening only catches about 25% of the patients, highlighting the need for a three, seven, ten and 15-day follow-ups with each patient by the respective state governments. This follow up is not being done in most states.”In Tamil Nadu, 47,645 passengers have been screened so far at Chennai, Trichy, Madurai and Coimbatore airports and 2,256 passengers are in home quarantine for 28 days. In Chennai, 650 passengers are in home quarantine for 28 days.And this has had an impact on foreign travel this summer. At least seven of 10 Indians are staying alert and taking precautions against coronavirus disease (COVID-19) and at least 40% of them are cautious while making travel plans for summer, shows the survey.

Title: Cops who detected last yr’s Gandhisagar lake murder case to be awarded
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nagpur: Detection of murder case in which seven body parts of a man were found at Gandhisagar lake in July last year has won the best detection award in state for September last year.

Crime branch sleuths, then led by senior PI Narendra Hiwre , had cracked the case and also arrested the accused. Currently, Hiwre is the senior PI of Lakadganj police station.

PI Hiwre along with API Pankaj Dhadge, Nitesh Dorlikar, ASI Rajendra Baghel, constable Sandip Mawalkar will be awarded with Rs10,000 cash prize and certificate of appreciation in Mumbai.

The award was announced by director general of police, Maharashtra state SK Jaiswal.

On February 15, city police chief BK Upadhyay has also felicitated PI Hiwre and his team during the crime meet.

In July last year, seven body parts were found in a sack in Gandhisagar, following which additional CP (crime) Nilesh Bharne and DCP (crime) Gajanan Rajmane had directed Hiwre to crack the case.

Crime branch sleuths had scrutinized around 500 CCTV footages, also made sketch of the deceased and conducted investigation across the city. Cops had also searched every single missing person to find out the identity of the deceased and conducted DNA tests.

After a long investigation of 28 days, cops cracked the case and identified the deceased, Sudhakar Rangari.

Cops subsequently arrested the accused in the case and seized the cutter and e-rickshaw used in the crime. CP Upadhayay had then announced an award of Rs75,000 to PI Hiwre and his team.

This is the second award being conferred to Hiwre who first bagged it in 2003 for cracking a murder case of three persons in Khapa. He is the only officer from city and possibly in state to be getting the award twice.

Title: No drug shortage in Tamil Nadu due to COVID-19 scare
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: While several state governments fear shortage of life-saving and essential drugs after the outbreak of COVID-19 ( coronavirus disease) in China, government hospitals in the state say they have adequate stock of most drugs, both at hospitals and warehouses.The Tamil Nadu Medical Services Corporation (TNMSC) had revised its protocol to ensure supply of drugs doesn’t dwindle after January, when China closed down for their new year celebrations. During this time a year ago, state-run hospitals in Tamil Nadu faced an acute shortage of essential drugs used to treat bacterial infections, diabetes and renal diseases. This was because several Indian drug manufacturers could not import the active pharmaceutical ingredient from China during the Chinese New Year holidays.In October 2019, TNMSC made plans to stock adequate drugs. “We have stocks of most medicines to last till June,” said TNMSC managing director P Umanath. “We have ordered for more stock. It’s expected soon and will last us for a few more months after June,” he said. TNMSC officials said the agency could blacklist the company if it does not supply drugs on time.In early 2019, when TNMSC issued bids for drugs, there were no bidders for at least a dozen drugs. “Many of these were inexpensive but essential drugs. We had to call for tenders again to get the drugs,” he said. This was because many states order for generic drugs around the same time and the cost at which Tamil Nadu buys them is lower compared to many other states.Drug manufacturers in the state say there is no short supply though the price of some pharmaceutical ingredients has gone up. “The prices go up around this time every year,” said J Jayaseelan, chairman, Indian Drug Manufacturers Association (Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Pondicherry). “But they settle down by April. We feared that the lockdown due to the virus may bring down the supply and increase prices. But that hasn’t happened yet, and it won’t be fair to block exports assuming there will be a crisis.”

Title: Missing rifles, cartridges: CBI probe sought at Kerala HC
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

ADGP Crime Branch Tomin Thachankery (right) inspects 660 INSAS rifles brought from 13 locations

KOCHI: A CBI probe was sought in high court over the alleged missing of 25 rifles and 12,061 live cartridges from Kerala Police . The demand for a CBI probe was raised in a public interest litigation [PIL] (WP-C No. 4513/2020) filed by George Vattukulam of Thrissur through advocate Joseph Rony Jose.
