A division bench comprising Chief Justice S Manikumar and Justice Shaji P Chaly will consider the PIL during admission hearing on Tuesday.

Stating that the missing of rifles and cartridges, which was pointed out in a CAG report, has serious implication on national security, the petitioner alleged that neither the state government nor the state police chief are conducting a proper investigation.

Though several days have passed since the report was presented, investigation is not progressing and police force is trying to cover up the matter, the PIL claimed. The state police chief has not conducted a fair investigation and the probe into such a serious issue is not progressing due to the clout of influential persons, the petitioner alleged.

State police delayed the investigation and didn’t collect primary evidence, the PIL added. The agency failed to trace the missing ammunition and fix responsibility on the officers who committed the offence. Moreover, there were attempts to cover it up by replacing them with dummy bullets. Police doesn’t know where the missing rifles and cartridges went, the PIL said.

It is feared that this unfortunate incident was caused by corruption in the force due to politicizing through police association, IPS association, etc. The petitioner is worried as to what would happen if the missing arms and ammunition reaches the hands of anti-nationals, stated the petition.

Investigation by a national agency must commence at the earliest and any delay will affect collection of primary evidence, the petitioner has contended while seeking a court directive for a CBI probe.

Title: Candidates challenge list of selected candidates for police constable
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

MADURAI: The Madras high court has issued notice to the Tamil Nadu Uniformed Services Recruitment Board ( TNUSRB ) on a plea moved by 11 candidates challenging the provisional list of selected candidates for the post of grade II police constable, citing that the backlog vacancies under BC (Muslim) were not filled up.

The candidates belonging to various southern districts, belonging to BC Muslim category, in their petition, stated that the TNUSRB had issued a notification dated March 6, 2019 for recruitment of 8,888 posts of grade II police constable, including 62 backlog vacancies of BC (Muslim) category.

They stated that they had cleared the written examination which was conducted on August 25, 2019. They also passed the physical test and participated in certificate verification and were hoping to get selected under BC (Muslim) category.

When TNUSRB issued the provisional selection list on February 4, they were shocked to notice that only 10 backlog vacancies of the 62 were filled up. As per provisions of the Tamil Nadu Government Servants (Conditions of Service) Act, 2016, backlog vacancies should to be filled up first.

Hence, the petitioners moved the high court Madurai bench challenging the provisional selection list and sought to appoint them in the post of grade II police constable under BC (Muslim) category based on their marks. The petitioners also sought for an interim injunction restraining TNUSRB from issuing appointment orders to the provisionally selected candidates till the disposal of the petition.

When the petition was heard on Monday, justice M S Ramesh ordered notice to TNUSRB and adjourned the case to a further date for hearing.

Title: Bhopal: Swachh fleet's GPS on blink over dues,complaints pile up
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Lose control: With the technology gone, the civic body has lost its ability to monitor the movement of its veh... Read More

BHOPAL: The vehicle tracking and monitoring system (VTMS), fitted in Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC) vehicles, has gone offline for almost a week now. This means that the civic body has effectively lost its ability to monitor the movement of its vehicles which transfer garbage, water and other services.

The GPS enabling of vehicles had been outsourced to a private company. However, BMC sources said GPS equipment has been placed offline due to non-payment. Off the record, a representative of the private company confirmed the same.

A meeting with senior BMC officials was held on Monday to resolve the situation. “We are working on putting the systems online. Some of the component of the management has to be taken care of by the smart city project,” said a BMC official.

GPS monitoring of vehicles takes place from the Integrated Control and Command Centre (ICCC) that operates from the Bhopal smart city building in Govindpura. Officials and a representative in ICCC did not alert BMC officials in time. The matter came to light when vehicles were checked at the civic body-run fuel station. Every vehicle's diesel consumption is matched with its GPS log.

When the system was put in place around two years ago, it exposed a diesel scam in the BMC. The civic body has a gas station that provides diesel to about 1,000 vehicles. The BMC station requires about one tank of 22,000 litre diesel each day, which amounts to a fuel bill of about Rs 4 crore per month.

BMC officials have also received complaints over garbage collection in the past week. “We cannot monitor the movement of vehicles. There is no way to determine the location and tracking of vehicles,” said a senior BMC official.

VTMS not only enables the waste management officials to monitor the vehicles, but also work carried out by the vehicles and the processes. The IT enabled system, linked with ICCC, is meant to improve productivity and curb pilferage.

The system is also meant to reduce the running cost, fuel costs and maintenance cost and has also helped in stopping unauthorised usage of municipal vehicles.

The vehicles are attached with GPS devices for location tracking, RFID readers to sense and verify the refuse bin pickups, fuel sensors to keep a track on the fuel used, and weight sensors to get information of weight collected at each garbage pickup location. The garbage bins are also fitted with RFID tag (passive tags), which are read by the garbage vehicle readers each time the bin is picked.

Title: Tweet on debris near Yamuna spurs depts into action
Content:
Construction waste, debris dumped in huge amount beneath Nizammudin Bridge, #Delhi. ~5 acres of #Yamuna #river… https://t.co/SlsvZYVvEq — SANDRP (@Indian_Rivers) 1581850667000

New Delhi: After images of construction debris being dumped on the Yamuna floodplain under the Nizamuddin bridge surfaced on social media on Sunday, both Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) and the NGT-appointed Yamuna Monitoring Committee (YMC) asked Delhi Development Authority (DDA) – the land-owning agency – to submit an action taken report in the matter.The two-member Yamuna monitoring committee, comprising retired NGT expert member, BS Sajwan, and former Delhi chief secretary, Shailaja Chandra, took cognisance of photographs submitted by a twitter user SANDRP (@Indian_Rivers), and asked the agencies concerned to take action to remove the construction debris. It asked DDA vice-chairman to submit a report in the next two days.“SANDRP (@Indian_Rivers) has been putting up posts on twitter relating to the dumping of construction waste and debris in huge quantities beneath the Nizamuddin bridge. There is criticism that DDA’s CCTV cameras are not working. The factual position may please be checked by sending a team to the site,” said the notice dated February 17.“Action may be taken to get the debris removed. The report on findings and action taken, including operation of the CCTV cameras, should be submitted within two days,” the notice added.Bhim Singh Rawat, who posted the pictures, said agencies needed to be pro-active to ensure the floodplain is not encroached upon or reduced to dumping grounds. “We will be monitoring the site to see if the debris gets removed,” said Rawat.“The issue has been duly noted and forwarded to the concerned department,” said DDA on twitter.

Title: Govt doubles Shiv Thalis
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nagpur: The state government on Tuesday has approved to double lunch plates under the Shiv Bhojan Scheme. The district administration may increase the number of plates at existing centres or open new ones.

The state’s food, civil supplies and consumer protection department issued a notification on Tuesday approving 100% times rise in lunch plates.

A pet project of CM Uddhav Thackeray, Shiv Bhojan Scheme was launched on January 26 across the state. Considering the huge response and need for expansion, the government has doubled lunch plates.

All 11 districts of Vidarbha had opened centres where delicious food is being served at the rate of Rs 10. Each lunch plate costs Rs 50. The government gives subsidy of Rs 40 per plate to the NGOs and organizations running the centres.

In Nagpur, the district administration had launched five centres at Daga Hospital, Matru Sewa Sangh’s maternity home in Central Nagpur, RST Cancer Hospital at Tukadoji Putla square, MSRTC Bus stand at Ganeshpeth and APMC Market at Kalamna.

With the latest decision, Nagpur will have to increase lunch plates from 750 to 1,500, Chandrapur 350 to 700, Amravati- 500 to 1,000, Akola- 300 to 600, Wardha- 200 to 400, Yavatmal- 450 to 900, Gondia- 200 to 400, Bhandara- 200 to 400, Gadchiroli- 150 to 300, Buldana- 400 to 800 and Washim- 300 to 600.

However, the timings of lunch has been not expanded. Lunch will be provided only between 12noon and 2pm. Most of the centres are opened at railway, bus stations, government hospitals etc.

Title: Delhi: 400 blue AC buses to hit roads by June
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Transport minister Kailash Gahlot said that in total 1,000 blue buses would be inducted in city fleet

NEW DELHI: Of the 400 blue-coloured , air-conditioned , low-floor buses set to be acquired by Delhi government by June , the first batch of 30 would be hitting the streets very soon. Apart from these, more low-floor buses, including electric ones, are expected to join the city’s public transport fleet this year.

Quoting TOI’s report “Public bus fleet crosses 6,000 for first time in 10 years”, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal tweeted: “It did take time. But finally we were able to overcome all obstacles. So, buses have started arriving. I can assure all Delhiites, soon there won’t be any dearth of buses.”

When the assembly elections were announced, 204 standard-floor buses with hydraulics were added to the fleet of DTC and cluster scheme, taking the total number to 6,223. Transport minister Kailash Gahlot said the 30 blue-coloured buses would be flagged off soon. In total, 1,000 such buses would be inducted. The contract for 650 buses was awarded earlier.

Delhi government also plans induct 1,000 electric buses under the cluster scheme. Though a tender for 300 buses was floated earlier, Gahlot said fresh tenders would be announced. “The parameters will remain broadly the same, we are trying to align it with FAME-2 (Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of Electric Vehicles-2) guidelines,” he added.

Title: Wildlife quiz for tribal students begins
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF)-India in association with the Andhra Pradesh tribal welfare department, Integrated Tribal Development Agency (ITDA) and the Andhra Pradesh forest department, is conducting a wild wisdom quiz (WWQ) for tribal students at the inter-district level from February 17-20.

The Telugu-language quiz on nature and wildlife has been tailored for tribal school students of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana. The quiz will cover around 170 schools and 13,500 students in five clusters in Andhra Pradesh and four clusters in Telangana.

In AP, the clusters include Seethampeta in Srikakulam district, Paderu in Visakhapatnam district, Rampachodavaram in East Godavari district, Tirupati cluster covering Rayalaseema districts and Prakasam cluster covering schools in the Nagarjunasagar Srisailam Tiger Reserve area.

The quiz uses a three-tier system that starts with elimination at the school-level before moving on to the district, state and inter-state levels. All schools have been given quiz books in Telugu.

Sixteen schools in Seethampeta, 36 schools in Paderu, 22 schools in Rampachodavaram and 34 schools from Rayalaseema are participating at the district-level. The school that secures the first position in the district level will move to the state-level quiz at Vijayawada on February 25.

Title: Defamation suits: Stalin asked to appear in court on February 24, March 4
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Chennai: Chennai district sessions court has summoned DMK president M K Stalin to appear before the court on February 24 and March 4 in connection with three criminal defamation complaints filed against him by the AIADMK government.

The issue pertains to complaints filed by the city public prosecutor for his social media posts in December 29, 2019, condemning the arrest of six people for protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and National Register of Citizen (NRC) by putting up kolams. He also criticized the government and chief minister , which was published in a Tamil daily the following day, the complaint claimed. The second complaint was about an article on DMK’s mouthpiece ‘ Murasoli ’ on December 28, 2019, where Stalin criticized the BJP-led central government’s report on Good Governance Index, in which Tamil Nadu topped.

The third complaint was about Stalin’s criticism of municipal administration minister S P Velumani. Stalin alleged the minister was involved in corruption to the tune of Rs 1,000 crore.

Title: Nine anti-CAA protesters get bail
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

RAMPUR: Nine anti-CAA protesters were released on bail from Rampur district jail on Monday evening. They were released after court officials removed errors and corrected the spellings of their names and sections imposed on them.

On Saturday evening, 17 anti-CAA protesters were released on bail. The remaining nine protesters were not released due to technical errors in their release orders.

The court of the district and sessions judge has so far granted bail to 26 anti-CAA protesters after the investigating officer dropped charges of heinous offenses like murder, attempt to murder and dacoity against them.

Title: Taapsee Pannu shares behind the scenes photo with Tanvi Azmi of 'Thappad'
Content:
“Kaash aapne usko sikhaaya hota... that it’s not ok” Such joy to work with some actors who you have admired on scr… https://t.co/EChPizrMRB — taapsee pannu (@taapsee) 1581942029000

Actor Taapsee Pannu on Sunday shared a behind the scene picture ( BTS ) from her upcoming film 'Thappad' and expressed her joy over sharing screen space with veteran actor Tanvi Azmi In the photograph Pannu is seen standing and working with Azmi in a kitchen set-up."Kaash aapne usko sikhaaya hota... that it's not ok" Such joy to work with some actors who you have admired on screen for years," she wrote in her picture caption.Further revealing that Azmi is essaying the role of her mother in law in the film, Pannu wrote, "Tanvi Azmi ma'am plays Amrita's Mother In Law and the first shot I gave for #Thappad was with her."The 32-year-old actor has been sharing BTS pictures from the flick ever since the release of its trailer.In 'Thappad' Pannu is seen essaying the role of a woman who does not tolerate domestic violence in the name of love and relationships.Helmed by Anubhav Sinha , the film is set to reach big screens on February 28 this year.

Title: Why no Hindi, English signage at Simhachalam, ask devotees
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The newly-opened museum of ancient jewellery at the Sri Varaha Lakshmi Nrusimha Swamy temple at Simhachalam , set up at an estimated cost of Rs 1 crore, lacks signage in English and in Hindi.

A devotee, P Ranganatha Sharma from Karnataka, expressed surprise at boards displaying information only in Telugu on a recent visit to the temple. “I did not understand what is written on the display boards for the jewellery inside the museum. It would be good if the temple management could provide information in both Hindi and English,” Sharma told TOI.

Another devotee said that apart from display boards inside the musuem, the temple should also set up signage at the foothill, toilets, bus stops and other spots around the temple in Hindi and in English.

When contacted, Simhachalam temple executive officer M Venkateswara Rao said they would take into consideration the devotees’ suggestion to have English and Hindi signboards inside the museum. Venkateswara Rao added that the management is looking into the possibility of introducing Odia and English sign boards, instead of Hindi and English, in view of the fact that a majority of visiting devotees are from Odisha.

The management is also considering includingthe history and importance in the description of each artefact on display, Venkateswara Rao said.

Title: Kerala govt: Ban on compostable carry bags too
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representational Image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state government reiterated that there is a complete ban on plastic carry bags , including those made of compostable materials , in the state. Though the government has exempted product-attached straws from the ban, it banned plastic sapling bags .

The latest clarification comes in the wake of a decision taken by a task force, which was constituted to address concerns and complaints regarding ban on plastic in the state. The task force, headed by principal secretary, department of environment, had met on January 28 and February 4 to discuss various issues raised through representations by organizations and review the general situation after the plastic ban. The exemption for compostable materials shall be applicable only for grow bags and garbage bags meant for segregation and collection of biomedical waste.

The task force noted that the market is being invaded by fake compostable carry bags and both the public and shop owners find it unable to identify actual compostable carry bags and it defeated the very purpose of the plastic ban.

Even though the government had issued a clarification specifically for the use of compostable carry bags listing down alternative materials that could be used as substitutes for the banned single use plastic items, compostable bags continued to be in use as carry bags.

In the order issued to clarify use of compostable carry bags, the government had mentioned that carry bags whether made of compostable materials or other materials were banned and instead only cloth or paper bags are allowed to be used as carry bags.

In the new order, there is an exemption for grow bags as compostable materials can be used. The government has said that compostable products should bear the details of the manufacturer, marketing agency, material specification, date of manufacture, batch number, CPCB approval details with license number and validity in the form of QR code. The product shall bear the title ‘this is a purely compostable product’ written in English and Malayalam.

Title: Barelvi cleric Tauqeer Raza booked for derogatory remarks against PM Modi, Amit Shah
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

RAMPUR: Police have registered a case against Sunni Barelvi cleric and Ittehad-e-Millat Council president Maulana Tauqeer Raza for allegedly making derogatory remarks against Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah during an anti-CAA protest in Sambhal on Sunday evening.

Nakhasa station house officer Divender Dhama said that an FIR was registered against Raza under section 504 (intentional insult), 505 (incitement) and 153A (promoting enmity) of IPC based on a complaint lodged by sub-inspector Rambhool Singh.

According to police, Raza was addressing the anti-CAA protest at Pucca Bagh, where women have been on an agitation since January 24, when he made the remarks.

Raza said, “I am a law abiding citizen and always respect the law. The protests across the country are an attempt to save the Constitution. The time has now come to see which ideology prevails here — Gandhivadi or Godsevadi.” “I have been booked for raising questions against the government. I welcome this move and if they want to arrest me, I’m ready for that too,” he added.

The cleric said, “However, registering cases and sending people to jail is not the solution. They (BJP leadership) have to come forward to resolve the issue through meaningful dialogue.”

The SHO said, “Notices have been served to 75 people, including nine women, under section 149 of CrPC for staging a protest. The administration has also identified 11 people for instigating the protesters. They have been served notices under CrPC sections 107 (security for keeping peace) and 116 (inquiry as to truth of information) asking them to sign a personal bond of Rs 50 lakh each with an undertaking that they would not indulge in any disruptive activity.”

Title: Man gets life term for raping 4-year-old
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: Additional district and sessions judge (POCSO), Lakhimpur Kheri district , Kuldeep Saxena on Monday awarded life imprisonment to a 32-year-old man for raping a four-year-old girl in Hyderabad area of the district in November 2019.

Kheri police had arrested the accused immediately after the complaint was lodged and SSP, Kheri, Poonam (who goes by her first name) herself monitored the investigation of the case.

According to sources, on November 17, the survivor was playing outside her house when accused Mukesh offered her a candy, took her to an abandoned place and raped her. The girl was admitted to hospital with severe injuries. The accused also set her house on fire after her family lodged a police complaint against him.

The chargesheet was presented within 10 days of the crime by investigating officer Dharamdas Siddharth in the court of ADJ Kuldeep Saxena. The proceedings of the case was duly monitored by the POCSO cases monitoring cell.

Additional district government counsel (ADGC) Prabhat Yadav said, “The survivor’s mother and the doctor who conducted the medical examination were the main witnesses in this case. ADJ Saxena has slapped a fine of Rs 14,000 on the accused and sentenced him for life for the heinous crime.”

Title: Court seeks more details on invasive species
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Chennai: A full bench of the Madras high court on Monday directed the state government to get an expert opinion from the National Environmental Engineering Research Institution (NEERI), Nagpur, on the ill effects of Prosopis juliflora ( seemai karuvelam), particularly on depletion of groundwater.

The full bench comprising chief justice A P Sahi, Justice M M Sundresh and Justice M Sundar passed the order on a PIL moved by advocate A Meganathan, seeking to forebear the authorities from drastically removing seemai karuvalam trees without scientific proof they have a negative effect. In April 2017, the first bench headed by then Chief Justice Indira Banerjee stayed the order to fell the trees and referred the matter to the full bench. Subsequently, an expert committee constituted by the court opined against removing them for alleged ill effects. Objecting to the opinion of the committee, petitioners including MDMK leader Vaiko impleaded in the case.

When the plea came up for hearing on Monday, MDMK leader Vaiko who impleaded in the case, appeared before the full bench and submitted reports explaining the ill effects of the trees. Recording the submissions, the bench said more material was to be relied on and ordered the state to consult with NEERI.

The bench adjourned the hearing to June 10.

Title: ‘Super specialty block in 6 months’
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Panaji: Health minister Vishwajit Rane on Monday stated that the super specialty block coming up in the premises of Goa Medical College ( GMC ) and Hospital , Bambolim, will be commissioned within six months.

“I’m looking forward to Prime Minister Narendra Modi inaugurating the largest super specialty hospital of the country,” Rane said in a Facebook post. He further said he received support from chief minister Pramod Sawant in taking the project forward.

The Rs 450 crore-project, built under the Pradhan Mantri Swashthya Suraksha Yojna (PMSSY), is nearing completion.

All the existing super specialties of the tertiary care hospital will be shifted into super specialty block, as also, the government plans to add a few more.

The health minister is keen on starting gastroenterology super specialty and cadaveric transplants in the state when the new block becomes operational.

Title: Genderqueer struggle to get a roof over their head
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Chennai: As a transwoman, life is a daily struggle for G Oorvashi. Despite it, she has been sheltering six other gender queer women for the past few years. For homelessness is a serious issue faced by people who are assigned female at birth (AFAB). Shunned by families, they are also refused shelter in government and private homes, say members of Srishti Madurai, which has been running a helpline for genderqueer and LGBTI+ people for the past 10 years.

“Every week, we get three to five calls from AFAB women — intersex women, lesbian, and transmen — most of who are from lower middle-class families, and lower income groups,” says Gopi Shankar Madurai, founder of Srishti Madurai, an LGBTQIA+ student volunteer movement. “Most of them are looking for a place to stay and also moral support.”

Though Srishti Madurai officially launched the 24X7 helpline – +91 9092282369 – only in 2012, it has been in existence for 10 years. “Our volunteers speak Tamil and English and we also direct callers to regional volunteers who can speak Telugu, Hindi and Malayalam,” says Gopi, adding that they started the helpline as two of their own members committed suicide . “One was a transman, who was being pressurised to get married and the other a genderqueer person who was struggling to get social acceptance. That’s why ‘Just Having Someone Understanding To Talk To Can Save A Life.’ is the tagline of our helpline.”

LGBTI+ persons are often shunned by their families and some are forced to turn to sex work and begging. They also face threats from family members, landlords and neighbours. Domestic violence includes physical force, sexual violence, wrongful confinement, forced marriage, and involuntary institutionalization. “Most of the AFAB women who leave home are aged between 20 and 30 years,” says Gopi, adding that most of the people who have reached out for help are from a non-metropolitan or rural background. “Unlike transwomen , when these women leave home, they do not have an organised community structure where they can live together. Government and private hostels also do not accept them.”

Annalakshmi, 23, from Sivaganga, for instance, left home this January as she was being pressurised to get married by her family members. “I am not attracted to men and feel I may be a transman but my family members beat me up when I said I didn’t want to get married,” she says.

Once the women contact Srishti, they are given shelter. “We negotiate with house owners who are known to us personally, or we send them to our transwomen volunteers,” says Gopi. For instance, Oorvashi, 34, has been sheltering and counselling six women, and also helping them with vocational training. “Many of them are from villages, but I have managed to help four of them find jobs in Chennai,” she says.

Initially, the women are given Rs 5,000 to Rs 10,000. “We then find them employment based on their qualification or give them vocational training, stitching bags, towels etc,” says Gopi. “Since we are getting an increasing number of calls for help we are also planning to start a care home for AFAB women, which will be headed by Oorvashi. Initially, we will be hiring an independent house in Madurai, which will accommodate people from rural south India. But we need a lot of resources and we are self-funded.”

Title: 9% of teen internet users face cyberbullying: Study
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

New Delhi: One in every three school students who use internet suffer from negative experience , including cyberbullying, a study has claimed. According to the study conducted by Child Rights and You (CRY), around 9% of the adolescent internet users were subjected to cyberbullying but only one out of the two among them reported such incidents.

The study involved 630 students in the age group of 13-18 years from eight schools in Delhi, Noida and Faridabad. Cyberbullying involves hateful comments on online platforms or through text messages. The affected students said it caused them psychological stress and humiliation.

“I had made a meme of a friend (a boy junior to me). I had shown him wearing the ‘Superman undergarment’ and circulated it within our friends’ WhatsApp group. It was an innocent playful activity and we had a good laugh at it. Then someone posted it on Facebook and made it public by tagging that boy,” Anjana (name changed), a Class XI student, has been quoted as saying. Few days later, she added, the boy started getting “comments and threatening messages that his meme has been posted on adult sites. We all got together and deleted all our accounts and were away from social media for two months”.

Another student told surveyors how a childhood photo of a friend, a 16-year-old girl, which was posted by her father on social media, attracted needless attention and comments. “The girl still stays away from social media,” she said.

According to Soha Mitra, the regional director of CRY (North), online safety is fast emerging as an important protection aspect to the wellbeing of children and youth. “While CRY recognises the internet as a vital medium for participation and expression of children, it is the duty of parents, communities, the state and the society” to protect children and empower them to save themselves from online addiction and threats, she said.

The study’s recommendations include awareness and capacity building among children, convergence of internet safety rules and curriculum, proactive engagement of parents and caregivers, and review of existing cyber laws.

The study shows 60% of the boys and 40% of the girls have their own device while almost half of them have two or more devices to access the internet. Three in every five adolescents — 63% — said they had accepted friendship request only from known people, while the rest added friends of friends and even strangers, it adds.

The internet exposes adolescents to cybercrimes like cyberbullying, hacking and misuse of online profile, morphing of images or videos, and internet addiction, it states.

Title: Kerala: Houseboats breaching rules to face govt action
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representational Image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The government will confiscate all houseboats operating without a registration and licence, while initiating stringent measures against those which do not follow rules and safety norms.

The decision was taken at a high-level meeting chaired by tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran on Monday.

As registration is mandatory for houseboats that ferry tourists in the Kerala ’s backwaters, there are many houseboats which operate under a single registration number and several others which do not have a registration, informed officials who were representatives of the department of ports.

Ports department will confiscate houseboats without registration, will deploy 15 ex-servicemen and install CCTVs for the safekeeping of confiscated boats. A decision was also taken to make bio-toilets compulsory in houseboats and also renovate the sewage treatment plants at Alappuzha and Kumarakom. Houseboats without registration will now be denied entry at boat jetties under the tourism department. Directives will be given to avoid storage of several inflammable materials in kitchen cabins of houseboats.

Fire and rescue services department will examine the quality of safety equipment and systems in each houseboat and ensure that the staff, who deal with safety, have adequate licence and wear uniforms. Besides, Kerala Institute of Tourism and Travel Studies will be entrusted to conduct a compulsory training for houseboat employees.

Among other decisions were speedy procedures for purchase of fire boats, conduct of surprise checks and ensuring GPS system in all houseboats.

Title: Lack of green turfs stunts progress of football in AP
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Visakhapatnam: At a time when states such as Kerala, Goa and Odisha are promoting football by creating state-of-the-art infrastructure, football infrastructure in Andhra Pradesh remains in a sorry state. The state does not have a single green turf where national and international events can be organised.

There are many reasons for the sorry state of football infrastructure in the state, of which, one is official apathy. While the Andhra Pradesh Football Association (APFA) has been requesting the government to allocate grounds to APFA, nothing has been done so far.

Kosaraju Gopalakrishna, APFA president told TOI that the state needs at least four to five FIFA-approved green turfs to promote football. “The advantage of green turfs is that players don’t get hurt if they fall. While Visakhapatnam does have grounds, they are not suitable for football events. There is need to develop these grounds for football,” Gopakrishna said.

“We have approached the sports department many times and have requested them to improve the quality of playing fields in terms of the level prescribed by FIFA for professional football. But our pleas have fallen on deaf ears,” said the APFA president adding that if the government allocates a playground to APFA, the association will develop it according to FIFA standards by mobilising funds.

Meanwhile, T Anil Kumar, a football enthusiast said that not just playgrounds, there is also a dearth of qualified coaches in Andhra Pradesh. “The government is supposed to appoint coaches in all parts of the state. Visakhapatnam has produced many talented footballers who have represented clubs in West Bengal,” he said.

The ministry of youth affairs and sports had promised to develop more than 600 playgrounds in Andhra Pradesh between 2008 and 2014. But a majority of those grounds have turned into dumping yards owing to the lack of maintenance.

“The TDP government had promised a lot for sports in Andhra Pradesh, but did nothing. If the YSRC government too neglects sports, it will dent AP’s image in the sporting fraternity,” another football enthusiast said.

Title: Tamil Nadu Open University VC tells students to use mobiles judiciously
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Madurai Corporation commissioner S Visakan (second from the right) handing over the prizes to winners of 'Art ... Read More

MADURAI: Students should use mobile phone judiciously as it can spoil their future if misused, said K Parthasarathy, vice-chancellor of Tamil Nadu Open University .

Speaking after taking part in the Art Expo organized under Happy Schooling initiative for corporation school students at Maditssia on Monday, Parthasarathy said, “Mobile phones pose a grave threat to students and are potentially the most destructive equipment in their hands if they do not know to use it judiciously.” However, he clarified that it can be the best tool for education if students use it properly.

He also lauded the creativity of students and the way they explained their output.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan said that students should always aim to achieve big in life and should not get demotivated by their present status. Many eminent people in the society were students of government and corporation schools. HCL founder Shiv Nadar is an alumnus of a school run by the Madurai Corporation , he recalled.

“Once a goal is set, the mind will start working towards it subconsciously. In today’s world, competition is high and one has to work a lot in order to achieve success. Victory is awaiting those who run the extra mile than others and those who work towards their gold when others are sleeping,” Visakan said.A large number of students participated and displayed various items they had created from waste. The three best were selected and given prizes. Happy Schooling programme is jointly implemented by the Madurai Corporation, HCL foundation and M S Chellamuthu Trust and Research Foundation .

Title: Madurai: All crew not likely to leave Diamond Princess
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

MADURAI: While the Government of India has started taking efforts to fly the Indian crew members on board Diamond Princess back home, it is learnt that not all Indians as well as those from other countries are interested in leaving the ship ahead of the quarantine period.

One of the factors is the attractive gifts offered by the ship management such as double salary, in addition to liquor, variety of food and gifts such as clothing to keep the crew in good spirits and extend their stay in the ship. Some crew members are also worried over rumours that they should remain under poor conditions during the 14-days quarantine period in India.

The crew waiting to be taken back home have requested the government of India to help them reach home early without being detained at a faraway camp and under stringent conditions as they have already been under quarantine for so long and proved that they are not tested positive for nCoV.

Title: Saligao: Tivim locals opposed to mud on playground
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The removal of mud dumped on and outside the playground.

SALIGAO: Around 100 Tivim locals gathered on the ground of the St Christopher Sports Club on Sunday demanding the removal of mud dumped on and outside the playground.

A local, Robert Colaco, had alerted villagers about the dumping, which was being carried out in a truck allegedly belonging to one pancha. He also explained how haphazard work was carried out on the ground in the name of development.

The St Christopher Sports Club, which maintains the ground, had earlier requested permission from the panchayat for undertaking repair work of the ground, slated to cost Rs 2 lakh. The panchayat, however, denied permission.

At a subsequent gram sabha , Colaco requested that a supervisory committee be formed to oversee repairs of the ground. Locals say this point was intentionally not recorded.

When questioned by the locals, Tivim sarpanch Sandeep Kauthankar and panchas present, Sandeep Khaunthankar, Shivadas Kambli, Michael Fernandes and Arjun Aroskar, were unable to reply about which scheme work on the ground was being carried out under or who was funding the project. The villagers also questioned the panchayat members as to what the difficulty was, in forming the committee.

Title: Cyanide Mohan Case: Cyanide Mohan convicted in 19th murder case
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

File photo of Mohan Kumar

MANGALURU: The sixth additional district and sessions court judge Sayeedunnisa on Monday sentenced Cyanide Mohan to life imprisonment for the murder of a woman from Kasaragod. This is the 19th case that in which he is being held guilty.

Public prosecutor Jayarama Shetty told TOI that the 23-year-old victim, who rolled beedis for a livelihood, had gone missing from her house on January 3, 2006. The two met at a wedding and he introduced himself as Mohan Kumar, a teacher from Vittal.

Later, Mohan visited the victim’s house and evinced interest in marrying her. She told her family that she was going for a picnic and left home on January 3, 2006. Both travelled to Mysuru and spent the night at a lodge. The woman came wearing her jewellery as advised by Mohan.

Like in all other cases, after having sex with the victim, the next day (January 4), he told her they would be going to a temple for puja. He told her to leave the gold in the hotel room as advised by a priest. Mohan then took her to the KSRTC bus stand where he gave her a tablet laced with cyanide, saying it’s a contraceptive pill. He then asked her to go to the toilet in the bus stand and take it.

Police constable Basavaraj from Lashkar police station found her lying in the toilet. She was declared brought dead at the hospital.

The connect to Mohan was made when he was arrested in another case in October 2009. Based on the woman’s father, Lashkar police converted the case into a murder. The court examined 48 witnesses and verified 70 documents.

Mohan has been awarded life sentence and fined Rs 25,000 under IPC Section 302 (murder).

Meanwhile, he also has been sentenced to 10 years of rigorous imprisonment (RI) and penalty of Rs 5,000 under IPC Section 366 (kidnapping), one year of RI under Section 417 (cheating), seven years of RI and penalty of Rs 5,000 under Section 376 ( rape ), 10 years and Rs 5,000 under Section 328 (Causing hurt by means of poison), five years and Rs 5,000 under Section 392 (robbery), 10 years and Rs 5,000 under Section 394 (voluntarily causing hurt in committing robbery) and seven years and Rs 5,000 under Section 201 (causing disappearance of evidence).

Title: Govt to fly home Indian crew on board quarantined ship
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

ON WAVES OF FEAR

MADURAI: The Indian embassy in Tokyo has informed Indian crew on board cruise ship Diamond Princess that those interested in leaving the ship before the end of their mandatory 14-day quarantine period can opt for the same by filling the form sent to them by email on Monday afternoon (Japan time). They are likely to be flown back home in a chartered flight. This has given a sigh of relief for the crew on board the ship that has been quarantined off the Yokohama port in Japan since the beginning of this month.

Around 3 pm (Japanese time), a few of the Indian crew received mails titled ‘Urgent’ from the embassy stating that it was a message to all the Indian crew members and that it was to facilitate their travel to India. Asking for their willingness to leave the ship before the expiry of the mandatory quarantine requirements, they were also asked whether they would like to avail travel by a chartered flight.

It stated that boarding the proposed chartered flight will be subject to the body temperature of the individual being normal at the time of disembarkation/boarding. The form made it clear that those who opt to leave the ship will be put under ‘mandatory quarantine of 14 days’ at government designated place(s). On refusing to the above, they will remain under quarantine on board Diamond Princess in accordance with Japanese regulations.

Nearly 150 Indian crew members, including five from Tamil Nadu are on board the ship. They have been identified as Anbalagan from Madurai, Muthu from Trichy, Daniel from Chengalpattu, Dhamodharan from Tuticorin district and Jayaraj from Coimbatore. Jayaraj is with the security department and the four others are chefs. It is learnt that all the five are not infected till Monday.

“At least four Tamils have expressed their willingness to prematurely end the quarantine and fly back to India. We thought that the passengers as well as the crew have a simultaneous quarantine. But we were wrong. Now we have understood that February 19 is the end of the quarantine period for the passengers and that the 14-days quarantine for crew will begin only after that,” Anbalagan said.

The form asked the crew members to reply not later than 12 pm (Japan time) on Tuesday (February 18). Thanking the government for taking efforts to bring them back, the crew also said that the letter was not sent to all the Indian crew members. They suggested that the authorities could have made an announcement in the ship and circulated the forms to all the crew members.

The crew members did not waste time as they filled the forms with details such as their passport numbers and sent it back to the embassy, after which the embassy officials got in touch with them over phone for a confirmation. The main reason for opting for the same is that the ship is still infected and it is unsafe to stay further.

Decision on the mode of transportation of the crew to India would be taken based on the number of applications they receive till Tuesday.

Title: ‘Magna Talyakathee’, a drama of love, joy & sorrow
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Artistes perform in the play ‘Magna Talyakathee’, written by Mahesh Elkunchwar, at 21st Bharat Rang Mahotsav a... Read More

Nagpur: ‘Magna Talyakathee’, a play by legend Mahesh Elkunchwar and directed by Venkatesh S Naik, was staged at the 21st Bharat Rang Mahotsav. The second part of the trilogy by eminent playwright Elkunchwar, ‘Magna Talyakathee’ is a family drama linked to ‘Wada Chirebandi’, the first part of the play.

Set in rural Vidarbha, the play is about relationships, aspirations, joy, sorrow, anger, insecurities and many other human emotions.

While a few things improve, many disintegrate, irrevocably. Reference to caste, apart from prejudice between two Brahmin sub-castes, a grain crisis and urbanization are the subjects of the hapless protagonists.

The expressions and the typical Marathi lingo were beautifully presented by the performers. Every line reflected the Maharashtrian culture and lifestyle of Vidarbha. The play was about a traditional joint family which makes challenging adjustments due to modernization.

The play highlights the three generations of Dharangaonkar Deshpande and the struggle of every family member. In the first play ‘Wada Chirebandi’, the hardships of the family are shown, including 10 years later, when the children grow up.

Bhaskar’s sons, Parag and Ranju, are about to get married when his younger brother Sudhir, along with his wife Anjali and son Abhay, who studies in America, return to the wada.

While Parag envies his cousin Abhay because he could not pursue his own education in Mumbai, Anjali feels her son will become a victim of the backward environment. Parag is not the most loved person in the village because he is in a relationship with a widow.

With time, Parag’s anger disappears and he bonds with Abhay, remembering their childhood days and finally, there’s peace in the household.

Parag and Abhay go back to their childhood spot, a pond where they used to spend hours gazing at the stars. Ranju, Parag’s sister, had eloped with her teacher 10 years ago and is still taunted and hated by her brother and family members.

In between the problems of the family, the soft and bubbly character of Ranju adds life to the play, making it a visual treat for the audience.

It was the concluding play of the weeklong Rang Mahotsav. The play was presented by Kala Academy, Goa.

Title: Policy SOS for stranded marine life
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Gandhinagar: India will launch a marine turtle and marine stranding management policy in 2020, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said on Monday. Addressing the inaugural session of the 13th Conference of Parties (COP) to the Convention on Migratory Species (CMS) in Gandhinagar via a video link, Modi said that single-use plastics have been a challenge in environment protection. He said Indians are urgently striving to reduce its usage. He said that the policy will also deal with the pollution caused by micro-plastics in oceans.

India proposes to strengthen its association with Asean and East Asia Summit countries, Modi said. He said the move will be in sync with the Indo Pacific Ocean Initiative (IPOI), in which India will play a leadership role.

Several protected areas in India share boundaries with protected areas of neighbouring countries. “Cooperation in conservation of wildlife through the establishment of ‘trans-boundary protected areas’ will lead to positive outcomes,” Modi said. India is a part of the Central Asian Flyway for migratory birds. “To conserve birds along the flyway and in their habitats, India has prepared a national action plan,” Modi said. “India will be happy to facilitate the preparation of action plans for other countries.” India will hold the presidency of the COP-CMS for the coming three years.

Highlighting one of India’s green achievements, Modi said that the country’s forest cover has increased significantly. The present assessment indicates that the forest cover is 21.67% of the total geographical area of the country, he added.

As for the 13th Conference of Parties event, its theme is ‘Migratory species connect the planet and together we welcome them home’. “Gujarat is an important migratory flyway,” said Gujarat chief minister Vijay Rupani at the inaugural function. “The Indian philosophy of ‘Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam’ — the world is one family — gels well with the theme. And we welcome all our guests by saying, “Atithi Devo Bhav”, or guest is God.”

Another part of the inaugural programme was the release of “My Stamp”, personalized sheets of postage stamps of India Post. Union environment minister Prakash Javdekar released the stamp. Personalization is achieved by printing a thumbnail image on a selected template. “Dharti bula rahi hai”, a song specially penned for the occasion by Prasoon Joshi and sung by minister of state for environment Babul Surpriyo, was also released in the inauguration session.

Title: Gujarat GIBs to get males from Rajasthan: Centre
Content:
Caption

Gandhinagar: With the last male Great Indian bustard ( GIB ) gone missing from the state for over one year now, the ministry of forest, environment and climate change (MoEFCC) has decided to push for translocation of a couple of male GIBs from Rajasthan to Gujarat.Soumitra Dasgupta, additional director general of forests (Wildlife), MoEFCC in an interaction with TOI said that the MoEFCC is aware that there are no surviving males left in Gujarat and hence the GIB population has reduced to less than seven in the state.“We, as a part of the long-term conservation of great Indian bustards have decided to introduce a GIB male from Rajasthan. The ministry is coordinating with both the state governments and soon a meeting will be held to finalize the modalities.”Dasgupta said that the in situ breeding programme in Rajasthan was not just for one state but it was for all states with GIBs including Rajasthan, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh,and even Karnataka where 12 GIBs have been spotted along with three chicks recently. The Karnataka government was asked to join the project, and they too have joined it.“As a part of the long-term project, the MoEFCC will steps up efforts to get the male from Gujarat,” he said.About two years ago, Vasundhara Raje who was the then chief minister of Rajasthan had refused to give GIB eggs to Gujarat for in situ breeding programme after which the MoEFCC and the Wildlife Institute of India shifted the breeding centre from Gujarat to Rajasthan. In August 2019, Rajasthan forest and environment minister Sukhram Vishnoi had said, “Even if the Gujarat government sends a proposal for getting a male from Rajasthan, it will be difficult to catch a male GIB and transport it to Gujarat. The Gujarat government should in fact catch all its female GIBs and send them to Rajasthan. Rajasthan has already set up a breeding centre with the help from Wildlife Institute of India (WII) and Abu Dhabi."A WII expert associated with the captive breeding centre in Rajasthan, said, “Sending a couple of male GIBs to Gujarat may not be a fruitful move as Gujarat has not addressed the principal issue, the overhead high-tension power lines in the GIB habitat. We want Gujarat to move all the high-tension lines underground or sending a male GIB will not serve any purpose. We are told that Gujarat government has even decided to have it own breeding centre where they intend to catch female GIBs from Kutch Bustard Sanctuary (in Naliya) and breed with the Rajasthan males.”Officials in the Gujarat forest department said that after the GIB population in the state fell to 20, it was proposed that the high-tension power lines be moved underground, but the state government has been dragging its feet. Even now, with no males left, the government has not addressed the issue.However, Dasgupta said, “The ministry has asked the power distribution companies to take high-tension lines in the country including those in GIB areas underground for 33kV lines but for 66kV transmission lines the companies were reluctant, as it was a very costly affair. We can only recommend or suggest such steps, but we cannot force any one to take power lines underground.”

Title: Torso of 30-year-old man found in Periyar river
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative Image

THENI: The torso of a 30-year-old man who was murdered by unidentified people was found in the Periyar river in Thondamanthurai village in Theni district . The victim has been identified as R Vigneshwaran from Nandagopalan Temple Street in Cumbum. The deceased is said to be addicted to ganja and other abusive substances.

According to police, with the water level in Mullaperiyar river having come down, locals have been fishing in the river using anglers. On Sunday night, they saw a youth and a woman dumping a gunny bag in the river. After they left in a two-wheeler, the fishermen called up the local police and informed them. A police team reached there and when they opened, they found a body without head and limbs. Police have picked up the victim’s mother R Selvi , 50, and younger son Vijaybarath, 25, and conducted an inquiry with them based on suspicion. Police also recovered the missing head from a field from Veeranayakkankulam near Cumbum and are searching to find the missing hands and legs.

Title: Kolkata: Crowd thins on first working day, but E-W staffers expect rush as week progresses
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: After a crowded weekend, truncated services of East-West Metro saw a thinner crowd on the first day of the week. While the number of joyriders, who had kept trains full since the commencement of the service on February 14, came down sharply, it was time for office-goers to take over. But the ticket counters didn’t see long queues on Monday morning.The crowd grew as the day progressed, though. The Sector V and Salt Lake Stadium stations saw a reasonable turnout in the afternoon. Unlike the first weekend, joyriders were replaced with those who availed the services to commute to work or for convenience. Calcutta State Transport Corporation employee Mrinal Das took a train to the Salt Lake Stadium station en route to work. Das said it was convenient for him. “It is getting warmer and I would prefer to avoid commuting in buses, which are crowded anyway. I plan to take an AC bus from Salt Lake Stadium, which is also cheaper for me,” said Das.Librarian Priyanka Naskar, a Sector V employee, walked into the swank, new Metro station on her way to Phoolbagan. It was her first ride since she had avoided the weekend crowd. “I am not for joyrides but the Metro will be extremely useful for me. I will be using it daily now. Everything about the East-West Metro is nice and perfect,” she said.Private hospital executive Tanmay Sil rued that the Metro services begin a little too late for him to be able to take a train to work. But he has decided to use it on the way back from work. “Since I stay at Sector V, I will be getting down at the station and walk home. It’s a pleasure to ride this Metro and I feel really proud as a Kolkatan,” Sil said.It could get crowded as the week progresses since many are still figuring out how to use the new Metro to commute to work, felt those at the ticket counters. “This is still a truncated service and the first day of the week. The crowd should swell towards the middle of the week,” said a Metro employee. It will indeed change the way people in the north-eastern part of the city travel, said state government employee Taj Ahmed. “My office is at Phoolbagan and commuting to work has suddenly become very easy and comfortable for me. And what’s more, the Metro is also faster and cheaper. I couldn’t have asked for more,” said Ahmed.
