Title: Kolkata: Fire kiosks a must for new high-rises
Content:
Representative Image

KOLKATA: The state fire services department has made it mandatory for all new high-rises, which are above 45 metres in height or has a floor area of more than 2 lakh square feet, to install a fully functional fire-service kiosk within the premises. The rule will also be applicable for education institutions equipped with air-conditioning, basement parking and having an auditorium with a capacity of more than 500 people.While inaugurating a fire-service kiosk at Acropolis Mall in south Kolkata on Monday, director general of fire services Jag Mohan stressed on the need of such kiosks at all major highrises. “We are already giving recommendation for all buildings that are 45m tall and wherever there is a steady footfall. We are issuing this recommendation for quite a few months now. For all the new buildings that are coming up, this clause is included in the fire-safety recommendation. For the existing buildings, the law cannot be applied retrospectively but we are asking them too to set up the kiosks on their premises,” he said.As per the new order, the department is recommending a dedicated kiosk measuring about 100ftX125ft area, preferably located on the ground floor, to be clubbed together with other service areas like security room, fire control room and reception with clear and easy access.“We have seen that during an emergency, local residents and club members are the first to respond and start rescuing people from a fire-trapped place. They often do not have requisite tools, thus hampering the initial fire-fighting process. The fire-service kiosk needs to be equipped with some basic fire-safety tools that are available in a firetender,” Jag Mohan added.The kiosk inaugurated at the mall on Monday has CO2 extinguishers, ABC-type extinguishers, ceiling hook, lock cutter, hammer, crowbar, insulated axe, stretcher, smoke hood, torchlight and sand buckets, in addition to inbuilt fire suppression and detection system.Real estate developers have welcomed the move. Nandu Belani, president of the Bengal chapter of Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India (Credai-Bengal), said the idea was good as it would give everyone access critical equipment in case of a fire. “No builder will have a problem investing space or resources,” he said.Yashasvi Shroff, director of Alcove Realty, one of the developers in the consortium that built The 42, the tallest building in Kolkata, agreed that nothing was more important or valuable to a builder than life of people inhabiting in a building. “Now all major builders take care of the statutory requirements and take fire-fighting seriously. We will also implement the new rule,” he said.Merlin Group chairman Sushil Mohta said they were even planning to conduct a fire drill for local club members with the councillor’s help to prepare everyone for any emergency situation.

Title: Kerala: Stream in Kavalappara to get a rebirth through MNREGS
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

After the landslide, the stream turned to narrow brooks and rills in many areas and it also diverted its cours... Read More

MALAPPURAM: The stream in Kavalappara village that almost disappeared after a massive landslide in August last year, will soon get a rebirth through the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme ( MNREGS ).

The stream was a major source of water for hundreds of families in Kavalappara and adjacent villages in Pothukallu grama panchayat. After the landslide, which engulfed the village, the stream turned to narrow brooks and rills in many areas and it also diverted its course in some other areas.

In a fresh effort, local bodies in the region are all set to revamp the waterbody through MNREGS works with the support of technical experts and scientists. The stream would be restored in the area by carrying out widening works. Protection wall would be constructed on both sides of the stream as part of the renovation works. Geo-textiles would be used for preventing the soil erosion. The works are expected to be completed before monsoon.

The project is being implemented jointly by Nilambur block panchayat, Pothukallu grama panchayat and district mission of MNREGS. As part of implementation of the project, accredited engineers of Nilambur block panchayat and Vandur and Kalikavu grama panchayats visited the spot on Sunday. They granted a preliminary-level technical sanction for the first phase of renovation works.

Block panchayat president of Nilambr, P P Sugathan, joint programme coordinator of MNREGS P Abdul Azees, block development officer of Nilambur C Rajeev also accompanied the team.

Meanwhile, an emergency meeting convened at Pothukallu grama panchayat on Monday granted approval for the estimate of the first phase of the project.

Title: 154 eminent citizens write to Prez, back CAA, NPR & NRC
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

NEW DELHI: A group of 154 eminent citizens — comprising former high court judges, ex-bureaucrats, armed forces veterans and academicians — on Monday wrote to the President of India expressing their concern at the “vicious” campaign and “fear-mongering” by “vested groups” against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, upcoming National Population Register (NPR) exercise and the idea of a National Register of Citizens (NRC).

In the letter — signed by 11 former judges of different high courts, 24 retired IAS officers, 11 ex-IFS officers, 16 former IPS officers and 18 former Lieutenant Generals — the citizens urged the government to look into the ongoing protests against CAA/NRC “with all seriousness” and safeguard the democratic institutions by taking stern action against the vested interests behind them. They even alleged that the protests were designed to destroy the fabric of the country and harm the nation’s unity and integrity. “We strongly feel that there is also an external dimension to the disturbances being created,” they said .

The citizens — which include former Chief Justice of Sikkim high court Justice Permod Kohli , former defence secretary Yogendra Narain, former RAW chief Sanjeev Kumar Tripathi , former Kerala chief secretary C V Anand Bose , former Kerala DGP R Padmanabhan and Puducherry University vice-chancellor Gurmeet Singh — said the campaign based on a “false and nefarious narrative” about CAA, NPR and NRC was being run in a “coordinated manner” leading to violent protests.

They defended CAA saying that it was a law passed by Parliament and did not apply to Indian citizens at all. On NPR, they said it was a legal obligation. As for NRC, the citizens stressed that it was an absolute necessity for a country to maintain such a register for its security safety and well being.

Title: More women take to streets as anti-CAA stir simmers in Madurai
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The protesters have been sitting under a tent night and day opposing the CAA and NRC

MADURAI: The protest by members of the Muslim community against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and National Register of Citizens ( NRC ), which began on Friday night at Mahaboobpalayam, continued for the fourth day on Monday. The protest has been witnessing the participation of more number of women than men.

The protesters have been sitting under a tent night and day opposing the CAA and NRC. They also condemned the police action against protesters in Chennai on Friday. Ever since they began the protest, they have been mobilizing money among themselves to distribute food and water to those involved in the protest.

Meanwhile, a large number of Muslims staged a protest in Nelpettai area on Monday till night. Many shops remains closed in the area to express solidarity with the protesters.

Police deployment was made at both the spots and higher officials are making occasional visits to ascertain the situation.

A peace meeting was organized at the office of revenue divisional officer, Madurai , on Monday evening.

Representatives took part in the meeting chaired by RDO Muruganandham in the presence of human rights activist and executive director of People’s Watch Henri Tiphagne.

Idol wing ADGP Abhay Kumar Singh, who reached Madurai on Sunday based on instruction from Tamil Nadu DGP J K Tripathy to oversee the handling of against CAA and NRC, held meetings with higher officials in Madurai and Virudhunagar district.

Title: Govt to replicate KC Valley scheme in Tier-2 cities
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Bengaluru: Buyoed by the success of diverting treated sewage water from Bengaluru to irrigate parched fields in Chikkaballapura and Kolar districts, the state government will replicate the scheme in other major cities of the state.

A first in the country, the treated water project was commissioned in 2018 and implemented at a cost of Rs 1,400 crore. Now, water from Bengaluru fills over 130 tanks in the two districts.

Governor Vajubhai R Vala, in his address to the joint-sitting of the legislature, said, "Secondary treated waste water from Bengaluru is being used to fill tanks in drought-prone districts of Chikkaballapura and Kolar. My government intends to implement this scheme in other important cities," Vala said.

On security, Vala said an anti-terror unit has been set up exclusively for Bengaluru and an emergency response support system (ERSS) rolled out with the Centre’s assistance to cater to citizens in emergencies. A high-security prison is being constructed in Parappana Agrahara, Bengaluru, to house hardcore criminals and terrorists, while central prisons are being constructed in Vijayapura and Bidar, he said.

Contrary to expectations, Vala did not mention implementation of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). The opposition was reportedly planning to disrupt the governor’s address in case he made a reference to CAA.

Vala also defended the government’s management of natural calamities, outlined its priorities especially the irrigation sector and complimented it for prudent management of finances. In his 30-minute speech, he hailed efforts of the government in providing relief to flood victims, helping farmers with additional assistance and maintaining financial prudence. "My government undertook rescue and relief operations in flood-hit areas on a war footing," he said

While the government spent Rs 827 crore on rebuilding and repairing damaged houses, Rs 207 crore was spent on compensation for loss of clothing, utensils and other household goods. The government also paid Rs 1,126 crore towards input subsidy at Rs 10,000 per hectare. "In addition, the government also released Rs 2,104 crore for restoration of critical infrastructure," the governor said.

The governor also said special watershed development programmes will be rolled out to prevent drought in 100 taluks by combining rural employment guarantee scheme and PM Krishi Sichayi Yojana. Claiming Karnataka stood at No 1 position in the country with respect to reduction of maternal deaths, the governor said over 3.3 lakh beneficiaries availed benefit of the Ayushman Bharat-Arogya Karnataka since July 2019.

The government also plans to increase the number of women in the police force by 5%. Vala said the government has approved reservation of 25% posts — up from 20% — of constable and sub-inspector posts for women.

Title: Darj hawkers get rehab at Motor Stand
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Darjeeling: Hawkers who were removed from Nehru Road near Chowrasta in Darjeeling were rehabilitated along the Hill Cart Road on Monday. They can now set up temporary stalls at the Motor Stand area in the heart of the town after 5pm. A total of 40 stalls will be allowed for the time being.

Last year, Darjeeling Municipality had removed hawkers selling tea, momo, puchka, chowmein, balloons and ice-cream from Nehru Road. Stalls of nearly 180 hawkers, who had temporary stalls near Chowrasta and Mall Road, were pulled down. The civic authorities on Monday allowed 40 of them to relocate. The others will be rehabilitated as well, a source said. Before they were removed, hawkers on Nehru Road kept shops open from 4pm to 9pm every day.

Those who were evicted from Nehru Road last year had termed the move “illegal”. They claimed that under the Street Vendors (Protection of Livelihood and Regulation of Street Vending) Act, 2016, there is no provision for eviction and protection of livelihood is a priority. They decided to open the shops again from 4pm. Following the stir, civic authorities held a number of meetings to reach an amicable solution.

“We are thankful to the administration for allowing us to reopen shops after months. Hawkers had to go through a harrowing time since it was a matter of their livelihood. Now we have been allocated a place and we no longer must remain in fear that we will be removed,” said Darjeeling District Hawkers Union president Kundan Dewan. The vendors, who had been removed, were members of the union. The union had later sought intervention of the National Hawkers Federation (NHF) which had attended the meetings with the civic authorities.

“They have been allowed to open their stalls — only after 5pm — on humanitarian basis. We have also kept a condition that they should keep the area clean,” said an official with the municipality. Hawkers have been asked to collect garbage after business hours and dump it in huge moveable dustbin provided by the civic body.

Title: Panaji: Ill-laid and illegal speed breakers top road safety debate
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

PANAJI: The risk that speed breakers without signage pose to motorists was one of the main grievances raised by participants during a round table discussion on youth and road safety held on Monday.

Students and representatives of various educational institutions highlighted not only the need for signage about speed breakers, but also the need for some standardisation.

Recently, citizens under the campaign ‘ Rosto ’ put the government to shame by painting speed breakers.

Goa Consumer Action Network convener Roland Martins said that some speed breakers are illegal as they are not government notified. Notified speed breakers must be accompanied by required signboards, he said.

Besides illegal speed breakers, Martins also educated the students about illegal bus stops, warning them that in the case of an accident while either climbing or alighting at an unauthorised stop, their case will not stand in the court of law.

On complaints of lack of shuttle buses from Margao to Panaji during peak hours in the morning emerged, Martins advised them to send in written complaints.

One participant said the rent-a-bikes and cars contribute to the traffic chaos.

Title: Bitter pill for Kerala doctor who prescribed ‘sweets for diabetics’
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representational Image

KOCHI: The Travancore Cochin Medical Council ( TCMC ) has decided to remove the name of an MBBS doctor who prescribed “sweets for diabetic patients” from its register for three months.

During the period of removal from the register he is not be eligible to practise medicine, consult patients, prescribe medicines or any other activities done by a doctor.

TCMC members discussed the issue and after referring to the detailed investigation conducted on the issue concluded that the doctor had indulged in professional misconduct. An order to this effect was issued on February 17.

“The council in its meeting held on Jan 10, 2020 endorses the views of the ethics committee that Dr M V Prasad is guilty of misconduct and for the proved charges of unethical advertisement and also unethical, unscientific practice without scientific evidence for this method of treatment,” the order signed by TCMC registrar states.

The order further states that Dr Prasad has been giving “unethical” advertisement —“Eat Sugar Avoid Medicine”— to diabetic patients despite being strictly warned by TCMC in the past. Dr Prasad had contended before the council that he had not violated any provisions in the code of ethics and the advertisement was made without his knowledge and he had asked people to stop such advertisements.

Since the ethics committee didn’t find the explanation satisfactory, they recommended the council to take disciplinary action for removal of Dr Prasad’s name from the register for three months. Accordingly, a notice was issued to him.

While diabetologists warn against sugar consumption and lifestyle changes by diabetes patients, Dr Prasad who practises in Wayanad , has claimed that intake of normal food without any restriction and moderate servings of sweets and exercise to burn out extra calories is all that is needed to control diabetes.

Title: Maha man, wanted for 30 chain snatchings in Hyd, nabbed in city
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Chennai: A notorious chain snatcher , who has more than 30 cases pending against him in Hyderabad, was arrested in Chennai on Sunday after the men in khaki travelled nearly 2,000km in pursuit of him. He was wanted by the city police in connection with four chain snatching cases reported in and around Anna Nagar since December last year.

Amol Bala Saheb Shinde, 29, of Parbhani in Maharashtra, arrested by a special team, was remanded in judicial custody on Monday. The team was formed after three chain snatching cases were reported on December 16, 19 and 29 last year. When suspect details were shared during the search, the Maharashtra and Telangana police identified him to be an offender wanted in their jurisdictions for several snatchings. They also shared 50 CCTV footage from the scenes of crimes in their limits for perusal.

The city police, while examining surveillance footage recorded in Anna Nagar, found that he had used a two-wheeler stolen from Hyderabad. Amol struck again in Anna Nagar on February 1, following which city police intensified the search. He was arrested during a vehicle check.

As many as 20 sovereigns of jewellery and a two-wheeler were seized from Amol.

According to a press note released by the Cyberabad police, Amol operated based on tip-offs given by prison inmates whom he had befriended and exchanged phone numbers with. He worked as a driver and has been involved in chain snatching since 2013. He committed the crime to spend money on booze and women, the note added.

Title: Gold Seized at Mangalore Airport: Customs seize 1.45kg gold worth Rs 58 lakh at Mangalore airport
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

File photo of Mangalore airport

MANGALURU: In separate cases, customs officials arrested two passengers who attempted to smuggle gold into the country through Mangalore International Airport on Sunday evening, and seized gold valued over Rs 58.95 lakh from them. The accused are Muhammed Swalih Chappathodi, 22, and Mohammed Nishad Cheruvanassery, 25, both from Malappuram district in Kerala.

Swalih, who arrived from Dubai on board SpiceJet flight, had concealed capsules containing gold in paste form inside his rectum which on purification resulted in the recovery of 797gms gold of 24 karat purity valued at Rs 32.35 lakh.

In another case of similar modus operandi, customs official recovered 655gm of gold valued Rs 26.59 lakh from Nishad who arrived from Dubai by Air India flight IX384.

Both of them were produced before the additional chief judicial magistrate court, said Joannes George, joint commissioner of customs, Mangaluru . Customs officials comprising superintendents Sreelakshmi, Gopinath, Savitha Kotian, Ramavtar Meena, and inspector Samala Mohan Reddy were instrumental in the detection and seizure of the gold concealed by the passengers, he added.

Title: Hinganghat police waiting for chemical analysis report in Ankita Pisudde murder case
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Ankita Pisudde was set on fire by her stalker Vikesh Nagrale on February 3 at Hinganghat. She succumbed to her... Read More

Nagpur: Hinganghat police of Wardha district are now gearing up to file the charge sheet in Ankita Pisudde murder case by the end of this week. It’s learnt the police are waiting for the chemical analysis report from Nagpur-based Regional Forensic Science Laboratory .

Pisudde was set on fire by her stalker Vikesh Nagrale on February 3 at Hinganghat. The victim, a contributory lecturer, was headed to her college when Nagrale had intercepted and set her on fire. She was rushed to Orange City Hospital and Research Institute in Nagpur by police but declared dead on February 10 after fighting for life for seven days.

State government, which had borne the expense of Pissude’s treatment and also compensated her family, had earlier announced to try the case in a fast-track court. The government had also promised employment for Pisudde’s kin.

The investigation was entrusted to sub-divisional police officer (SDPO) Trupti Jadhav who was assisted by legal team and other officers to complete the probe in the quickest possible time.

Apart from recording the statements of the eyewitnesses before the magistrate, sources stated that police have managed to put together several crucial pieces of strong evidence in the case so far. “We are only waiting for the chemical analysis report after which the charge sheet would be sent,” said a police source.

It’s learnt that the laboratory has been requested to furnish its findings as soon as possible for an early filing of the charge sheet.

Title: ‘Cross-check facts to avoid fake news’
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Ankita Deshkar conducts a workshop on ‘How to identify fake news’ at Blind Relief Association’s Mundle Hall, S... Read More

Nagpur: Certified Google news trainer Ankita Deshkar explained the importance of fact checking to avoid ‘misinformation’, ‘disinformation’ and ‘malinformation’ which generally result in the spread of rumours, in a workshop on ‘How to identity fake news by using simple online tips’, held on Saturday. The workshop was conducted at Blind Relief Association’s Mundle Hall.

“Misinformation happens unintentionally, whereas disinformation is fabricated or deliberately manipulated via audio or video content. Malinformation is deliberate publication of private information for personal or corporate gains and not really in the interest of the public,” said Deshkar.

The International Federation of Library Association and Institution (IFLA) has come up with various ways to know whether news posted online is factual or fake.

“It has been observed that people forward news based on just headlines. Pictures and videos are being doctored and manipulated, thereby putting a question mark regarding the credibility of the content,” she said.

Google search can be used in many ways that are unknown to the common man. Factual of fake status of photographs or videos can be known through this device. Google provides a feature for picture search which can give precise information. One can gain access to this service via images.google.com

Apart from Google, other search engines like Yandex, Baidu, Tineye and Revere, too, are credible.

“A little effort is needed as one needs to key in words in Google search to get accurate information instead of banking on news that’s forwarded and fake,” said Deshkar.

After her presentation, Deshkar engaged is an interactive session with the audience to clear their doubts.

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: Panaji: RBI extends curbs on Mapusa Urban Cooperative bank by 2 months
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The Reserve Bank of India

PANAJI: The Reserve Bank of India ( RBI ) has extended the financial sanctions imposed on the Mapusa Urban Cooperative Bank (MUCB) since July 2015 for two more months even as the bank continues to explore its dwindling options to revive its fortunes.

The apex bank had extended its embargo on lending and withdrawal for three months, up to February 18, and depositors had feared that the bank would go into liquidation.

“RBI has not relaxed any conditions. They have extended the restrictions for another two months,” general manager of MUCB Sailendra Sawant said.

The RBI extension will come as a relief to the MUCB management which is facing the ire of depositors and shareholders.

Even though the state government has made it clear that it is unable to infuse any share capital into the beleaguered bank, the management is counting on the state government to bail it out.

“Our position is not so bad, asset wise, that the bank needs to be liquidated,” Sawant said. One option that the state is exploring is a merger or consolidation with local cooperative banks.

Under the Section 35A of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949, the apex bank has directed MUCB not to grant or renew any loans and advances, make any investment or accept fresh deposits.

It may be recalled that MUCB’s finances came under strain after RBI imposed certain curbs on its financial transactions in 2014.

MUCB has 24 branches in the state besides the head office in Mapusa, and 193 staff members in all. Besides, the bank has 1.19 lakh shareholders and 2.48 lakh depositors.

Title: S corpn may collect garbage charges with property tax
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

New Delhi: With the levying of user charges for garbage collection back on the agenda, South Delhi Municipal Corporation ( SDMC ) may collect it along with property taxes.

The SDMC commissioner has directed the property tax department to consider the proposal for incentivising the tax payers if they make a one-time annual payment of user charges along with the property tax.

Confirming that the proposal is under consideration, a senior official said, “The user charges cannot be legally added to property taxes but we are trying to incentivise their one-time payment.” While a Geospatial Delhi Limited survey says SDMC’s four zones have around 14 lakh households, the municipal data reveals 4.5-5 lakh of these houses pay property taxes.

The user charges were approved by the court in February 2018. For residential areas, these are expected to vary between Rs 50 and Rs 200 per month, depending upon the plot area. While residential dwellings up to 50sq m will be charged Rs 50 every month, those between 50 and 200sq m will have to pay Rs 100 and all units above 200sq m Rs 200 per month, the highest slab in the residential category, said a senior official of the sanitation department, citing a notification.

Similarly, the street vendors will be charged Rs 100 and commercial establishments like shops, eating places, dhabas and sweet shops Rs 500. For larger commercial units, falling under the bulk garbage generator category, the monthly charges are likely to vary between Rs 2,000 and Rs 5,000.

While the charges for unstarred hotels will be Rs 2,000, it will be Rs 3,000 for those up to the three-star category and Rs 5,000 above that, the official explained. Party lawns, Banquet halls, big godowns and cold storage facilities will also be charged Rs 5,000.

North Delhi Municipal Corporation is also finalising its procedure to levy user charges for garbage collection.

AAP had opposed the idea last time.

Title: Madurai: MKU CoE issued two charge memos over alleged wrongdoings
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

MADURAI: The vice-chancellor (VC) of Madurai Kamaraj University ( MKU ), M Krishnan has issued two separate charge memos to the controller of examination (CoE), O Ravi seeking explanation regarding two incidents that raised questions of wrongdoing in the latter’s office.

On January 23, an unauthorised official from a distance education centre accessed the consolidated mark sheets of various centres in the office of the CoE. The VC had acted on a tip-off, nabbing the person in the act. “A charge memo was issued last week regarding this, seeking explanation about how the official managed to get in and in what capacity,” he said.

On Monday, a second memo was issued seeking explanation for the case of exam answer papers that had been lost and found. On February 6, when results of the exam conducted in November 2019 were supposed to be announced, the VC received information that a bundle carrying 138 exam answer papers had gone missing.

Later, on February 10, the staff found the missing answer papers under the seat of a bus, which is used to collect the papers. “The second memo was issued seeking explanation as to why the issue of the missing papers was reported only during the time of announcing results and was not brought to the attention of higher authorities earlier,” explained the VC.

Earlier, I Ismail, general secretary of the MKU Principals’ Association, had sought the suspension of the CoE and a directorate of vigilance and anti-corruption (DVAC) probe for allegedly collecting Rs 3 crore bribe from various distance education centre coordinators in Tamil Nadu and other states by distributing consolidated mark statements without collecting fees dues to the university.

Title: Panaji: Fate of Rohan Khaunte’s Revenue Bhavan in Porvorim uncertain
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Former revenue minister Rohan Khaunte

PANAJI: Former revenue minister Rohan Khaunte ’s pet project, a Revenue Bhavan for Porvorim constituency, has been put in cold storage, at least for now. The government said the project, proposed to be set-up on an area of 3,800 sqm, is not possible due to non-availability of land.

Khaunte pursued the project until he was removed from the cabinet in July 2019, an official said.

The former minister had caused eyebrows to be raised when he tried to get the project constructed through the Info Tech Corporation, which was under his IT ministry. Government department projects are normally carried out through either the PWD or Goa State Infrastructure Development Corporation (GSIDC).

“Questions were certainly raised as he wanted the project to be constructed through the IT corporation,” an official said. The project proposal remained pending with the finance department for a while, he said.

The project was proposed to be setup in the village panchayat of Penha de Franca and part of the area was purchased from the Goa Housing Board for Rs 9.7 crore.

The balance 1,030sqm was proposed to be transferred from the general administration department (GAD) to the revenue department. However, the government didn’t approve the transfer.

Revenue minister Jennifer Monserrate in her written reply to Goa legislative assembly, in the budget session held earlier this month, gave reasons for the delay as “due to non-availability of total area (3,800sqm), the construction cannot be processed.”

The work of building a Revenue Bhavan in Mapusa has been delayed as statutory approvals from North Goa Planning and Development Authority (NGPDA) are yet to be received. The delay is also on account of obtaining a NOC from directorate of health services. The work was tendered in August 2019 and while technical bids were opened, financial bids were not as statutory approval from NGPDA, construction licence were not obtained.

Title: KMDA works on Salt Lake Bypass flyover alignment plan
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The proposed flyover will run parallel to the Metro viaduct

KOLKATA: KMDA will finalize the alignment of the proposed flyover from Chingrighata to New Town in a week or two for placing the proposal to the board for approval. The project was discussed in the government’s infrastructure sub-committee meeting on Monday.

IIT-Kharagpur has been engaged to prepare a study to assess the traffic scenario of Chingrighata crossing on EM Bypass and to come up with the most feasible layout.

Earlier, it was proposed that a flyover will be set up over the wetland but the plan was scrapped and the authorities came up with a few alternative alignments, in which a flyover had been proposed from Captain Bheri on EM Bypass, which will take right from Chingrighata to move over Salt Lake Bypass — parallel to the Metro alignment — before entering Sector V from Nicco Park.

“As per the proposed alignment, the flyover seems to just move past a few waterbodies behind Sector V before entering New Town. The proposed alignment will be finalised by looking into the best possible options so that no waterbody gets affected,” said an official.

Once the authorities come up with the final alignment, a detail project report will be prepared and an environment impact assessment will be done.

Title: Abhijit Bangar posted as director of textiles
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nagpur: IAS officer of 2008 batch Abhijit Bangar has been posted as director, Textiles, here. He was without charge after being replaced by Tukaram Mundhe from the post of municipal commissioner at the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) since January 28.

The state government on Tuesday issued a notification shuffling 21 IAS officials, including Bangar. He replaced Madhavi Khode-Chaure. The government has transferred Khode to Jalgaon Municipal Corporation as municipal commissioner.

The government had transferred Bangar within 14 months from the NMC despite tenure of 36 months. He was transferred to make way for Mundhe.

During his 14-month tenure, Bangar used to meet people whenever present in his cabin and never fixed any time table for visitors. Bangar had successfully revised door-to-door garbage collection system, improved city’s ranking under Swachh Bharat Mission, took city to top post under Smart City Mission, tackled water crisis very well last year and expedited various developmental projects.

Among the other transfers, Devendra Singh has been appointed as collector of Yavatmal.

Title: Madurai: Branding their rice, Veppankulam farmers script a success story
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

A woman serving Kalathu dosai to a farmer who came to the paddy procurement centre in Veppankulam village in S... Read More

MADURAI: Following a bountiful harvest after nearly a decade, the villagers of an agrarian hamlet in Sivaganga have decided to make the best out of it. When traders who approached them offered low price for their produce, they decided to brand the rice they have cultivated in their village as ‘Veppankulam brand’ and market it by themselves. This has resulted in the tiny village attracting the attention of the district administration and now they have become a community that is helping farmers in more than one way. Veppankulam , a tiny rain fed village near Kallal in Sivaganga district , had its fields green and lush this year after many years. The drought had made the villagers revive and desilt their tanks. Last year’s rain had filled most of the tanks and the farmers were able to cultivate paddy successfully.

However, the traders offered only Rs 850 for a 66 kg bag of paddy. This was pittance and would not help the farmers in any way. The villagers came together and decided to process their own paddy under the brand name and sell it in their village. “We fixed the price at Rs 1,100 per bag, and told the villagers that they could get a month’s supply of rice cheaper than the market rate if they pay and book in advance,” said R Thiruchelvam, a villager.

The advance bookings helped them procure 300 bags of rice from farmers and they started processing it. Sivaganga district collector J Jayakanthan, who was impressed on hearing the initiative, asked the Civil Supplies Corporation to start a paddy procurement centre in the village. On February 7, a centre was inaugurated in the village for the first time. As the government was paying Rs 1,070 for a bag of paddy, the villagers stopped their procurement as the farmers started getting a good deal from the government. Now, the paddy procurement centre is helping many farmers from the neighbouring villages, and about 40 of them come to their village to drop their produce at the centre. The women of the village now started distributing citron juice with jaggery and salt to the farmers who wait for many hours to give away their paddy at the procurement centre. Thangavelu, a farmer, says that this is the first village in the region where they really get an energizing juice free of cost. “Citron juice is an excellent cooler and full of nutrition and what the women are doing is a noble thing,” he said.

A common Chettinad food, Kallathu dosa, is also sold by women who have established a shop near procurement centre, at a very nominal cost. This is benefitting the farmers and workers at procurement centre.

Title: Laxman Savadi wins council seat, remains deputy chief minister of Karnataka
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Laxman Savadi

BENGALURU: Deputy chief minister Laxman Savadi was elected to the legislative council on Monday and although it was a done deal that he would win, a vote from across the aisle spiced up the election.

Counting was conducted soon after ballots were cast and Savadi polled 113 of the 120 votes cast, including the vote of disgruntled JD(S) legislator GT Devegowda. Seven votes were declared invalid. Members of the two opposition parties — Congress and JD(S) — abstained from voting.

The election was necessitated following the resignation of Rizwan Arshad of the Congress. Rizwan resigned after he was elected to the legislative assembly from the Shivajinagar constituency in the assembly bypolls held for 15 seats in December last year.

BR Anil Kumar, who was initially promised the support of both Congress and JD(S) was supposed to contest as an independent candidate. However, as both parties refused to support him at the last minute, he withdrew, paving the way for Savadi’s victory.

The BJP has 117 members in the 225-member assembly, but N Mahesh of the BSP and two independents, H Nagesh and Sharath Bachchegowda, besides GT Devegowda also voted, taking the total electorate to 120 (including the speaker). BJP’s SA Ramadas did not turn up because of health reasons.

“I would like to thank all those who were responsible for my victory. Special thanks to leaders of my party and chief minister BS Yediyurappa, who gave me the opportunity to be the BJP candidate,” said Savadi.

Winning this council election was crucial for Savadi to retain his ministry as he was not an elected member of either of the houses. Rules mandate that a non-member must get elected either to the assembly or council within six months after taking over as minister. February 20 was the deadline for Savadi, who had lost 2018 assembly polls from Athani, to get elected.

Officials in the assembly secretariat said seven votes were invalid because voters had wrongly marked their choices on ballot paper. According to norms, a voter has to mark numerical one, two and three against the names of the candidates in order of preference. Marking only numerical one is allowed. However, six ballots had a tick mark, while a voter had registered a cross mark. Since it was a secret ballot, it was not known who the MLAs were whose votes were invalid.

“The ballot papers bear serial numbers and they are randomly distributed. It is virtually impossible to say who a voter cast his or her vote for,” said assembly secretary MK Vishalakashi, the retuning officer for the bypoll.

Title: No action to be taken against five Pondy govt officials: CBI
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Puducherry: Chief minister V Narayanasamy said the CBI director has written to the government conveying that ‘no action is contemplated’ against officials of the Centralized admission committee ( Centac ) in a case probed by the investigation agency into corruption in the MBBS admission in private colleges and deemed universities in the Union territory of Puducherry .

Speaking to reporters on Monday, he said MCI had lodged a complaint with the CBI after lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi visited the Centac office and private medical colleges, deemed universities and leveled corruption charges against the government and officials involved in MBBS admission and demanded a CBI probe in 2017.

The investigation agency, which booked a case against 13 people including government officials on charges of criminal conspiracy, cheating and criminal misconduct by public servant in September 2017, sent a letter dated February 14 to the government, stating that no action is contemplated against five government officials — Narendra Kumar, K V Raman, B R Babu, V Govindaraj, K Pajaniradja alias Kichena and M Jonathan Daniel, who served as Centac chairman, health and family welfare director, secretary (health), Centac convener, Centac joint convener and Centac coordinator respectively then.

Narayanasamy said the corruption charges levelled by Bedi against the government and the officials turned out to be false after the investigation agency’s report.

“Lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi, instead of focusing on her work, has been attempting to gain cheap publicity (by levelling corruption charges). Now, the CBI has said no action is contemplated against officials. It is just the tip of an iceberg. There are several false allegations levelled by her,” Narayanasamy said adding that all her charges will be proved false sooner or later.

He said Bedi must leave Puducherry soon for the betterment of the Union territory. “What is her contribution to the territory? She has been blocking all development and welfare schemes. She has blocked schemes related to promoting tourism, industries and preventing flooding. She has been interfering in the day-to-day affairs of the administration. The lieutenant governor must act as per the aid and advice of the council of ministers. She cannot act independently, hold review meetings with the officials and intimidate officials to obey her orders. We will support the officials and protect them,” he said.

He questioned the reluctance of Bedi to appoint a regular secretary for her and her decision to appoint a retired government official as an officer on special duty despite the Union home ministry directing her to appoint the official as a consultant to the lieutenant governor. He accused her of attempting to tarnish the image of the Congress government and to disrupt the smooth functioning of the administrative machinery.

Title: Land dispute: Man tries to end life at collectorate
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Villupuram: Tension prevailed at the Villupuram collectorate on Monday after a 59-year-old construction worker attempted suicide on the premises over a decade-long land dispute. The worker, Sarathi, said he had filed multiple complaints with police seeking action against the encroacher, but all were in vain.

A senior police officer said Sarathi lived with his wife Rakini, 58, at Sinagarathoppu in Kidangal-2 locality in Tindivanam town of the district. The couple lives in a thatched roof house measuring 2.5cents, with the remaining portion of their 5-cent plot was left vacant.

Sarathi said his neighbour Venkatapathy, 45, who started building a concrete house a decade back in a plot adjacent to his, has put up a fence encroaching around 300sqft of Sarathi's land. “The two families have been fighting over the encroached space for a decade. In 2016, to settle the dispute, Sarathi invited a revenue surveyor to measure the plots but Venakatapathy is said to have bribed and cancelled the survey,” a police officer said. The couple said they had registered multiple complaints at the Tindivanam town police station and Tindivanam DSP office but no case was registered.

Disappointed over the inaction, Sarathi and Rakini came to the Villupuram collectorate on Monday where her doused himself with kerosene. Police present there intervened. Taluk police officials pacified the couple and asked them to register a fresh complaint at the Tindivanam police station and revenue office.

Title: Madurai: School apps, a double-edged sword for students, parents
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

While apps have made the communication quicker and easier, this has also created room for bullying, invasion o... Read More

MADURAI: Many private schools in the city have moved on to the digital platform for communication between teachers and parents using mobile applications (apps) like WhatsApp and separate apps designed by individual schools. While it has made the communication quicker and easier, this has also created room for bullying, invasion of privacy and creation of unnecessary tension or conflict among students and parents.

“My daughter’s school has an app, where we get homework messages, test marks, timetable, and other important updates, making it easier to access rather than diary notes earlier,” said Ramya R, a parent. Such apps by private schools also provide audio and video recordings of subject portions so the children do not miss out on the lessons. For schools that cannot afford to maintain separate apps, WhatsApp is their go-to alternative to keep up with their competition.

“It is useful but it makes the student lazy and makes the parent stressed over every small thing,” said a parent, who did not wish to be named. Even when it comes to complaints, several parents noted that school teachers, who usually think twice before calling parents to discuss their child’s behaviour, are not showing any restraint in sending messages. Hearing complaints over little things every other day makes things stressful for the child, they added.

Meanwhile, there are also few unofficial WhatsApp groups created by parents sometimes with or without teachers, which does more harm than good. “Mothers of students from a particular class and section have a WhatsApp group, where they keep discussing the progress of children or rant about the school and teachers ,” added the anonymous parent.

The president of private schools correspondents’ confederation, Senthilnathan M, noted that the technology when used judiciously really does benefit students and parents. “However, in my opinion, official communication should still happen through manual channels via circulars or secure official emails to ensure no miscommunication ,” he said.

Title: In custody battle, children are always losers, says apex court
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

New Delhi: Recording the failure of Delhi high court and the Supreme Court to settle a matrimonial dispute , leading to a bitter fight for custody of their children, the apex court on Tuesday said no matter which parent won the legal battle, children always lost and could never be compensated.

The custody battle between a couple, residing in the posh Greater Kailash locality in south Delhi, started in 2013 in Delhi HC. It reached the SC in 2016. Judges hearing the case made attempts in chamber to mediate and settle the dispute, helped the children gain admission in a reputed school in Dehradun and then in Sherwood College, Nainital.

The judges even fixed the itinerary for holidays of the boy and girl with their father and mother separately but were forced to give up, saying the couple could move the trial court for guardianship rights as also the plea for divorce.

A bench of Justices A M Khanwilkar and Ajay Rastogi said, “In a custody battle, no matter which parent wins, the child always loses and it is the children who pay the heaviest price as they are shattered when the court by its judicial process tells them to go with the parent whom he or she deems fit.”

Narrating the extraordinary effort by the HC and the SC to resolve the matrimonial dispute keeping in mind that the interest of children was paramount and they were entitled to the love and affection of both parents, the SC bench said, “But if the parents are bent on separation or divorce, it is always the children who pay the heaviest price and are the sufferers.”

Writing the judgment for the bench, Justice Rastogi said, “If the parents fail to enable themselves to decide their inter se dispute, particularly in reference to custody of minor children, the court, after due scrutiny of the records of the case, reaches a conclusion that always remains a guesswork.”

On a more general note, the bench said, “All endeavours are to be made to resolve matrimonial disputes in the first instance through the process of mediation, which is one of the effective modes of alternative mechanism in resolving personal disputes (but if this not possible through mediation), further endeavour must be made by the court through its judicial process to resolve such personal disputes as expeditiously as possible.

“Delay in a decision certainly causes a great loss to the individual and deprives him/her of rights which are protected under the Constitution and with every passing day, children pay a heavy price of being deprived of the love and affection of parents for which they were never at fault but are always the loser which at no stage could be compensated monetarily or otherwise.”

Title: Kandla port: Ship from China with missile equipment for Pakistan at Gujarat port?
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

The Da Cui Yun is reportedly carrying an autoclave, a pressure chamber which is used in launching of ballistic... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Central and state security agencies accompanied by experts from the Defence Research & Development Organisation have launched a detailed probe into a Hong Kong-flagged ship detained by the customs department at Kandla port on February 3.

The vessel “Da Cui Yun” had started its journey from Jiangyin port in China on January 17 and was destined for Port Qasim in Karachi with cargo that included some equipment used in the manufacture of missiles, according to some Indian and foreign media reports.

The ship, a general cargo vessel built in 2011, has 22 crew on board and has been moored at jetty 15 at Kandla port. Sources in Kandla Port said the vessel had called there to either load or unload some cargo but was detained after customs found something suspicious. It is also learnt that customs had an intelligence tip-off regarding suspicious goods on the vessel.

The ship was reportedly carrying autoclave, a pressure chamber weighing thousands of tonnes which is used in the launching of missiles.

Title: Jipmer will not hold entrance exam from 2020; only Neet
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Puducherry: The Union health and family welfare ministry will decide on the quota for Puducherry students for the MBBS course in Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education and Research ( Jipmer ) after the National Testing Agency takes over the conduct of entrance examination for admission from 2020.

Currently, 54 of 200 MBBS seats in Jipmer (150 in Puducherry and 50 seats in Karaikal) are earmarked for Puducherry students. There is a proposal to increase the number of seats from 200 to 250 from 2020.

A Jipmer official said the institute has sent details on reservation and quota pattern followed by the institute so far to the ministry. “The ministry sought details on reservation and quota (for Puducherry students). We sent documents explaining reservation and quota pattern followed by the institute. We are not in the position to decide on the issue. We have done our job. Most probably, the ministry may follow the same pattern and publish details on reservation and quota in the prospectus,” said the official.

The Union health and family welfare ministry, in an official correspondence to Jipmer, said the ministry will hold a common and uniform National eligibility cum entrance test ( Neet ) for admission to the undergraduate medical courses in all medical institutions as per the provisions of Section (14) of the National Medical Commission Act, 2019. The institute, following the communication, announced that it will not hold entrance examinations for admission into MBBS course from 2020.

“Admission to MBBS course in Jipmer, Puducherry and Jipmer, Karaikal, will be made through National Entrance Eligibility Test (Neet UG) and the entrance exam will be conducted by the National Testing Agency and not by Jipmer from 2020 onwards,” said a notice from Jipmer.

The notice said students can get more information from websites www.nta.ac.in or ntaneet.nic.in.

Title: Girls stripped for period check: Bhuj college principal arrested
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Two of the accussed in police custody on Monday

RAJKOT: Four employees , including the principal , of the Shree Sahjanand Girls Institute in Bhuj were arrested on Monday for outraging the modesty of 68 girls by allegedly forcing them to strip to confirm their mensuration status last week.

Those arrested include principal Rita Raniga (38), coordinator Anita Chohan (49), hostel supervisor Ramila Hirani (29) and peon Nayna Gorasia (40). Besides outraging modesty of women and intimidation, all have also been charged under section 341(wrongful restrain) , 348 (Wrongful confinement to extort confession) and 343 (wrongful confinement) of the Indian Penal Code .

All the accused arrested by the special investigation team (SIT) formed by the Kutch police were produced in court which them sent to police custody till February 19.

Before the court police stated they wanted to find out why the accused took such extreme step and forced the girl to undress and who played the key role in the offence.

The incident had triggered outrage across the country against the ‘inhuman’ practices and humiliation the young girls had to go through.

On Sunday, a team of the National Commission for Women (NCW) met the girls at the college campus. An inquiry committee led by Dr Rajul L Desai, (member, NCW), along with advocate Malshree Gadhvi, DLSA, discussed with 44 girls (out of 68) and assured them of trying to dissuade the administration from following such inhuman practices.

The NCW team flayed the institute for heaping such rigorous practices on the young students. It however, admitted that the girls were left with little option but to follow the diktats “if they wanted to study there”.

The rules of the hostel are in violation of the girls’ right to education, which has been guaranteed to them by the constitution, Desai had said after meeting the girls.

Title: Uttar Pradesh man rapes to-be wife, robs her gold
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

PONDA: Athar Khan, 25, a native of Uttar Pradesh was arrested by Ponda police on Monday for raping a 35-year-old woman residing in Ponda for the last six months after promising to marry her and decamped with her gold.

Ponda PI Mohan Gaude said the accused fled to UP and following a complaint by the victim, Ponda police persuaded him to come back to Goa and arrested him on Monday evening.

Though they have arrested him on charges of rape and cheating her on pretext of the nikah and stealing her gold, no ornaments have been recovered yet, police said.

An offence under Sections 376, 420 and 380 of the Indian Penal Code has been registered against the accused.

Title: Panaji:‘Sudin using Mhadei to return to power’
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

State Congress president Girish Chodankar, Image taken from twitter

PANAJI: Fissures within the loosely stitched opposition are beginning to show. Congress on Monday accused lone MGP MLA Ramkrishna Dhavalikar of using the Mhadei water diversion issue to try and get back into the BJP-led government.

State Congress president Girish Chodankar said Dhavalikar only began an agitation in support of Goa’s interests in the Mhadei river after being unceremoniously dropped from the cabinet.

“He (Dhavalikar) was a partner of this government when the Mhadei issue was on. Why didn’t he put pressure on the government when he was deputy chief minister? Today, when he is the opposition, after Congress has been holding taluka-wise agitations on the Mhadei issue, he is blaming Congress,” Chodankar said.

A few days earlier, the former PWD Minister said Congress cannot be trusted on the Mhadei issue. He had cited comments made by Karnataka’s Congress MP BK Hariprasad .

The war of words between Congress and MGP comes just over a week after the two parties joined hands to corner BJP during the state legislative assembly session on a variety of issues.

Chodankar defended the stand taken by Hariprasad, saying that the Karnataka Congress MP was fighting for the interests of his own state. “Our Congressmen are faithful to our mother. Dhavalikar remembered to become faithful to his mother, Mhadei, only after he was out of the government,” Chodankar said.

Chodankar further said Dhavalikar would end his Mhadei agitation if the BJP offered him a post in the cabinet. “Dhavalikar is simply making allegations against Congress because he wants to get back in power. Mhadei is not an issue for him, but only a way to get back into power, which he is trying desperately,” Chodankar said.

Title: City-zens keen to test driving skills on foreign soil
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Chandigarh: Going by a steep increase in demand for international driving licence (permit) over the last five years, the craze for driving at international locations is apparently on the rise among the city residents.

According to a data compiled by the registering and licencing authority (RLA) of the Chandigarh administration, the demand for international licence increased from 806 in 2015 to 1,232 in 2019. In these last five years, a total of 4,639 residents applied and got international driving licence from the RLA.

The RLA data suggests that 806 applicants got the international driving license from the authority in the year of 2015, followed by 816 in 2016, 826 in 2017 and 959 in 2018, while number went up to 1,232 in 2019.

Although the authority does not have exact country-wise data, sources revealed that Canada remained the top priority for applicants to apply for international licence, followed by Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United State of America.

Besides the youngsters, people from different age categories also came to the authority seeking international licences. “Currently, we don’t make a data of countries where people are going to use the international license, but while talking to them, majority of the applicants said they would go to Canada or Australia,” an official said.

The authority official said, “The craze to get international licence has been increasing over the past years consistently. Besides those seeking licences for professional purposes, many youngsters going to foreign countries for studies are also quite eager to make international licence.”

BOX:

How to get int’l DL

For obtaining an international driving licence, the applicant has to first fill the forms and obtain a medical fitness certificate from a recognised MBBS doctor. After that, the applicant has to submit a copy of valid passport, visa, air ticket and domestic driving licence, passport size pictures and deposit a fee of Rs 1,000. Thereafter, the authority verifies the documents and then issues the international driving licence. The licence is provided within a day post submission of the documents and the fee

Title: Panaji: Woman attacked at housing society
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: A cooperative housing society has filed a complaint against an unidentified person for attacking and attempting to outrage the modesty of a woman.

In the complaint, the society said that the victim entered the water pump room of the building at around 6.20am when the unidentified man followed her into the room and attempted to molest her. When she struggled against her attacker, she was pushed on to the running water pump, and sustained a big cut on her chin.Her shouts brought the residents of the building to her rescue, but the attacker managed to flee.

“We submit CCTV footage and request you to take action against the accused as senior citizens and women are living in fear after this incident,” the society said .

Title: Guild to help Bangladesh host first international book fair
Content:
Diwas in February 2.5 million people visited the Kolkata book fair this year

KOLKATA: The International Kolkata Book Fair has become a role model for Bangladesh. It now plans to design its first international book fair on the same. The book fair in Bangladesh is slated to be a week-long affair in November this year and is being planned as part of Sheikh Mujibur Rehman’s birth centenary celebrations.The Publishers and Booksellers Guild , the organizers of the Kolkata book fair for the past 44 years, has been requested to assist in organising the fair in Dhaka, because of its experience. Bangladesh deputy high commissioner in Kolkata, Toufique Hasan confirmed the development.In the past, book fairs in Bangladesh have been organised in February to coincide with Bhasha Diwas on February 21. But these fairs have been local affairs where only Bangladeshi publishers participate. The international book fair that is being planned now will have foreign publishers participating for the first time. The culture ministry of Bangladesh is drawing out the plan for this and most of the leading publishers from India will be invited to set up stalls.Bangladesh has sought affiliation from the International Publishers Association, Geneva, to which all such fairs are affiliated. This global umbrella organisation allots dates for the fair. “We are excited about the first international book fair. much like the Kolkata book fair, this will become an annual feature on our calendars from now,” Hasan said.This development comes on the heels of the February 9 announcement that International Kolkata Book Fair, 2021, will celebrate the birth centenary of Bangabandhu Mujibur Rehman. The theme country will be Bangladesh and a special pavilion will be allotted to the country. The culture ministry of Bangladesh will design the stall and set up the exhibition along with special published and handwritten works on and by the first prime minister of Bangladesh.The Guild was happy with the invitation. “This validates the efforts that we have put into the Kolkata edition. It’s a huge honour,” said Tridib Chatterjee, president of the Guild.
