Title: Reach Goa in 2hr, 50m from Feb 20
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Mohali: A private airlines will start a direct flight from Chandigarh to Goa from February 20, the first from the Chandigarh international airport.

The IndiGo A-320 Airbus will have 180 seats. It will depart from Chandigarh at 7.45pm and reach Goa at 10.35 pm. The flight will depart from Goa at 11.25pm and arrive at Chandigarh at 2.15 am.

IndiGo station manager said, The one-way introductory fare is between Rs 8,000 and Rs 10,000 depending upon the time of booking. We are expecting a good response.”

The start of the flight will also justify the 24x7 operations at the airport. At present, the first flight arrives at Chandigarh at 6.35 am and the last flight at 10pm.

Chandigarh will also get direct connectivity to Patna from March 30. IndiGo will operate two flights daily to Patna from Chandigarh. The first flight will arrive from Ahmedabad at 11.35 am and depart for Patna at 12.05 pm. The second flight will arrive from Patna at 6.35 pm and depart for the Bihar capital at 7.05 pm. The flight will make its maiden journey on March 29.

IndiGo will also start a direct flight to Chennai from Chandigarh for six days a week from March 29. The flight will arrive from Chennai at 1.30 pm and depart for the destination at 2 pm.

IndiGo is likely to operate 29 flights to various destinations from Chandigarh out of a total of 64 flights announced in the summer schedule. Other operators like Air India, Air Vistara, GoAir, and Air Asia have said they too will connect the city with other destinations in the country.

BOX

Dubai flight resumes

The Dubai flight on February 16 resumed its operations after remaining suspended for over two months from December 14, 2019. The flight will depart and arrive at the old time, with return fare ranging between Rs 19,000 and Rs 27,000 depending upon the booking time. Owing to the airport using an outdated landing system not supporting visibility factors, IndiGo had announced to temporarily discontinue its Dubai flight. According to sources, the decision was taken owing to regular delays and cancellation of the flight during the winter season.

due to poor visibility and bad weather Indigo had temporarily discontinued its Dubai flight operations for 2 months.

Title: Day after boy goes missing, body washes up on riverbank
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: A day after 16-year-old Abhijith M R went missing from his home, his body was found on the banks of Karamana River on Monday. A Class XI student of Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, Kodunganoor, he was the son of Ratheesh Kumar and Manju G, residents of Abhiramam, Karamana–Nedumcadu Road. Ratheesh Kumar is an employee of postal department and Manju is a housewife.

There were no clothes on the body when it was found at the river bank. There were injury marks on his lips and nose. The police said that they have not found anything suspicious so far. They had registered a missing case on Sunday and changed the section to 174 CrPC for unnatural death on Monday. Police sources said that the cause of death and other details can be ascertained on after post-mortem and detailed probe.

Abhijith was preparing for his annual examination on Sunday. He had lunch together with his parents and grandmother Gomathi around 1.30pm. After lunch, his parents left for a private lab at Medical College Junction for a health check-up for Ratheesh Kumar.

A kid in the neighbourhood saw Abhijith at the door step around 3pm on Sunday. His parents also spoke to him over mobile phone, according to relatives. By 4pm, the parents returned and found out that Abhijith was not at home. He had reportedly told his grandmother that he was going out and would be back soon.

When the parents found out that Abhijith was missing, they got worried and rang up Padmakumar, the younger brother of Ratheesh Kumar who also lives at Karamana. Soon, the neighbours started searching all around for Abhijith. The search continued on Monday and went on till noon when they were told that the body of a boy had washed ashore near Sasthri Nagar-South.

The relatives went to the spot and identified the body. Karamana police completed the inquest procedures and the body was taken to the Medical College Hospital for post-mortem.

The unexpected demise of the boy threw the housing colony at Karamana into despair. Both Ratheesh Kumar and his wife Manju sat devastated in the drawing room “I had not ever scolded him, why did he leave us?,” Manju spoke between her sobs even as people around tried to comfort her. Every time a relative came, she grasped their arms and said, “You promised me you would bring him alive, right”.

The neighbours and relatives remembered Abhijith as a boy who usually kept to himself. “Being a single child, he was very much attached to his parents. He rarely went out except with his parents,” said Balu, a neighbour. During office get together, Abhijith remained mostly with his parents, recollected colleagues of Ratheesh Kumar.

The relatives found it hard to believe that Abhijith was no more. He is not known to have shared any issues at tuition centre or school nor with his parents or close relatives. They said that on Sunday he had told his father to drop him off at school for the examination.

“He was a quiet child, he didn’t have many friends. He never seemed to have been too much concerned about his studies because he always did well in his exams,” said Padmakumar, brother of Ratheeshkumar.

Title: Tipeshwar ranks 6th among 11 sanctuaries evaluated in state
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nagpur: The presence of tigers in a sanctuary is not the only criteria for a protected area (PA) to be adjudged the best. In the management effective evaluation (MEE), the Tipeshwar wildlife sanctuary, which has 12-15 tigers, has ranked sixth among the 11 PAs that were evaluated in Maharashtra.

According to the MEE report on national parks and wildlife sanctuaries (2018-19) released recently, the 148sqkm Tipeshwar scored 70.80% and Painganga sanctuary 62.06%. Both PAs in Yavatmal district were rated as ‘good’. The report has also recommended Tipeshwar to be notified as a tiger reserve.

The exercise is conducted by MoEFCC every year. For tiger reserves, MEE is conducted every four years. Rating up to 40% is considered as poor; 41-59% is rated as fair; 60-74% is considered as good and those above 75% fall in very good category.

Apart from Tipeshwar and Painganga, the other 9 PAs that were evaluated by MEE team included Mayureshwar Supe, Nandur Madhameshwar, Sagareshwar, Sanjay Gandhi, Thane Creek, Tungareshwar, Yawal, Yedsi Ramling Ghat and Naigaon Mayur.

Thane Creek Flamingo Wildlife Sanctuary topped the chart with a score of 75.92% and was rated as ‘very good’ followed by the Sanjay Gandhi National Park (SGNP) 75.80% and Mayureshwar Supe with a score of 75%, both also in the ‘very good’ category.

According to MEE chairperson UM Sahai, former chief wildlife warden of Rajasthan, the MEE of sanctuaries is done every year.

“In 2017-18, six sanctuaries were evaluated in Maharashtra. It is done as per listings by the Wildlife Institute of India (WII), Dehradun. These PAs were first evaluated in 2005-06 and now were subjected to evaluation for the second time,” Sahai said.

It is not only the presence of tigers or leopards which makes a national park and sanctuary best. Of the 11 PAs, Tipeshwar, which is being proposed to be a tiger reserve, was ranked sixth.

Seema Bhatt, an independent scientist, who was one of the members of the MEE team, said, “The presence of big carnivores is not the sole criteria to judge any PA. We have a very detailed questionnaire. We consider factors like habitat development, human interference, flora and fauna, biotic pressure among a host of other issues.”

Bhatt said, “The exercise is done with the involvement of the staff. While valuating the PAs, we also mention their strengths and weaknesses.”

The report though mentions several strengths of Tipeshwar like adequate staff, protection huts, tourism potential, notified eco-sensitive zone, vehicles, presence of tigers, no villages inside, eco-development committees (EDCs) among a host of other facilities. The major weaknesses include 26 villages around the sanctuary, poaching by wire snares, illicit felling and grazing and forest fires.

The expert committee has suggested to declare Tipeshwar a tiger reserve, prepare a zone plan, develop better tourist facilities, display signage, create one more range and take up capacity building of staff and guides.

Title: Two lionesses found dead in Amreli
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Carcass of a lioness in Anida village of Khambha

Rajkot: Two lioness carcasses were in as many days in Amreli district at different locations. The forest department is investigating the cause of death in both the cases. However, prima facie, nothing suspicious was found, said forester officials.

According to forest department, carcass of a lioness aged 9-12 years was found dead in Jasadhar range of Ghelipat area.

The second carcass of 8-9 years old lioness was found from a farm well in Anida village of Khambha revenue area. The farm belongs to Kalu Findalia. The primary reason for death was drowning.

The carcass of both lionesses were sent to animal care centre for postmortem.

Title: Junction devpt works to begin in March
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: After several years of dilly-dallying, stage is getting cleared for Vattiyoorkavu Junction development.

Public works department (PWD) minister G Sudhakaran will lay the foundation stone for the junction widening project on March 4. He will also launch works to lay boundary stones. Ahead of this, a joint survey by PWD and revenue department will begin on Wednesday.

The junction widening scheme, a long-pending demand of the area, got the much needed push when Kerala infrastructure investment fund board (KIIFB) approved Rs 100 crore after the detailed project report was submitted by the PWD for widening of the junction and four roads leading to it.

MLA V K Prasanth said that the land acquisition for widening of the junction will begin soon. He said that Trivandrum Development Authority (TRIDA) is in charge of the project for rehabilitation of traders.

“A joint survey of PWD and revenue department to mark the alignment will be held on Wednesday,” said an official of the PWD. PWD has estimated that around 10.9 hectares will be acquired for widening of the junction and nearby roads.

“Four roads – Vattiyoorkavu-Peroorkada Road, Vattiyoorkavu-Sasthamangalam Road, Vattiyoorkavu-Thoppumukku Road and Vazhayila-Mannarakonam Road will be widened to 18.5m. KIIFB has approved the DPR of the project and has approved allotment of Rs 100 crore for it. This will pave way for widening of the junction,” said the PWD official.

Meanwhile, the project for rehabilitation of traders to be undertaken by TRIDA too got approval in the recent board meeting of KIIFB.

For the project worth Rs 45 crore submitted by TRIDA, KIIFB has given approval for initial fund of Rs 27 crore. According to TRIDA officials, the shopping complex could accommodate over 300 traders who will be shifted for the junction improvement works. As per TRIDA’s proposal, a bus terminal, shopping complex, multi-level parking plaza, auto-taxi stand, comfort station etc. will be included in the triangular plot in Vattiyoorkavu Junction.

With the bus terminal planned in the plot, the traffic congestion caused due to the presence of a bus stop along the busy road will be resolved. TRIDA is acquiring around three acres in the area.

A social impact assessment (SIA) study will be conducted for land acquisition after the initial survey. PWD officials said that tender for the project could be invited after acquiring 90% of land.

Title: Panaji: No tainted candidates for Zilla Panchayat polls says Congress
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Welcoming the Supreme Court’s observations over criminals contesting elections, Congress on Monday said they will “maintain high moral ground” and not select candidates with criminal records for the coming Zilla Panchayat (ZP) .

The party also accused the state election commission of colluding with BJP to give the saffron party an advantage in the rural body elections.

“ZP election candidates will be scrutinised and we will see that the high moral ground for ZP polls are maintained,” Chodankar said.

He went on to allege that BJP was dictating terms to the state election commission in order to put opposition parties at a disadvantage.

“It is BJP organising secretary and the president who are deciding which constituency is to be reserved. They are trying to destroy opposition candidates,” he said.

When asked if the state election committee was supporting BJP, Chodankar said, “They want to reduce time for the opposition to select the candidates based on reservation.”

Title: Jakhar: Looking into Pargat’s concerns
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Chandigarh: Reacting to the letter by Congress MLA Pargat Singh pointing out that the state government had faltered in keeping its promises, party’s Punjab president Sunil Jakhar on Monday claimed that the issues flagged by the former Indian hockey captain were already being look into.

Incidentally, Jakhar and Pargat were together at a programme of the Punjab Youth Congress (PYC) in Chandigarh, a day after the MLA’s letter to the party leadership surfaced in the public domain on Sunday.

Talking to mediapersons, Pargat confirmed having raised the issues with chief minister Amarinder Singh and said he stood by the content of his letter. Since Pargat is known to be close to former cabinet minister Navjot Singh Sidhu, his letter set the political circles abuzz with speculations.

Asked if he tried to reach out to the Jalandhar Cantonment MLA, Jakhar said the chief minister had given directions to the deputy commissioners last week pertaining to some of the issues raised by Pargat. “I believe the letter was written sometime back. He has pointed out certain expectations of the people and corrective steps are being taken. The CM has already asked the DCs to prioritise people’s issues,” he added.

In his letter, Pargat said the Congress was given a big mandate by Punjabis in 2017 with Amarinder’s performance and working style during his first tenure in mind, but an impression was now gaining ground that they were getting disappointed with the performance of the state government. He listed drug menace and empty coffers among the main reasons.

There has been talk of increasing discontent among a section of the Congress MLAs and before Pargat some others too had questioned the free hand given to the civil and police administration in the state, besides delay in taking convincing action on the issue of religious sacrilege.

Title: CM Amarinder Singh says Punjab will renegotiate power pacts with private players
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Punjab CM Amarinder Singh

CHANDIGARH: Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh on Monday said his government would renegotiate the power purchase agreements (PPAs) which the erstwhile SAD-BJP government had signed to “defraud the state and its people.”

He added that given the shortfall in production by the state-owned power plants at Lehra Mohabbat and Ropar, the government would work around the existing arrangements with private players to make power rates more affordable while ensuring that the peak demand of 13,000MW is effectively met. He also warned the private players against messing with Punjab’s finances.

The CM was addressing the newly elected Punjab Youth Congress (PYC) office-bearers over tea on Monday when he made the announcement. He claimed that the state was reconsolidating its financial position due to his government’s efforts over the last three years and any attempt to scuttle the momentum would not be tolerated. A section of Congress leaders, including Rajya Sabha MP Partap Singh Bajwa and state president Sunil Jakhar, have been demanding that the controversial PPAs be renegotiated so that the consumers do not have to face back-to-back hikes in tariff.

The PPAs had lately turned into a political issue with AAP also targeting the Congress government for continuing with the arrangement made by the previous SAD-BJP government. It had demanded that the state government scrap the PPAs. Reacting to this, the chief minister had announced last month that a white paper on the power scenario will be presented in the monsoon session of Punjab assembly to “expose the fraud” committed by the Akalis with regard to the controversial PPAs with private players.

Last week, AAP MLA Aman Arora wrote to Congress national president Sonia Gandhi, pointing out that the state Congress unit, in its 2017 assembly election manifesto, had promised to scrap or review the “anti-Punjab” agreements with three private power plants but nothing had been done in this regard even when the government was about to complete three years in power.

Even the Akalis had sought an independent probe into the matter, alleging that the state extended “undue benefits” of Rs 2,500 crore to private power plants. SAD had accused the government of “deliberate laxity” in pursuing disputes involving Rs 2,500 crore on account of coal washing charges.

Through the coal washing process, impurities like ash, soil, rock are removed from coal. Due to these charges, power rates in Punjab were increased by 36 paise a unit from January 1 for domestic consumers.

Title: Govt should take over agri college under Annamalai univ, says PMK
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Villupuram: Pattali Makkal Katchi founder-leader S Ramadoss on Monday urged the Tamil Nadu government to take over the agriculture college in Annamalai University and declare it as a government agriculture college, similar to its take over of the administrative control of Rajah Muthiah Medical College in Annamalai University.

Ramadoss in a statement said students have demanded that the government take over Annamalai University’s agriculture college and affiliate it to Tamil Nadu agricultural university (TNAU), following its successful taking over of the university’s medical college.

“There are more reasons for taking over the university’s agriculture college than the medical college. The decrease in annual fees of the medical college by Rs 5 lakh after the government took over the administrative control is the primary reason for the change in administrative control. But for the agriculture college, there are several genuine factors necessitating the change in the administrative control other than the decrease in annual fees,” Ramadoss said.

He said though the college has basic infrastructural facilities, there are doubts over its quality of education. He cited that the TNAU in its 2019-20 prospectus openly declared that students with an undergraduate degree from the agriculture college in Annamalai University are not eligible to apply for postgraduate courses offered by it.

He said the college, which is spread in 860 acres, includes several farms. The college has qualified and talented teaching faculty members and researchers and there are ample opportunities to transform the college into the best agriculture college and research institute, the PMk founder said.

Title: Panaji: Cyclone warning towers to be installed in state by October
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Goa to be ready for future

PANAJI: The state government has set a deadline of October 2020 to install 38 early cyclone warning dissemination towers across the coastal belt of the state. The World Bank will provide Rs 108 crore to the state government under the National Cyclone Risk Mitigation project.

The early warning dissemination system has three components that include installation of towers, shelter home during cyclone and underground electricity cabling, revenue secretary Sanjay Kumar told TOI. The World Bank funds for the project will not come as a loan, he said.

Kumar said that under the project, 39 towers — 19 in North Goa and 20 in South — would be installed across the coastline. The towers will be 5m, 10m and 15m in height and once they receive an alert, they will automatically raise an alarm, he said.

The project is being executed by the water resources department and the total cost of installation will be around Rs 18 crore. “We have set a deadline to install the tower by October 2020,” the secretary said. The state government has awarded the contract to erect the towers to BIPS System Ltd.

Around Rs 33 crore would be spent on laying underground power cables in the coastal belt so that if a cyclone hits the state, then electricity supply is not disrupted.

Twelve cyclone shelters — five in the North and seven in South — will be established in the state under the same project at a cost of Rs 38 crore. The state government has issued tenders for four shelters, construction has started on six shelters and in two cases — Zuarinagar and Altinho — the location will be changed.

Shelters will come up at Dabolim, Mahalwada, Nagarcem, Aquem and Porvorim. Kumar said that for the maintenance of cyclone shelters, as per rules, a society will be formed by involving locals. The society has to conduct social activities at the cyclone shelter and the revenue generated will be used for the maintenance of the shelters.

Title: Woman, teenager say sorry to family in suicide notes
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nagpur: Two women, including a Std XI student, committed suicide at different locations in the city. In both the cases police have recovered suicide notes and have registered accidental death.

In the first incident, Trisha Patil, 16, hanged herself at her home in Wadi . In the suicide note, the girl said sorry to her family for taking the drastic step.

Sources in Wadi police station claimed that a ‘shayari’ written in the suicide note suggests that Trisha might have taken the drastic step after getting into a fight with a male friend.

Trisha had gone to tuition on Sunday at around 1.30pm. After returning home at 5.30pm, Trishna went to her room where she hanged herself. Her mother and grandfather were at home but they thought she was studying in her room. The incident came to light after Trisha’s father Sumant came home and inquired about her in the night.

When Trisha did not respond to their calls, her family members broke the door and saw her hanging to the ceiling fan. She was taken to a private hospital where she was declared brought dead. As soon as the news broke on Monday, her schools friends started approaching her house.

The post mortem was conducted on Monday at Mayo hospital after which the body was handed over to her relatives for performing last rites.

In another incident, Surbhi Kudve, 24, hanged just months before her marriage. Surbhi was found hanging to the ceiling fan at her home in Vakil Peth. Cops said Surbhi was alone at her home when she took the drastic step.

Imambada police have also recovered a suicide note in which Surbhi claimed that she blames no one and asked for forgiveness from her parents.

Police are yet to find any concrete reason behind both the suicides.

Title: Ponda: Usgao locals relent, but set conditions
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

WATER WOES

PONDA: Locals of Dhatwada and Usgao on Monday relented to allow the water resources department (WRD) to lay a pipeline on the Dhaushirem-Khandepar nullah, but under certain conditions.

The Dhatwada-Usgao Citizen Forum submitted a letter to the superintending engineer of WRD, Pramod Badami, on Monday setting conditions for the pipeline, which includes laying it a meter above and along the border of the nullah, and demolishing a bandhara constructed on the nullah by a private factory. The locals have also demanded that the WRD should release water to horticulture farms on the banks of the nullah and that all assurances be given in writing.

So far, the locals have been opposed to laying of an underground pipeline in the nullah, demanding that the WRD either change the route of the pipeline or lay it at a raised level.

The WRD has been laying a 1,000mm pipeline to facilitate augmentation of the Khandepar river during summer using water from the Ganjem water scheme on the Mhadei. The Opa water works complex, which comprises five water treatment plants that collectively supply potable water to over 90% of Ponda and Tiswadi talukas, is fully dependent on the Khandepar river.

Until last summer, water from Ganjem would be poured directly into the Dhaushirem nullah, from where it would flow into the Khandepar river.

As the entire quantity of water does not reach the river due to losses by evaporation, ground seepage and drawing by farmers midway, the WRD has been laying the pipeline.

Title: Kerala: CBI arrests sub-inspector in Nedumkandam custodial death
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Sabu KA (face covered) at CBI court in Kochi on Monday

KOCHI: The special crime branch unit of Central Bureau of Investigation ( CBI ) has arrested a sub-inspector in connection with Nedumkandam custodial torture death case in which private financier Rajakumar (53) died in police custody in June 2019.

Sub-inspector Sabu K A (46), a native of Perumpilly near Njarackal in Ernakulam, is under suspension. He was arrested by the officials after being summoned for interrogation in the case on Sunday night.

“Sabu was summoned to Kochi CBI office for interrogation on Sunday. Later, based on his statements, his arrest was recorded at 9.30pm on Sunday night. We produced him before Ernakulam chief judicial magistrate court and the court granted a six-day custody of him for further interrogation. He will be produced in the court again at 4pm on Saturday. He will be taken to Nedumkandam to recover the materials used to torture the deceased,” said an officer.

Sabu served as sub-inspector of Nedumkandam police station when the incident pertaining to the case happened. Following a case registered under Kerala Money Lenders Act, Rajlkumar, a native of Wagamon, was taken into custody on June 12 by a team led by Sabu, who was claimed to be in charge of the station in the absence of station house officer. After remanded to Peerumedu sub jail, he died at a hospital on June 21.

Though Sabu was earlier arrested by the crime branch in the case, the high court granted him bail. CBI took over the case in December from the crime branch. CBI arrested Sabu after the Supreme Court cancelled the bail granted by the HC when the state government challenged it. Six other police officials of Nedumgandam police station are accused in the case.

Rajkumar was kept in illegal custody till June 15 before his arrest was recorded by the police and during this time, he reportedly underwent severe police torture. Though the initial postmortem report stated pneumonia as the cause of death, a re-postmortem carried out on August 22 found 22 injuries on the body. A judicial inquiry is also underway by a commission led by Justice K Narayana Kurup.

Title: BMC widens career horizon for students and families, hopes to ‘break cycle of poverty’
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

After Class X, children are guided on what steps to take next.

Every time her taxi enters her colony in Dharavi, Naghma Sayyed slips on her burkha and enters her alternate muted avatar. Otherwise, the fiesty 23-year-old is busy learning how to apply false eyelashes or creating Instagram videos on how to do your make-up that are gathering more likes than she ever imagined. Recently, she gave an impassioned speech at a national UNDP-sponsored conference on youth and skilling. “My family doesn’t like all this, but I am certain I want to be financially independent before I get married,” says the school dropout. “Slowly, slowly, they have begun to understand that I really mean it.”

Sayyed is one of urban India’s millions of young adults who are trying to navigate the mismatch between aspiration and opportunity. Theirs is a world where being 10th pass rarely translates into employment; where career counselling is non-existent; and where parents are indifferent, clueless or even adversarial—especially when it comes to girls. “Working girls are not considered good marriage material,” says Priya Agrawal, founder of Antarang Foundation, a non-profit organisation that trains youth in employability skills and empowers them to find suitable careers. Girls like Sayyed have had to constantly negotiate with a family for whom education is dangerous because it gives a girl “wings on her feet”. But Antarang has given her the wings.

Recognising the long-unadressed gap between education and employability, the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation ( BMC ) has tied up with Antarang to offer career counselling in 223 of its schools . The counsellors engage with not just students, but also their parents, helping them break gender stereotypes, understand their child’s potential better, or feel more comfortable with unusual career choices. “For example, a Dadar girl’s parents realised their daughter had options even in the field of sports and became open to the idea of her wearing shorts and playing basketball,” says a facilitator.

The ‘Career Aware’ program, started a couple of years ago, comprises an intensive series of sessions that take place in classes IX and X. It includes psychometric tests —conducted in Hindi, Marathi, Urdu and English— which help children become more self-aware about their abilities, desires and potential. Group sessions are followed by one-on-ones, followed by sessions with parents, many of whom are themselves in dead-end or low-paying jobs and have no idea how to break the cycle. “After the children are exposed to various options out there, we find they really speak their minds and identify what they want to do,” says Mamta Rao, BMC deputy education officer. “So indirectly it also helps them build self-confidence.”

After Class X, children are guided on what steps to take next. They are also exposed to real professionals in fields of their choice, to get a sense of what a waiter, a beautician or a physiotherapist’s day looks like. They are nudged to think about family issues and confront questions like: If I know I have to start earning and contributing to the family income within the next two years, can I realistically become an architect, which requires many more years of education? What are my job options? How much can my family support this decision? What is the average pay in this sector?

“Half the problem is awareness, exposure and access,” says Agrawal. For example, few are aware of an all-girls Industrial Training Insitute (ITI) in Dadar. Or, that there are 16 ITIs in Mumbai, run via public-private partnerships. Or, that the Tatas run a free hospitality service training centre called Tata Strive which offers training in everything from how to serve water to how to fold a bed.

Once students complete school, Antarang conducts the ‘Career Ready’ program at colleges and in various communities. More than 6,000 youth have gone through the program and some 2,000 are working in full-time and part-time jobs with an average starting pay of Rs 10-12,000

“We are now involved in setting up a national framework on career counselling, which would ensure that every school will have a career facilitator, have exposure visits,” says Agrawal.

She suggests just as there are anganwadis in every neighbourhood, there should be localised career counselling centres for young adults which can become employability hubs in every ward. Two such have already come into being—in Dharavi and Powai. “The idea is to facilitate the school-to-work transition to break the inter-generational poverty cycle.”

Title: Innovation needed to boost biz says Goa CM Pramod Sawant
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Chief minister Pramod Sawant

BICHOLIM: Chief minister Pramod Sawant called for vendors in the Sakhali market to develop innovative tactics to attract customers, in order to tackle competition from shops that have opened in other parts of the municipality. He expressed concern that business in the market has been affected due to the “opening of shops in nearly every building from Honda village to Sakhali”. He also said that unorganised vendors should not be allowed to sell their wares— fish, fruits or flowers— on the roadside.

Sawant was speaking after laying the foundation stone for a new bridge connecting Bhandarwada to Vithalapur-Karapur, Sakhali, on Sunday. The new bridge will be constructed at the site of the existing pedestrians’ steel bridge.

Title: Mosquito menace leads to clash between traders, cops
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Video grab of police action against the protesters

Rajkot: One may have heard of traders’ agitations breaking out over the issues of fixing the falling prices of their produce and other such demands, but to take to the street over the issue of mosquito menace is quite unheard of.

Such was a scene on Rajkot-Morbi Highway, where an unresolved problem of mosquitoes drove traders of Rajkot new market yard to resort to stone pelting when cops tried to stop their stir on Monday. About 30 protesters were detained for rioting and preventing the police from performing their duty.

On Monday afternoon, about 50 traders staged a chakka jam (road block) on Rajkot-Morbi Highway and burnt tyres. “When we tried to disperse the protesters, they pelted stones at us, in which five cops received injuries,” said M C Vala, inspector with Kuwadawa Road police station.

“We have been suffering from the mosquito menace for the past five years. Hydrilla and water hyacinth in the still water of a stream that eventually flows into Aji River has become a breeding ground for mosquitoes. The dirty water from gutters in Rajkot is released into this stream on daily basis, spawning mosquitoes,” said Atul Kamani, president of commission agents’ association associated with the new market yard.

Kamani said that after several representations before Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) failed, they were left with no option, but to take action. “We had called for a one-day strike at the market yard on Monday as a mark of protest. As part of the protest we blocked Rajkot-Morbi Highway, which invited the police’s action,” he said.

“We had written to the RMC to take a cue from Surat Municipal Corporation and make use of weeder machines to weed out hydrilla and water hyacinth. But our request fell on the deaf ears of the RMC officials,” said one of the agitating traders.

Those cops injured in the stone pelting were identified as crime branch sub-inspector P M Dhakhda, crime branch head constable Mayur Patel and crime branch constables — Jayantibhai and Jagmalbhai.

Title: Waste management: Minister unveils Trivandrum Declaration
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Local self-government minister A C Moideen unveiled the ‘ Trivandrum Declaration ’ formulated by representatives of various cities who took part in the Zero-Waste Conference which concluded here on Monday.

The declaration aims at establishing a collective of cities working towards attaining ‘zero-waste status’ in their areas by implementing a set of measures like reduction of single-use materials, green protocol, engaging youth and encouraging agriculture and water conservation activities.

As many as 260 representatives from 23 cities took part in the zero-waste conference, which was organised by the city corporation.

As per the declaration, it was decided that representatives of the cities would meet every two years and review the activities each city has initiated and the progress it has achieved. The declaration lays focus on extended producer responsibility, reduction in generation of waste and recycling.

Moideen said that for all such initiatives to be successful, public have to be prepared for reducing waste and for undertaking source-level waste management .

“Awareness is the key. How we can line up people for noble causes regarding waste management is the major challenge. Kerala can create models in this sector like we had done in other areas,” said the minister.

The minister said that after the closure of Vilappilsala waste treatment plant, city corporation tried out different methods involving people and the success indicates that it can be emulated everywhere. He said that finding land is a huge challenge with regard to various projects.

Vattiyoorkavu MLA V K Prasanth said that if source-level waste management could produce good results what was the need for centralized waste treatment plants. “Why do we have to carry waste from one place to another if it can be treated at source,” he asked. He said that corporation has been able to significantly reduce number of dumpsites in the city .

Title: Amritsar family suicide: 16 years on, ex-DIG, DSP convicted
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Representative image

AMRITSAR: Nearly 16 years after a “suicide pact” wip- ed out a five-member Amritsar family, a city court on Monday convicted a former DIG of Punjab Police , a serving deputy SP, Hardev Singh , and four relatives of the deceased of extortion and abetment, among other charges.

Retired DIG Kultar Sin- gh was the SSP of Amritsar in 2004 when Hardip Singh , a resident of the Chowk Karori neighbourhood, and four members of his family — mother, wife Romi and minor sons — were found dead in their home.

A suicide note purportedly written by Hardip and messages scribbled on the walls of a room accused Kultar Singh of driving him and his family to take the extreme step on the night of October 30, 2004.

According to the case diary, Hardip had allegedly murdered his father and was spotted by a relative while trying to dispose of the body. She told her father-in-law about it and he started blackmailing Hardip, extorting Rs 7.25 lakh.

When some officers at the local thana got wind of this, they too extorted Rs 5 lakh from Hardip and demanded another Rs 7 lakh, the prosecution established. DSP Hardev Singh was then the officer-in-charge of Kotwali police station.

Title: Pak marine apprehends three Indian boats, 17 fishermen
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Indian fishermen at Karachi in Pakistan

Rajkot: Three Indian boats from Porbandar and Okha with 17 fishermen on board were apprehended by Pakistan Maritime Security Agency near international maritime border with Pakistan on Monday.

The three boats were Pawan Sagar with five fishermen on board from Porbandar, and Al Madina and Bhagyalakshmi with six fishermen each on board from Okha.

“In the past three days, a total of nine Indian fishing boats from coastal Saurashtra with 51 fishermen on board have been apprehended by Pakistan Maritime Security Agency,” said Manish Lodhari, president of Porbandar Fishermen’s Association.

Title: Sexual assault case probe over in 45 days, accused prof sacked
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Nagpur: In a fast track action in case involving crime against women, a college from East Nagpur has terminated services of a professor accused of molesting a first-year student in just 45 days after completing probe. The professor was about to retire on March 31.

The accused has also been ordered to shell out Rs25,000 compensation for the trauma inflicted on the student belonging to reserved category.

TOI is withholding the name of the professor as the student has refused to file an FIR though the college has submitted a complaint application with the local police.

The sexual assault took place on December 26, 2019, when the professor had allegedly taken the girl out in his car on the pretext of attending a conference and made undue advances towards her. Next day, the 18-year-old girl broke down before a woman professor who informed the principal.

Acting swiftly, college management set up an eight-member inquiry panel as per Vishakha Guidelines on December 27 and started the proceedings from December 28 onwards. Nagpur University (NU) and college authorities decided to process the complaint through the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC), which deals with sexual harassment of women at workplaces, to ensure the accused is punished.

Following NU’s Ordinance 53 would have allowed the accused professor to retire with all benefits even before the first hearing had taken place. After several rounds of hearing till January 16, the ICC indicted the professor and recommended his removal from service.

In his defence, the tainted professor had sought 15 days time in the last week of January to explain his side after the management served him one last show cause notice. The college gave him only a week to respond before confirming his termination on February 14.

As per inquiry report, the professor had given contradictory statements in response to the allegations. While he claimed before the panel that he didn’t know the student, he had admitted to have picked her up in his car on December 26 from outside the college. The professor had also admitted to having apologized to the girl by falling on her feet the next day when principal and other teachers questioned him.

According to college officials, the girl is reluctant to file a police complaint against the professor fearing that her parents will stop her education after that. The survivor belongs to a poor family and the professor had promised to give her Rs550 for enrolling in a computer course, said college officials.

The panel, led by vice-principal and comprising two outside members, also secured the testimony of another girl who confirmed the pervert behaviour of the professor.

A college official said that the professor had harassed several other girls also, but none came forward to complain. In this case, the college had also sent him on compulsory leave to prevent him from influencing the victim.

The professor was one of the suspects in the murder of principal Moreshwar Wankhede in November 2017. Wankhede’s wife and daughter were also charged with the murder. The mother-daughter duo had allegedly taken help of the professor, who was underground for several days after the murder. Role of senior cops had come under scanner after they failed to question the professor in the case.

What happened

Dec 26 | Professor promises to help the student financially by paying Rs550 for a computer course. Takes her out in his car on pretext of conference and makes undue advances

Dec 27 | Girl breaks down before a woman teacher, who informs principal. Principal informs college management which sets up 8-member probe panel

Dec 28 | Show cause notice issued and a brief hearing held in college

Dec 29 to 30 | The panel meets to discuss complaint

Jan 8 | Panel calls both the girl and the professor for hearing

Jan 16 | Panel indicts professor and recommends his termination

Jan last week | Last show cause notice issued

Feb 14 | College issues termination letter, submits it to NU and joint director of education along with report

Title: Women in Army: Veterans hail SC judgment
Content:
This story is from February 18, 2020

Short Service Commission women officers Anjali Bisht, Seema Singh and Sandhya Yadav flash victory sign outside... Read More

CHANDIGARH: The Supreme Court judgment making women army officers eligible for permanent commission and in commanding roles has been received well by the defence fraternity, who have described it as a fair verdict.

According to experts, the issue was more of an administrative or technical issue had the government not have taken an “hypothetical” and “fallacious” stand that women may not be accepted as commanders by male troops.

Even in its 54-page verdict, criticizing the central government’s argument and emphasizing on women officers’ right to equality, the Supreme Court observed that 70 years after the birth of a post-colonial independent state, there still was need for change in attitude s and mindsets to recognize commitment to the values of the Constitution.

Gen V P Malik, the former Indian Army chief, said the Supreme Court judgment is “welcoming and implementable.”

Lt Gen D S Hooda, former Army commander, Northern Command , said the apex court’s decision is a move towards gender mainstreaming in the Indian Army. “Now, the next task for the Army would be decide the modalities regarding their selection for command positions and I believe that the Army should do a fair tresatment with them,” Hooda added. Major Navdeep Singh, a former military reservist, and an expert in military law, said, “Nari Shakti now actually gets translated into reality, beyond parade ground.”

Ranjana Malik, former Army captain and wife of General V P Malik, said she had served in Army Medical Corps where the women officers have reached to the rank of Lt General and headed the command hospitals. “It is a great decision and the government’s argument that soldiers will not accept orders from woman officers was fallacious and undignified for men and women of the armed forces,” she added.

Flt Lt Promila Dhaka , who has served Indian Air Force (IAF) as short service commission officer, said it is a great moment, especially for short service commissioned women officers who gave their prime years to the forces and were not allowed to continue the job at a time when it was difficult for them to re-start a new career at that phase of life.

Terming the verdict as “heartening,” Major Priya Jhingan, the first lady cadet to join the Indian Army in 1992, said women officers had already proved their capabilities when they were inducted first time in the Army even in new roles, after this decision, they would prove best for this great institution (Army). “It is a day which will go down in the history of the Indian Army as a golden day. I appreciate the progressive and positive attitude of the Supreme Court. Now perhaps my granddaughter will be able to join the infantry too. Go ahead women! Show them what you are made of. All the best,” she added.
